Sunday, with the only probable exception of this Wednesday. 
Fortunately, dry weather will accompany the cold spell, except for
20% pops over the northern mountains of northeast TN and 
southwest VA on Thursday. But return flow will bring milder and 
more moist air back into the area beginning Sunday, with precip 
moving in Sunday night (possibly precipitating into a slightly 
subfreezing air mass during Monday morning).

909 
FXUS64 KMRX 310834
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
334 AM EST Sun Dec 31 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
The cold air will continue to build over the region on Sunday as a
large 1050mb surface high slides southeastward from Alberta and
into the northern Great Plains. A shortwave will rotate through 
the longwave trough across the Eastern CONUS today deepening the
trough and ushering in more cold air. Lift ahead of the shortwave 
will also bring some additional clouds to northeast Tennessee and 
southwest Virginia, but do not expect any precipitation with such 
a dry boundary layer. PWs are expected to drop below 0.2 inch by
Sunday evening as the Arctic airmass continues to advance into 
the region.

Sunday night, minimum temperatures are expected to range from the
low single digits to mid teens across the region. Additionally, 
winds are expected to be between 5 and 10 kt with slightly higher 
winds possible at times across the higher elevations as well as
the southern plateau and ridgetops around Chattanooga. This will 
lead to very cold wind chills of -5 to -10 along the higher 
elevations of the mountains, southwest Virginia, southwest North 
Carolina, and the Cumberland Plateau. For these areas, have issued
a Wind Chill Advisory between midnight and noon on Monday. The 
Valley is currently expected to see wind chills between 0 to 5 
which is above criteria for our forecast area. However, have continued
an SPS for the entire forecast area to highlight the dangerously 
cold wind chills across the region. The air will also be very dry
with PWs of around 0.1 inch or less and Td near zero across lower
elevations and below zero across the higher terrain.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Friday)...
A very cold Arctic air mass will remain over the Southern 
Appalachian Region through the extended. This will mean overnight 
lows generally in the teens and single digits and highs mainly in 
the teens and 20s and occasional low 30s. With these 
temperatures...even light winds can create significant wind 
chills. On Monday night when the coolest air is expected to settle
into the area...higher elevations could see wind chills of minus 
10 to minus 20 degrees and a Wind Chill Advisory or possibly a 
Wind Chill Warning may be needed. A couple of weak impulses riding
trough the upper flow may briefly generate an occasional band of 
clouds and could produce a few pockets of light snow or flurries 
across far northern areas and over the higher elevations of the 
East TN Mountains. The initial impulse should move in Wednesday 
night into Thursday and another around Friday. With the very dry 
and cold air mass in place...there will be little moisture 
available and should see little if any accumulations.


&&

577 
FXUS64 KMRX 300832
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
332 AM EST Sat Dec 30 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Longwave troughing continues across the Eastern CONUS in the short
term. Isentropic upglide leading to low-level clouds on Saturday 
ahead of a cold front that is expected to move through late in the
afternoon. There is very little moisture associated with this 
front, so do not expect much, if any, precipitation with it. One 
of the main forcing mechanisms for precipitation will be weak 
northwest flow behind the front with the potential for some very 
light snow or flurries across the higher elevations. However, 
because of the weak upslope component of about 10 kt or less and 
limited moisture and lift, do not expect more than a potential 
dusting to a couple tenths of an inch of snowfall across the 
highest elevations. With continued troughing and low clouds, 
expect temperatures to be about 5 to 10 degrees below normal on 
Saturday.

A much colder and drier airmass advects into the area tonight in
the wake of the cold front, and it should stick around for the
foreseeable future. This will result in temperatures plummeting
into the teens across much of the forecast area. Light winds will
make it feel even colder with wind chill values expected to be in
the single digits across the plateau, parts of NE TN, and SW VA
with potential wind chill values between 0 and -5 across the 
higher terrain of SW VA late Saturday night and early Sunday 
morning.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Friday)...
The weather pattern through the extended generally has a cold 
surface high pressure in control with a large...broad upper trough
positioned over the eastern U.S. As a result...expect little 
change in the weather with very cold air in place. Weak 
disturbances in the upper flow will occasionally ride through the 
upper trough and bring additional surges of cold air. Overnight 
lows in the teens and single digits across the Tennessee Valley 
can be expected each night. Sunday may see highs in the mid 30s to
mid 40s but for the rest of the time frame...temperatures will 
struggle to climb into the 20s...and maybe occasional into the low
30s. Overall...it looks dry through the period...however...a weak
disturbance on Wednesday night and another around the Friday time
frame may generate a few areas of light snow or flurries...mainly
over far northern locations and along the East TN Mountains. No 
accumulations are expected at this time.


&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

hold in most of the afternoon across the northern 1/2 to 2/3 of

mention of snow showers or flurries for tomorrow afternoon in the
northeastern valley as well as in the mountains from the Smokies 
northward. The cold air in the lower levels of this airmass will 
likely support small ice crystal growth in these areas, but this 
moisture is several thousand feet below the dendritic growth 
zones, where it is expected to be dry--so accumulations should be
minimal.


.LONG TERM (Saturday night through Friday)...Will see little change 
in the overall weather pattern through the extended forecast period 
with a very cold air mass remaining in place.  Upper trough firmly 
in place over the eastern CONUS will keep temps below normal. 
Additional surges of cold air will cycle through the trough next 
week, reinforcing the cold temperatures. In fact, there is a good 
chance from Saturday night through Wednesday afternoon that much of 
the area will remain below freezing. 

For the most part, despite the cold temperatures, we will stay 
mainly dry through the extended forecast period. A weak wave on 
Saturday night may bring some light flurries across far northern 
areas and the higher elevations of the East TN mountains. However, 
with very little moisture available, nothing more than a dusting is 
expected. Another wave on Wednesday night may produce similar 
flurries, but at this point, not enough moisture is present to 
include snow showers in the grids.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
340 PM EST Thu Dec 28 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...
Cold air mass continues to spread across the area.  A short-lived 
and weak warming will start tonight, as return flow aloft slowly 
brings slightly warmer air as well as more moisture toward the area. 
Expecting a layer of stratocumulus to start to spread/develop this 
afternoon and accelerate development tonight and spread northeast 
across a good part of the area during the late evening.  Then late 
tonight as a low-level trough moves through the stratocu will be 
shoved off the east by about daybreak. The NAM 875 mb RH and Wind 
showed this scenario pretty well.

The clouds should limit radiational cooling, so min temps tonight 
should not be as cold, and then the slightly warmer air mass 
Saturday should help to get temps across the valley into the 40s for 
all but the most northern parts of the valley.  Temps today have 
generally been running a little warmer than original guidance 
values. 925 mb temps for tomorrow look a little warmer for most area-
-think this will be reflected at the surface.


LONG TERM (Friday night through Thursday)... Model runs continue 
to come into better agreement for much of the long term forecast, 
showing an extended period of very cold temperatures and dry 
conditions. 

Troughing will stay in place over the eastern CONUS through next 
week. This trough will help temperatures below normal. A few 
shortwaves will rotate through this longwave trough, bringing 
reinforcing shots of cold air. The first of these shortwaves will 
rotate through on Sunday. Model solutions continue to trend drier, 
and opted to remove slight chance snow showers from the forecast for 
Sunday/Monday. Following this shortwave, a strong surface high 
settles over the area and will keep temps will be around 20 degrees 
below normal on Monday. There's a good chance we may not see temps 
above freezing from Saturday night through Tuesday night, with 
windchills well into the single digits or lower during the overnight 
hours.

Another system will approach the area during the Wednesday/Thursday 
timeframe. The upper air pattern splits with the northern stream 
bringing a strengthening clipper system out of Canada. The southern 
stream brings a wave of Gulf moisture up the eastern seaboard. For 
now, the 12/28 12Z runs of both the GFS and ECMWF have the brunt of 
both systems missing us with just some light snow from the northern 
system grazing our area Wednesday night. However, there is still 
plenty of model differences and plenty of time -- we will have to 
closely monitor the development of these systems and how they 
interact over the coming days. Of additional note, this storm could 
pull even colder air into the region, with the Superblend showing 
Thursday night lows in the single digits across the entire area (and 
even sub zero in the mountains). Again -- we will have to continue 
to monitor this system through next week as there is still plenty of 
time for conditions to change.

lift. A shortwave will also be rotating through the longwave trough

area. Both operational and ensembles favor only light precipitation 
at this time on the order of about 0.1 inch across SE TN and SW NC 
with only a few hundredths near the KY border and in SW VA. Lack of 
run to run consistency still increases uncertainty with the 
precipitation forecast for Sunday into Monday. If precip does occur, 
the atmospheric profile does support all snow at this time. 

The biggest story will be the very cold air through the period, 
especially Sunday through the middle of next week. GEFS and ECMWF 
ensembles continue to show the likelihood of most of the forecast 
area not making it above freezing from Sunday evening through 
Wednesday midday with lows in the teens or potentially single
digits.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
303 PM EST Tue Dec 26 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Wednesday)...(Tonight and Wednesday)...A
broad upper trough is positioned over the eastern U.S. with 
generally zonal flow over the Southern Appalachian Region. A weak 
short wave moving through the flow tonight will increase clouds 
tonight and may bring another weak shot of cooler air into the 
area for Wednesday. Highs on Wednesday should only reach into the 
30s and low 40s. The air mass remains quite dry and minimal 
moisture associated with the short wave so expect dry conditions 
throughout the short term.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday night through Monday)...The long term 
continues to look unsettled with various shortwaves impacting the 
region. The main story appears to be the increasing confidence in 
very cold air to start the new year.

A shortwave late Wednesday will bring a cold front through the area 
with a very strong surface high to our north. With surface winds 
expected to lighten late Wednesday night, temperatures are expected 
to drop into the teens and low 20s with dew points primarily in the 
single digits.

For Thursday, a weak shortwave to the south should provide lift for 
some precip, but it appears that it will remain far to our south 
with dry air over our area. A stronger shortwave will move 
southeastward and pivot across the area on Thursday night with a 
trailing surface cold front, but moisture looks limited with this 
system as well. However, there may be enough moisture, lift, and 
orographic forcing from westerly/northwesterly flow that there will 
be slight chance and chance PoPs for some light snow showers across 
the higher elevations of northeast Tennessee and southwest Virginia. 

On Saturday, another northern stream shortwave across the Great 
Lakes and Ohio Valley will bring a surface front through the region 
which will usher in another reinforcing shot of colder air. Moisture 
is once again limited but may have some slight chance PoPs for light 
snow showers or flurries across the higher elevations of northeast 
TN and southwest Virginia.

Model solutions greatly diverge past Saturday and uncertainty is 
very high late this weekend into early next week. The GFS continues 
to dry and develop an area of low pressure along the Gulf Coast with 
moisture over our region Sunday and Sunday night which is also 
supported by GEFS members. The ECMWF and CMC continue to be dry with 
the Gulf low suppressed far to the south with slight differences 
with respect to timing. Therefore, went no higher than chance PoPs 
for Sunday through Monday because of the very high uncertainty. 
Exactly how the Sunday through Monday forecast plays out will depend 
on a small, relatively weak shortwave and how it evolves from a 
closed low over the eastern Pacific. Models routinely have a 
difficult time with this type of setup and this seems to be no 
exception. Regardless, we'll have to continue to watch for at least 
the potential for winter weather Sunday through Monday.

The one variable that models do seem to have agreement on is that 
very cold air will impact the region to start the new year. 
Ensembles are also in overwhelming agreement with a colder than 
normal airmass for the early to middle part of next week with 
forecast temperatures to be 10-20 degrees below normal. In fact, 
GEFS members currently indicate an 80 percent or greater chance of 
temperatures remaining at or below freezing during the 48 hour 
period from Sunday night through Tuesday night. While the ECMWF 
ensembles are not quite as cold, a majority still indicate max 
temperatures near freezing for most of the area early next week.

northwest tonight, a weak northwest flow snowfall event will setup
across the higher elevations. This will provide additional 
orographic lift across the higher elevations where slightly higher
precip amounts can be expected. Total snowfall accumulation 
should remain light due to the limited moisture and recent warm 
surface temperatures. We may see a dusting to a few tenths of an 
inch across the plateau, southwest VA, and northeast TN.

above 4000 feet elevation along the TN/NC mountains from about 
Sevier County northeastward.

It will dry out quickly on Monday with subsidence in the wake of 
the shortwave and surface high pressure moving into the region.

temperatures well below normal on Christmas with max temperatures
in the 30s which will be about 10-15 degrees below normal.

area with a weather disturbance riding along the zonal flow to our

uncertainty with the timing and exact track. Precipitation with

at times.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
315 AM EST Sun Dec 24 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
As a shortwave trough and the jetstream move into the OH Valley
region today, a surface low will take shape over OH late in the
day. This will strengthen the W-SW flow across our area in the
21-00Z time frame, bringing strong cold advection and steepening
lapse rates under the upper trough axis. Initially, scattered rain
showers will develop late this afternoon, with a quick change to
snow showers as temps aloft fall rapidly. Although moisture is 
shallow, model soundings show saturation extending up to the -15 C
level, adequate for dendrite growth across the northern half after
00Z. Thus, some light accumulations will be possible in SW VA and
NE TN, but mainly at elevations above 3000 ft where a 30 kt
upslope wind will enhance lift. Up to one inch is expected in the
NE TN mountains and High Knob in SW VA. 

.LONG TERM (Monday through Saturday)...
At the beginning of this period on Monday/Christmas morning, we will 
be under the influence of a large and dominating upper trough that 
covers most of the CONUS. At the surface strong high pressure will 
be continuing to settle into the area.  The whole forecast area will 
be frozen at the surface and up through the entire vertical profile. 
This dry pattern will continue through Wednesday night for most of 
the area.

Models continue to be unsettled with handling the scenario for 
Thursday through Saturday, with an west-east oriented moist plume 
across the SE US and about three clippers racing across the Ohio 
Valley. The 00z models generally are keeping the moist plume farther 
south--mainly south of our area, while the southern parts of the 
Ohio Valley clippers are trying to dip southward into our area. 
Going with POPs for Thursday through Saturday without too much 
gradient since the southern areas are closer to the plume and the 
northern areas are closer to the lift of the clippers. Trimmed back 
some of the higher POPs a bit (from their initial Blend values), 
since the elements don't look to be organizing very well.

For Temps, pretty much went with Blend values.  

As these days get closer, we will need to watch to see if the models 
start moving the southern plume farther north and any associated 
cold overrunning scenario looks to evolve, especially over the top 
of a frozen surface.  As it stands right now, the current scenario 
does not look too threatening.  Will briefly mention in HWO that we 
will continue to monitor Thursday through Saturday.

gradient winds. While dry air aloft builds in through the

keep cloudy skies and drizzle through the night.

.LONG TERM (Sunday through Friday)...

into the region with relatively mild temperatures Sunday morning. 
However, during the day on Sunday a re-enforcing shot of cold air 
will be hitting, then the strong high pressure from the Plains 
will begin to build into the region, with colder air. Going with 
the low POPs for Sunday with higher POPs north Sunday night as a 
shortwave trough swings through quickly. The Plateau, SW VA, NE TN
and the mountains could all get some snow on the ground Sunday

in those previously mentioned locations.

question as to the rest of the week as models are in high 
disagreement on the axis of the moisture that may or may not be 
centered over the area for part of the time from Wednesday through 
Friday.  Chances for precip for Wednesday and Wednesday night look 
to be mainly across our southern counties, but for Thursday and 
Friday better chances of precip spread across the area.  There 
should be some chances of wintry precip during this time, but it's

the latter part of the week.

FXUS64 KMRX 222011

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
311 PM EST Fri Dec 22 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...
Shortwave trough across the Southern Plains will move
northeastward tonight tapping into deep Pacific and GoM moisture.
A cold front is located across western TN and KY extending
northeastward into the Ohio River Valley. Most of the rainfall
tonight will be located along that surface boundary to our north
and west. However, before midnight tonight, 850-700mb
frontogenesis through Middle TN and along the TN/KY border will
result in enhanced rainfall across the Cumberland Plateau. This 
area of frontogenesis will shift northward during the night with 
lower PoPs after midnight.

The upper shortwave will pass through the forecast area on
Saturday with a surface cold front providing deep lift for rain. 
Some of the rain could be locally heavy at times with PWs near the
97th-99th percentile of climatology. With 6 hour FFG values of 
2-3 and storm total rainfall to be primarily between 1 
and 3 across the forecast area, do not expect to have much of a
widespread flash flood risk beyond localized flooding in the 
standard low lying poor drainage areas. The strong lift and deep 
moisture will not be located over our area for near as long as 
areas west of us which are seeing much higher rainfall totals.
Thunder does not appear to be much of a risk with very low
instability.

Strong winds will also be a concern on Saturday morning as an 
anomalously strong southwesterly 850mb low-level jet with winds 
of 60+ kt will impact the region. While the angle of winds and 
lack of strongly negative omega across the mountain foothills do 
not favor a mountain wave high wind event, believe that the very 
strong 850mb winds will still result in Wind Advisory criteria 
high winds across the higher elevations of the TN/NC mountains. 
May also have some gusty, sub-advisory winds along the plateau, 
southwest Virginia, and along ridgetops within the valley. These 
gusty winds, along with saturated soils, could lead to some downed
trees and localized power outages.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Thursday)...
A few showers may linger across the area Saturday evening...with 
coverage slowly decreasing through the night as a cold front 
continues to pull away from the region. Temperatures should remain
warm enough through much of the night for mainly rain...though a 
mix of rain and snow will be possible over higher elevations late 
in the night. An upper trough moving through Sunday into Sunday 
night will provide a reinforcing shot of light showers. Mainly 
scattered light rain Sunday with more isolated showers overnight. 
As cooler air continue to filter into the area...will see any 
linger rain showers Sunday night transition to light snow or 
flurries. Precip amount should be light and little to no 
accumulations are expected. On Christmas Day...flow aloft becomes 
zonal with a dry...cool air mass moving in. We should remain in 
this dry weather pattern through Tuesday with temperatures 
moderating slightly. A weak short wave to our south on Wednesday 
could pull a few showers into far southern areas on Wendesday 
afternoon. Then...the next system of concern will move in Thursday
and Friday and provide us with our next chance of widespread 
precipitation.

to increase across Middle TN through SE KY this afternoon 
providing a focus for ascent along the Cumberland Plateau between 
roughly 20z-04z this evening. This will likely keep the heaviest 
and most likely precip this afternoon across portions of the 
northern Cumberland Plateau and the mountains of SW VA. Could have
some localized flooding with heavier downpours, but the primary 
flash flood threat will be to our west. 6-hour FFG is generally 
about 2-3 inches with storm total 24-36 hour precip expected to be
at most 2-3 inches across the northern plateau counties with 
totals tapering off to lesser amounts southeastward toward the 
TN/NC mountains, so this looks more like beneficial rainfall for 
our forecast area.

Made adjustments to reflect current observations and try to 
refine PoPs for this afternoon and tonight. Also, updated QPF and
storm total QPF with slightly higher QPF between 18z-00z this
afternoon corresponding to the additional focused lift across the
plateau.

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...
Precip will begin to blossom across the TN Valley region through

Of greater concern will be the development of a frontogenesis zone
that the models indicate will form across Middle TN and SE KY this
afternoon. The position of this zone may result in locally heavy
rain for a few of our Plateau counties, particularly between 21Z 
and 00Z. However, the frontal zone pushes northward through the 
evening, taking the heavy rain potential with it. With the 
expected short duration of heavy rain, the small area in our CWA 
that may be affected (parts of Morgan-Scott-Claiborne), and the 
modest amount of rainfall recently in that area, will continue
without a flood watch for now.

The approach of a cold front and the midlevel shortwave trough
will bring a second round of showers to the area on Saturday. We
will be firmly in the warm sector with a brisk SW flow aloft, so
with the strong warm advection, highs before the fropa may reach
the lower to mid 60s. It will be a breezy day, particularly in the
mountains, although the SW direction will not be ideal for
mountain waves. A Wind Advisory may be needed as we get closer to
that time period. Fropa occurs in the late afternoon hours, with
rain chances ending in the evening as dry air aloft moves in.
However, model soundings indicate low level saturation remaining
in place, with drizzle lingering through the night.

.LONG TERM (Saturday Night through Thursday)...
A fairly broad eastern U.S. H5 trough will bring isolated to 
scattered northwest flow-upslope type showers and snow showers 
Sunday and Sunday night, but not anticipating anything problematic
in part because of no direct connection to the Great Lakes. Then 
the troughing will flatten into a zonal flow during Monday, and 
dry weather will prevail Monday through Wednesday, before return 
flow spreads showers back into the region early Thursday. The 
returning moist airmass will modify temps, but maybe initially 
early Thursday there could be a brief window of wintry precip 
before changing over to rain.

FXUS64 KMRX 210845
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
345 AM EST Thu Dec 21 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Shortwave trough moves to the east today with ridging and
subsidence aloft across the region. This should keep us dry on
Thursday, but low-level moisture beneath the inversion will keep
those pesky clouds around through the day, especially across
southern portions of the forecast area. We may finally see some
more breaks in the clouds by late in the day, so don't be 
surprised to see some sunshine by the afternoon as boundary layer
heating attempts to mix in some of the drier air aloft. With 
expected low-level cloud cover, max temperatures are forecast to 
be a couple of degrees below MAV MOS guidance but still be about 
10 degrees above normal.

Southwest winds will increase Thursday night ahead of an upper-
level trough to the west. An upper-level jet streak will begin to
setup over the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley with high clouds beginning
to arrive during the night. Mid-level subsidence, sufficient
boundary layer moisture, and light surface winds will mean the
potential for fog and low clouds on Thursday night and Friday
morning, but a big question will be if high clouds move in early
enough to prevent much radiation fog development. We should stay
dry overnight until Friday and Saturday as the low pressure system
moves closer to our region. With abundant low-level moisture and 
possible cloud cover, minimum temperatures are forecast to remain 
10-15 degrees above normal.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...
Another day of warming temperatures between systems as we take a 
brief break from precipitation on Friday. Moist flow from the Gulf
of Mexico will increase as a front moves in from the west. This 
flow will run relatively parallel to the frontal boundary as it 
moves through allowing for an extended period of moderate 
precipitation over the weekend. Many locations (especially closer 
to Middle Tennessee) could see 1-2 inches of rain over the weekend
with locally higher amounts. Along this front the 850mb jet will 
get cranking with model forecasts indicating a potential jet max 
of around 50+ knots which could lead to gusty winds, especially in
the higher terrain closer to the jet on Saturday. Heaviest and 
most widespread precipitation will likely occur on Saturday during
the daytime hours as the actual front pushes through the forecast
area. 

Behind the front temperatures start to drop quickly as cold air
from the northwest replaces the warmer air. Models begin to 
diverge with how to handle the post frontal atmosphere with 
regards to additional precipitation. There is the possibility that
a trailing short wave could bring wintery precipitation to the 
area. With the highest chances being in the higher terrain of NE 
Tennessee and SW Virginia. However some models depict this same 
trailing shortwave as a much weaker system with less moisture to 
work with and keep all precipitation well to our north. So 
certainty with precipitation as we move into next week is 
relatively low for now.


All models do agree that any precipitation will be out of the are by 
Tuesday and much colder temperatures will remain over the region. 
Highs will be several degrees below normal on Monday before they 
slowly climb back up to around normal near the middle of the week. 
This portion of the forecast looks to remain dry and we should get 
to see a decent amount of sunshine after the cloudy weekend.

.Short Term...(Today and Tonight)...A short-wave moving across the
OK/AR/TX area is producing a large area of divergence aloft over
the Mississippi/Tennessee Valleys. A jet over the Ohio Valley is
also placing the area under the favored right entrance region with
the direct circulation around the jet enhancing the fronto genetic
forcing along a frontal boundary near the TN/AL and GA state-
lines. Models show the southern half of the area being under the
strong fronto genetic forcing this morning. Given PWs between
1.4-1.5 inches pulling into this boundary, locally heavy rainfall
is anticipated. Will maintain current watch over the south.
Localized flooding is possible.

The dynamics starts to weaken this afternoon, but given weakening
upper trough will move across the region, will maintain high
chance/likely PoPs this afternoon. Rain ends by this evening.
Plenty of residual boundary layer moisture will keep most of the
area in low cloudiness, except over southwest Virginia where
enough drying will breakup the cloud cover.

Besides the rain, areas of fog will continue this morning, some
locally dense. Patchy fog will likely redevelop tonight.

.Long Term...(Thursday through Tuesday Night)...
Some slight ridging will take place to end the work week and we will 
get some more southerly flow increasing moisture over the area. This 
moist air will cause cloudy skies to stick around through the 
weekend. The next major system to affect the area will be a wide 
trough/cold front expected to sweep through the Eastern United 
States over the weekend. Models are still not in great agreement of 
the timing/strength of the front and when the precipitation will 
begin and end with this system. They do agree that widespread 
precipitation will affect the area sometime over the weekend and 
colder temperatures will be ushered in behind the front. 

Along the front a low level jet will form over the area and bring in 
very strong 850mb winds as it sweeps through. While models are not 
in exact agreement on the timing they are showing the 850mb jet with 
strong winds of 50+ knots. These winds will likely impact the higher 
elevations the most, but some of the gusts could be transported down 
to the surface in the Valley. The strongest winds look to move in 
early Saturday morning and exit to the East by Saturday night. 

In addition to the winds, widespread precipitation is expected along 
and behind the front as it moves through. QPF amounts are a bit 
difficult to pin down at this time, but many people could see an 
additional 1-3 inches of rainfall Friday through the end of the 
weekend.

There could be a few lingering showers with wrap around moisture in 
SW Virginia that could bring a few flurries to the higher 
elevations, but certainty at this point in the forecast is pretty 
low. Most locations should remain relatively dry after the weekend 
and into the upcoming week, Christmas included. Behind the front the 
cold temperatures will remain for several days, through the end of 
this 7-day forecast.

and the E-W boundary along the southern TN border becomes better
defined. No changes are needed to the Flash Flood Watch. Widespread
rain amounts in the range of 2-3 inches are still expected in 
that area through Wednesday.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight through Thursday)...The next 24 hours will

forecasts may not be sufficiently high enough along the boundary.
Thus, we have hoisted a Flash Flood Watch for the southern tier 
of counties, because its a good thing to be aware of in this
atmospheric scenario. The rain will taper off from west to east 
beginning Wed afternoon as the culprit H5 shortwave moves to our 
east late in the day. By sunrise Thursday, rain should be ended, 
but cloudcover is expected to persist all day Thursday with 
continued mild temps.

.Long Term (Thursday night through Tuesday)...Models start out in
decent agreement, but quickly descend into very poor agreement 
and consistency by the weekend. Forecast confidence is fairly 
average early, but poor the remainder of the forecast given model 
difficulties. Should start out dry Thu night, but then the next 
system will be approaching by Friday. While models agree that we 
will have a front move through during the weekend, timing is all 
over the place. We should see rain chances increasing Friday, and 
some significant rain is expected during the weekend although 
timing is uncertain. For now will go with highest PoPs Friday 
night and Saturday. Given expected rain during the short term 
period leaving ground rather wet, there may be enough 
precipitation for some flooding issues Friday night/Saturday and 
this will be mentioned in the HWO. Also will keep mention of 
possible strong winds in the HWO given the expected strength of 
the low level jet. Colder air will push in for Sunday through 
Tuesday, and while not much precipitation is expected at this time
there may be a few showers/snow showers Sunday night into Monday.
Looks dry but still cold for Tuesday right now.

200 
FXUS64 KMRX 190836
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
336 AM EST Tue Dec 19 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Wednesday night)...
Dense fog has set up over the area, with many places dropping 
down to a quarter mile or less visibilities. This fog will likely 
stick around the rest of the overnight hours and even into the 
late morning hours before the sun gets a chance to peek through in
the afternoon hours. Even with the morning fog in place, building
heights will help raise temperatures high enough to where some 
valley locations could flirt with 60 for a high temperature today.

Our next system, a low moving out of Texas, will begin to set up
leading to a widespread rain event for the forecast area. Ahead of
the low a strong 850mb jet will set up and pump in abundant
moisture to the region. PWAT values jump up to near or above 1" 
putting us above the 90th percentile for this time of year. The 
southerly 850mb strong jet will likely be forced upwards towards
the upper level jet, leading to rapidly rising air and effective 
precipitation. When all is said and done, many locations in SE 
Tennessee could see around 2 inches of rain with locally higher 
amounts, which could cause localized flooding. With how little 
precipitation we've seen the past month or so (about 2 inches 
below normal for this month in Chattanooga) hopefully the 
rivers/lakes/soil will be able to absorb the heavy rain and keep 
widespread flooding issues away. There will be enough lift and 
instability that we can't rule out a rumble of thunder on 
Wednesday as well. The main system and associated jet will 
eventually move off to the East by Thursday morning and rain 
chances will taper off during the day. Even with the increased
cloud coverage over the upcoming days the low level jet will help
bring in warmer air leading to relatively similar high
temperatures for the next couple of days.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Monday)...
The extended will start quiet on Thursday with upper ridging over
the area, but boundary layer flow will already becoming southerly
in advance of next very strong upper level system over the plain 
states. The southerly flow will pull low-level moisture back into
the southern Plateau/Valley.

The low-level southerly jet will strengthen late Thursday night into 
Friday as a strong upper level jet moving into Missouri/Ohio Valleys.
Showers/thunderstorms will likely break-out across the lower 
Mississippi Valley in response to upper dynamics and isentropic 
lift. Some of the convection will move into the southern 
Plateau/southeast Tennessee toward daybreak Friday.

The strong synoptic lift over the Tennessee Valley Friday and Friday 
night will continue to strengthen the low-level jet pulling 
unseasonably high amounts of moisture into the Region. The 850mb 
jet will increase to 60kts plus by Friday night. Widespread 
convection can be expected with training possible over the 
Plateau. Will need to watch for the potential of localized flash 
flooding there the latter half of Friday and Friday night.

Do want to emphasize that the GFS/ECMWF are depicting a abnormally 
strong upper jet across the mid-section of the nation with winds of 
150-155kts. Give this strength, the associated dynamics will be 
quite strong, so will need to pay attention for a heavy rainfall 
event. Also can not rule out strong convection as well over the 
Plateau and southeast Tennessee.

The strong low-level jet will also produce windy conditions across 
the Mountains. Currently low-level jet is more southwesterly which 
is not conducive to Mountain-wave winds, but will also need to watch 
for the potential of a Mountain-wave event.

System moves east of the area for Saturday. For Saturday night 
through Monday (Christmas Day), the medium range models have been 
very inconsistent and thus confidence is low. At this time, cold air 
will pull back into the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians 
with more or orographic lift and cold air advection light snow 
and rain showers/flurries possible.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
300 PM EST Mon Dec 18 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight through Wednesday)...Fair weather tonight,
although low clouds and fog may redevelop overnight. A shortwave 
will eject out of the southern plains Tuesday and Tuesday night, 
spreading rain showers along a frontal boundary that will stretch 
eastward across TN. Rain chances will increase through the day 
Tuesday, becoming categorical Tuesday night, with locally heavy 
rain over the southern half of our forecast area Wednesday morning
before the system moves off to the east Wed afternoon and 
evening. Temperatures will be mild through the period.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday Night through Monday)...Rain chances will 
decrease overnight Wednesday into Thursday morning as a surface 
ridge of high pressure sets up over the Ohio Valley. Enough mid 
and upper level dry air will allow for mostly clear skies and dry 
weather...while zonal mid level flow will keep temperatures 
several degrees above normal. A surface low pressure 
system...developing ahead of a deep trough across the entire 
western CONUS...will cause SW flow to be channeled into the east 
TN Valley Thursday night through Saturday afternoon.

Models diverge on timing with the next line of showers moving 
through the area...with ECMWF slightly slower. Clouds will begin to 
increase overnight Thursday as moisture increases...and scattered 
rain will approach the southern Plateau and Southern Valley 
Friday morning and move to the NE through the day Friday and into 
Saturday. Low level convergence will allow for enough lift to keep
showers widespread through the overnight hours Friday. A low 
level jet will follow the rainfall through the valley...peaking in
the late afternoon and early evening. Winds could gust to around 
30 mph...with around 50 mph in the higher elevations. 

The GFS moves the rain east of the area by Saturday morning...but 
have trended towards the ECMWF with rain ending Saturday afternoon. 
PW values through Friday and Saturday are above 1...which is 
reaching the 90th percentile for this time of year. Rainfall totals 
of an inch or two could be expected if models remain consistent 
through the next few days. 

Saturday night...the low pressure system will move east...with high 
pressure and dry weather expected for most of Sunday. By Sunday 
night...the models are in rare agreement for day 7 of the 
forecast...and show the trough over the western US strengthening and 
slowly moving to the east. With the trough remaining to the west of 
the MS Valley...mid and upper level flow will be from the SW through 
the day Monday. Warm air and moisture will be advected in at least 
as low as the midlevels...and with an upper level jet causing plenty 
of lift...can expect scattered showers through the day. Models 
disagree on the low level winds...with cooler air possible at the 
surface. But with the forecast being on day 7...will hold off on 
mentioning any other precip type besides rainfall right now. Monday 
night...The axis of the trough approaches...with the flow possibly 
changing to out of the NW with cold air moving into the area. 
Uncertainty about timing of the cold air arrival and whether enough 
moisture will still be over the area...remain.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
233 PM EST Sun Dec 17 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...

Isentropic ascent to the north of a warm front is leading to 
widespread light rain across the area. Rainfall amounts have been 
light and do not expect to see anything over a tenth of an inch. 
Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicate a 
mid-level shortwave trough moving to the east across the Ohio 
River valley and Great Lakes with a ridge across the Florida 
Peninsula. At the surface, a warm front stretches W-E across South
Alabama and Georgia. Current radar imagery indicates that the 
back edge of the precipitation is moving into the Plateau. Due to 
this, have decreased PoPs throughout the remainder of the 
afternoon and into the evening hours. The isentropic lift is 
forecast to move to the southeast during this timeframe. The lift 
will exit the region tonight but the low level moisture will 
remain with the boundary to the south. Due to this, expect fog and
drizzle to develop overnight. Not forecasting dense enough fog 
for an advisory at this point but conditions will need to be 
monitored throughout the evening and overnight hours. Have also 
increased low temperatures overnight with widespread cloud cover 
lows will generally be in the upper 30s to mid 40s. 

On Monday, the upper level ridge will expand slightly to the north 
with the front to the south nudging to the northeast. The clouds 
will slowly dissipate late tomorrow morning. With the higher heights 
aloft and partly sunny skies by the afternoon, highs will warm into 
the mid to upper 50s. The boundary will not be too far to the south 
but the lack of a lifting mechanism aloft and PW values in the 0.4-
0.5 inch range will keep the forecast dry.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Saturday)...

Fairly active pattern will bring three precip episodes into the 
forecast area during the extended period, first on Tues night/Wed,
second on Friday night/ Sat, and the third potentially on Sunday.
Model solutions for the late portions of the forecast, around 
Christmas Eve, continue to fluctuate wildly. The 12Z EMCWF just 
arrived, showing a fairly warm Christmas Eve and Christmas Day 
with the frontal boundary and rain field to our north over the 
Ohio Valley, while the GFS is cooler and wetter with the frontal 
boundary near us, but still not cold enough to produce wintry 
precip. We will have to wait and see what comes of this epic 
battle of model solutions. But as it stands presently, this week 
looks to be warmer than normal, continuing into the holiday 
weekend.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)...

moves through westerly flow south of our area increasing clouds but

result in likely rain chances late Tuesday and Tuesday night south

the area Wednesday with the best lift and moisture across southeast 
TN and southwest NC. More ridging across the eastern states again 
Wednesday night through Thursday with mostly clear skies. Friday and 
into the weekend a deepening trough over the Rockies gets kicked 
east into the Southern Plains. A surface low over the southern 
plains on Thursday moves into the Great Lakes Friday. The trailing 
cold front will move across the Tennessee Valley Friday and into the 
Southern Appalachians by Saturday morning. A secondary front 
saturday will bring more rain and mild temperatures. Temperatures 
will stay mild with highs in the 50s to lower 60s all week and lows 
mostly mid 30s to mid 40s.

857 
FXUS64 KMRX 161954
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
254 PM EST Sat Dec 16 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...

The surface high pressure is shifting to the south and east of 
the area with weak southerly to southwesterly winds at the 
surface. Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis 
indicates a closed low spinning to the west near the Texas and New
Mexico line. A shortwave ridge ahead of this trough can be noted 
across the Northern Gulf of Mexico into the Central Plains. These 
higher heights aloft in combination with southerly flow and mostly 
sunny skies have allowed temperatures to rise up into the 40s this
afternoon. A few locations will top out in the 50s across the 
Central and Southern Valley. 

For tonight, the trough to the west will lift northeastward across 
the Southern Plains. At the same time, a warm front will begin to
lift slowly north across the Northern Gulf of Mexico. Isentropic 
lift ahead of this boundary will saturate the atmosphere from the 
top down. The atmosphere is rather dry currently with PW values in
the 0.2-0.3 inch range, therefore, it will take some time before 
precipitation begins to fall. Overnight lows will be a few 
degrees warmer tonight and range from the upper 20 to low 30s. 

Precipitation will begin near daybreak tomorrow across the 
Southern Valley and Plateau. With temperatures near freezing 
during this time there could be a brief period at the onset of 
light sleet or freezing rain but do not expect any impacts due to 
the light and brief nature. Just above the surface at the 850 mb 
level temperatures will be well above freezing with values in the 
6-8 degree Celsius range. A cool and rainy day is generally 
forecast for Sunday with the boundary remaining to the south. It 
looks like the best isentropic lift will be over the area late 
morning to mid afternoon. PW values during this timeframe will 
increase to around an inch. Model soundings indicate that this 
saturations will be below 500-600 mb and due to this expect 
rainfall amounts will be light and generally under a quarter of an
inch. With the persistent clouds and light rain, reduced highs on
Sunday with temperatures only making it up into the low to mid 
40s.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Friday)...

Models continue to come into better agreement through midweek with 
upper ridging resulting in above normal temperatures across the 
area. Minor shortwave traverses through westerly flow to the south 
of our area on Monday with slight chance PoPs across our southern 
sections. Stronger shortwave trough moves eastward across the 
Southern Plains on Tuesday with southwest flow and isentropic lift 
increasing across the Southern Appalachians. This will result in 
chance PoPs for most on Tuesday with likely PoPs possible across 
southern portions of the forecast area by late Tuesday and Tuesday 
night. The trough axis will move through the area on Wednesday with 
the strongest lift and moisture combination across southeast 
TN/southwest NC.

In the wake of this trough, models are in good agreement with 
ridging developing across the southeast CONUS leading to a moist 
southwest flow across the area ahead of a large scale trough and 
cold front late next week and into next weekend. It must be 
emphasized that there continues to be poor agreement on the exact 
track and strength of the system next weekend as well as the exact 
position of the surface cold front. There is impactful differences 
between model solutions with poor run to run model consistency. 
Highlighting the uncertainty, even the GEFS ensembles have fairly 
large spread with a standard deviation for surface temperatures next 
Saturday around 10 deg F. In short, there is still a lot of 
uncertainty with how things will setup next weekend, but there is 
growing certainty and agreement for a pattern favorable for 
precipitation. However, it would still be irresponsible to speculate 
with any certainty on specific precip type or coverage next weekend 
through Christmas based on current modeling and ensemble solutions.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...

Temperatures have struggled today under mostly cloudy skies with
most locations as of 2 pm still in the low to mid 30s. Recent

degrees this afternoon. At the surface, high pressure is building
in behind a departing cold front. In the upper levels, the axis of
the upper level trough is passing to the east with northwesterly
flow developing aloft. For tonight, expect the clouds will
continue to erode with mostly clear skies by daybreak. Light winds
moving in with the surface high will create radiational cooling
conditions. Overnight lows will generally be in the 20s.
Temperatures will begin to rebound on Saturday with light
southerly to southwesterly flow developing as the surface high
shifts eastward. Additionally, higher heights aloft will build in
as a shortwave ridge builds in behind the trough. High
temperatures on Saturday will range from upper 40s to low 50s
across most locations under mostly sunny skies.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Thursday)...

Models remain in very good agreement on the weather system for 
Sunday as shortwave energy rides NE out of Texas across a building 
middle level ridge over the Southeast US. Low level southerly flow 
ahead of this system on Saturday night into Sunday morning should 
greatly limit any frozen pcpn to the pre-dawn hours on Sunday with 
no accumulations expected before any mixed pcpn becomes all liquid 
by mid morning.

Continued low level southerly flow coupled with weak ridging aloft 
will help to keep temperatures about 5-10 degrees above normal from 
Sunday afternoon through Tuesday. Although bulk of moisture remains 
south of the area for the start of the work week, chance pops remain 
as the southern branch of the jet remains active with a series of 
shortwave troughs moving across the southern quarter of the area 
Monday and Tuesday. Given above normal temps and persistent WAA, no 
frozen pcpn is expected. Cold front finally pushes through very 
early Tuesday evening. Associated cold air lags well behind the 
front with temperatures Wednesday still expected to be slightly 
above normal for mid December. 

Solution to late week system is gaining confidence with the latest 
runs as GFS, Canadian, and ECMWF are all in fair agreement on 
position of surface cold front into Middle TN by the end of the 
forecast period.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
256 AM EST Fri Dec 15 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
With the front off to our southeast we are seeing colder air
funneled in from the northwest today. This will lead to a decrease
in temperatures on the order of 5-10 degrees when compared with
yesterday. Low level winds will be out of the southwest which
should help off-set a bit of the coldest temperatures. A little
bit of mid level moisture is still lingering behind the front
which means we should have a few clouds out there early this
morning, but the moisture will push off leading to clearing skies
during the daytime hours. Warmer air will begin to move in 
overnight, so the below average temperatures should only last for 
today before we warm up tomorrow.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday night)...
Models remain in very good agreement on the weather system for 
Sunday as shortwave energy rides NE out of Texas across a building 
middle level ridge over the Southeast US. Low level southerly flow 
ahead of this system on Saturday night into Sunday morning should 
greatly limit any frozen pcpn to the pre-dawn hours on Sunday with 
no accumulations expected before any mixed pcpn becomes all liquid 
by mid morning.

Continued low level southerly flow coupled with weak ridging aloft 
will help to keep temperatures about 5-10 degrees above normal from 
Sunday afternoon through Tuesday. Although bulk of moisture remains 
south of the area for the start of the work week, chance pops remain 
as the southern branch of the jet remains active with a series of 
shortwave troughs moving across the southern quarter of the area 
Monday and Tuesday. Given above normal temps and persistent WAA, no 
frozen pcpn is expected. Cold front finally pushes through very 
early Tuesday evening. Associated cold air lags well behind the 
front with temperatures Wednesday still expected to be slightly 
above normal for mid December. 

Solution to late week system is gaining confidence with the latest 
runs as GFS, Canadian, and ECMWF are all in fair agreement on 
position of surface cold front into Middle TN by the end of the 
forecast period.

airmass will continue into Friday with highs in the upper 30s to 
mid 40s.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Wednesday)...

Models continue to be in good agreement early in the long term 
period with diverging solutions late in the period. Surface ridging 
on Saturday will keep things dry with low boundary layer moisture 
resulting in large diurnal temperature variation through the day. As 
a shortwave trough moves eastward across the Southern Plains on 
Saturday night, southerly flow and moisture will increase ahead of 
it on Sunday. Model soundings indicate very dry air within the 
boundary layer on Sunday morning even though mid-levels are nearly 
saturated. This will likely limit precipitation on Sunday, 
especially during the early onset of precipitation. Cannot rule out 
a slight chance of brief light mixed precipitation early on Sunday 
morning with lingering cool air in the valleys and evaporational 
cooling. However, temperature profiles show warm air advection will 
keep any mixed precip brief and switch to all liquid rain by mid-
morning Sunday. We stay in a southwesterly flow on Monday and 
Tuesday with most moisture expected to remain to our south. A cold 
front sweeps through late Tuesday with lingering moisture across the 
higher elevations of the mountains and northeast TN on Tuesday 
night. Surface ridging expected to keep us dry on Wednesday and 
Thursday. Model solutions diverge late week with increased 
uncertainty regarding strength and position of trough and expected 
position of the surface cold front.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...

Northwesterly flow aloft currently across the area with a shortwave 
trough to the northwest across the Western Great Lakes. At the 
surface, high pressure has shifted to the east with southerly to 
southwesterly flow across the region. In addition, a cold front in 
association with the shortwave trough stretches from near Chicago to 
the southwest to near Kansas City. The atmosphere remains dry across 
the Southern Appalachians with dewpoints currently in the single 
digits to low teens. Winds are also increasing with the high to the 
east and low to the northwest. Due to the dry air and winds, have
a Fire Danger Statement throughout the remainder of the 
afternoon. Winds will continue to increase into the evening and 
overnight hours and have a winds advisory for the mountains along 
the Tennessee and North Carolina line and Washington County in SW 
Virginia. In these locations, winds will gust to over 40 mph at 
times. In the valley, winds will be below advisory criteria but 
could still see gusts into the 25-30 mph range. 

The cold front will rapidly move through the forecast area later 
tonight into Thursday morning. PW values are in the 0.2-0.4 inch 
range ahead of the boundary but models are showing some flurries 
across portions of SW VA and NE TN and have continued this in the 
forecast for late tonight into Thursday morning. Confidence is low 
and do not expect any impacts or accumulations. Winds should subside 
on Thursday as the front races quickly to the south and east and 
have the wind advisory ending at 15z. Skies will be mostly to partly 
sunny on Thursday but a fresh supply of cold air advection behind 
the departing boundary will keep highs generally in the upper 30s to 
mid 40s. 

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Tuesday)...

Models seem to have a good handle on the forecast through Sunday,
but consistency greatly deteriorates as we head into next week. 
Models continue to trend drier on Friday with a weak shortwave 
moving through, and have therefore continued the no-precip 
forecast. Weak high pressure builds in from the Gulf Coast for 
Saturday with another system approaching the area by Sunday. Front
will push through the area during the second half of the day on 
Sunday, and with highs in the 40s on Sunday, precip will fall as 
mainly rain with maybe just a few flakes mixed in over the higher 
terrain early Sunday morning or later Sunday evening. From here, 
model solutions digress. Wetter GFS keeps our area in moist SW 
flow behind the front, with continued precip chances through 
Tuesday evening when another shortwave rotates through. In 
contrast, ECMWF is drier with NW flow immediately moving in behind
the front and a faster, drier shortwave moving through Monday. 
For now, have chance PoPs Monday becoming slight chance and 
decreasing from west to east on Tuesday, but this forecast will 
likely change as models come into better forecast agreement. 
Regardless, both models appear to dry out by Wednesday. The model 
differences also impact temperatures for Monday/Tuesday and 
current confidence in forecast highs/lows is below average.

north to the lower and middle 20s south. Dry cold advection is

southeast through the forecast area later Thursday night into Friday 
knocking high temperatures back about ten degrees below normal again 
to end the work week. It looks like the same story with northwest 
flow producing light orographic snowfall in the higher terrain. The 
upper flow gradually shifts to a more zonal configuration over the

maritime polar air rather than the much colder continental stuff.

should be rain, but had to sprinkle a small chance of some snow in

expected through the day as the cold front and trough moves

amounts in the mountains are expected to be around one inch, and
with low temps in the teens, wind chills in the mountains could
drop below zero. Wednesday will be dry with decreasing clouds as
the midlevel thermal trough exits and warm advection develops.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Saturday)...
Wednesday night the forecast area should be in between systems and 
still dry but clouds will be increasing across the north as the next 
clipper system moves into the Ohio Valley. On Thursday farther west 
short wave energy moving into the plains states digs south and as 
moisture pools along and ahead of another cold front the 
precipitation type will be mostly rain showers ahead and along the 
front across central and northern sections. Temperatures warm 
Thursday so any snow showers will be early or at the highest 
elevations. Highs will be 40s to lower 50s lower elevations and 30s 
in the higher elevations. Thursday night and Friday a colder 
secondary trough will change the rain showers to snow showers with a 
couple inches possible in the higher eastern mountains and mainly 
trace amounts at lower elevations. Friday night and Saturday high 
pressure builds back in...another dry period with clearing skies. As 
high shifts east Saturday much warmer temperatures in the mid 40s to 
lower 50s. A final system to move into the Tennessee Valley Saturday 
night and Sunday. With southerly flow this system warms temperature 
even more into the 50s with just rain as the main precipitation
type.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Very challenging forecast for

the NAM/SREF/ECMWF solutions. It will be cold enough aloft for 
all snow in the higher terrain, and precip amounts are expected to
be enough for the winter weather advisory to be expanded to the 
northeast TN mountain zones. Will also spread PoPs further west 
into the valley, but precipitation amounts should be light and 
will keep PoPs fairly low. Rain may mix in with snow in some of 
the lower elevation areas as well since boundary layer temps 
expected to be borderline for snow. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday)...This period should be 
another chilly one with approximately three short waves or 
"clippers" rotating southeast around a seemingly permanent upper 
level low over Quebec. The first moves across the forecast area 
during the period Saturday afternoon through early Sunday morning 
generating some orographic snow showers in the higher terrain 
across Southwest Virginia and Northeast Tennessee with a few 
flurries in the valleys in these areas. Due to limited moisture, 
snowfall amounts look to be around a half to one inch in these 
higher terrain areas into Sunday morning. Sunday afternoon through
the daytime period Monday will be a dry period while the region 
awaits the next clipper which impacts the area from about Monday 
night through Tuesday night. This system looks like it will 
produce a few more orographic snow showers in the higher terrain 
of Southwest Virginia, Northeast Tennessee and the Smoky Mountains
of Central East Tennessee with moisture limitations keeping 
amounts around an inch or less, along with a few flurries in the 
valleys, generally north of interstate 40. Wednesday should be 
another dry day with the final clipper building southeast across 
the forecast area later Wednesday night through Thursday night. 
This system is modeled to have a little more moisture associated 
with it, generating perhaps one to two inches of snow in the 
higher terrain. However, due to the fact that this feature is 
about a week away, forecast uncertainty is a bit higher. 
Concerning the temperature forecast, max and mins will be around 
ten to as many as fifteen degrees below normal for mid December, 
with slightly warmer maxes on Monday and again on Thursday, due to
winds shifting to a west to southwesterly direction ahead of each
short wave.

.SHORT TERM (Today through Friday night)... 
At the surface, a cold front marked by a wind shift and dewpoint 
gradient now over E KY and Middle TN will push across our area this 
evening. As a result, drier low level air in the TN Valley will be a 
factor in how far west precip will reach late tonight/Friday. Models 
have come into better agreement with the 12Z runs that the mountains 
and SW NC will see some snow. The NAM spreads precip farther west, 
along a line from CHA to TYS to TRI, while the GFS precip hugs the 
terrain more closely. The difference appears to be in their moisture 
profiles, with the GFS showing much drier air below 600 mb than the 
NAM. Will keep PoPs in the mountain zones and SW NC to account for 
the dry post-frontal air mass, more like the GFS, but will raise 
PoPs and QPF in those areas from the previous forecast. Both models 
indicate that forcing associated with the jet will be weak in our 
area, and remain to our SE. Thus, snow accumulations are expected to 
be light, with up to 1 inch expected in Clay Co. NC and the higher 
elevations of the Smokies. For timing, onset of snow is expected to 
be within a few hours of sunrise tomorrow, ending near midnight 
Friday night as the upper jet pushes moisture east of the area.

.LONG TERM (Saturday through Wednesday)... 
Cold upper low over eastern Canada near Hudson's Bay and 
northeast Canada will keep the eastern two thirds of the country 
in a longwave upper trough and bring a series of cold fronts 
across the region from the Great Lakes. The first system will move
in late Saturday and Saturday night. Light snow flurries and 
showers possible across mainly southwest Virginia and northeast 
Tennessee higher elevations with one half to one inch accumulation
possible. Another impulse late Sunday night early Monday looks 
dry. Then Monday night and Tuesday a stronger impulse which 
deepens trough will reinforce the cold air and bring a better shot
of frozen precipitation late Tuesday into Wednesday morning. 
Orographic northwest snowfall will develop Tuesday with good cold 
air advection with even light snow or flurries possible at lower 
elevations. The deeper moisture and strong northwest flow brings a
better chance for more significant high elevation snowfall. This 
is followed by another quick moving weaker system Wednesday night 
into Thursday. 

Cold temperatures will prevail Saturday and Sunday but high 
temperatures warm into the mid 40s to lower 50s ahead of the next 
system. Lows will be several degrees below freezing Saturday through 
Sunday but closer to freezing early Monday and Tuesday. Temperatures 
become much colder again Tuesday with a slow warming by Thursday. 
Night time lows stay below freezing through the end of the forecast 
period.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...
Few changes are expected to the general weather pattern over the
short term period, with a NW flow continuing through the lower
levels (below ~750 mb), and a W-SW flow at and above 700 mb that
will continue to keep broken to overcast midlevel clouds overhead.
A dry layer from the surface to 700 mb will evaporate any precip
from the midlevel cloud layer through the period. We will have a
cold front that is currently across northern IL/IN and MI that
will be moving into our area late tomorrow, but it will have very
little impact this period other than a shift of surface winds to 
N and perhaps an increase in low clouds late in the day. With
temperature advection ahead of the front being near neutral and 
mid/high clouds perhaps being a little thinner, Thursday's high 
temps should be warmer than today, mainly in the mid to upper 40s.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Tuesday)...
The troughing pattern will be the main theme through the extended
with cold air entrenched across the Eastern CONUS. Shortwaves 
will continue to rotate through the longwave trough bringing a 
parade of weak systems that will give us a low chances of light 
precipitation and continued cold weather.

On Friday, a surface front will be oriented SW-NE across AL/GA/SC/NC 
with widespread precipitation likely to our southeast. A 
strengthening jet streak will place our area within the right-front 
entrance region and favored area of upper-divergence and lift. As 
the 500mb shortwave approaches, lift will strengthen and provide for 
slight chance/chance PoPs across far eastern portions of the 
forecast area. Very dry air in the low-levels will likely limit 
precipitation and result in virga. Light snow accumulations would be 
possible Friday across the higher elevations of the far eastern 
mountains if this system makes a slight westward shift and additional 
moisture can overcome the dry air.

For Saturday, latest model guidance continues to show a shortwave 
diving southward into the Ohio Valley with the majority of moisture 
and lift remaining to our north. With northwest upslope winds and 
shallow moisture, may have some rain or snow showers on Saturday 
afternoon and into the early overnight hours. Light snow 
accumulation will be possible across the higher elevations of the 
TN/NC mountains and especially in SW VA in areas such as High Knob 
where more moisture will be available. A few flurries may be 
possible across the lower elevations.

For Sunday and Monday, dry NW flow aloft and surface ridging will 
produce dry weather and milder, but still slightly below normal, 
temperatures on Monday.

By Tuesday through the middle of next week, additional shortwaves 
are expected to dive southward providing more slight chance PoPs for 
light rain or snow showers. At this time, the GFS and ECMWF both 
show cyclogenesis occurring off of the East Coast as a stronger 
shortwave deepens the upper trough. This would result in more cold 
air spilling into our area and the bulk of precipitation remaining 
far to our east.

The winter chill has definitely arrived with temperatures forecast 
to be below normal through at least the forecast period.

FXUS64 KMRX 060820
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
320 AM EST Wed Dec 6 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Our warmer weather is gone and it 
looks like the cold is here to stay. Robust long wave trough 
barreling down across a large portion of the U.S. behind the 
departed, strong, cold front. With the front now to our east, 
surface high pressure begins to build in today across the area. 
Though low clouds and precip will be gone, mid/upper level clouds 
will hang in through the day and yield mostly cloudy skies. Highs 
will be a good 15 degrees colder today as cold air has ushered in 
behind the front. Highs will generally be in the low to mid 40s, 
which is around 8 degrees below normal. 

Overnight, some moisture moves NE out of the Gulf Coast states but 
will remain well off to our SE. The only affect to our weather will 
be some more clouds moving northward into our area. Because of 
additional clouds moving in overnight, lows will generally stay 
right around freezing to a few degrees blow freezing for most 
locations. The colder overnight lows come in the long term period. 

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...The theme for Thursday 
through Friday Night will be that the Tennessee Valley/southern 
Appalachians will be between the northern stream storm track (over 
the Great Lakes/upper Ohio Valley) and southern stream (from Texas 
across the southeast United States). Plenty of high level clouds 
will remain, but precipitation will be rather limited.

For Saturday, latest GFS and ECMWF agree with taking a fast moving 
short-wave farther north across the Great Lakes and Ohio Valley and 
just brushing southwest virginia and northeast Tennessee with light 
precipitation. A mixture of snow and rain showers are expected. 
Limited snow accumulations are possible across the higher 
elevations, such as High Knob, especially Saturday night.

For Sunday and Monday, dry west to northwest flow aloft and 
surface ridging will produce dry conditions and milder 
temperatures for Monday.

For Monday night and Tuesday, another short-wave dives toward the 
Ohio/Tennessee Valleys. Precipitation in for the form of snow is 
possible, but the evolution of the system will likely change, so will
not get too specific.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
301 PM EST Tue Dec 5 2017

.Short Term (Tonight and Wednesday)...A cold front is pressing 
slowly east across Middle Tennessee at mid afternoon. The upper 
trough driving this system is rather unimpressive for the active 
colder season. The back edge of the shield of rain associated with 
this front will be edging off the Cumberland Plateau and through the 
Great Valley fairly quickly after the valid period of the public 
forecast begins this evening. Sufficiently dry northwest flow 
will be filling in behind this front by midnight which will leave
very little precipitation behind across the forecast area. There 
will just be a slight chance for a sprinkle or flurry in the 
higher terrain along the North Carolina border through the 
remainder of the overnight period, as cold air builds into the 
region. Wednesday will be a quieter; albeit much colder day with 
chilly northerly flow pulling high temperatures back a good 
fifteen degrees below today's highs. 

.LONG TERM (Wednesday night through Tuesday)...The main story in 
the long-term forecast will be the persistent arctic air 
intrusions into the area and the chance for snow showers and 
flurries over the weekend. 

To start the extended forecast period, a baroclinic boundary will 
stretch across the Gulf Coast eastward to the Carolina Coast. Cold 
air advection to the north of this boundary will produce lows on 
Thursday morning in the upper 20s to mid 30s for most valley 
locations. The upper level pattern throughout the extended forecast 
will take shape during this timeframe with a longwave trough across 
the Eastern CONUS and a longwave ridge across the Western CONUS. A 
cold front will approach the forecast area on Thursday as a 
shortwave trough digs into the Lower Mississippi River Valley. PW 
values ahead of this boundary will be near the 10th percentile in 
the 0.2-0.3 inch range and do not expect any precipitation with this 
frontal passage. The aforementioned trough will move across the 
Tennessee River Valley on Friday with cyclogenesis along the 
Carolina Coast with the baroclinic boundary. With this occurring 
well to the east, expect most area will remain dry but models depict 
the northwestern periphery of the precipitation will be near the 
Smoky Mountains and into SW North Carolina. Therefore, have 
continued with a small mention of snow showers for these areas on 
Friday. 

The main chance for widespread snow showers/flurries will come on 
Saturday as an upper level trough dives southward out of Canada into 
the Tennessee River Valley. Another arctic boundary associated with 
this trough will race across the region. Model soundings indicate a 
shallow layer of saturation from about 850-700 mb with some 
suggesting weak instability less than 100 J/Kg. Due to this have 
continued with slight chance to chance PoPs with best chances north 
of I-40. The recent GFS has backed off slightly with the QPF values 
and think any accumulation at this time would be less than an inch, 
again with best chances north of I-40. The main story will continue 
to be the cold weather. On Sunday morning, 850 mb temperatures will 
drop down into the -13 to -8 degrees Celsius range or around two 
standard deviations below normal. This will lead to morning lows in 
the upper teens to low 20s on Sunday. 

Temperatures will moderate some on Monday as the intrusion of arctic 
air takes a brief break. Regardless, the upper level pattern 
continues to be rather unchanged with another blast of cold air 
forecast to arrive on Tuesday with the chance for light snow 
showers and flurries once again.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
339 AM EST Tue Dec 5 2017

.Short Term (Today and Tonight)...An active period with a strong 
frontal boundary moving through the region this afternoon. A 300 mb 
jet over the Ohio Valley will place the area under the favored right 
entrance region of the jet enhancing the frontal-genetic forcing.

Widespread showers will accompany the frontal-genetic band with 
model sounding showing some elevated instability (rather limited 
though) over the Plateau and southern half of the Tennessee Valley.
Due to the strong deep vertical ageo-strophic forcing along the 
front, will include a slight chance of thunder with the area of 
elevated instability.

Given PWs between 1.15 and 1.3 inches, plenty of moisture will be 
available with PWs ranging from the 90% and Daily Max PW 
climatology. Locally heavy rains are expected, but given the 
progressive nature, widespread flooding issue are not expected. 
Localized runoff or street flooding is possible.

Besides the rain, strong low-level jet will produce windy conditions 
across the higher elevations with breezy elsewhere. Will continue 
with wind advisory through early afternoon.

Due to the cold air advection behind front and frontal-timing in the 
early afternoon, highs today will likely be around noon/early 
afternoon with falling temperatures by mid to late afternoon.

For tonight, cold air advection, left over moisture and orographic 
lift from northwest flow will allow rain to change to light snow 
showers/flurries over the higher elevations. Little to no 
accumulation expected. Otherwise, dry air advection will dissipate 
the cloud cover from west to east.

.Long Term (Wednesday through Monday)...At the beginning of this 
period, the large polar upper trough will now have a firm grip on 
the area, and it should have this grip through the entire period. At 
the surface, the initial front will be past us, and cooler air will 
be pouring into the area.  

Question about Wednesday and Wednesday night, as drier air pushes 
into the area, but a wave of lift near our eastern areas may keep 
the threat of light POPs in our far east Wed and SE on Wed night. 
Will keep some light POPs from Smokies southward on Wed, and in SW 
NC counties Wed night.  Snow shower threat in SW NC on both Wedneday 
night and Thursday night, but very light.  Totals each night less 
than 1/4 inch in the higher terrain there.

There will be several short waves moving through the area--looks 
like one short wave that will bring some moisture with it and a 
reinforcing cold front will arrive on Saturday.  It should be cold 
enough on Saturday for snow showers, even in the valley.  In the 
mountains, after the front passes, we will see upslope snows 
lingering as the valley turns dry, but the moisture in the mountains 
looks like it will not last very long as drier air continues to push 
into the region.  

For temps, guidance looks good except for Saturday.  Will go about 3 
degrees below guidance T Max for Saturday, considering lift, clouds, 
and extremely cold thickness values surging into the area.  This 
colder air will make better chances of light showers in the valley 
being snow showers in addition to (or instead of) rain showers for 
Saturday.

precipitation is ending. Several pieces of short wave energy will 
shift south out of Canada on the back side of the long wave trough
which will serve to hold the feature in place. This means that 
we're looking at a very cold latter half of the week with high 
temperatures a good 15 to 20 degrees lower than the balmy near 60 
degree readings we will enjoy on Tuesday. Detailed timing and 
positioning of the clipper short waves not yet available but it 
appears there will be two main features. The first moves across 
the area later Friday into Friday night with the second moving 
across the area on Saturday. It doesn't look too impressive for a 
great deal of snow with mainly flurries in the lower elevations 
with some snow showers in the higher terrain aided by orographic 
lift. At this time, Sunday appears to be dry.
