FXUS64 KMRX 030828
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
328 AM EST Sun Dec 3 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Clear sky, calm winds, and saturated air-mass has allowed patchy
fog to develop with some dense, especially near area lakes and
streams. At this time, coverage does not warrant an advisory.

Surface and upper ridging will keep conditions dry and
unseasonably warm today with highs in the upper 50s and 60s most
locations.

For tonight, clear sky and calm winds will once again allow
temperatures to drop quickly due to good radiational cooling.
Patchy fog is possible near area lakes and streams.

.Long Term (Monday through Saturday)...Active weather pattern for 
the long term with mild temps to start, then rain, followed by the 
coldest air of the season.

Through Monday night, ridging ahead of an approaching storm system 
will keep conditions mild and dry. Highs on Monday will climb into 
the low to mid 60s under warm, southerly flow. This will also keep 
lows well above average Monday night, ranging from the mid 40s to 
mid 50s.

By Tuesday morning, models are in fairly good agreement on placing 
the front over west TN. Shower chances will increase from west to 
east through the day on Tuesday with the highest chances for rain 
looking to come during the mid afternoon through evening. PW values 
will be near to slightly above the 90th percentile for this time of 
year based on soundings. With plenty of forcing in place, we could 
see some moderate to locally heavy rain as this system sweeps 
through. On average though, most places will see around 0.75-1.5 
inches of rainfall from Tuesday morning through Wednesday morning. 
Behind the front Tuesday night cold air rapidly surges in and some 
snow will mix in overnight at higher elevations. However, the front 
and most of the associated moisture will already be well to our east 
by this point and little to no accumulation expected at this point. 
Light snow showers/flurries could linger Wednesday morning across 
the favored eastern slopes as the now NW flow will help to squeeze 
out any remaining moisture.

From Wednesday through Saturday a deep longwave trough will be in 
place across the entire Eastern United States. This will allow for 
the colder air to be locked in through the remaining long term 
period. Highs will generally be in the low to mid 40s with lows in 
the 20s. Wednesday and Thursday will be dry, but by next weekend 
both the GFS and ECMWF show another low diving down into the already 
present long wave trough. This will bring in another reinforcing 
shot of cold air and perhaps some moisture which could result in 
light snow showers/flurries across much of the area. Confidence is 
fairly low in the weekend system at this point, so for now have 
capped PoPs in the slight chance category.

112 
FXUS64 KMRX 020835
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
335 AM EST Sat Dec 2 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
A weak shortwave will cross the area today, bringing morning
clouds to the region. As the wave moves east this afternoon, skies
will clear. With very little moisture available, no precipitation
is anticipated today. Upper level flow becomes more amplified by 
tonight, with ridging building out of the central US. This will
maintain dry and pleasant conditions areawide.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Friday)...
Amplified pattern results in ridging on Sunday and Monday keeping
us dry, mostly clear, and warm. In fact, we'll have very warm 
temperatures on Sunday and Monday with highs about 10 to 15 
degrees above normal. High and midlevel clouds will be on the 
increase during the day on Monday ahead of a longwave trough and 
surface cold front. As a jet streak across the Upper Mississippi 
River Valley and the Great Lakes strengthens on Monday, upper- 
level divergence across the Ohio River Valley will lead to a 
strengthening low-level jet across the Tennessee River Valley. 
PoPs will increase on Monday night as isentropic lift increases. 
The cold front will move through the region on Tuesday with likely
to categorical PoPs along and just ahead of the cold front 
primarily midday Tuesday through early Tuesday night. There is not
much instability ahead of the cold front, so do not expect 
thunderstorms at this time. Could also have some locally heavy 
rainfall on Tuesday with PW values and integrated water vapor 
transport around the 90th-95th percentile. There is much better 
consistency in guidance and ensembles with the timing of the cold 
front and heaviest precipitation, so forecast confidence is 
increasing and is higher than yesterday with this upcoming system 
on Tuesday.

We'll have to pay for the amplified pattern and warm temperatures 
early in the week with very cold air late week. Behind the cold 
front, temperatures take a nosedive as troughing sets up over the 
Eastern CONUS and cold, surface high pressure from Canada slides 
southeastward into our region. Shortwave energy will continue to 
rotate through the longwave troughing pattern keeping the late week 
forecast cold and uncertain, and it will bring the potential for 
some light rain or snow showers/flurries with these quick moving 
systems. At this time, the best chance for precipitation may be on 
Friday as models show a strong shortwave and quick moving surface 
low with limited moisture moving through the Ohio River Valley, but 
forecast confidence this far out is very low. Overall, the best 
chance for precipitation late week will be across the higher 
elevations where low-level winds will enhance orographic lift in 
northwest flow and make the most efficient use of the limited 
moisture. Just remember that the main weather story through late 
next week is the very cold air. This will likely be the first real 
shot of very cold air this winter season for our area with 
temperatures potentially 10 or more degrees below normal on Thursday 
and Friday.

FXUS64 KMRX 010826
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
326 AM EST Fri Dec 1 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Saturday)...
Cold front has pushed east of the area and showers have ended.
The back edge of the clouds associated with the front will move
through during the next few hours, but low level moisture trapped
along the mountains will keep low cloud cover and fog across the
area through the morning hours today. Surface high pressure and
zonal upper level flow builds in for the afternoon hours through
Saturday, bringing increasing sunshine and mild temperatures with
highs in the upper 50s and lower 60s.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Thursday night)...
Ridging is expected on Sunday and Monday keeping us dry, mostly 
clear, and warm. Very warm temperatures will be expected across 
the forecast area on Sunday and Monday with highs about 10 degrees
above normal. High and midlevel clouds will be on the increase 
during the day on Monday ahead of the longwave trough and surface 
cold front across the Great Plains. A strong 150+ kt jet streak 
across the Great Lakes will enhance upper-level divergence across 
the Ohio River Valley, and in response, lead to a strengthening 
low- level jet across the Tennessee River Valley. PoPs will 
increase on Monday night and Tuesday morning as isentropic lift 
increases in response to the strengthening southwesterly flow with
likely PoPs along and just ahead of the cold front primarily 
Tuesday afternoon and night. There is not much instability ahead 
of the cold front, so the chance of thunderstorms is very low and 
have only included a slight chance for thunder in the forecast. 
Could also have some locally heavy rainfall on Tuesday with PW 
values and integrated water vapor transport around the 90th 
percentile. PoPs have been broadbrushed to a degree because of the
uncertainty with timing of frontal passage. The ECMWF is much 
quicker bringing the cold front through around Noon on Tuesday and
the GFS is slower with frontal passage occurring closer to 
sunrise on Wednesday. This is about an 18 hour difference between 
the two models, and is the reason that higher PoPs are spread out 
from Tuesday through Wednesday at this time. Behind the cold 
front, temperatures take a nosedive as troughing sets up over the 
Eastern CONUS and cold, surface high pressure from Canada slides 
southeastward towards our region. Shortwave energy will continue 
to rotate through the longwave troughing pattern keeping the late 
week forecast cold, uncertain, mostly cloudy, and bringing the 
potential for some light rain or snow showers/flurries with these 
quick moving systems. This is especially true across the higher 
elevations where low-level winds will enhance orographic lift in 
northwest flow. The big story through late next week appears to be
the very cold air. This could be the first real shot of very cold
air this winter season for our area with temperatures potentially
10 or more degrees below normal by late next week.

Carolina border later Thursday into Thursday night.

.Short Term (Today through Friday)...
Weak frontal passage will bring light rain to the area especially
this afternoon and evening. POPS of 60% seemingly dominate the
forecast, but QPF amounts are going to be skimpy...the POPS look
worse than the nature of the event. But the front and precip will
end by Friday, allowing Friday to be a pretty nice and mild day
with weak ridging.

.Long Term (Friday Night through Wednesday)...
Dry air and high pressure will be in place to start the extended 
forecast with PW values in the 0.4-0.6 inch range. These values 
are around the median value for late November. A weak mid-level 
trough will move through the Southern Appalachians late Friday 
into early Saturday. Moisture as mentioned will be somewhat 
limited and models only depict the possibility for a few light 
showers across the higher elevations along the Tennessee and North
Carolina line. Therefore, did continue with s slight chance for 
precipitation across the higher elevations late Friday into early 
saturday. 

The majority of the weekend will be dominated by high pressure and 
northwesterly flow aloft. Cloud cover in association with the mid-
level trough on Saturday will keep temperatures in the mid 50s to 
low 60s. Higher heights aloft, southerly low level flow and an ample 
supply of sunshine will push highs up into the upper 50s to mid 60s 
on Sunday and Monday. 

A robust upper level trough will move into the Central CONUS on 
Monday with a strong cold front stretching across the Great Plains. 
A 25-35 kt low level jet will advect in moisture Monday and Tuesday 
with PW values up into the 1.2-1.4 inch range by Tuesday afternoon. 
Looking at model soundings, it appears that any instability will be 
limited and less than 250 J?Kg. Due to this, have not mentioned 
thunderstorms in the forecast at this time. Models are fairly 
consistent with the onset of precipitation late Monday into early 
Tuesday. Models diverge some with the strength of the southern 
shortwave trough early in the week. The ECMWF is more progressive 
with the trough and pushes the front through the forecast area by 
Wednesday morning. The GFS is a bit weaker with the southern 
shortwave trough and about 12 hours slower with a more NE-SW 
oriented front. Due to this, have elevated PoPs Monday night through 
Wednesday.

The main story in the extended will be the influx of arctic air 
across the eastern half of the CONUS as a longwave trough digs in 
across the region. A few shortwave troughs will rotate around the 
base of the longwave trough and models do indicate the possibility 
of some light snow showers near the end of the long-term period.

time of year...will say confidence is low on timing and intensity 
of storms Tuesday. After the front moves east of the Appalachians 
Tuesday night...the low pressure will strengthen...bringing cold 
air advection to the area beginning Wednesday.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
405 AM EST Wed Nov 29 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Ridge of high pressure across the eastern states gradually shifts
east today as a weak cold front moves into the Ohio Valley. This
front will weaken by tonight just to the north of the region. A
closed upper level low over Oklahoma early this morning will move
into the Mississippi Valley late today and open up as it
approaches the Tennessee Valley. Most of the moisture associated 
with the system will be confined to west of the forecast area
through early Thursday morning but clouds will increase overnight.
Removed rain chances through sunrise Thursday.

Tonight skies are mostly clear. Wide range of temperatures from 
readings in the 20s in colder sheltered valleys northeast but 
warmer 40s to lower 50s where mixing is occurring. Because the air
mass is still very dry temperatures will warm quickly into the 
lower to mid 60s once again this afternoon. Tonight skies will 
initially be mostly clear then increasing clouds overnight with 
lows from the lower 40s to lower 50s except some 30s northeast 
where clouds move in late.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...
A mid-level shortwave trough will approach the area on Thursday 
with southwesterly flow in the low levels advecting in moisture 
into the Southern Appalachians. PW values will increase into the 
90th percentile for late November on Thursday. Model soundings 
indicate that the saturation will generally be below 600-700 mb 
and only forecast a tenth to two tenths of an inch of precip. at 
the most. A cold front associated with the mid-level trough will 
pass through the area late Thursday into early Friday. High 
pressure will build in behind the departing front on Friday. 
Cooler and drier air will advect in on Friday with PW values in 
the 0.2-0.4 inch range with precipitation coming to en end early 
Friday. The cold air advection behind the boundary is not overly 
impressive and with mostly sunny skies on Friday, highs will top 
out in the mid 50s to low 60s for most locations. 

The surface high will shift to the east late Friday into early 
Saturday with light southerly flow returning by Saturday afternoon. 
There is a weak upper level trough that moves through during this 
time period but the atmosphere will be too dry except for a few 
light showers across the higher elevations. Ridging from the 
surface to the upper level will build in on Sunday with high 
temperatures rising up into the upper 50s to low 60s. 

The GFS and ECMWF both indicate a more robust upper level trough 
moving across the Northern Plains to start the work week. Southerly 
flow ahead of this system will continue to keep temperatures above 
seasonal averages. There are some timing differences in the models 
but both indicate increasing PoPs late Monday into Tuesday. 

Just beyond the long-term forecast both models indicate strong cold 
air advection behind the boundary with temperatures well below 
normal by the middle of next week.

trough and progress eastward tomorrow, but 850-700 mb winds 
remain out of the WSW/W ahead of the disturbance with continued 
dry air evident through the mid to upper levels in forecast 
soundings. May have some scattered clouds, especially across the 
southern portions of the forecast area, but don't anticipate any 
precipitation on Wednesday. With surface ridging to our east and

remain above average and be within a degree or two of Tuesday
afternoon observations.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Monday)...

east across the Ozarks tonight, and across our area Wednesday

will remain quite limited, according to model forecast sounding 
profiles. The main impact will be increasing clouds, but a slight 
chance PoP seems warranted for southern sections late Wednesday
night as shown by the NAM and SREF, both of which produce light 
QPF.

mb shortwave trough. Advection of warm/moist air with a SW 20-25 kt 
LLJ will bring rising rain chances through the day. Model agreement 
with this timing is much better than previous runs, so PoPs on 
Thursday will be raised into the likely range. The surface cold 
front lags behind and does not cross the area until late Thursday 
night, so likely to high chance PoPs will be continued for that 
period. For Friday, high pressure will settle into the OH Valley 
region, with a dry W-NW flow aloft.

Both the GFS and ECMWF show a weak shortwave trough crossing the 
area on Saturday, which spread some moisture into the Southern 
Appalachians. The are some differences with the position of this 
moisture, with the ECMWF keeping it to our east. Will have a slight 
chance PoP for now along the mountains. 

A more amplified pattern develops for next week, with a large ridge 
over the Southeast through Monday. The ridge gets suppressed as a 
trough moves into the Great Lakes, which may result in rain chances 
returning on Tuesday.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

The surface ridge has shifted just to the east with calm winds and 
cold temperatures early this morning. Ideal radiational cooling 
conditions continue with clear skies and light winds with 
temperatures in the upper 20s to mid 30s across most locations to 
start the day. PW values remains near th 10th percentile for late 
November with values in the 0.2-0.3 inch range. Will start to see 
some light southeasterly to southerly flow later today as the 
surface high shifts further to the east. Warm air advection and 
higher heights aloft will lead to highs a couple of degrees warmer 
than yesterday with temperatures ranging from the upper 50s to mid
60s for most locations. The warming trend will continue tonight
with overnight lows in the mid 30s to low 40s.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday)...

Weak trough will continue to make it's way towards our area and 
ahead of it we should get some increasing moisture due to southerly 
winds. Weak trough will also bring through a weak front late 
Thursday into early Friday morning. We should see precipitation 
along the front, but QPF amounts should be pretty light through this 
event. Highest precipitation chances begin Thursday afternoon and 
continue through early Friday morning until the front passes 
through. Front doesn't pack to much of a punch and winds will 
quickly return to a westerly/southerly flow behind it so 
temperatures won't take too much of a hit as it passes through. 

Relatively zonal flow sets up behind the front and we continue with 
similar weather to what we have seen for the past few days leading 
up to today. Some of the long term models hint that we see a weak 
secondary short wave zip across over the weekend, but there is still 
disagreement with how to handle this system. Even if it does come to 
pass that a shortwave moves across it looks to be relatively quick 
and only brings a chance of rain on Saturday afternoon. After
these two systems move through we begin to see ridging build in 
and temperatures warm up into the upper 50's/60's across much of 
the area as we move into next week.

FXUS64 KMRX 272030
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
330 PM EST Mon Nov 27 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...
Surface ridge begins to shift eastward overnight bring a return of
a weak southerly flow. With weak flow, clear sky, and dry air,
believe that a strong nocturnal inversion should keep winds calm
across the lower elevations with light southerly winds across 
higher terrain after midnight as 925-850mb southerly winds 
increase to 10-15 knots. This should keep the higher terrain more 
mixed out for most of the night with coldest temperatures in 
protected valleys and lower elevations by sunrise.

The increased southerly flow and upper ridging will continue to
keep the area under a mostly clear sky and abundant sunshine on
Tuesday with temperatures expected to be about 4-5 degrees warmer
than on Monday. The southerly flow will allow some moisture return
on Tuesday, but it remains dry with max dew points in the 30s and
low RH.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Sunday)...
High pressure near the NC/SC coastline plus a low pressure system
moving across the Great Lakes will equal a strengthening 
southerly low level flow across the region to start the period. A 
warm front and associated isentropic lift will begin to spread 
clouds over our area starting Wednesday, with warm advection 
bringing temps into the lower 60s. 

A mid/upper level closed low is expected to cross the 
area Wednesday night, which will increase lift and the chance of 
rain. Moisture still appears shallow at this time, so will only have 
low to slight PoPs with this feature. Better rain chances arrive on 
Thursday afternoon as forcing with the cold front and upper jet 
moves through, but model agreement with the timing of this is not 
good, the NAM being a slower outlier. Thus, will carry chance PoPs 
into Thursday night. 

Behind the front, slightly cooler temperatures can be expected, but 
highs will still be a little above normal for the weekend. The flow 
through the weekend will be nearly zonal aloft, with surface high 
pressure over the TN/OH Valley regions. On Monday, the surface ridge 
will be east of the Appalachians, while the mid/upper pattern will 
become increasingly amplified with a large ridge over the Southeast. 
The next chance of rain appears to come after the end of this 
forecast package, with the models currently in poor agreement on 
the progression of the ridge.

FXUS64 KMRX 260822
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
322 AM EST Sun Nov 26 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

The cold front is now nearing the Eastern Seaboard as an upper level 
trough passes across the Northeastern U.S. Drier and cooler air is 
moving in behind the front with PW values down into the 0.2-0.3 inch 
range. These values are in the 10th percentile for late November. 
Temperatures across the Southern Appalachians vary a good deal early 
this morning. Where there is some weak mixing, temperatures are in
the 40s with sheltered valley locations in the low to mid 30s. 
When these winds eventually subside, expect temperatures will drop
quickly with most locations in the 30s by daybreak. 

Mostly sunny skies are forecast today with the dry airmass in place. 
The forecast area is in the right exit region of a strong upper 
jet to the north with subsidence aloft. Cold air advection is 
forecast to continue behind the front today. The cold air 
advection is not overly impressive and think the ample supply of 
insolation will be enough to favor the higher side of guidance 
with most locations topping out in the 50s. 

Ideal radiational cooling conditions are forecast tonight as the 
surface high to the west builds across the Southeastern U.S. Light 
winds and clear skies will allow for temperatures to drop down into 
the upper 20s to low 30s with the coldest temperatures forecast for 
those favored sheltered valleys.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)...

Surface high pressure will dominate the area with a ridge 
building in aloft Monday into Tuesday. As a result...the extended 
will begin in a quiet weather pattern with dry and clear 
conditions. Southerly flow developing over the region combined 
with plenty of sunshine will produce good daytime heating. This 
will allow temperatures to warm to near or slightly above seasonal
norms. The area will then transition into a more active pattern. 
Models diverge through the rest of the extended and confidence 
becomes quite low. First...models somewhat on track with a 
weakening frontal boundary coming in from the northwest combined 
with a minor short wave pushing up from the south on Wednesday 
into Thursday. The southerly flow ahead of the system will bring 
in low level moisture but dynamics is minimal and overall should 
see an initial round of showers move in over southern locations on
Wednesday...then a band of light to moderate rainfall moving 
through Wendesday night and Thursday. Temperature profile current 
looks to be warm enough for all rain. Then...models show 
significant differences with the ECMWF slower to exit the system 
while the GFS quickly pushes the system out and quickly brings a 
secondary front into the area Thursday night into Friday. For now 
...will keep isolated to scattered showers in the forecast for 
this period. Cooler temperatures will move in by this time and 
could see a mix of rain and snow over northern areas and along 
higher elevations late Friday night. Dry conditions should return 
for Saturday.

once again. Dry afternoon relative humidity is expected.

.Long term (Sunday night through Saturday)...High pressure will 
remain over the area through Tuesday...with mostly clear skies and 
dry weather expected. Northwest flow that set up over the weekend 
will quickly transition to out of the SW bringing warmer and moist 
air advecting into the area. Temperatures will be several degrees 
below normal Sunday night...quickly warming to near or a degree or 
two above normal for Monday through Wednesday. 

By Thursday...a weak shortwave will move ahead of a frontal boundary 
associated with a deep trough...providing a source of lift to the 
area Thursday morning. Scattered showers are possible by late morning
...increasing in coverage through the day Thursday into Friday 
morning as the frontal boundary moves through the area. PW values 
are around 75th percentile for this time of year...but little to no 
instabilities are present. With winds also chaotic in the low 
levels...would expect light showers...with an isolated shower 
producting several tenths of an inch of rain at once.

night. Nowrthwest flow could keep light showers over the higher

behind this system.

to east during the night keeping minimum temperatures on the
warmer side. Moisture will be limited with this system as ridging
across the Gulf Coast prevents much moisture return from our south
and keeps 850mb-700mb winds from the west ahead of the front.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday)...

period will being with a weakening frontal boundary moving across

system is showing little moisture or lift and expect mainly an 
increase in clouds as it move through. However...across northern 
areas and in the higher elevations where orographics adds to the 
lift...there may be sufficient energy for isolated showers. 
Surface high pressure builds in behind the front....bringing in

weather Sunday through Tuesday. With abundant daytime

should see highs reaching near normal levels Monday and Tuesday. 
By Wednesday and Thursday...models begin to diverge and confidence
lowers. However...models do want to bring another weak frontal 
boundary through during this time frame. Timing and the amount of 
moisture are in question and for now will continue with current 
forecast of 20 to 30 pops for this system.

Virginia.

moisture ahead of the next system which is expected to affect us 
around Wednesday. However, there is high uncertainty with the exact 
timing, strength, and available moisture with this potential midweek 
system because of large differences in how the GFS and ECMWF handle 
the upper-level pattern as well as large spread in the GEFS members. 
Because of the uncertainty, kept PoPs in the slight chance/chance 
range toward the end of the period.

.DISCUSSION...

A cold front is currently moving into the forecast area with an
upper level trough moving across the Great Lakes. PW values ahead
of the boundary are in the 0.6-0.8 inch range,which are slightly
above normal for mid to late November. Model soundings indicate
that the moisture ahead of the boundary is shallow and only 2-3
kft deep. Latest Hi-Res guidance suggests a few sprinkles or light
showers across the higher elevations through midnight or so. For
now, have continued with 20-30 PoPs for the higher elevations.
Cooler and drier air will advect in behind the front ending these
low PoPs late tonight into early Wednesday. Overnight lows will
range from the mid to upper 30s.

AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
319 PM EST Tue Nov 21 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...
Upper level trough continues to swing across the area today with
an approaching weak frontal boundary. With limited moisture,
expecting a mainly dry fropa with just a slight chance for some
drizzle/light showers across the higher terrain through the
overnight hours. Surface high pressure will build in behind the
front, with a dry west-northwest flow aloft. Slightly colder
temperatures are expected for tomorrow with highs topping out from
the mid 40s to mid 50s. Cloud cover will slowly lift throughout 
the day Wednesday, with sunshine expect areawide by the afternoon.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Monday)...Quiet weather 
will be in store for us the rest of the week and through the 
upcoming weekend. Dry air behind the front will lead to clearer 
skies and a slow warm up in temperatures the second half of this 
work week. Secondary front will push through over the weekend and 
bring in another round of colder temperatures. Right now most 
models depict that the front will move through dry, but there is a
chance for a quick shower as it passes through if we get enough 
moisture return ahead of the system. After this system passes 
through we will begin to try and warm up again as we head into 
next week.

546 
FXUS64 KMRX 210807
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
307 AM EST Tue Nov 21 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Thursday night)...
A low level ridge off the NC/SC coast will produce a southerly
flow that will advect higher theta-e air across GA and into the
Appalachians today, while a cold front will advance toward our
area from the NW. Satellite and obs show low clouds spreading N
across GA, nearly to our SW NC counties. Model moisture profiles 
show that it is confined below 850 mb with very dry air above, but
with some isentropic lift from a 30-40 kt wind at 290-295 K, 
drizzle or light rain will be a possibility today, mainly in the 
mountains. NAM QPF amounts over a tenth in SW NC seem rather high 
given the lack of moisture depth, and just a few hundredths of an 
inch seems more realistic. The cold front sweeps through our area
late tonight, which will be a dry fropa for most of the area with
the low level moisture/isentropic lift having pushed east of the 
mountains by that time.

Surface high pressure will build over the region for the rest of 
the short term period, with a dry W to NW flow aloft. A shortwave
trough that crosses the area on Thursday will have too little
moisture with it to affect the sensible weather, other than
perhaps an increase in high/mid clouds. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Monday)... 
Some rather decent weather is in store for the last few days of 
November even though another upper trough and cold front will be 
building across the region over the weekend. The front moves 
through on Saturday but there is no low level inflow of moist air 
off the Gulf due to the presence of a large surface ridge over the
Southeast states. Another amplified ridge pattern fills in behind
the early weekend system for a gradual return to sunshine. The 
sunshine won't be too effective in warming the lower atmosphere 
Sunday and Monday with highs rising only to the 40s both days.

with lows generally expected in the 30s across most valley

disturbance into GA and then the Carolinas. The main affect for
the MRX CWA will be a few bands of clouds moving through...mainly

across extreme southwestern NC with the rest of the area expected
to stay dry. The sunshine and southerly flow will also help
moderate temperatures and afternoon highs on Tuesday should reach
into the mid to upper 50s across lower elevations.

.LONG TERM (Tuesday Night through Monday)...Storm path stays well to 
our north, and our humidity seems low enough that the tail end of 
systems won't be able to generate enough precip to mention through 
the extended period, with the lone exception of Tuesday night in the 
mountains, where 20 percents will be placed. Temperatures won't 
stray too far from normal through the period.

FXUS64 KMRX 200752
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
252 AM EST Mon Nov 20 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Surface high pressure over West/Middle TN this morning will shift
east to the NC Piedmont through the period, while the flow aloft
will shift from a NW flow this morning to a W-SW flow tonight.
Clear and dry conditions will prevail in the NW flow today. Wtih
full sun, highs will be 6-8 degrees above yesterday, generally in
the 50s. Shallow low level moisture may start to increase late 
tonight as the 850 mb flow turns to the SW and warm advection 
picks up, with lows in the 30s expected.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)...
The extended will be characterized by generally dry west to 
northwest flow aloft and persistent surface ridging.

The GFS and ECMWF keep the main storm tracks well north along the 
Canadian/United States border and far southeast United States with 
little to no synoptic forcing over the Tennessee Valley.

For Tuesday, a storm system moving across the Great Lakes will pull 
a frontal boundary souht across the area Tuesday night. Boundary 
layer moisture does get pulled north ahead of this front Tuesday 
producing mostly cloudy sky for TYS/CHA, but limited moisture, so
generally dry frontal passage.

For Wednesday through Friday night, surface ridging and dry 
northwest flow aloft will produce dry conditions and seasonal 
temperatures.

For Saturday, another dry frontal boundary moves across the southern 
Appalachians/Tennessee Valley as Gulf moisture remains well south 
and east of the area. The frontal passage brings chilly and dry 
conditions for Sunday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
320 PM EST Sun Nov 19 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...
Northwest flow remains in place across the area today. This will
continue to shuttle dry, cool air into the area. Cloud cover is
gradually starting to clear across the south and this trend will
continue through this evening into the overnight hours. 

The combination of colder, drier air and clear skies will result
in cold temperatures overnight with lows dropping into the 20s
areawide. Wind chills will dip into the teens in the mountains
overnight. 

Surface high pressure will be in place tomorrow and upper level 
flow becomes more zonal, allowing temperatures to rebound a bit, 
climbing to near 50 across the north and the mid 50s across the 
south. With high pressure in control, clear skies and light winds
are expected.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...
Surface high pressure over the region Monday night and Tuesday 
will allow for continue dry and cool conditions. A weak frontal 
boundary will push through the area late Tuesday into Tuesday 
night. With little moisture in place and minimal moisture or lift 
associated with the system...mainly expect an increase in cloud 
cover. So for now...will keep the forecast dry. High pressure 
builds back in for Wednesday through Friday for continued dry and 
cool conditions. Another weak system moves through during the 
weekend. Confidence quite low in details but models again show 
little moisture or lift attached to the system. At best...expect a
few isolated showers across northern areas and over higher 
terrain. A few flurries may mix in Saturday night.

FXUS64 KMRX 190810
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
310 AM EST Sun Nov 19 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Behind the exiting cold front, a NW flow pattern will be in place
across the area today. Observations across the area this morning
show winds falling below advisory criteria, so the Wind Advisory
will be allowed to expire. Scattered to isolated showers will 
continue for northern sections this morning, with the higher 
elevations seeing some light snow accumulations. With 850 mb cold 
advection and a second 500 mb vort max crossing the area this 
afternoon, cloud cover will be slow to clear today, and will have
high temps a little below MOS guidance. With clearing tonight and
the surface high building into Middle TN, lows will fall into the
20s area wide tonight.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Friday)...
Seasonably cool and dry conditions will dominanate the forecast 
through the extended. Main storm track will be mainly north and 
south of the area with surface ridging from the southern 
Appalachians in the Gulf Coast states.

This surface ridging will not allow deep Gulf moisture to return 
northward into the area through the extended. Even though a frontal 
boundary will move through the region late Tuesday/Tuesday night, 
only effect will be shallow boundary layer moisture producing cloudy 
sky for Tuesday.

Models do show a Gulf of Mexico system pulling northeast across the 
far southeast United States for the latter half of the week, but 
synoptic lift and moisture will stay well south and east of the 
southern Appalachians. 

For next Saturday, another frontal boundary will move across the 
region, but again little to no moisture and dynamics, so dry 
conditions anticipated with frontal passage. However, have included 
a chance of orographic lift producing showers across the mainly the 
higher terrain.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...
Gusty winds out of the south will continue into this evening
before a cold front crosses the area. Rain will overspread the

Precipitation will quickly move out of most of the area after 
midnight as the front continues to march east. The line of storms 
currently moving into west Tennessee looks healthy, but there's 
less instability to work with over our forecast area and the line 
should weaken as it moves through our forecast area this evening. A
few isolated thunderstorms will remain possible, but the main 
threat for our area will be the shifting but continued gusty winds
through the overnight hours. Winds should diminish after sunrise 
Sunday as the cold front moves east of our forecast area. Cooler 
air working in behind the front combined with lingering moisture 
over the eastern mountains will produce some snow showers 
overnight across the higher terrain, but accumulations should top 
out around 1-2 inches. With the strong cold air advection behind
the front, it will be much colder tomorrow, with highs staying in
the 40s across much of the forecast area.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Friday)...
Cool...dry air will continue to push in behind an exiting cold 
front with surface high pressure building in. This will allow for 
a quiet beginning of the extended with dry conditions and slowly 
moderating temperatures Sunday night through Tuesday. Model 
consistency begins to degrade by mid week with a weakening frontal
boundary moving through around the Tuesday night time frame. The 
amount of moisture available and timing remain in question but 
overall trend should allow for a slight chance of showers mainly 
over northern areas and across higher terrain. Will be between 
systems Wednesday through Saturday for a dry and quiet end to the 
extended...however there is a system approaching around the 
Saturday time frame but for now this looks to hold off until later
in the weekend.

FXUS64 KMRX 180805
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
305 AM EST Sat Nov 18 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Clouds will be increasing through the day as isentropic lift
strengthens ahead of the approaching low pressure system, which is
now near the KS/MO border. As it tracks into the Ohio Valley
region this afternoon, S-SW winds at 850 mb will increase to
around 50 kts, creating gusty conditions area-wide. Moisture
remains confined below an inversion around 750 mb today, and only
increases in depth after 00Z in forecast soundings. Once the
inversion erodes, we develop some weak instability that should 
allow for some isolated thunderstorms in the evening. 
Frontogenetic forcing moves through in the 02-07Z time frame, with
strong advection of colder/drier air occurring through the rest 
of the night. A change of precip to snow in higher elevations may 
also occur, enhanced slightly by a 30-35 kt NW flow, but any 
accumulations will be less than one inch through 12Z.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday)...
Upper trough will move quickly east of the area Saturday 
night/Sunday morning with northwest flow aloft. Boundary layer 
moist and cold enough in the morning Sunday to produce a chance of
snow showers/flurries across the west/northwest facing slopes. 

Drier air will advect into the region with snow showers ending and 
clouds dissipating in the afternoon Sunday. A much cooler day is in 
tap for Sunday.

Upper flow pattern quickly de-amplifies flattens for Sunday night 
and Monday with strong surface riding producing mosty sunny 
conditions.

For Tuesday and Wednesday, another strong upper trough moves across 
the Great Lakes with trailing front moving across the Tennessee 
Valley. This frontal boundary will be moisture starved given the 
Gulf moisture will remain south and east due to continued surface 
ridging over the Gulf Coast states.

There is a potential of seeing some orographic showers/snow showers 
over southwest Virginia/northwest Tennessee early Wednesday, but 
confidence too low to mention. Will keep Frontal passage mainly dry 
for now.

For the latter half of the week, models differ in the evolution of a 
Gulf coast system that moves into the southeast United States. At 
this time, plan on following the dry northwest flow aloft ECMWF 
pattern along with surface ridging. Will keep Thanksgiving 
Day and Friday dry.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
257 PM EST Fri Nov 17 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...
Clouds move in tonight and tomorrow morning ahead of an 
approaching cold front. This will keep overnight lows mild, only
dipping into the 40s across the majority of the area. For
Saturday, south-southwest winds ahead of the cold front will
increase throughout the day, producing breezy conditions across
much of the area by the afternoon hours. This fast southerly flow
will also help temperatures warm into the mid 60s Saturday
afternoon before the overnight cold frontal passage. Rainfall
chances will gradually increase across the Plateau Saturday
afternoon/evening, but the majority of the rainfall should hold
off until after nightfall as we transition to the long term period.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)... 
Focus of the long term will be from Saturday night through Sunday
as this is where all the action is, then pretty quiet for the 
rest of the period. 

Cold front is quickly approaching to begin the period with models 
showing the front across middle TN. There will be a well defined 
line of showers moving through the area with perhaps a few embedded 
thunderstorms but soundings still show weak instability. The
biggest threat with this line will be strong and gusty winds due 
to a strong 850 jet screaming through the area. Any heavier 
showers moving through could transport stronger wind gust down to 
the surface but the main source of the winds will be from the 
tight pressure gradient. A wind advisory starts in the short term 
period and carries into the long term period ending 08Z Sunday. It
looks like the highest winds will occur across the higher 
elevations. Models still show the front to our east by midnight 
with much colder air pouring in behind the front. Lingering 
moisture will transition over to snow showers across the highest 
elevations where up to half an inch of snow is still possible. A 
few flurries may be possible across the lower elevations of 
extreme NETN and up into SWVA. Precip generally ends Sunday 
morning as much drier air moves in. Highest elevations could hold 
onto light precip into early Sunday afternoon as upslope flow 
wrings out any remaining moisture. Highs on Sunday will be in the 
lower to upper 40s with calmer winds than Saturday but still 
breezy. With overcast skies through much of the day, cold temps, 
and breezy conditions, wind chill values will range from the upper
30s to low 40s during the afternoon hours with values down into 
the upper teens across the highest peaks, above 5000 feet.

High pressure slowly builds back in on Monday and Tuesday with 
gradual warming temps but another trough and weak front move through 
on Wednesday. Still keeping Wednesday precip free as little moisture 
is present with this system. Thanksgiving and Friday continue to 
look nice as of now with highs in the lower to mid 50s.

FXUS64 KMRX 170858
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
358 AM EST Fri Nov 17 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Surface high pressure will drift from the Ohio Valley this morning 
to the NC coast by tonight, while a 850-700 mb ridge will also be 
crossing our area today. Cloud cover along our northern broder 
should retreat as this ridge progresses east and the flow in that 
layer turns to a SW direction with warm advection in the afternoon. 
Cirrus in advance of the jet stream will be over the area today, 
with highs in the lower to mid 60s expected. Tonight, a 
strengthening SW flow as low pressure tracks into the Great Lakes 
region and its resulting positive theta-e advection/isentropic lift 
should bring increasing cloud cover, but moisture depth and lift 
will not be adequate for precip yet. Higher elevations could be 
breezy tonight as the LLJ increases to around 40 kts, but the 
SW direction of flow does not favor a mountain wave event.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday)...

At the beginning of this period, we will be in a fast WSW flow 
aloft, that will be in the process of backing, as an upper trough 
and frontal system approach the area.  At the surface, as mentioned 
a front will be to our west, ridging in the Carolinas, and a return 
flow intensifying over us.  The front is expected to move quickly 
through our area generally Saturday evening.  

The weather from Saturday through Saturday night will be quite 
active with increasing winds Saturday and into Saturday evening 
ahead and behind the front.  The angle of the winds is not set up 
for a classic mountain wave pattern, but the winds are favorable for 
stronger winds up the valley, even flirting with advisory criteria 
for parts of the valley.

Showers and possible embedded storms will bring even faster winds 
from aloft, down to the surface, as the precip moves in from the 
west late Saturday afternoon and into the evening. Late Saturday 
night as the colder air moves in the rain showers will be changing 
over to snow showers in the higher mountains, and lingering into 
Sunday morning.  

Sunday will be much colder, and with an inversion above the cold 
air, moisture will likely be trapped making for stubborn 
stratocumulus clouds for a good part of the day, especially in upper 
east TN and SW VA.  This will help prevent the temps from rising 
much on Sunday as well, so went a few degrees below guidance at most 
locations.  

For the rest of the forecast, it turns very quiet overall, with 
temperatures rebounding as we get into the work week.

FXUS64 KMRX 162030

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
330 PM EST Thu Nov 16 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...
Ridging and surface high pressure building in from the north will
maintain fair skies and dry conditions across the area through
Friday. Winds will be a little gusty in the mountains this 
evening, but should stay well below advisory criteria. Under clear
skies, lows tonight will dip to near freezing areawide. With 
sunny skies Friday, temperatures will warm into the lower 60s.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Wednesday)...
The start of the long term will be quite active but after our 
system passes through there is not much to talk about. The main 
focus of the forecast will be from Friday night through Sunday.

Southerly flow rapidly increasing across the area on Friday night 
out ahead of a strong cold front located back across the Great 
Plains. On Saturday the 850 jet is quite strong across the area with 
values from 50 to 55 knots. Southerly flow will allow some moisture 
to be transported north into our area by moreso the warmer air. 
Highs on Saturday will be in the mid to upper 60s. The strong 850 
jet will allow for gusty winds areawide. The higher elevations will 
likely need a wind advisory as we get closer to the event. Rain 
chances increase from west to east as we go through the day as the 
front draws closer. By late afternoon chances really begin to ramp 
up as a strong 300 mb jet core spreads across the region just out 
ahead of the front. Models in decent agreement on timing but there 
is still some minor disagreement. The earliest that the line would 
arrive would be around 6 PM and the latest it would arrive would be 
around 9 PM. So somewhere between 6 and 9 is when we expect the 
heaviest showers to move into the area. This line will be moving 
pretty quickly so the heaviest showers should only last for 3 or 4 
hours. The actual front should be to our east by midnight. Soundings 
show very little instability but enough present that there could be 
a few embedded thunderstorms within the line but mainly expecting a 
rain event. Looks like most places will see around half an inch of 
rainfall. 

Cold air quickly ushers in behind the front and temps will drop 
fast. The higher elevations could see a few snow showers as moisture 
lingers just behind the front. The highest peaks could see up to 
half an inch of snow, above 4000 to 5000 feet. Light snow showers 
linger across the higher elevations into early Sunday morning as NW 
flow helps to squeeze out any remaining moisture. Highs on Sunday 
will be around 20 degrees colder compared to Saturday, with highs 
only in the mid to upper 40s. Sunday night will be quite cold with 
lows in the mid to upper 20s. High pressure gradually builds back in 
on Monday and Tuesday with temps slowly moderating. Then another 
trough moves through mid-week but it looks moisture starved so no 
POPs in place for now. The trough brings another round of cold air 
just in time for Thanksgiving.

FXUS64 KMRX 160757

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
257 AM EST Thu Nov 16 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Weak cold front sliding through area this morning.  Water Vapor loop 
shows strong, deep subsidence over the area.  The combination of 
drier air in the lower layers and subsidence from above are expected 
to erode stratocumulus layer by mid morning.  Temperatures won't be 
cooling much behind this cold front--some locations will be warmer 
today than yesterday.  Winds will be a little gusty in the 
mountains, this afternoon and evening, but should stay well below 
advisory criteria.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...
With temperatures continuing to warm behind the front we should see 
highs right around normal for this time of year on Friday, and then 
a few degrees warmer on Saturday. A cold front will then sweep in 
from the west Saturday night into Sunday morning. With the front 
moving through pretty quickly we won't see much in the way of 
moisture return ahead of the front, so most of the precipitation 
over our area will come as the front is moving through in the 
overnight hours. Most places should see rain as the front passes 
through, but since it moves through pretty quickly models are 
indicating that most places see less than an inch of rainfall. As 
the front is exiting there could be enough moisture lingering around 
early Sunday morning for some of the rain to briefly switch over to 
snow in the higher elevations, but widespread accumulations are not 
anticipated at this time.

Temperatures will only be able to warm up into the 40's for most 
locations on Sunday and overnight lows will drop down into the 20's. 
Ridging begins to build in as we start the new work week and we 
experience a warming trend for a couple of days. At this point long 
range models begin to diverge with how to handle the next system 
that's supposed to roll through the east half of the United States. 
All models show a trough of some sort moving through, but there 
could be a stronger low moving across the Gulf Coast states or a 
stronger low staying well to our north near the Great Lakes keeping 
the moisture out of our area. And to throw another wrench into 
things the Canadian model is showing a low moving right over us and 
brining in widespread precipitation during the middle of next week. 
Will go ahead and keep out precipitation chances for now since the 
more consistent models keep our area dry, but early next week will 
be a time to keep an eye on the weather as models may likely change 
their tune over the next few runs.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...
Weak cold front will sweep across the forecast area tonight. There 
won't be a ton of moisture left with this boundary, but ceilings 
will be low and overcast. Areas across the Cumberland Plateau and 
far NE TN/SW VA have the best chance of seeing some scattered 
showers the evening into early tonight. A shower can't be ruled out 
farther south, but they will be much more hit or miss. Overcast 
skies will help keep lows fairly mild -- bottoming out in the 40s at 
most locations. Front will be clear of the area by dawn Thursday, 
and drier air from the northwest will funnel in behind it. This will 
help skies clear fairly quickly after sunrise and plentiful sunshine 
through the afternoon hours will allow temperatures to warm into the 
50s and even the lower 60s in southern portions of the Tennessee 
Valley.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...A dry Friday 
gives way to a return to more active weather on Saturday as a 
relatively strong upper trough shifts east from the Plains States 
to the Eastern Seaboard by Sunday. A strong cold front will move 
through the forecast area Saturday night bringing a pattern of 
scattered showers mainly during the afternoon hours Saturday with 
a better likelihood of rain area wide by evening. The system moves
quickly east with temperatures turning sharply colder behind the 
front. There may even be a snow flurry in the fading back edge of 
the precipitation shield across higher terrain areas across the 
northern half of the viewing area after midnight. Typically, 
clouds may end up being slow to clear on Sunday and it will feel a
little more like Winter with highs mainly in the 40s. The large 
cold surface high left in the wake of the early weekend system, 
will shift slowly east into the beginning of the work week as the 
upper flow becomes more zonal in configuration. The resulting 
sunshine in the fair weather pattern should help max temperatures 
rebound back into the 50s by Tuesday. The gfs and ecmwf not 
entirely on the same page at the end of the long term period, but 
it appears that a northern stream trough drives east across the 
Great Lakes and Northeastern U.S. Tuesday into Wednesday. Degree 
of forecast uncertainty quite high for this late period. Will 
await better model resolution in future runs to more accurately 
determine how this will play out.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Surface ridge will be sliding east, allowing return flow to start 
up, increasing the low level moisture.  A cold front currently over 
the Plains will be making its way toward the area. Showers will be 
developing ahead of the front and are expected to move into the 
western areas this afternoon and continue tracking across the rest 
of the area tonight, but probably not extending all the way to the
southern tier. The front will be moving through after midnight, 
however most of the showers will be moving through prior to 
midnight as they propagate along with the lift ahead of an upper 
short wave. Much of the area should get good amounts of sunshine 
today, although clouds will be increasing from the west during the
afternoon as the lift moves into the area. Temperatures tonight 
should be milder, with a little breeze keeping the lower levels 
mixed, warm- air advection ahead of the front, as well as a layer 
of stratocumulus for much of the night that limits radiational 
cooling.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...
Front will be east of the area shortly after sunrise on Thursday,
and colder air form the northwest will funnel in behind it. While
colder air will be moving in the skies will also be clearing out 
and allowing the sun to shine through and we should actually warm 
up into the 60's across most of the Tennessee Valley on Thursday. 
Clear skies will continue Thursday night and temperatures will 
drop into the 30's across the area with many places north of 
Interstate 40 (and those in the higher elevations) expected to get
below freezing. Ridging begins to build in at the end of the week
and temperatures will continue to warm ahead of an approaching 
cold front slated to move through Saturday into early Sunday. 

GFS is still slightly faster with the frontal passage than the 
ECMWF, but the latest run of the ECMWF has speed up a bit as well. 
Will continue to bump up precipitation chances as all models depict 
this front bringing rain, but just haven't decided on the exact 
timings of when it will begin/end. All models have the front and 
precipitation out of the area by late Sunday morning. Depending on 
the exact timing of the front we could see a brief switch over to 
some light snow flurries in the higher elevations early Sunday 
morning, but widespread snowfall is not expected and the few 
isolated places that do see snow most likely will not see any 
significant accumulations. Temperatures behind the front will be 
about 10-15 degrees colder to end the weekend, and pretty much every 
location in the forecast area should see sub freezing temperatures 
overnight Sunday. Slight ridging will build in behind the front and 
a warming trend will begin to end this 7-day forecast.

leading to mostly sunny skies by the afternoon. This will allow 
temperatures to warm up to temperatures similar to what we saw 
yesterday, and maybe even a few degrees warmer in SW Virginia. 

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday)... 
At the beginning of this period, the U.S. is in an almost zonal flow 
with only a subtle couple of waves embedded in this fast flow.  At 
the surface, the ridge is now east of us and a return flow has just 
begun.  Also a cold front is located from a Low over Lake Superior, 
southwest across OK, and continuing into SW TX.  This front will be 
moving quickly eastward, and should push through the area Wednesday 
night.  There will be very little instability as the front moves 
through, so will only go with "showers" for the precip associated 
with the front for Wednesday afternoon and Wednesday night.

High pressure will settle into the area Thursday, the next return 
flow on Friday, and the next cold front on Saturday.  This front is 
followed by stronger high pressure that takes a couple of days to 
settle into the area.  Similarly, as with the system for Wednesday 
night, the precip with this front will be mostly stable, so just 
going with showers. Also, looking at the timing of the cold air and 
precip, it looks like the moisture will be exiting the area pretty 
quickly, so only including flurries in and near the mountains for 
late Saturday night, then just dry on Sunday and into Monday.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Some light reflectivities are moving across NE Tennessee and
SW Virginia overnight associated with the trough moving across our

most of the rain should be out of the forecast area shortly after
sunrise. Northerly flow behind the front moving through will
funnel in colder air behind it... But with the dry air after this
front the skies should be able to clear out today and allow for
the sun to shine. This should help offset the colder air moving 
in and result in temperatures pretty similar to what we saw 
yesterday under overcast conditions. However the clear skies and 
colder air will allow temperatures overnight tonight to drop about
10 degrees colder than this morning with many places expected to 
see lows in the 30's.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday)...
Predominate zonal flow aloft through Friday before a digging trough 
moves across the area over the weekend. 

On Tuesday, a shortwave trough pushes across the northern third of 
the area bringing only a slight increase in cloudiness over that 
area for the early part of the day. As that shortwave shifts east by 
Tuesday night, weak ridging persists through Wednesday before 
flattening out as next shortwave pushes east across the Great Lakes 
late Wednesday and Wednesday night. With it, expect chance POPs over 
the northern half of the area, mainly during the overnight hours.

To this point in the forecast, confidence is good with model 
agreement on timing associated with this first boundary on Wednesday 
night. Unfortunately, confidence decreases from this point forward 
as models diverge greatly with the next system for the early part of 
the weekend.

GFS being most progressive, pushes the front through by Saturday 
afternoon while the ECMWF is slowest with frontal boundary not 
moving through until Saturday evening. Without a strong consensus, 
have opted to maintain chance POPs through Saturday at this time. 
However, regardless of frontal timing, expect a strong low-level jet 
out ahead of the front to create windy conditions across much of the 
area on Saturday, with higher elevations being especially 
susceptible Saturday afternoon. Although tstms are possible with 
this front, uncertainty of timing and resulting available 
instability remain convincing enough to carry only showers in the 
fcst for Saturday.

Temperatures should remain near climatological norms through 
Saturday before seeing a significant cool down on Sunday as the 
upper level trough shifts east and the cold, dry air funnels SE into 
the area bringing daytime high temperatures about 10 degrees below 
normal by the end of the period.

FXUS64 KMRX 121954
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
254 PM EST Sun Nov 12 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...

Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicate a 
shortwave trough across the Western Great Lakes moving into the Ohio 
River Valley. At the surface, a cold front stretches from Southern 
Indiana back to the southwest into Eastern Texas. The area of low 
level isentropic ascent is now to the south and east of the area 
with scattered showers across Georgia and South Carolina. Therefore, 
have decreased PoPs down in the near-term forecast. 

PW values will increase ahead of the cold front into the 0.8-0.9 
inch range later tonight, which are around the 75th percentile for 
mid-November. Model soundings indicate that the saturated layer is 
shallow from around 950-750 mb at best. Due to this, expect any 
precipitation that does occur will be light with only a few 
hundredths of an inch at most. The deepest saturation will be across 
SW Virginia and NE Tennesse and this is where the highest PoPs are 
featured. With this low level saturation, there could also be 
some patchy fog late tonight into early Monday morning. Overnight 
lows will range from the upper 30s to mid 40s. 

Much drier air will push in behind the boundary on Monday with PW 
values down into the 0.2-0.3 inch range, which are around the 10th 
percentile for mid-November. Despite the mostly sunny skies, 
northerly winds will advect in cooler air and high temperatures will 
generally be in the 50s for most valley locations.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Saturday)...

A zonal flow pattern with surface ridging into the southern 
Appalachians for Monday night through mid-week. Only caveat will 
be a weak frontal boundary with little upper forcing moving south 
into the region for Wednesday night. This boundary will producing 
a chance of showers for mid- week.

A very strong upper level storm system will be moving into the 
Pacific Northwest for mid-week. The associated strong upper level 
jet will move out into the Plain States by Thursday. Strong surface 
cyclo-genesis will develop over the Plain States for Friday. There 
are significant timing differences with this system as the GFS is 
faster/a little weaker, while the ECMWF is slower and stronger 
with the associated cyclo-genesis. 

As the cyclogenesis strengthens for the latter half of the week, the 
developing low level jet will increase the isentropic lift across 
the Tennessee/Ohio Valleys by Thursday night and Friday. Strong 
southerly boundary layer jet will pull moist and unstable air 
northward into the Ohio/Tennessee Valleys. 

As the frontal boundary moves across the area either late Friday 
night or Saturday, widespread showers are anticipated with elevated 
thunderstorms possible..per model soundings. Due to the uncertainty 
of how much instability and timing of frontal passage, will only 
include showers, but need to monitor the potential of storms.

Beside the convection, the strong low-level jet will likely produce 
windy conditions, especially across the higher elevations as the 
storm nears.

Front moves east of the area Saturday with drier and cooler weather 
returning.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...

A rather quiet pattern across the entire CONUS with mostly zonal 
flow aloft with a couple of low amplitude shortwave troughs to the 
north and west. At the surface, high pressure is currently located 
across the Northeastern U.S. Closer to home, skies are mostly to 
partly sunny this afternoon with a few passing high clouds. 

For this evening and overnight, the surface high will continue to 
shift further to the east with low level southeasterly flow slowly 
returning to the region. An area of low level isentropic ascent will 
lift northward across the area tonight with increasing cloud cover. 
Can already see this area of lift and cloud cover showing up on 
visible satellite imagery with widespread cloud cover across South 
and Central Georgia. This area of cloud cover is building to the 
north and will see overcast skies moving into the southern tier of 
counties near to shortly after sunset. With this increased cloud 
cover, expect overnight lows will be warmer than the last couple of 
nights with lows ranging from the low 30s across SW Virginia and NE 
Tennessee to low 40s across the Southern Valley. Light showers and 
sprinkles will be possible as the area of isentropic ascent lifts 
northward across the area. The NAM is the most aggressive with 
precipitation but it does appear most models have increased the 
amount of moisture slightly. Due to this, increased PoPs overnight 
tonight into Sunday morning with best chances across SW North 
Carolina and SE Tennessee. With widespread cloud cover and light 
precipitation throughout the first half off the day, went with 
cooler daytime temperatures with highs in the mid 40s to low 50s. 

The area of isentropic lift will push off to the east later in the 
day on Sunday as an upper level trough and weak cold front approach 
from the northwest. PW values will max out ahead of this boundary 
around 0.6-0.8 inches, these values are slightly above normal for 
mid-November. Model soundings during this time period feature rather 
shallow saturation from around 950-750 mb with the deepest moisture 
to the north. For now, have gone with 20-50 PoP for Sunday night 
into Monday morning with best chances north of Interstate 40. With 
the widespread cloud cover and scattered precipitation went with 
warmer lows with temperatures generally in the 40s Sunday night. 
Northerly winds behind the frontal boundary on Monday will advect in 
drier air into the region. Precipitation chances will come to an end 
with mostly sunny skies by the afternoon. High temperatures will 
range from the low 50s to the low 60s. Any precipitation during the 
short-term period will be light and do not anticipate any more than 
a few hundredths at the most.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Friday)... 

The upper flow pattern will be dominated by fast zonal flow, 
except for the latter half of the week into Saturday.

For Monday night through Tuesday...surface ridging and zonal flow 
will produce dry conditions and generally slightly above normal 
temperatures.

For Wednesday and Wednesday night...fast moving jet/short-wave 
across the Ohio Valley will enhance the isentropic lift across the 
region with chance/likely rain showers. For Thursday...associated 
frontal boundary will becoming near stationary across the Tennessee 
valley with a low chance of showers.

For Thursday night through Friday night...a stronger upper jet will 
move into the Plain states to the Great Lakes/Ohio and northern 
Tennessee valleys. This stronger system will pull a frontal boundary 
through the area for late Friday and Friday night. Likely chances of 
showers are expected. At this time, instability is lacking so will 
keep thunder out of the forecast. Dry and cooler conditions return 
for Saturday.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...
A sunny day today with clear skies and temperatures in the mid 40s
to upper 50s. Cold high pressure at the surface was centered over
the Great Lakes with almost zonal flow across the country. This 
will keep the eastern Tennessee Valley Cool and dry through 
Sunday. The biggest effect from this system is cold temperatures 
tonight across the forecast area with lows in the 20s for the 
northeast half of the region. The coldest night there so far this 
season. The warmest area will be the southwest third of the region
where temperatures will be closer to freezing or just above. 
Saturday will be similar today with abundant sunshine and highs 
mostly in the 50s. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Thursday)...
Low level isentropic lift will increase from the southeast to 
northeast late Saturday night into Sunday morning. Model soundings
indicate a shallow saturated layer from around 950 mb to 800 mb. 
For most locations, just forecasting overcast cloud cover but 
there could be a few light showers/sprinkles in portions of SW 
North Carolina and SE Tennessee. Warm air advection will keep all 
of this precipitation in the liquid form with overnight lows 
generally in the 30s. 

The area of isentropic lift will weaken and push off to the 
northeast during the day Sunday but expect mostly cloud skies will 
persist. A weak cold front in association with an upper level trough 
will approach the area late in the day on Sunday. Moisture will 
remain limited with PW values peaking around 0.6-0.8 inches, which 
are slightly above normal for mid-November. Model soundings are once 
again not overly impressive with a shallow moist layer. Have 
continued with 20-30 PoPs across the area late Sunday into early 
Monday with best chances across NE Tennessee and SW Virginia. 
Precipitation amounts will be light and should be just a couple of 
hundredths. 

Monday and Tuesday will be dry with the upper level trough departing 
to the east and higher pressure building in across the region aloft 
and at the surface. Forecast highs will be near to slightly below 
average for this time of the year with highs in the mid 50 to low 
60s and lows in the mid 30s to low 40s. 

The global models begin to diverge moving into the middle part of 
next week. The GFS indicates a progressive pattern with the next 
frontal passage late Wednesday into early Thursday. The ECMWF has a 
weaker upper level trough associated with this cold front and stalls 
the boundary to the north. Regardless of model solution, 
precipitation chances will increase during the middle and later 
parts of next week. In addition, any instability with both of these 
solutions will stay well to the south and not forecasting any 
thunderstorms at this point.

672 
FXUS64 KMRX 060832
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
332 AM EST Mon Nov 6 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...A fairly active next 36-48
hours with a series of jets/short-waves moving across the
Ohio/Tennessee Valleys focusing lift along/near a frontal
boundary. Front is currently moving into northern middle Tennessee
with a band of showers and isolated thunder. This activity will
move into the region early this morning with the greatest coverage
of convection between 12-16Z. The forcing associated with the
first jet and divergence aloft will move east of the southern
Appalachians by noon. 

Plenty of low-clouds will remain across the Tennessee
Valley/southern Appalachians this afternoon and overnight with
boundary layer becoming saturated for fog development tonight.

Another jet streak will move the Ohio/Tennessee Valleys late
tonight enhancing fronto-genetic lift across the boundary. Models
show enough instability (mostly elevated) to produce a chance of
thunderstorms with widespread showers. PWs increase to the 90
percentile or higher overnight with some training possible along
the frontal boundary to produce locally heavy rainfall. Will
include this potential within the HWO.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday)...
At the beginning of this period we will still be in a zonal flow 
aloft, while at the surface we will likely have a stalled front in 
our area, generally oriented west to east. During the day a weak 
surface low pressure center is expected to track along the front to 
the northeast and will be close to or in our area.  At first glance 
pattern recognition might suggest some severe weather threat with 
this setup, however, it looks like instability will be very limited 
(<500J/kg) , so unless something changes, it looks like mostly 
showers, with just a few embedded storms with only moderate outflow 
winds. For Thunder chances will forecast a NW to SE gradient--will 
not include thunder for on the northern Plateau and parts of SW VA, 
will have a slight chance of thunder for the central plateau to near 
Abingdon, VA, and a chance of thunder generally along and SE a 
Chattanooga to Knoxville to Bristol line. For heavy rain chances, 
the precipitable water values will still be high, but storms will be 
zipping eastward very quickly.  The only chances for problems with 
flooding would be where training occurs.  Short-range convective 
models suggest some broad clusters that show a hint of training 
Tuesday morning, but these move quickly out of the area by Tuesday 
afternoon. So, two things to watch for that would elevate a threat 
for Tuesday--#1 a little more instability (500-1000 J/kg CAPE) that 
could tap the existing shear to produce more organized convection, 
and #2 more defined and organized W-E band of training cells that 
could offer significant rains Tuesday morning. Neither of these is 
being forecast right now.

Tuesday evening the bulk of the precip should exit the area to the 
east, however, chances for light precip will linger as the front and 
moisture linger in the area waiting on an upper level clipper that 
moves into the area around Wednesday night or Thursday. Then by 
Friday things dry out. Finally, around Sunday another clipper along 
with a cold front will sweep through, likely with a line of showers 
that sweeps through as well. Timing is still iffy, so there are POPs 
from Sat night through Sun night. 

The precip on Wed and Thu will be in a cool airmass, but right now 
it looks like even the mountains will not be cold enough for wintery 
precip.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...

A cold front currently stretches from near Chicago to the south to

Upper level flow is mostly zonal but there a is a shortwave trough
currently moving across the Central Plains with a strong 100-120
kt 300mb jet associated with this trough. Due to this, strong to
severe storms are forecast today across the Ohio River and Mid-
Mississippi River Valley. Closer to home, temperatures and
dewpoints are elevated for early November with southwesterly flow
in the low levels continuing the supply of warm/moist advection
ahead of the approaching cold front. With this trough passing well
to the north, not forecasting any precipitation this afternoon or
evening. The cold front will advance to the southeast throughout
the short-term forecast period. The front will take on more of a
southwest to northeast orientation as the trough to the north
advances quicker with the support of the upper levels. A weakening
line of showers and storms will move into the Plateau after
midnight. Instabilty across the forecast area will be limited with
the more aggressive models only indicating values of SBCAPE around
250-500 J/Kg. Due to this, did mention thunderstorms in the
forecast but do not expect any strong or severe storms. The cold
front will continue to advance across the forecast area on Monday.
PW values will increase into the 1.3-1.6 inch range ahead of the
front, which are near the maximum values observed for early
November. Due to this, increase PoPs for late tonight into Monday
into the 60-90 percent range. Temperatures overnight will be mild
again with lows in the upper 50 to mid 60s and went closer to the
raw model guidance. The front will sweep across the forecast area
tomorrow and could see precip. chances decrease from the northwest
to southeast late tomorrow with highs in the upper 60s to mid 70s
for most locations.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Saturday)...
Near zonal flow aloft at the start of the forecast period. At the
surface a frontal boundary will stall and perhaps lift north of 
the forecast area. As it weakens early Monday night...shower 
activity will wane before midnight and pick back up a few hours 
after midnight, especially over the southern Tennessee Valley. In 
fact, showers and thunderstorms will become more frequent by early
morning. 

The front will slowly ooze southward on Tuesday with showers and 
thunderstorms likely through much of the day. With the front south 
of the forecast area Tuesday night it appears that most locations 
with the exception of the mountains will be mostly dry or have 
mainly light rain. Light rain chances persist into Wednesday. The 
total QPF for this system from Monday through Wednesday looks like 
it will range anywhere from near one inch to one and three quarter 
inches. 

Wednesday night the surface front is south of the area however the 
850 front will still be over the southern portions of the CWA. An 
approaching shortwave trough combined with moisture advection along 
the boundary will bring more showers across the region early 
Wednesday night. Rain chances come to an end by Thursday afternoon 
in the wake of the shortwave trough. Dry conditions persist through 
Saturday before another clipper system dives southward out of 
Minnesota. More rain showers will be possible Sunday afternoon and 
Sunday night.

temperatures will suppress convection for this afternoon and

day across the Region.
