area early Monday morning, mainly after 12Z. Will include chance
of showers over mainly the Plateu and far western southwest
Virginia late in the period.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)...At the beginning of this 
period the upper flow will be zonal across almost the whole U.S. at 
our latitude. At the surface our warm air mass will still be in 
place, but a cold front will be closing in on our area from the 
northwest.  During the day Monday the front is expected to settle 
into the area and stall.  By Tuesday a surface Low will be moving up 
the front from the southwest and depending on the path and strength 
of the low, the front may surge northward again.  Then by Tuesday 
evening, once the Low gets far enough north and east, the cyclonic 
flow will send the frontal boundary surging southward again, this 
time moving southward, quickly into Georgia.  The busy pattern 
continues as the zonal flow ends as an upper level clipper system 
comes sweeping through the area Wednesday night, spreading light 
precip northward across the area.  The surface cool airmass will 
still be in place, but it looks like this airmass will not be cold 
enough for wintry precip.  After this clipper passes, by Friday and 
into Saturday, the pattern flattens out again into a zonal flow, 
with maybe some slight ridging over the area.  

Focusing back on the storm threats for Monday through Tuesday--the 
northern plateau may have some storms early Monday as the left-over 
storms from the Midwest roll in.  Then during the day Monday, the 
cold front will be moving through and there should be some storms 
develop along the front, however, it doesn't look like there will be 
much instability ahead of the front on Monday. On Tuesday as the 
front surges northward, it still looks like instability will be very 
limited, resulting in storms with little to no hail and localized 
storms with gusts to maybe 40 mph.  Over the two-day period, some 
locations will likely get over an inch of rain, but it should be 
spread out enough to limit the flooding potential.  As we keep an 
eye on this, the heaviest rains will likely be between midnight 
Monday night through the day on Tuesday.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
332 AM EDT Fri Nov 3 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Pattern continues to shift to the east, putting us closer and closer 
to deeper moisture and lift. Convection currently over the Ohio 
Valley is expected to head this way, but without as complete of 
coverage. 850 mb winds feeding the Ohio Valley convection now will 
be weakening and veering as the convection approaches, so feed of 
moisture will be less here.  However, regardless of this lack of 
organization, there will be some surface based instability this 
afternoon as well as some outflow boundaries moving in that will 
favor localized new convection. Best instability (CAPE) will be 
west 500-1000 J/kg, while most of the northern valley will be <500
J/kg--really struggling for more than showers. Also, the best 
chances of outflow boundaries surviving will be in the western 
areas, as the convection first moves into the area later today. 
Temperatures this afternoon will likely be muted/slightly cooler 
due to increased cloud cover.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday)...Fast zonal flow will 
dominate the pattern across much of the nation with a series of 
weak short-waves moving across the Ohio/Tennessee Valleys through 
early/mid week next week.

Upper troughs will move across southern Canada/northern United 
States bringing a frontal boundary into the Ohio/Tennessee Valleys. 
Given the west to east upper flow this boundary will not pull 
quickly south across the Tennessee Valley, but instead meander 
across the lower Ohio and Tennessee Valley Saturday through 
Tuesday. 

Airmass over the region will be moisture and marginally unstable 
allowing frontal boundary to produce periods of scattered showers 
and thunderstorms. Greatest coverage will be Saturday and late 
Monday through Wednesday. Least chance will be Sunday and Monday as 
warmer mid-level temperatures will limit instability.

For mid-week next week, a more amplified pattern will pull frontal 
boundary south of the area with cooler temperatures.

as some weak short wave energy moves across as it shears out. 
Moisture will increase, but best moisture and lift will stay to our 
west and north. Best chance for any showers looks to be plateau and 
southwest VA counties, so will carry low PoPs there late tonight 
into Wednesday.  Will keep things dry elsewhere for now.  Will make 
some minor adjustments to MAV temps, mainly to go a bit lower for 
some Min temps tonight. 

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...High pressure over 
the SE coast will slowly move to the east through the work week. Low 
level flow will shift to out of the southeast...increasing moisture 
and warm air advection to the area. Thursday and 
Friday...temperatures will be near or a degree or two above 
normal...while several shortwaves are expected to bring scattered 
showers and thunderstorms to the area both days. PW values increase 
to around 1 by Friday afternoon...though little instability is 
present either day. Wind shear is weak...with less than 30 kts 
expected through the low and mid levels. Any showers will be slow 
moving...with only a small threat to localized ponding on roadways 
possible in areas that recieve several showers through the day.

The high pressure shifts east...allowing the remaining showers to 
move east by Saturday morning. By Saturday afternoon...diurnal 
showers and thunderstorms are possible with around 1300 to 1800 J/kg 
instabilty remaining. Upper level flow will remain fairly 
zonal...with little relief in the warming temperatures expected. 
Sunday...high pressure and mostly clear skies are expected through 
the day. A low pressure system moving across the Great Lakes and 
associated frontal boundary will move across the Ohio Valley Monday 
afternoon through Tuesday...with scattered showers possible through 
this time.

eastern sections but clouds were absent and winds were light.
Higher pressure will build southeast from the Plains into the Ohio
and Tennessee Valleys today. Highs will be similar to Monday in
the upper 50s to lower 60s. Tonight clouds increase as front moves
back north as a warm front. A few showers may move into plateau 
area before morning otherwise another seasonally cool night a few
degrees warmer than this morning.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Monday)...
Zonal flow aloft and surface ridging into the southeast United 
States will be the main story through the extended. The zonal flow
will allow temperatures to moderate to above normal by mid to 
late week, and pull a good deal of mainly mid and high level 
clouds into the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians.

Persistent surface ridging across the far southeast United States 
will keep moisture limited. The deepest moisture seems to be 
Saturday with PWs increasing to 1.25 inch. Best southwest flow 
moisture fetch and isentropic lift will be across the lower 
Mississippi and western Tennessee Valley regions. Will call for low 
chances PoPs through Saturday (best over the Plateau). Enough 
instability Saturday to include slight thunder chances along and 
south of interstate 40.

Upper ridging strengthening over the southern Appalachians Sunday 
and Monday with a mid-level inversion developing. This inversion 
will suppress convection development producing unseasonably warm and 
dry conditions.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Northwest flow affects across the forecast area are ending early
this morning. Low clouds across the northeast area is eroding
quickly with mostly clear skies now across all but southwest
Virginia and extreme northeast Tennessee. Deep surface low over
New York and associated upper low over Pennsylvania with wrap
around low clouds was finally shifting northeast. Temperatures
have dropped into the mid 20s plateau and higher elevations to
lower to mid 30s elsewhere. Weak high pressure builds in today
with much warmer temperatures and winds shifting to the south and
southwest. A rapid warmup from below freezing to the 50s to lower
60s. A weak front will move quickly southeast into the Ohio and
Tennessee Valleys today and through the eastern Tennessee Valley
tonight. Some increase in clouds will occur tonight but air mass
will be too dry for any precipitation. Temperatures tonight will
not be as cold mid 30s to lower 40s.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday)...
No breaking news here, extended period still looks unchanged 
which will disappoint many due to the dreary forecast in store for
much of the week. The good news is that we will see a warming 
trend with 70s right around the corner!

On Tuesday the weak frontal boundary is just to our south. Cold air 
behind this front isn't strong so temps on Tuesday remain unchanged 
to those we see Monday. Tuesday night lows will be in the upper 30s 
to low 40s. On Wednesday we start to see clouds and precip chances 
increase as high pressure to our east and a shortwave back to our 
west work together like two cogs to pump in moisture from the 
southwest. Moisture moving in, an active jet, old frontal 
boundary/new warm front, lift back north and allow for the 
aforementioned rain chances. Warm front rapidly moves north 
Wednesday night into Thursday as southerly flow picks up steam. 
Thursday through Friday we are entrenched within the warm sector 
with lingering moisture. This setup doesn't scream high POPS due to 
lack of forcing but will have slight chance and chance POPs in place 
nonetheless due to weak isentropic lift pattern in place. Any precip 
that occurs will be very light. Temps on Thursday and Friday will be 
in the upper 60s and to near 70. 

On Saturday we see a weak shortwave zip across the area from out 
west. This feature will generate additional lift and provide a 
better chance for showers and possible a few storms compared to the 
previous setup. Chances for precip will carry over into Sunday as 
the system exits but with much lower chances than Saturday. Highs on 
over the weekend will be right around 70 with lows ranging from the 
lower 50s to upper 50s.

areawide with a widespread freeze likely late tonight and Monday
morning.

exits to the northeast and zonal flow sets up. Surface winds will
shift to the southwest ahead of another front that drops south
through the Ohio Valley and toward our region on Monday. However, moisture
is limited so do not anticipate more than potentially some 
increasing clouds late Monday.


.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Saturday)...
The extended scenario hasn't changed too much in the last twenty 
four hours. A frontal boundary will still drop south into the 
region and hang around for a couple days at mid week with an 
initial short wave building into the area for Wednesday into 
Thursday time frame. Chance probabilities for some rain showers 
should cover this part of the forecast. Another wave and cold 
frontal boundary will slip south toward the Southern Appalachian 
region Friday into Saturday bringing another chance for a few 
showers to the forecast area. However, probabilities may be on the
decrease Saturday night into Sunday as a more amplified upper 
trough and surface frontal system build into the Central U.S. The 
strengthening southerly component to the low level flow will push 
the mid week frontal boundary well to the north of the region 
allowing for the decreasing chance for rain. The most pleasant 
warming trend is still in the works during the extended. The first
couple days of the forecast period on Tuesday and Wednesday will 
be around 60 degrees for high temperatures but with the return to 
a southerly wind direction for the latter part of the forecast, 
highs may rebound to the upper 60s and lower 70s.

FXUS64 KMRX 290826
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
426 AM EDT Sun Oct 29 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Steady precipitation has ended across the region tonight but bands
of light rain were still moving across the extreme northeast
sections. Areas of light drizzle continue over the remainder of
the eastern Tennessee Valley as moisture is still being squeezed
out of the lower part of the atmosphere. Temperatures are in the
lower 30s to near 40 across the area but below freezing above
about 3000 feet where patchy freezing drizzle or very light
freezing rain is possible mainly this morning. Only very light
icing is expected but it could make some high elevation roads
slick. As deep upper trough approaches the next few hours strong
NW flow aloft will squeeze out enough moisture below 800 mb to
produce areas of very light rain or drizzle lower elevations and 
light snow and freezing rain or freezing drizzle mountains. 
Accumulations of snow of a few tenths to over one inch possible in
the higher mountains during the day. Low clouds will linger for 
the day with clearing by afternoon in the south. Highs will be 
more like winter time...in the 40s but upper 30s higher elevations
of southwest Virginia and eastern Tennessee mountains. The 
highest elevations will stay below freezing. Northwest winds will 
be gusty in the higher elevations especially this afternoon and 
evening. Gusts as high as 35 mph extreme northeast mountains. This
will make it feel even colder. Tonight a freeze warning has been 
issued as low level moisture moves out skies will clear from 
southwest to northeast. Temperatures will drop into the upper 20s 
to lower 30s area wide. The only places that may not freeze will 
be around the urban cities of Chattanooga and Knoxville. Winds 
should decrease after midnight with widespread frost formation.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)...
We begin the period with zonal flow returning to the forecast 
area. Models continue to show a weak frontal boundary dropping 
down out of the Ohio River Valley and approaching our area late 
Monday. We begin to see an increase in cloud cover through the day
from northwest to southeast. Highs will range from the mid 50s to
low 60s. Weak boundary with little moisture moves into the CWA 
Monday night into Tuesday and then stalls across the area. Lows 
Monday night will be warmer and range from the mid 30s to near 40.
A few degrees warmer Tuesday with a few clouds around due to the 
boundary and lows in the upper 30s to low 40s overnight. By 
Wednesday a shortwave moves in from the west and brings increasing
moisture to the region. This is when chances for showers return 
to the forecast as the shortwave interacts with the stalled, weak,
boundary that resides in the area. Showers remain on Thursday but
then the shortwave begins to lift off to the NE. Chances for 
showers remain on Friday though as southerly flow and an active 
jet remain across our area ahead of an approaching shortwave for 
Saturday. Shortwave rolls in on Saturday, allowing for more 
showers across the area. Wednesday through Saturday temps slowly 
climb as southerly flow returns. By Thursday we hit the low 70s 
and this continues into Saturday. Lows will be in the mid 50s.

So overall, no real big/organized system comes through but unsettled 
weather in store due to the active jet, stalled boundary, and 
multiple shortwaves that roll through.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
340 PM EDT Sat Oct 28 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...
Cold front continues to move east of the area tonight with rain
slowly shifting east and colder air moving in from the west. 
Trough axis will pivot east tonight, and winds will increase from 
the northwest late tonight and Sunday morning. The combination of 
upslope orographic lift and remaining moisture may allow for some 
precipitation across the higher terrain. While temperatures will 
be cold enough for a wintry mix of light precipitation late 
tonight and Sunday across the higher elevations above 3000 feet, 
think that most will be drizzle/freezing drizzle/ice riming due to
the fact that there is very little moisture through the DGZ and 
efficient snow growth appears unlikely. Regardless, this wintry 
mix will lead to some icy spots across the higher elevations. 
Highs on Sunday will be very cold with temperatures about 20 
degrees below normal.

.LONG TERM (Sunday night through Saturday)...
The period starts out with an exiting upper trough Sunday night 
followed by a drier regime on Monday. Another wave of low pressure
will be slipping east from the Great Lakes through the 
Northeastern U.S. corridor Monday into Tuesday and the northerly 
flow extending through the deamplifying base of this trough will 
drive a weak frontal boundary into the forecast area during the 
day Tuesday. The good news is there doesn't seem to be enough 
moisture for much more than a few clouds during the day. However, 
another short wave will be on the move at mid week and this 
feature should be able to activate the frontal boundary generating
a few showers across the Southern Appalachian region Wednesday 
into Thursday. The active fall pattern continues into the end of 
the extended forecast with another short wave and increasing moist
southerly flow Friday into Saturday. This will require the use of
chance pops right through the end of the long term period. While 
there will be clouds and some light showers at times, the return 
to a southerly low level flow regime will allow for a pleasant 
warming trend ending up with high temperatures back around 70 
degrees by the end of the week.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
1054 AM EDT Sat Oct 28 2017

.DISCUSSION...
A strong cold front is moving through the area this morning. 
Surface observations show the front located NE to SW across the 
valley with temperatures dropping quickly into the upper 30s to 
mid 40s in the wake of the cold front. Ahead of the front, 
temperatures are much warmer in the mid 50s to lower 60s across NE
TN and parts of SW VA. Could see some heavier downpours ahead of 
the front this afternoon in NE TN and SW VA where moisture is 
highest and PWs are near the 90th percentile of climatology. 
Upper-divergence is assisting with synoptic lift across the region
as we're located within both the right-front entrance region of a
jet streak across the Ohio Valley and the left-exit region of a 
jet streak to our south. With the front slowly moving east across 
the region and favorable synoptic lift, this setup should be 
favorable for wet weather the remainder of the day.

Cold air will continue to move in tonight with winds out of the
northwest providing some orographic lift. However, model soundings
still indicate moisture will be very shallow with the DGZ being dry
and unfavorable for efficient snow production. Setup seems to 
favor drizzle/freezing drizzle and ice riming rather than light 
snow across the higher terrain late tonight and Sunday.

FXUS64 KMRX 280843

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
443 AM EDT Sat Oct 28 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Sunday)...
Rain is spreading into east Tennessee this morning just ahead of a
cold front now moving onto the Cumberland Plateau counties. A big
temperature drop will impact the region behind the front with
temperatures tumbling from the upper 50s to mid 60s now to the 40s
later this morning and afternoon. The front may not reach the
eastern and northeast areas until this afternoon. Instability is
very low and so not expecting any thunderstorms. Rainfall amounts
may reach over one inch in the eastern mountains and 1.5 inches
extreme northeast. The heaviest rainfall will move from the
plateau early this morning to the valley and southeast mountains
later into early afternoon and then northeast half this afternoon
and evening.

The system will linger over the extreme northeast into this 
evening. Gusty south to southwest winds over 30 mph have occurred 
in the valley and higher elevations. Gusty winds will continue 
until rain begins with the front so continued advisory until 14Z. 
Tonight and Sunday morning longwave trough moves through the 
region and with very cold air aloft and lingering moisture. 
Northwest winds and low moisture aloft will produce some very 
light freezing rain or drizzle late tonight and early 
Sunday...mostly at elevations above 3000 feet in the eastern 
mountains. Any accumulations will be very light. Temperatures will
drop to near to below freezing only in the higher elevations. 
Elsewhere lows mostly in the upper 30s. Due to cloud cover and 
light precipitation and northwest winds frost formation unlikely. 
Sunday cold temperatures continue and more light freezing drizzle 
or drizzle possible. With extensive clouds northeast half and cold
air advection highs will stay in the upper 30s northeast...even 
below freezing higher elevations to possibly only mid 40s central 
valley. Places in the southern valley may not reach 50 even with 
some sunshine.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Friday)...
Negatively tilted trough axis just off to our east to start the 
period along with associated area of low pressure. Majority of the
precip is over for us at this point but redevelopment and 
intensification of the system occurs as a new area of low pressure
develops off the coast of Virginia. As this new development takes
place we begin to see some weak wrap around moisture into NETN 
and SWVA. Because of this, slight chance POPs in place Sunday 
night and then drop them after midnight as the low pulls further 
up the coast. Shallow moisture depth will lend to freezing drizzle
instead of snow showers as the moisture column only goes up to 
-8/-9 deg C. Any precip that occurs should be light but with icing
it doesn't take much to cause trouble spots. Any slick spots that
develop will likely occur across the higher elevations as 
temperatures don't reach freezing across valley locations until 
precip is exiting. Lows Sunday night will be in the upper 20s to 
lower 30s, 10 to 15 degrees below normal. A freeze watch will 
likely be needed during the next forecast package.

On Monday a weak cold front drops down out of the Ohio River valley 
associated with an area of low pressure up across the Great Lakes. 
No POP chances though as moisture is very limited. We will see a 
slight increase in cloud cover across northern areas bu that's about 
it. Highs will be in the mid to upper 50s, around 8 to 10 degrees 
below normal. Lows Monday night will be warmer, in the mid to upper 
30s. On Tuesday the front is draped across the area which will 
bring slightly more cloud cover. Highs will be in the upper 50s to 
low 60s. Warmer again Tuesday night with lows in the upper 30s to 
low 40s. Wednesday through Friday looks unsettled as we see return 
flow across the area as well as an active upper level jet. During 
this time chances for rain return along with warming temperatures.

061 
FXUS64 KMRX 271924
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
324 PM EDT Fri Oct 27 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight through Saturday)...Everything still on track 
for things going downhill tonight as system moves our way.  System 
expected to move slowly, with measurable rains possibly not 
getting to NE corner of CWA until after sunrise Saturday. With 
clouds and rain associated with the cooler air, expecting non-
diurnal temperature trend as colder air pushes in from the west--
the western sections will likely have their max temp early in the 
morning. Rain totals look to generally be around an inch, so not 
too heavy overall and PW values for this event are notably lower 
than our soupy airmass on Monday. By the end of this period, the 
temps will not be cold enough to change any of the precip to any 
frozen precip. 

Will continue the Wind Advisory for late tonight into Saturday 
morning.  Moderate downsloping mountain wave event looks to set up 
ahead of front.

.LONG TERM (Saturday night through Friday)...
The longwave trough axis will pivot through the region late Saturday 
night and Sunday morning bringing with it very cold air aloft. 
Temperatures at 850mb will be around -5C to -8C. Lingering low-level 
moisture combined with northwesterly winds through the boundary 
layer behind the cold front will produce orographic lift and result 
in some light precipitation across the higher elevations. With very 
dry air aloft and very little moisture through the DGZ, believe that 
most orographically forced precipitation late Saturday night and 
Sunday will be drizzle with freezing drizzle possible above 3500 
feet elevation where temperatures are expected to remain near or 
below freezing on Sunday. With some moisture around -8C to -10C 
across the highest peaks, might could see some light snow flurries 
across the highest elevations, but overall, the setup looks more 
favorable to freezing drizzle/riming across the higher elevations of 
the mountains.

Temperatures will drop near or below freezing Saturday night and 
Sunday morning across many locations, especially higher elevations, 
so a frost advisory or freeze warning may be warranted on later 
shifts. However, remaining moisture on plants and latent heat 
release may act to offer some limited protection for vegetation 
Sunday morning as temperatures approach the freezing mark.

Expect unseasonably cold temperatures across the area on Sunday 
behind the departed front. Highs will range from the lower 40s to 
near 50, which is around 20 degrees below normal. Much of the higher 
elevations above 3500 feet will stay near or below freezing through 
the day. It looks like most of our forecast area will see a 
widespread freeze Sunday night as temperatures will range from the 
upper 20s to low 30s, which is 10 to 15 degrees below normal.

A shortwave passing to our north on Tuesday will help to shift a 
cold front southward toward our region. Lack of moisture with the 
front means we should stay dry with only a few additional clouds. 
Zonal flow will be the setup through the week with highs back near 
normal in the low to mid 60s. In response to a shortwave across the 
Southern Plains, southwesterly flow begins to return across the 
Tennessee Valley on Wednesday and Thursday bringing in additional 
moisture and isentropic lift. The main result looks to be increased 
cloudiness late week with just slight chance/chance PoPs across the 
area. Highest rain chances are expected to remain west of our 
forecast area where moisture and lift are best co-located. 
Uncertainty is high late next week because of model difficulties 
resolving exact timing, strength, and location of shortwaves moving 
through the zonal flow.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
427 AM EDT Fri Oct 27 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Skies are clear across the forecast area early this morning.
Temperatures are in the upper 30s to lower 40s across most of the
valley areas of the north and eastern sections and mid to upper
40s elsewhere. Higher elevations of the Cumberland Plateau and
some locations of the eastern mountains are still in the 50s as
south to southwest winds aloft is keeping air mixed. Some patchy
fog is forming where winds are calm but areas affected by fog will
be limited. Surface high pressure has shifted to the eastern
Carolinas and upper ridge of high pressure was not over the
Appalachians as a cold front moves into the Ohio and mid-
Mississippi Valleys today. Another sunny and warmer day today 
with highs uniformly in the upper 60s to lower 70s. South to 
southwest winds will gradually increase during the day which will 
help with the warming. Late this afternoon and tonight clouds 
increase ahead of the cold front and winds will continue to 
increase. Wind speeds in the eastern mountains will be 15 to 25 
mph with gusts to around 40 mph from about 03Z to 12Z Saturday so 
a wind advisory may need to be issued there. Instability looks 
very low so removed slight chance of thunder. Rain showers should 
move into western sections during the evening and reach the 
northeast area by Saturday morning. Highest rainfall amounts 
should be about 0.50 to 0.75 inches across the plateau counties by
Saturday morning. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday)...

Showers ongoing to start the period out ahead of a strong cold
front moving in from Western/Middle TN. At this point, it sill
looks to be only showers as there is no instability with this
system. Locally heavy rainfall possible as PWs will be elevated 
due to stout southerly flow ahead of the front. PW values average
around 1 inch which is near the 75th percentile for this time of 
year. Cold front rapidly pushes east through the day and much 
colder and drier air begins to push in by late afternoon. 
Lingering moisture in place across the eastern mountains, NETN, 
SWVA Saturday night into Sunday morning will result in possible 
light snow showers. A few light snow flurries may linger into 
early Sunday afternoon as upslope flow squeezes out any remaining 
moisture across the highest peaks of the eastern mountains.

Very cold temperatures across the area on Sunday behind the
departed front. Highs will range from the lower 40s to near 50,
which is around 20 degrees below normal. It looks like a good
portion of out forecast area will see a freeze Sunday night as
temperatures will range from the upper 20s to lower 30s, which is
10 to 15 degrees below normal. A more zonal flow returns for
Monday through Wednesday with highs and lows slowly climbing each
day. By Wednesday highs will be back into the lower to mid 60s.
Wednesday, POP chances begin to slowly increase through the day as
we begin to get some moisture return back out of the SW with high
pressure to our east. Chance POPs in place by Wednesday night for
most areas and this continues into Thursday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
253 AM EDT Thu Oct 26 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Much quieter period in store as 
our longwave trough pushes further east and out of the area. High 
pressure will build in behind this trough and will return us to more 
seasonable conditions. Clouds around early this morning but 
decreasing quickly and giving way to full on sunshine by late 
morning. Highs today will rebound into the low to mid 60s, which 
only puts us 3 to 5 degrees below normal. Warmer tonight as well as 
temps will range from near 40 to the mid 40s. Because of the warmer 
overnight temps frost shouldn't be an issue. 

Overall, once the clouds exit this morning it's smooth sailing with 
calm and clear conditions with near seasonable temperatures. 
However, colder temps return soon. Soon.


.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...The upper level ridge 
will be departing to the east on Friday as a closed low dives out 
of the Northern Plains into the Western Great Lakes. In the low 
levels, southwesterly flow will develop ahead of a fast moving 
cold front. These winds will advect in warmer temperatures and 
moisture. Friday will be the warmest day throughout the forecast 
period with highs in the low 70s across most of the valley. PW 
values will remain low on Friday in the 0.4-0.7 inch range and 
expect conditions will remain dry throughout the day. 

Models are all in fairly good agreement with the front moving 
through the area late Friday night into early Saturday. Widespread 
showers will develop along the boundary as the cold front races 
across the region. PW values on Saturday morning will climb up into 
the 1.0-1.2 inch range, which is in the 75th-90th percentile. The 
timeperiod of southerly flow ahead of the boundary will be limited 
and do not expect any instability will move into the area and have 
just mentioned showers in the forecast for now. Post-frontal 
precipitation will continue late in the day Saturday into early 
Sunday as a strong 120-130 kt 300 mb jet races across the 
Southeastern U.S. This will put the forecast area in the favored 
left exit region for continued synoptic lift behind the surface 
boundary. Colder and drier air will advect in behind the boundary 
and rain could change to snow across the higher elevations early 
Sunday morning but no impacts are expected. Neither the GFS or ECMWF 
are impressive with wrap around precipitation on Sunday and have cut 
back PoPs some. The GFS now indicates that the cyclogenesis will 
occur further to the north and east and any wrap around showers/snow 
showers will be limited to southwest Virginia and northeast 
Tennessee and confidence is low for these locations as well. 

Zonal flow aloft is forecast to start the work week with 
temperatures beginning to moderate some. Models differ on the timing 
of the next system but both main models do indicate PoPs increasing 
once again by mid-week.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...
We'll start off the night with some clouds and maybe a patchy 
shower/flurry across SW Virginia or far NE Tennessee. As the base 
of the deep upper level trough parked overhead continues to shift 
east of the area this evening, northwest flow will prevail across 
the area. Expect below normal temperatures again tonight with as 
the northwest flow continues to usher cold air into the area. 
Additionally, moisture exits the area after midnight, allowing 
skies to clear and temperatures to drop further. Lows tonight will
range from freezing to the upper 30s; 5-10 degrees below normal 
for this time of year. A freeze warning is in effect again tonight
for the eastern mountain zones with a frost advisory for NE 
Tennessee, SW Virginia, the far northern Tennessee Valley, and the
northern Cumberland Plateau.

The upper trough will continue to race northeast on Thursday, 
with a shortwave ridge building in by the afternoon hours. This 
will result in ample sunshine across the area. Combined with 
higher heights aloft, temperatures will be slightly warmer 
tomorrow; topping out in the lower 60s across the valley and the 
mid to upper 50s elsewhere.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)... 
Thursday night into Friday...an upper ridge will quickly build in
and then shift east of the area with temperatures slowly 
moderating. With dry air in place and warming 
temperatures...Friday should be mostly sunny with highs mid 60s to
mid 70s. Models in good agreement with the main system of the 
extended moving in for the end of the week. A cold front will 
track across the region quickly Friday night into Saturday with a 
band of showers spreading in from west to east. The air mass is 
stable and do not anticipate thunderstorm development. Cooler air 
moving in behind the front will drop temperatures enough that 
higher elevations may see a transition of rain to light snow or 
flurries. Behind the fast moving cold front...a deep upper trough 
will drop in and this will bring in limited low level moisture and
weak lift. As a result...may see showers linger over the 
northeastern half of the area Sunday and Sunday night. With the 
cooler air in place...expect a mix of rain and snow Sunday night. 
However..with the limit moisture...should see little to no 
accumulations. Will be between systems Monday and Tuesday. Model 
consistency degrades by the end of the period and confidence 
becomes quite poor...but models trending towards bringing the next
system in around the Wednesday time frame.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
343 AM EDT Wed Oct 25 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Below normal temps again for 
today and tonight as we remain well entrenched in the longwave 
trough. Highs today will range from the upper 40s to the mid to 
upper 50s. These highs are 15 degrees below normal. Clouds around 
this morning with perhaps a peek of sunshine this afternoon before 
another shortwave drops down into the longwave trough. Because of 
this, clouds move back in and will have slight chance POPs in for 
NETN, SWVA, and our eastern mountain zones. Any showers that do 
develop will be very light. 

These POPs carry over into the first half of the tonight period as a 
strong 300 mb jet moves into the area. Additionally, northwest flow 
will help promote further lift across the high terrain and squeeze 
out a few light showers. Moisture quickly exits after midnight and a 
dry forecast for the rest of the night. Before exiting, there could 
be a flurry or two across areas that dip below freezing. The 
shortwave rolling through will help to maintain the cold airmass in 
place. With clearing clouds late tonight expect another cold one 
across the forecast area with lows ranging from freezing to the mid 
to upper 30s. These lows are around 8 degrees below normal. Have 
issued a freeze warning for the eastern mountain zones for tonight 
and a frost advisory for NETN, SWVA, as well as the northern plateau 
and extreme northern TN valley.


.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...Thursday morning will start off cold with temperatures in the 30s as 
a negatively tilted trough moves across the Mid-Atlantic. This 
trough will race quickly to the northeast as a shortwave ridge 
builds in later in the day on Thursday. Higher heights aloft and an 
ample supply of sunshine will warm temperatures into 60s across most 
valley locations on Thursday. The ridge will pass quickly to the east 
late Thursday into early Friday morning as a closed low dives out of 
the Northern Plains into the Mid-MIssissippi River Valley. Southerly 
flow will develop ahead of the system early Friday with PW values 
beginning to creep up. A cold front will quickly race into the 
Tennesse Valley by Saturday morning with widespread showers forecast 
throughout the day. With the limited time for return flow, do not 
expect there will be any thunderstorms with little to no instability 
present. The models are all in fairly good agreement with the 
frontal passage occurring on Saturday, so have increase PoPs into 
the 80-90 range for this timeframe. 

Drier air will begin to move in late Saturday night and into Sunday 
as the front races to the east. The main upper level trough will 
swing across the area on Sunday. The models differ some on the 
amount of wrap around precipitation across the area as the main 
trough swings through. The GFS is a bit more aggressive with strong 
cyclogenesis along the Carolina coast. The ECMWF is a bit weaker but 
still shows a decent low developing along the Carolina coast. Due to 
this, have continued with chances for wrap around precipitation on 
Sunday with best chances across southwest Virginia into northeast 
Tennessee. With this lingering moisture, the question is will there 
be enough moisture left for snow as the cold air moves in. For now, 
have mentioned some snow showers late Sunday into early Monday as 
the moisture begins to depart to the east. 

Dry conditions are forecast to start the work week as the system 
departs to the east and zonal flow aloft develops across the 
Southeastern U.S. Temperatures should be near seasonal average to 
start the new work week.

fall to around the freezing mark and a Freezing Warning will be in

30s...a few flurries will be possible. The potential for frost is
limited due to expected cloud cover and light winds.  However... 
some areas of frost are expected and a Frost Advisory will also 
be in effect. The cool air will continue to advect in on Wednesday
and temperatures will only be able to climb into the 50s across 
most valley locations and only into the 40s at some higher 
elevations. A weak disturbance riding through the upper flow will 
track through the Southern Appalachian Region late Wednesday. 
This may generate a few areas of light rain or sprinkles across 
northern areas and eastern mountains during the late afternoon. 
Amounts should be very light...generally a trace to a hundredth or
two.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday night through Tuesday)...Models are in 
better acquirement today that a midlevel temperature minimum and 
vort max will be crossing our area Wednesday evening. SREF 
probabilities are low and available moisture looks limited, but 
there should be enough for a slight chance of measurable QPF. 
Cold advection at the time of best moisture depth suggests a 
change to snow showers above 3000 ft before dry air aloft ends 
precip chances around 06Z. Clearing skies and slackening winds 
late in the night will drop lows into the 30s, with a hard freeze 
possible in the mountains and widespread frost in the Valley. 
Rather than issuing a watch this far out, it will be mentioned in
the NPW product for tonight's frost/freeze threat.

Thursday and Friday will be clear with a warming trend as a ridge 
builds in behind the departing longwave trough. It will be short-
lived however, as a deep closed low drops into the upper Midwest and 
Great Lakes region over the weekend. Timing of the associated cold 
front and precip with it is shown by the models to affect our area 
between midnight Friday night and Saturday afternoon. We could 
see similar impacts to the last frontal passage yesterday, with 
locally heavy rain and strong winds in the higher elevations 
during that time. The upper trough passage occurs Sunday afternoon
and night, and with very cold temps aloft, it could bring a 
potential for snow showers to the northern half of the area. 

A more zonal flow develops across the eastern Conus for Tuesday and 
Wednesday, with a high pressure system near the Gulf Coast. This 
should provide dry conditions and temps closer to normal both days.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Time to break out the winter 
coats and hats as a reinforcing shot of cold air moves into our area 
via a secondary cold front. This front is associated with a closed 
upper low and strong vortmax divign down into the existing longwave 
trough and will help to amplify it even greater. There will be 
minimal moisture with this front so only slight chance POPs for 
showers up across NETN and SWVA for the first half of the day. After 
that, will have in slight chance POPs across the eastern mountains 
for the afternoon and overnight hours. Any precip that occurs will 
be very light, only expecting trace amounts up to a hundredth of an 
inch or two. 

Greater cloud coverage across northern areas compared to the 
southern valley for today. Winds will be gusty this afternoon due to 
the tight pressure gradient, winds will gust up to 25mph at times. 
Temps will only reach into the lower 60s, which is around 5 to 8 
degrees below normal. Temps fall into the mid to upper 30s for most 
areas tonight. Clouds and light winds should keep temps above 
freezing but it is possible a few isolated locations, especially 
across the high terrain, could reach freezing. Due to winds and 
clouds am skeptical that any frost develops but isolated patchy 
frost possible in sheltered valley locations that see calmer winds. 
Lows will 5 to 8 degrees below normal. With the falling temps late 
tonight the highest peaks across the eastern mountains may see a 
flurry or two if enough moisture can be squeezed out. 

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Monday)...The longwave trough axis 
will be to the east of the Appalachians to start the long-term 
forecast. Northwesterly flow aloft and in the low levels will 
continue to advect in colder air into the region. Wednesday will 
see highs only topping out in the 50s across the valley and 40s in
the mountains. Late Wednesday night into early Thursday morning a
shortwave trough will rotate around the western periphery of the 
departing longwave trough. This shortwave will five across the 
Western Great Lakes into the OHio River Valley and Central 
Appalachians. PW values will be in the 0.4-0.6 inch range around 
the 10th-25th percentile for late October. However, models do 
indicate enough lift for a few sprinkles mixed with some light 
snow across southwest Virginia and the higher elevations along the
Tennessee and North Carolina line. Due to the limited moisture, 
not expecting any impacts. The main impact Wednesday night into 
Thursday morning will be the widespread frost with light winds and
temperatures dropping down into the 30s. Based on current 
guidance, a freeze will be possible as well across portions of 
southwest Virginia and northeast Tennessee. 

A shortwave ridge will move across the area on Thursday. 
Temperatures will moderate some with higher heights across the 
region. Forecast highs for Thursday are in the upper 50s to upper 
60s. 

The pattern will become amplified on Friday as a trough dives 
southeast out of the Northern Plains into the Mid-Mississippi River 
Valley as a second shortwave to the south dives across the Mountain 
West into the Southern Plains. Even though it is still several days 
away, the GFS and ECMWF are both in fairly good agreement with the 
overall pattern and timing for the weekend. At the surface, a cold 
front will race across the Plains into the Mid and Lower Mississippi 
River Valley on Friday. Southwesterly flow will develop across the 
Gulf Coast into the Ohio River Valley with moisture advecting in 
ahead of the approaching system. The cold front will move across the 
area on Saturday with widespread showers along the boundary. Models 
are not forecasting much in the way on instability and have not 
included any thunderstorms at this time. Post-frontal precipitation 
will continue Saturday night into Sunday as a strong jet develops 
across the Southern U.S. The 120-140 kt jet will put the forecast 
area in the left exit region with continued synoptic support for 
lift and precipitation. With this lift persisting behind the front 
and cold air advecting in, the question becomes will there be any 
wintry precipitation. For now, have included a mix of rain and snow 
in the forecast for northeast Tennessee and southwest Virginia 
Sunday night into Monday. This is still several days away and do not 
expect any impacts.

upper trough to help prevent a widespread freeze. With the upper 
trough axis to our east on Wednesday, highs will only reach the 
50s in the Valley. 

Decreasing clouds and diminishing winds should result in a greater 
frost/freeze potential for Wednesday night, and the need for a 
freeze watch will need to be monitored by later shifts. For now will 
continue to mention just frost with lows in the mid to upper 30s in 
most spots, and lower 30s in the mountains. Another noteworthy item 
Wednesday night is the NAM's depiction of a secondary vort max that 
drops SE on the back of the larger trough, which squeezes some low 
QPF out in SW VA in the form of snow. However, no other model 
supports this right now, with SREF snow probabilities around 5% or 
less, so will maintain a dry Wednesday night.

A surface-to-midlevel ridge builds across the region for Thursday, 
providing dry weather and a slight warming trend through Friday, but 
another deep trough drops into the Plains and Midwest over the 
weekend. Precip ahead of a cold front may enter our area as early as 
Friday night, with the GFS and ECMWF pointing toward Saturday for 
the timing of highest rain chances and frontal passage. With the 
models depicting a deep, longwave trough over the region, another 
surge of below normal temperatures will follow for Sunday and 
Monday, with a widespread freeze potential Sunday night.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
415 AM EDT Mon Oct 23 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...A deepening upper level low will
swing rapidly northeast from the Mid Mississippi and Ohio Valley
region today on its way through the Eastern Great Lakes by the end
of the short term period. A strong southerly flow ahead of the low
is pulling a broad swath of moist air out of the Gulf of Mexico
and this moisture is being lifted ahead of the upper trough and
surface cold front. Therefore, categorical pops were used for
showers today and there may be just enough instability for a
thunderstorm across the southern third of the forecast area.
Slightly drier air will flow into the region behind the cold front
from west to east through the day allowing the more persistent
rain to become a little lighter and more scattered in nature. The
chance for showers will continue tonight ahead of a reinforcing
cold front building southeast through the strong cyclonic flow 
present within the Eastern U.S. mean trough. Much drier air behind
this front should bring an end to the light precipitation across
most of the forecast area by daybreak Tuesday. High temperatures
will be tricky today due to the fact that the lowest readings
around sunrise are elevated in the strong southerly flow regime
but cold air advection will be filling in behind the initial front
relatively quickly today. Tonight's lows will drop into the middle
and upper 40s. 

.LONG TERM (Tuesday through Sunday)...The cold front and lead 
shortwave trough will be to the east of the area to start the 
long-term forecast. A highly amplified pattern will being to take 
shape on Tuesday as another trough dives out of the Mid-
Mississippi River Valley into the Tennessee River Valley. The 
atmosphere will be dry behind the front with PW values ranging 
from around 0.4-0.6 inches, which is around the 10th-25th 
percentile for late October. Overall, there is sufficient lift for
precipitation but the lack of moisture will really limit any 
showers to the higher elevations with dry conditions elsewhere. 
Cold air advection will drop high temperatures into the upper 50s 
to mid 60s across most valley locations on Tuesday. Cold air 
advection Tuesday night into Wednesday morning will drop overnight
lows into the mid 30s to low 40s. Expect the pressure gradient 
will remain elevated enough for some light winds overnight Tuesday
night and should prevent any widespread frost from forming. 
However, there could be some patchy frost in the sheltered valley 
areas Wednesday morning, especially for Northeast Tennessee and 
Southwest Virginia. 

The trough axis will shift to the east on Wednesday with 
northwesterly flow aloft. Wednesday will be the coldest day of the 
forecast period with highs only making it into the 50s across most 
valley locations. By Wednesday night, surface high pressure builds 
into the region. Ideal radiational cooling conditions will setup 
Wednesday night into Thursday morning with lows in the 30s. Due to 
this, expect a widespread frost on Thursday morning. For now, will 
mention this in the HWO. A shortwave ridge moves in on Thursday with 
dry conditions and moderating temperatures. 

The GFS and ECMWF are both in good agreement with a highly amplified 
pattern again over the weekend with a deep trough across the Eastern 
CONUS. The models differ slightly on the timing of the system but 
both suggest that the weekend will be cool and wet. For now, have 30-
50 PoPs throughout much of the weekend with below normal 
temperatures.

frontal system.

832 
FXUS64 KMRX 210729
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
329 AM EDT Sat Oct 21 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Seeing high clouds stream into the area with the ridge axis now to 
the east of the area. There is some patchy fog currently across the 
area and any ongoing fog should quickly dissipate after sunrise. The 
higher heights aloft associated with the ridge will keep 
temperatures well above normal today. Expect highs will be similar 
to yesterday with values ranging from the mid to upper 70s across 
most valley locations. PW values throughout the short-term period 
will range from 0.2-0.4 inches, which is near the minimal values 
observed for mid to late October. A milder night is forecast for 
tonight as southwesterly winds throughout the atmosphere finally 
begins to advect in warmer temperatures and higher dewpoints into 
the region. Overnight lows will range from the mid 40s to mid 50s.


.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Friday)...

The period starts out dry with a fair amount of sunshine to 
complete a fine weekend, but conditions deteriorate Sunday night 
into Monday as a rather strong short wave and associated surface 
cyclone press east across the Southeastern quarter of the nation.
The healthy low pressure center should be able to pull a deep 
layer of Gulf moisture ahead of the trough for the production of 
widespread showers and even a couple thunderstorms Monday into 
Monday night. Another, upper trough will be amplifying into the 
Eastern U.S. Monday night into Tuesday with more showers being 
lifted in advance of a significant cold front which will be 
moving so fast that it will be east of the Southern Appalachians 
early on Tuesday. However, the deep trough will have several 
shorter wavelength enhancers dropping south through its base all 
the way into Wednesday night. Therefore, kept a chance for some 
showers going through mid week. The coldest air of the season will
be spilling south into the Southern Appalachians during the 
period and some of the precipitation that falls in the highest 
elevations across Southwest Virginia and along the North Carolina 
and Tennessee border may fall in the form of light snow showers. 
Finally drier air and higher pressure brings an end to the precip 
on Thursday and the dry period should last through Friday. 
Although another upper trough and cold front will be on the 
approach. This system will be arrive in the region early in the 
weekend.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
250 PM EDT Fri Oct 20 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...We continue in a rather 
stagnant pattern and thus another mostly persistence forecast. High 
pressure at the surface and aloft over the region will be shifting 
slowly east during the period. The atmosphere will remain on the dry 
side. Temperatures running slightly higher again today than 
yesterday, so the gradual warming trend is continuing. Some patchy 
fog can be expected late tonight especially near bodies of water. 
Tomorrow will feature plenty of sunshine despite some high clouds 
and temperatures generally near or a bit higher than today. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...By Saturday evening the 
upper ridge moves off the southeast U.S. coast. Meanwhile, a deep 
long wave trough and associated cold front will move across the 
Midwest. So, expect dry conditions across the forecast area with 
prefrontal warming bringing temperatures on Sunday 5 to 10 degrees 
above normal.  

The high amplitude trough will slow forward/eastward progress of the 
entire system. Showers and thunderstorms will remain over West 
Tennessee for much of Sunday and early Sunday night. Eventually, a 
closed upper low forms over northern Mississippi early Monday 
morning. This is where the forecast gets difficult due to location 
and evolution of this closed low. Current model progs are having a 
tough time not just with timing but also location. Should the low 
dive into central Alabama the highest QPF will occur over the 
southern TN Valley. Downsloping winds from the east/southeasterly 
wind component would limit heavy rainfall over northeast TN...say 
from Knoxville east along and north of I-40 and the I-81 corridor. 

This upper low is kicked out rather quickly with another following 
in its wake by Monday night. This will bring significantly colder 
air to the region on Wednesday into Thursday. In fact, some higher 
elevations could see snow, perhaps mixed with rain, across northern 
parts of Tennessee, mountains of southwest Virginia and the 
Appalachians. Precipitation chances diminish by Wednesday night. The 
remainder of the week will be below normal with another trough 
expected to produce more precipitation by early next weekend.

FXUS64 KMRX 200750
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
350 AM EDT Fri Oct 20 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Clear skies, light winds and surface high pressure have lead to some 
patchy fog across the area this morning. Expect any ongoing fog will 
quickly dissipate after sunrise with mostly sunny skies forecast for 
today. Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis 
indicate a ridge extending from the Gulf Coast into the Northern 
Plains with drier along this axis. Upper level heights will continue 
to increase today as the ridge axis moves overhead. Temperatures 
will range from around 5-10 degrees above normal with 500 dm heights 
in the 588-590 dm range. High temperatures are forecast to be in the 
mid to upper 70s across most valley locations. The ridge axis will 
pass to the east tonight with overnight temperatures around 5-10 
degrees warmer than last night with forecast lows in the mid 40s to 
low 50s. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday)...

Protective ridging holds on through most of the weekend keeping 
skies mostly sunny with little chance for rain. However, a 
relatively strong short wave trough will drive northeast out of 
the Lower Mississippi Valley across the Mid South generating 
showers and some thunderstorms over the Southern Appalachian 
Region later Sunday night into Monday night. There won't be much 
of a break behind this feature as more short wave energy dives 
southeast out of the Northern Plains and Western Great Lakes for 
arrival in the forecast area on Tuesday, generating a decent 
chance for more showers through Tuesday night. Additionally, there
will be a final, weaker upper level feature moving through the 
base of a deep long wave trough over the eastern states that will 
have just enough moisture for the possibility of some light rain 
on Wednesday. Drier air on the back side of this departing trough 
may allow for a dry Thursday at the tail end of the extended. The 
weekend will be pleasant with above normal warmth but temperatures
will be gradually dropping back to normal early in the work week 
under a shield of rain producing clouds. And by Wednesday and 
Thursday readings will be several degrees below normal as chilly 
Canadian air spills southward into the Eastern U.S.

FXUS64 KMRX 191856
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
256 PM EDT Thu Oct 19 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...A mostly persistence 
forecast as surface high pressure will remain over the region 
along with a building upper/midlevel ridge. The atmosphere will 
remain quite dry. Temperatures running slightly higher today than 
yesterday, so the gradual warming trend is continuing. Some patchy
fog can be expected late tonight especially near bodies of water.
Tomorrow will feature plenty of sunshine and temperatures a bit 
higher than today. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...We begin the period 
with ridging in place and surface high pressure centered just off to 
our southeast. This area of high pressure begins to move farther 
east on Saturday in response to a long wave trough digging down 
across the Central Plains. With the high moving east, we will see a 
return flow from the Gulf, which will help to slowly raise dewpoints 
during the day. Saturday night into Sunday southerly flow continues 
to strengthen as the trough draws closer. Models have slowed a bit 
with the onset of precip out ahead of the cold front so it looks 
like Sunday just be dry for a good portion of the day. By Sunday 
night/Monday POPs really begin to ramp up as an area of low pressure 
has become cutoff from the northern jet stream. On Monday the models 
still show the closed low off to our southwest, pumping in quite a 
bit of moisture out of the Gulf and into our area. Because of this, 
we will see chances for thunderstorms along with our rain chances on 
Monday due to the climbing dewpoints and instability. Dewpoints in 
the afternoon hours will have climbed into the lower 60s with 
soundings showing PW values around 1.5 inches, which will be 
approaching max values for this time of year. Will taper off thunder 
after midnight to just showers.

Monday night into Tuesday a secondary and more robust trough dives 
down into our area from out of Canada. This stronger trough and 
associated front will pick up the closed low to our south a quickly 
usher it off to the northeast by Tuesday afternoon. This second 
front moves into the area late Tuesday afternoon/Tuesday night and 
brings much colder air into the area. This will be the coldest air 
of the season thus far. Highs on Wednesday will be in the mid to 
upper 50s, which is around 10 to 15 degrees below normal. Lows on 
Wednesday night will range from the lower to mid 30s across NETN and 
SWVA and from the mid to upper 30s across the central and southern 
valley, which is around 10 degrees below normal.  The models hint at 
some moisture and lift with this system as it comes through--have 
minimal precip chances late in the forecast for a few area north and 
in the mountains. The air may be cold enough in these areas to see a 
few snow flakes--will see how cold things look as it approaches.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Wednesday)...

and strength issues but it appears that we squeeze out one final 
day of basically dry weather on Sunday as an upper trough deepens

over the Eastern states. Therefore, a medium to high chance for 
showers will continue Tuesday into Wednesday as sufficient 
moisture and lift accompanies this slow moving trough. Very chilly
air will build south into the forecast area at mid week.

Wednesday and there may even be a few snow flurries in the highest
elevations along the North Carolina border Wednesday night.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
302 PM EDT Wed Oct 18 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...Surface high pressure will 
remain over the region as an upper ridge builds in during the short 
term period.  The atmosphere will remain quite dry.  Dewpoints/temps 
running higher today than yesterday, so should be slightly warmer 
tonight with less chance for any patchy frost.  Some patchy fog can 
be expected late tonight especially near bodies of water.  Tomorrow 
will feature plenty of sunshine and temperatures a bit higher than 
today. 

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...A quiet start to the 
long term, but hold on to your hats because there's some cold air 
headed back our way toward the end of the period. Riding is in place 
from Thursday night through Saturday night. During this period, 
expect clear to mostly clear skies along with calm conditions. Temps 
on Thursday night still a few degrees below normal as the airmass 
continues to modify. Temps will be in the low to mid 40s. On Friday 
we see temps continuing to slowly climb with highs in the mid to 
upper 70s. Friday night near normal temps in the mid to upper 40s. 
Saturday temps remain in the mid to upper 70s. 

On Saturday the ridge begins to amplify in response to an upper level 
trough digging down across the Central Plains. The low pressure 
center associated with this trough is well into Canada but the cold 
front sweeps down all the way into Texas! As of now though, Saturday 
looks to remain dry with pleasant conditions. Saturday night 
southerly flow begins to ramp up as the front draws closer. The 
actual precip doesn't move in until later on Sunday and perhaps even 
holding off until Sunday night. Will have POPs slowly increasing 
through the day on Sunday from west to east. The best chance for 
POPs come on Monday. By this time, a closed off low has developed 
just to our west-southwest as the northern jet has separated itself 
from this system. The closed-off low rotates just to our south 
Monday night into Tuesday, which will therefore continue higher POP 
chances. We could also hear a few rumbles of thunder as we may have 
a storm or two across the area. On Tuesday we see another surge of 
cold air coming down out of Canada and into the Plains. This 
secondary trough will quickly catch up to the closed low and help 
move it along and out of our area by Tuesday afternoon. With this 
trough though comes the coldest air of the fall season. High 
temperatures on Wednesday, after the secondary frontal passage, will 
only be in the mid to upper 50s. These values are 10 to 15 degrees 
below normal. The lows Wednesday night will range from the mid to

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Friday night)...
So far this morning, dewpoints have been holding in the upper 30s
to mid 40s across the area, making it unlikely that widespread

not be continued. Some cirrus is spreading across the area
associated with an upper level shortwave trough, but it will have
little impact on today's weather, with sunny skies and high temps
in the lower 70s. An increasingly amplified ridge will build over
the Southeast through the rest of the period, providing a warming
trend each day and clear skies. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Monday)... 
Amplification of the upper pattern keeps a nice, warm reminder of
the great Summer season around this weekend with an increasing 
southerly flow between a protective Eastern U.S. upper trough and 
a slowly advancing Western states trough and cold front. A short 
wave feature shifts, in negative tilt fashion, northeast toward 
Hudson Bay in Canada Saturday into Sunday while the southern part 
of the trough slows in response to a developing closed low over 
the Southern Plains. Moistening in the southerly flow regime and 
convergence ahead of the slow moving cold front will lead to the 
development of showers and thunderstorms mainly Sunday night into 
Monday. Another, more amplified upper trough and an associated 
reinforcing shot of colder air will drop southeast out of Central 
Canada later Monday into Tuesday bringing a continued chance of 
showers to the Southern Appalachians. After a mild weekend, high 
temperatures will drop back near normal for mid October in the 
middle and upper 60s.

period of convection over the area. Models have been slowing down 
the timing of arrival of the showers...with scattered showers and 
thunderstorms expected Sunday late afternoon into the early 
evening...with only showers expected as instability weakens with 
the sunset. Scattered showers are then expected through the day 
Monday.

from west to east as dry air aloft works its way in behind the
midlevel trough axis.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)...
After the front moves through we move into a period of quiet and 
pleasant weather across the forecast area. Temperatures at the 
start of the week will max out in the 60's with mostly sunny skies
and light winds. Quasi-zonal flow in the upper levels will 
eventually transition into a ridge of high pressure. This will 
help keep the skies clear and allow temperatures to warm up 
throughout the week. By next weekend high temperatures will reach 
back up into the mid 70's cross most of the area. No chances for 
precipitation are expected through the long term portion of the 
forecast.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

be realized in the form of cloud cover where lift is lacking. Mild
temps in the lower 80s will continue today.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...
We star the weekend with the ridge of high pressure continuing to
dominate the weather pattern. Daytime high temperatures through 
the should remain about 10 degrees above normal with mostly sunny 
skies, light winds, and no chances for rain, but things begin to 
take a turn towards the end of the weekend.. A low pressure system
north of the Great Lakes will drag a cold front across the 
eastern half of the United States bringing with it chances for 
rain and cooler temperatures. Models are begging to narrow down 
the time frame for the frontal passage in our area with the most 
likely time being Sunday afternoon through Monday morning. Front 
will push through relatively quickly and precipitation will be 
tied closely with the actual front so our rain chances stay around
for only about 24 hours. Forecast model soundings are in some 
disagreement with how much instability will be present along this 
front, but it looks like most places will just see rain with maybe
an occasional rumble of thunder. 

The front will be totally east of the area by Monday afternoon and 
pretty dry air will set in behind it. In addition temperatures will 
make a dramatic drop with temperatures on Monday forecasted to be 
about 15 degrees colder than on Sunday. Ridging builds in behind the 
front and traps the drier and cooler air leading to temperatures at 
or just a bit below normal through the end of this 7-day forecast.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...

The cold front is now along the Cumberland Plateau with westerly

and evening and expect most locations will remain dry. Current 
water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicates a 
shortwave trough passing to the north across the Great Lakes 
Region with a ridge along the Northern Gulf Coast. The low level 
dewpoints and PW values are elevated for early October but the 
forcing is lacking. However, could still see a few isolated 
showers with best chances across the higher elevations. Post 
frontal cloud cover has been persistent today behind the boundary 
across Middle and Western TN. Due to this, increased cloud cover 
this evening and during the overnight hours. There could also be 
some patchy fog near sunrise. Overnight lows will still be 
slightly above normal but several degrees cooler than the last 
couple of nights in the 50s generally areawide.

Much drier air will advect into the forecast area on Thursday with 
PW values dropping down into the 0.5-0.7 inch range. These values 
are near the 10th percentile and expect dry and mostly sunny 
conditions during the day on Thursday. Highs will still run a few 
degrees above average with the lack of any substantial cold air 
advection behind the front and the ample supply of insolation. 
Forecast highs on Thursday will generally be in the mid to upper 70s.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Tuesday)...

Upper level ridge in place to start the period along with drier 
air and more seasonable temperatures. Lows will be in the mid to 
upper 50s, but still a few degrees above normal. Broad longwave 
trough begins to push into the Ohio River Valley on Friday but 
high pressure centered to our SW remains in control of our 
weather. Expecting another dry day with temps in the upper 70s to 
low 80s, 5 to 8 degrees above normal. Lows overnight will be in 
the upper 50s to low 60s. Same story on Saturday with high 
pressure still in control, though the ridge beginning to become 
more suppressed as a wave of energy moves across the Rockies and 
into the Central Plains. We do see a little more moisture enter 
into our area from the east on Saturday as high pressure off the 
east coast brings in moisture from the Atlantic. We could have a 
few spotty showers across the eastern high terrain but the valley 
will stay dry. Highs in the upper 70s to lower 80s. 

By Saturday night an area of low pressure has developed with the 
aforementioned wave of energy. Center of the low is across the 
Northern Plains with a trailing cold front. On Sunday the front 
begins to approach our area and will draw closer by Sunday night. 
With the front still well to our west Sunday we should see another 
dry day with highs around 80. A line of showers and storms sweep 
through sometime Sunday night with the actual front not passing 
thorugh until sometime Monday, depending on what model you go with. 
The latest GFS is a little quicker with the front than the ECMWF. 
Behind this front we will see much cooler and drier air move in. 
Sunday night lows will be in the upper 50s. Highs on Monday will be 
in the upper 60s with lows that night in mid 40s!. Two gorgeous days 
follow behind the front with Tuesday and Wednesday looking more like 
fall. Highs will be in the upper 60s to near 70 with lows in the mid 
to upper 40s with clear skies.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...As the remnants of Nate pulls
away from the Southern Appalachian Region...will continue to see
winds decrease over the area and rain slowly coming to an end.
Winds have already diminish somewhat and will...therefore allow 
the current High Wind Warning and Wind Advisory to expire. A few 
showers may linger over the area through the morning but most 
locations should be dry. However...with deep low level moisture 
remaining in place across the region and warm daytime temperatures
in the 70s and 80s...may see isolated to scattered convection 
develop during the afternoon...mainly over higher terrain and 
across southern locations. With the recent rainfall...a few area 
rivers may rise and the French Broad River near Newport and the 
Pigeon River at Newport are expected to rise above flood stage and
a Flood Warning remains in effect for these areas.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday)...Models are in reasonable 
agreement overall although some differences in the details, and run 
to run consistency is decent. Forecast confidence is about average 
for this time of year. Upper trough/low will lift across the plains 
into the great lakes region early in the period, with a weak surface 
low tracking northeast well to our west.  Moisture out ahead of this 
system will be over our area early, along with some convection for 
the Tuesday/Wednesday time frame. Drier air will spread in behind a 
very weak frontal boundary by Thursday.  The upper ridge/surface 
high pressure pattern will re-establish itself across the region 
Thursday through at least Saturday.  The next cold front may be 
approaching by the end of the period, bringing the possibility of 
some convection on Sunday.

FXUS64 KMRX 081943
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
343 PM EDT Sun Oct 8 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...
The remnants of Tropical system Nate continue to speed north
toward middle Tennessee with locally heavy rainfall along the 
eastern side across southern and central sections of the forecast
area at mid afternoon. The heaviest rainfall is starting to shift
east of the forecast area into eastern Georgia and the Carolinas.
Still could see a few more hours of heavy rain in the south before
it shifts to the northern areas later tonight. Winds are just
starting to increase across the southern parts of the area as the
pressure gradient tightens and have not changed wind advisory or
high wind warning areas...although not sure winds will be strong
enough in the warning area. This will have to be monitored in the
evening hours. Temperatures were mostly lower 70s and will change
little overnight. Tonight and early Monday as the remnant low 
moves northeast into the mid Atlantic and northeast states there
will be a break in the rain from southwest to northeast. Air mass
will be moist and with heating Monday expecting scattered showers
and thunderstorms will be possible. Rainfall amounts look to be 
light. Kept highs a few degrees below guidance.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Saturday)...
A large mass of moisture carried north out of the Gulf of Mexico 
in the wake of Nate will continue to advance north through the 
Deep South into the Southern Appalachian region Monday night 
through Tuesday night. The moisture will be lifted in warm frontal
fashion into a pattern of showers and thunderstorms through this 
period as a closed upper level low lumbers slowly northeast out of
the Plains into the Great Lakes. A cold front associated with the
deep low will generate a continued chance for convection on 
Wednesday with decreasing pops expected later Wednesday night into
Thursday behind the departing system. Following this unsettled 
period, the sub-tropical high will strengthen again over the 
Southeastern U.S. leading to a dry end of the week. Typical late 
period timing issues are present with an advancing upper level 
trough through the middle of the nation due later in the weekend. 
Superblend populates some chance category pops for convection with
the associated front on Sunday; especially by Sunday night. Due 
to uncertainty so many days into the future, yanked pops back to 
slight chance through the 24 hour period at the end of the 
extended for this system.

.DISCUSSION...
Now Tropical Depression Nate is located over central Alabama at

at about 25 mph and has weakened rapidly over the last 12 hours 
but bands of rainfall have been moving north across the southern 
and western sections of the forecast area since late saturday 
evening. Currently the most intense rainfall bands were setting up
over Bradley and Hamilton counties northeast to Bledsoe county
Tennessee.

The highest rainfall amounts so far have been across the southern
plateau and valley in Marion and Hamilton counties with totals of
1.5 to 2.5 inches there. Elsewhere amounts were mostly from a few
hundredths northeast to over an inch in the south. Adjusted total
rainfall amounts through tonight to 1.5 inches northeast to 
around 3 to 4 inches west and south...locally higher amounts to
around 6 inches where the bands form. Winds have not increased 
much but still expecting them to increase later today. With the 
decrease in intensity of Nate may have to adjust advisory this 
afternoon. Temperatures will rise little with the clouds and rain 
and adjusted highs down a few degrees most locations.

337 AM EDT Sun Oct 8 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Remnants of hurricane Nate 
will be tracking into the region today, before exiting late 
tonight. Winds will pick up and become gusty this afternoon and 
into tonight, and some wind gusts to 40 mph or higher will be 
possible across much of the area. While model soundings do not 
look ideal for mountain waves, there is still some risk and also 
given stronger winds at 3000+ feet will go ahead and upgrade the 
high wind watch to a warning. Will tweak the times for both it and
the wind advisory to narrow the window of higher winds. While it 
looks like total precip through tonight will generally be in the 
2-4 inch range with locally higher amounts, very dry soils should 
help to lessen flooding potential. Flash flood guidance values are
very high, so while localized flooding issues will be possible no
flood watch will be issued at this time.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)...The widespread showers and a 
few thunderstorms over the area will slowly decrease in coverage and 
intense on Monday as the remnants of Nate exit the region.  Also... 
as the system pulls away...winds will continue to lessen. 
However...as Nate moves out...an area of weak low pressure will move 
in from the south and a weakening frontal boundary will come in from 
the northwest.  This will bring another round of showers and 
thunderstorms into the area for Monday night and Tuesday.  Scattered 
convection will continue into Wednesday as the front slowly pulls 
away from the area.  A few isolated showers and possibly a stray 
storm may linger into Thursday but at this point we should be 
trending drier as high pressure begins to build in.  The high should 
dominate area weather for the rest of the extended for dry and warm 
conditions Friday and Saturday.
