Moisture will continue to increase tonight as the remnants of Nate
move northeastward towards our area. As lift increases late
tonight, rain will become likely from south to north. Temperatures
will be above normal with extensive cloud cover and anomalously
high low-level moisture.

A frontal boundary to our west will accelerate Nate northeastward
on Sunday with increasing winds through the afternoon.
Additionally, low-level moisture is very high with PW values near
climatological maxima across southeast Tennessee and southwest
North Carolina. Could have some localized flooding with upslope
flow producing enhanced rainfall amounts along the southern
plateau and higher elevations of southwest North Carolina.
However, flooding issues seem minimized for most areas due to the
quick movement of Nate and high FFG values due to recent dry
weather. The foothills of the TN/NC mountains may see more limited
precipitation (less than 2.0 inches) due to strong downsloping 
late Sunday and Sunday night. The current representation of
precipitation amounts from high-res model seems reasonable.

With 850mb winds of greater than 50 kt, expect the potential for
gusty winds, and therefore, a wind advisory has been issued. The
potential for up to 60 mph wind will exist across the highest 
elevations of the TN/NC mountains. The combination of strong flow
at 850 mb and the potential for some mountain wave enhanced winds
will lead to the potential for strong winds, and because of this,
a High Wind Watch has been issued. Between 00z-06z Monday,
mountain waves seem at least possible as southeast winds will be about
50-60 kt at 850mb combined with a tightening pressure gradient 
across the mountains and a neutral to slightly stable layer near
the mountain tops.

Late Sunday night, winds should begin to decrease as the remnants
of Nate move away from our area. Rain will also decrease as
slightly drier air moves in from the west.

.LONG TERM (Monday through Friday)...
Nate will be well northeast of the forecast area at the beginning
of the period. In fact, Nate will be moving north across the 
region so fast, it will leave a vapor trail in place, so to speak.
A corridor of deeper moisture will be streaming northeast in the 
gradient between a Western U.S. upper trough and the expansive 
sub-tropical high holding its position over the Western Atlantic 
and Southeastern U.S. Following the departure of the tropical 
system, this axis of moisture will be lifted in the presence of a 
couple shorter wavelength features. The trailing, more amplified 
upper feature will be associated with a frontal wave at mid week 
keeping the chance for showers and thunderstorms going through 
Thursday. Drier air filling in behind the wave and a re-emergence 
of the sub- tropical across the Eastern U.S. should allow for a 
dry end to the week on Friday and Saturday.

334 PM EDT Fri Oct 6 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Saturday)...
Tonight should be slightly warmer than the past several nights as
southerly winds, low-level moisture, and mid-level clouds begin to
increase late tonight. Depending upon cloud cover, may have some 
patchy fog near area lakes and rivers once again, but any fog 
should remain localized.

A potent shortwave trough across the upper Mississippi River
Valley combined with an upper jet producing strong upper-
divergence across the Great Lakes region will act to strengthen 
low-level southerly flow across the Southeast CONUS on Saturday. 
This increasing low-level flow will act to increase moisture 
substantially with dew points rising to the upper 60s to lower 70s
by Saturday evening. PW values will also increase to near 2.0 
2.2 inches by 0Z Sunday which is very high  around the 99th 
percentile of climatology for this time of year. With the 
increasing moisture, we may begin to see some rain or isolated 
thunderstorms on Saturday afternoon, especially across southeast 
Tennessee and southwest North Carolina where best lift and
instability will be colocated. 

.LONG TERM (Saturday night through Friday)...
Some relief from the dry conditions are on the way as a cold 
front builds toward the Southern Appalachians. Moisture will be 
advancing north out of the Gulf of Mexico ahead of the tropical 
system called Nate. Still a fair amount of uncertainty in the 
track of Nate with a swath of model run forecasts that take the 
center of circulation west of the Appalachians and a few that take
the feature just east of the spine of the Appalachians, which is 
basically what the official NHC forecast depicts at this writing. 
Would expect some changes in track, intensity, and forward speed 
of this circulation which will mean some shifts in amounts of rain
and wind strength during the next couple days of forecasts. At 
this time, went with increasing chances for showers and some 
thunderstorms Saturday night into Sunday with the tropical 
circulation (likely a depression) passing along its closest path 
to the forecast area Sunday night. At this time, the strongest 
wind would be in the higher terrain over Southwest North Carolina 
and in the higher terrain along the Tennessee border with North 
Carolina. Wind speeds are currently forecast to be in the 25-35 
mph range for a brief time Sunday evening in the higher terrain 
with 15-25 mph winds in the adjacent lower elevation areas. As 
stated earlier, rainfall will be contingent on the actual track of
the tropical low and its depth; but at this time our forecast has
the highest amounts in Southwest North Carolina and in the higher
terrain over Southeast Tennessee where 48 hour amounts may be 
around 4-5 inches with some locally higher totals in a few spots. 
Would expect quite a bit of "rain shadowing" keeping totals 
significantly lower across much of the remainder of the forecast 
area with a system path just east of the spine of the 
Appalachians. A trailing wave of low pressure behind the departing
tropical system will keep the chance for rain alive in showers 
and some thunderstorms Monday night into Wednesday as the moist 
southerly component keeps the Gulf of Mexico open for business. 
There is quite a bit of uncertainty in the remaining two days of 
the extended period with the ECMWF more active than the GFS, 
despite what looks like another building upper ridge. The drier 
GFS looks a little better at this point with that beautiful ridge;
thus kept pops way down in the slight chance category for 
Thursday into Friday.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
335 PM EDT Thu Oct 5 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Friday)...
High pressure remains in control with continued dry weather
tonight. May have a few passing high clouds during the night, but
otherwise, it should be mostly clear with minimum temperatures 
expected to be a degree or two warmer than last night.

Friday should be another warm day with mostly clear conditions.
Surface high pressure shifts slightly to the east and winds will
become more southerly in response to an approaching shortwave
across the Great Plains. We should see 850mb temperatures increase
by a degree or two resulting in surface max temperatures expected
to be about a degree or two warmer than Thursday afternoon. Max
temperatures will continue to be about 10-13 degrees above normal. 

.LONG TERM (Friday night through Wednesday)...
We get to experience the sunny and warm weather for just a bit 
longer Friday into Saturday, but after that things begin to cooler
and wetter. The biggest weather to watch will be Tropical Storm 
Nate as it moves north out of the Gulf of Mexico and how it 
interacts with an advancing front from the west. 

Ahead of the storm making landfall on Sunday we will see 
precipitation chances increase as low level flow begins to turn 
southerly bringing in more moist air. Precipitation ahead of the 
tropical storm looks like it could start as early as Saturday 
morning, but we will have much better chances Saturday evening. 
Precipitation should continue as the tropical storm moves up the 
southeast towards our area. Latest National Hurricane Center 
forecast has the storm passing over our area Monday morning with it 
possibly still being a tropical depression. The latest ECMWF has 
shifted the path of the storm further west towards Louisiana to be 
more in line with the GFS. So over the weekend I have trended a bit 
more towards the GFS and it's QPF amounts since it has been pretty 
consistent in it's path of this system for several runs now. 

The main path of this storm and the location of the frontal boundary 
will likely be where we see the highest precipitation amounts over 
the weekend and into next week. Most models are keeping the main 
band of the heaviest rain off to our west...But we can't rule out 
some heavy rain here if the track of the storm shifts or the front 
makes further eastward progress than we anticipated. Currently think 
we could see widespread precipitation amounts of 1-3 inches in our 
area, but it's possible some places could see up to 4 or 5 inches. 
This rain will fall over several days and with our recently (very) 
dry conditions we've experienced the rivers and lakes should be able 
to handle a good amount of water. Wind speeds are tough with a 
system like this since they can really lose steam once they move 
inland into rougher terrain, but we could see winds of 20+ mph with 
higher gusts Sunday and Monday, especially in the higher terrain. 
Once this system finally exits the area we could see some lingering 
showers into the middle of the week, but dry conditions should 
return by Thursday as a high pressure system slides south of the 
area.

remain in control of the weather pattern across our area again 
today and tonight. This will result in another day of above normal
daytime temperatures and sunny skies. Dewpoints may be a degree or
two higher than yesterday as a bit of moisture slowly begins to 
work back into the area. This slight increase in moisture will
help hold lows tonight in the 50s across the region, despite
continued mainly clear skies.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...
High pressure will provide one more day of dry and seasonally 
warm weather on Friday. The high should shift east and out of the 
area on Saturday. This should allow southerly flow to develop 
across the region and bring an increase in low level moisture. 
This change in the weather pattern will transition us into wet and
unsettle conditions. Models continue to struggle with consistency
and confidence remains rather low for the bulk of the extended. 
The main concern through the period will be the track of the 
remnants of tropical depression 16 progged to push through the 
area this weekend into early next week. Also of concern will be 
the approach of a weakening frontal boundary and its interact with
the depression. The GFS is a bit faster and farther west with the
track of the system...while the ECMWF is slower and farther east.
The frontal boundary should move in around the Saturday night or 
Sunday time frame. While details remain in question...the overall 
scenario of increased chance of showers and thunderstorms can be 
expected Saturday through Monday...with the best chance generally 
around the late Sunday into Monday time frame. Improving 
conditions are expected Tuesday into Wednesday with some lingering
showers continuing across the area through this period.

Upper ridge over local area begins to break down over the next 24

to lower 80s with still low afternoon relative humidities...mostly
in the 30 to 40 percent range. Pattern changes little overnight 
and Thursday with some patchy fog in the valleys and near bodies

normal for this time of year. Thursday again warming to upper 70s 
to possibly as warm as mid 80s a degree or 2 warmer than today. 
Dew points might be slightly higher but no significant changes in 
relative humidities.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Tuesday)...
High pressure and dry weather will continue through the work week
with temperatures slowly creeping into the mid/low 80's by 
Saturday across the Tennessee Valley. Weather pattern remains 
relatively stagnant until the weekend when precipitation chances 
increase. High will shift far enough east that we get moist flow 
from the Gulf leading to increased clouds and (finally) some 
decent shower/thunderstorm chances. 

The second half of the weekend will see two systems battle against 
each other near our area. One system is a frontal boundary moving in 
from the northwest and the other will be the remnants of Tropical 
Depression 16. Long term models are still not in great agreement 
with how to handle this system at this time. ECMWF keeps the system 
in the Gulf longer and allows it to strengthen quite a bit before it 
makes landfall in the central Florida Panhandle. The GFS, on the 
other hand, wants to quickly bring the system into the Louisiana 
coast before zipping up towards us. Both models do show the remnants 
of this storm bringing precipitation to our area over the weekend 
and into next week. Will increase precipitation chances during this 
time frame, but QPF output from the models looks reasonable this far 
out. Models are hinting we could see 1-4 inches of rain over the 
weekend into next week, which our area should likely be able to 
handle with how dry we have been this past month.

FXUS64 KMRX 021859
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
259 PM EDT Mon Oct 2 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Tuesday)...
Clouds across the southern portions of the area have shown a
decreasing trend in satellite imagery in the past couple of hours,
so most of the area should have clear skies around sunset.
Considering how low temps dropped around the area last night, and
current observed dewpoints, MOS guidance seems on the warm side 
for lows. Perhaps there will be a bit more wind tonight than last
night, but will lean on the cooler side of guidance. High pressure
through the lower and midlevels will continue to extend across the
region tomorrow, so mostly clear skies and above normal
temperatures are expected to persist.

.LONG TERM (Tuesday night through Monday)...
Not much has changed with the long-term forecast. This weeks 
looks warm and dry with big model differences for the weekend.

Tuesday night through Friday look dry with high pressure in control 
early then becoming suppressed by Friday as our first system of 
interest draws closer. Highs during this time will be in the low to 
mid 80s with lows gradually becoming warmer each night. Starting out 
in the lower 50s Tuesday night and warming into the upper 50s by 
Friday night. As with yesterday's discussion, still watching an 
upper-level trough and associated frontal boundary for Friday. 
Latest run of the GFS has this front further to our north, which is 
more in line with what the ECMWF has been showing. This result keeps 
us dry on Friday with the boundary well to our north. 

Over the weekend the models really begin to disagree. On Saturday 
The GFS has another shortwave rotating through the Great Lakes with 
a trailing cold front through the Ohio River Valley and down across 
the Central Plains. Meanwhile an area of low pressure is moving 
northward out of the Gulf and into the Gulf Coast States. This area 
of low pressure advances northward Saturday night into Sunday and 
transports a considerable amount of moisture northward into our 
area. If this model solution is correct, we could be looking at a 
very rainy Saturday night through Monday. 

The ECWMF on the other hand is quite different. The shortwave on 
Saturday is more amplified and digs further south into the Ohio 
River Valley. This prevents the low in the Gulf from migrating 
northward and pushes it more NE toward the Coastal Carolinas. This 
path would keep us mostly precip free from the Saturday through 
Monday time-period. So for now, relied heavily on Superblend POPs 
for that stretch which yielded chance POPs across the board.

FXUS64 KMRX 020733

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
333 AM EDT Mon Oct 2 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
High pressure will continue to dominate the weather pattern today
with ridging anchored in place over the eastern US. Surface high
pressure will be centered over the northeast today, opening up 
our area to easterly flow at the surface. This will help usher
some Atlantic moisture and resultant cloud cover into the 
southern half of the Tennessee Valley today, but it will remain 
dry. The rest of the area will see mainly clear skies with 
downsloping winds off the mountains helping to suppress cloud 
cover. 

A bit more moisture overhead will help keep lows tonight a few
degrees warmer than the past nights, with most locations staying
in the lower 50s under mainly clear skies.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday)...
The main story over the week ahead will be dry and unseasonably warm 
weather as a ridge remains anchored across the Southeast CONUS. This 
ridge will be strongest on Tuesday and Wednesday with 500mb heights 
of around 594-595 dm. Surface high pressure across the Mid-Atlantic 
region will place our area under an easterly/southeasterly flow with 
downsloping across the western foothills of the Southern 
Appalachians resulting in dry conditions for our area. A quick 
shortwave moving across the Great Lakes begins to flatten the ridge 
by Wednesday night and Thursday. 

Model disagreement increases beyond Thursday with handling of 
another shortwave expected to pass across the Great Lakes region on 
Friday with a surface cold front digging southward across the Ohio 
River Valley. The 00Z GFS brings this front near our area by Friday 
and Saturday while the 00Z ECMWF keeps things dry with the front 
remaining to our north. Believe that with the current pattern we are 
in with such a strong ridge, it will be difficult for the front to 
make it this far south without a very strong shortwave and trough 
progressing further south toward our region. Will still keep slight 
chance PoPs across the the very northern fringes of the forecast 
area because of the low chance of a passing light rain shower with 
this front.

Model agreement next Saturday/Sunday is even worse. The 00Z GFS and 
ECMWF are both on completely different wavelengths with the upper-
level pattern. Both models show the potential for some rain showers 
across the region on Sunday, but for very different reasons. The GFS 
has the remnant surface front across the region with longwave 
troughing developing across the Eastern CONUS. The ECMWF has a 
lifting shortwave across the Upper Mississippi River Valley with 
limited moisture to our west and a tropical low to our southeast. 
Because of the potential for some weather systems to impact us next 
weekend with at least light precipitation, have slight chance PoPs 
for Sunday, but did lower PoPs substantially from guidance because 
of the high forecast uncertainty. With such varying solutions, 
forecast uncertainty for next weekend is higher than usual. 

As for temperatures, lower dewpoints and clear conditions will 
result in relatively large diurnal temperature swings with near 
normal lows and high temperatures about 5-10 degrees above normal 
through the work week. This weekend, increasing moisture and rising 
850mb temperatures results in both min and max temperatures about 5-
10 degrees above normal.

675 
FXUS64 KMRX 011900
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
300 PM EDT Sun Oct 1 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Monday)...
A midlevel ridge will continue to extend across the southern
Appalachian region through the period, with the center of high
pressure at the surface shifting slightly southward across the Mid
Atlantic region. Satellite shows an easterly fetch of moisture off
the Atlantic creating some cloud cover in southern GA, and as the
surface high drifts south, that cloud cover should spread north
and west. The NAM brings more clouds into our area than the GFS,
but both keep precip well to the SW. The forecast will bring some
clouds into southern sections late tonight and tomorrow morning. 
The rest of the area will have a downslope wind component that 
will maintain clear skies tomorrow.

.LONG TERM (Monday night through Sunday)...
Not much to talk about in the long term. High pressure dominates 
our weather through Wednesday with not a drop of rain in sight. 
Highs will be in the lower 80s with lows generally in the low to 
mid 50s. The positioning of the high will provide us with an 
easterly flow and dry air, so plenty of sunshine to come. 

Wednesday night into Thursday the high flattens and breaks down in 
response to an upper level trough swinging down across the Northern 
Plains and Great Lakes. We stay dry and sunny on Thursday but with 
the trough and weak front drawing closer. Highs again in the lower 
80s and lows in the mid to upper 50s Thursday night. Models differ 
on how they handle the trough and front. The GFS brings the front 
further south and closer to our area while the ECMWF keeps it well 
to our north. Even if the GFS is correct moisture associated with 
the front really weakens as it enters our area on Friday and most 
areas look to stay dry. Currently, only a slight chance POP in for 
portions of SWVA. 

Both models show another shortwave moving through in the 
Saturday/Sunday timeframe but positioning of this feature is vastly 
different between the two models. At this point, it's safe to say 
the high breaking down earlier in the week will allow for an 
increasing chance for POPs over the weekend but details remain 
unclear on what the weekend system will look like. For now, only 
have a slight chance POP in for SWVA on Saturday and slight chance 
across some of the high terrain on Sunday due to uncertainty. Temps 
will remain in the lower 80s on both days with lows in the upper 
50s to near 60. A general increase in cloud cover expected both
days.

451 
FXUS64 KMRX 010700
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
300 AM EDT Sun Oct 1 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
High pressure will continue to remain in control today with an
upper level ridge continuing to build across the eastern CONUS.
Resulting strong subsidence will yield sunny skies with dry air.
Under this abundant sunshine, highs this afternoon will again 
climb into the mid to upper 70s. Low dewpoints and clear skies 
tonight will allow temperatures to dip into the lower 50s across 
the southern valley and the 40s elsewhere.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)...
Bottom line...dry and unseasonably warm days with seasonal nights
through Thursday. Moisture gradually creeps back into the area 
with slightly increasing pcpn chances by the weekend.

Ridge axis remains anchored over the Eastern US through Wednesday 
before flattening out across the Ohio Valley Wednesday Night. Ridge 
then elongates east to west from the Mid Atlantic Coast across TN by 
Thursday Night as shortwave energy moving across the Great Lakes 
begins to break down the ridge. This finally allows for shortwave 
energy to influence our weather by the weekend. 

Disagreement remains on timing and position of surface front late 
week. Models range from ECMWF pushing front into the area Friday 
night to GFS keeping the front north of the area across the Ohio 
Valley through Saturday. Forecast remains a blend of these 
solutions.

Surface high pressure centered over the DELMARVA through mid-week 
will keep dry, downsloping easterly flow across the area. With it, 
daytime highs will reach about 5-7 degrees above normal for early 
October. Meanwhile, lower dewpoints will let overnight lows get to 
within 2-3 degree of normal making for some pleasant fall nights.

667 
FXUS64 KMRX 301847
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
247 PM EDT Sat Sep 30 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Sunday)...
A mild and dry pattern continues as a midlevel ridge will be
building over the region through this period. High and midlevel
clouds will be crossing the area through the evening, but they
will be decreasing as the ridge continues to build and a jet
streak moves away, with clear skies expected by midnight. This
should allow temps to drop a bit lower than last night, in the low
40s north to low 50s south. Highs tomorrow will again be in the
mid to upper 70s.

.LONG TERM (Sunday night through Saturday)...
An anomalously strong ridge over the eastern CONUS will result in 
continued dry, sunny conditions for the extended period across our 
area. At the surface, high pressure shifts to the east with tropical 
moisture on its southern edge across the Gulf Coast. A dry 
east/southeasterly low-level flow supporting downsloping and large 
scale subsidence keeps us dry. The upper ridge will be strongest 
midweek on Tuesday and Wednesday with 500mb heights of around 594 
dm, near record max heights. Later in the week, the ridge 
retrogrades and is suppressed southward. This will place the region 
under a dry westerly to northwesterly flow on Thursday and 
continuing into the weekend. There is the potential that a frontal 
boundary will approach the region late in the week or next weekend, 
but there is considerable uncertainty with timing and location. The 
most recent 12z GFS favors a solution where the front never makes it 
south of the Ohio River Valley and the 12z ECMWF is quicker with a 
frontal boundary dropping southward and approaching our area Friday 
night. Even though the ECMWF does bring the front closer to the 
area, a predominantly westerly flow will limit moisture return and 
keep PoPs very low. Both models are consistent with the overall dry 
pattern through the week.

Expect temperatures to be generally about 10 degrees above normal 
for the upcoming workweek under the strong ridge. With clear skies 
and dry air, large diurnal temperature swings are likely with 
minimum temperatures into the 50s (and even the upper 40s across the 
terrain) overnight.

260 
FXUS64 KMRX 291847
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
247 PM EDT Fri Sep 29 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Saturday)...There is just enough moisture 
and lift in an area of convergence associated with an inverted 
trough along the Appalachian spine for the formation of a narrow 
layer of strato cumulus mainly east of interstates 75 and 81 this 
afternoon. There may even be a brief shower over the higher 
terrain with the added support of orographic lift. Would expect 
the layer to gradually dissipate toward evening leaving a mostly 
clear sky in place. Cooler air which has filtered into the region 
will continue to slip south behind another weak frontal boundary 
due in the region overnight. The cooler push and some radiation 
will lead to low temperatures in the upper 40s across the northern
third of the forecast area to the 50s over the remainder of the 
region. Another beautiful Saturday is in store with dry air 
compliments of the prevailing northerly flow. The abundant 
sunshine will boost high temperatures to the upper 60s and lower 
70s across Southwest Virginia and northern sections of the 
Cumberland Plateau while much of the remainder of the forecast 
area warms into the middle and upper 70s.

.LONG TERM (Saturday night through Friday)... A high amplitude 
midlevel ridge will be dominating the eastern Conus through the 
first half of next week. The surface high will drift from the 
Great Lakes to New England through Monday, and the easterly fetch 
off the Atlantic may spread some moisture across GA on Monday. The
NAM brings some precip to our GA/TN border counties, but other 
models keep it well to our south, and will go with that drier 
solution. Temps will be near normal on Sunday, rising to 3-6 
degrees above normal by Tuesday underneath the strong ridge. 

The upper ridge peaks on Tuesday, then retrogrades and gets 
suppressed southward through the rest of the week. This may open up 
an opportunity for a cold front to affect the area on Friday. 
However, the Gulf never opens up ahead of it as the ridge over TX 
will extend along the Gulf Coast. With the air mass ahead of the 
front expected to remain dry and stable, the forecast will take a 
skeptical approach to any rain chances with the front, and will 
remain precip-free on Friday.

.LONG TERM (Saturday through Thursday)...

ridge building across the eastern US. Resultant strong subsidence 
will mean clear skies and dry air for the forecast area. This 
combination will finally result in a bit of a taste of fall with 
mild days of highs in the 70s and cooler nights due to radiational 
cooling. The coldest night appears to be Saturday night/Sunday 
morning with temperatures dipping into the mid 40s across southwest 
Virginia and far northeast Tennessee. With anomalously strong 
ridging continuing into next week, highs will again climb into the 
upper 70s/lower 80s by Tuesday. 

Surface high pressure and weak flow will suppress precipitation 
chances, and at this point, rain is not expected through at least 
midweek. October is climatologically our driest month, so this is 
not overly surprising. However, fuel moisture has been decreasing 
recently, and continued lower RHs will further dry fuels.

636 
FXUS64 KMRX 281905
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
305 PM EDT Thu Sep 28 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Friday)...A weak cold frontal boundary is
making its way south across the forecast area at mid afternoon.
There may be an isolated, brief sprinkle in a spot or two along
the boundary or on a mountain peak this afternoon; otherwise, the
forecast remains benign with a partly cloudy sky tonight followed
by a mostly sunny day on Friday with a light northerly wind. 
Additionally, patchy fog may form across the northern reaches of 
the forecast area where temperatures dip into the 50s late 
tonight. 

.LONG TERM (Friday night through Thursday)...On Saturday, upper 
trough axis across the Northeast CONUS will transition off of the 
East Coast with ridging at the surface and aloft building in 
across the region. This will place the area under strong 
subsidence resulting in a clear sky and dry air through the air 
column. PWs at the surface are expected to be low between 0.25- 
0.5 inch which is approaching the 10th percentile of climatology. 
The low boundary layer moisture and clear conditions means we'll 
see large diurnal temperature swings with cool nights and pleasant
afternoons. While RH will be low and further contribute to drying
of fuels, winds are expected to be weak with high pressure in 
control. Temperatures this weekend will be closer to normal.

The upper ridge continues to strengthen Monday through Wednesday of 
next week with 500mb heights of 594-596 dm, around the 97th-99th 
percentile compared to climatology. Concurrently, surface high 
pressure will shift eastward resulting in a more southerly component 
to low-level flow. However, moisture return looks questionable and 
potentially limited to southern areas of the forecast area because 
of downsloping across the mountains, especially across northeast 
Tennessee and southwest Virginia where downsloping would be expected 
to be strongest. While there could be a stray rain shower across 
southern portions of the CWA early in the week as some slightly 
higher moisture arrives, the continued subsidence, weak flow, and 
low instability make PoPs unlikely. Any isolated rain shower which 
manages to defy the odds will be constrained to live a short life 
across the higher terrain. High temperatures next week should 
generally be about 8-13 degrees above normal with anomalously strong 
ridging in place.

The main story for the long term is the continued dry weather with 
ridging dominating the Eastern CONUS. Fuel moisture has been 
decreasing recently, and lower RH through the weekend will further 
dry fuels. As we head into October, our climatologically driest 
month of the year, this pattern of dry weather looks like it will 
continue.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
259 PM EDT Wed Sep 27 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Thursday)...
With continued ridging across the Eastern CONUS and warm, moist 
air across the region, minimum temperatures tonight should remain 
10-15 degrees above normal. We may once again have some patchy fog
development near favored locations such as area lakes and rivers.

Troughing across the Great Lakes will act to move an area of low
pressure across the Northeast CONUS and drag a trailing cold 
front across our area on Thursday. The front first reaches the 
northwest corner of the forecast area on Thursday morning and 
travels southeastward through the day. As the result of a dry 
northerly flow ahead of the front, don't expect much, if any, 
precipitation. The main impact for our area will be a cooler and 
much drier airmass behind the front with lower relative humidity.
We'll say goodbye to the near-record highs in the short term with
max temperatures still expected to be above normal on Thursday 
ranging from the upper 70s to mid 80s for most areas.

.LONG TERM (Thursday night through Wednesday)...
H5 shortwave will move through the Great Lakes during the late 
week and help usher cooler air into our region, dropping 
temperatures to near normal values into the new work week. But 
once we get to next week, the models begin to diverge in their 
solutions, with the ECMWF maintaining a stronger ridge of high 
pressure over the southeastern U.S. than does the GFS or Canadian.
In fact, the Canadian lifts the ridge center to NJ/NY by middle 
of next week, opening us up to increased moisture here; but GFS 
and ECMWF focus the ridge over Arkansas, keeping us dry, and that 
looks to be the likely scenario. The ECMWF would only be warmer. 
Thus, rain chances are too low to carry any mention of precip 
throughout the extended.

convection anticipated for Thursday's frontal passage.

northwest winds dropping PWs to 0.5-0.75 inch for the weekend.

Upper trough lifts out for Sunday into early next week with ridging 
aloft strengthening. Dry conditions and warmer thickness/850mb 
temperatures will produce dry afternoon relative humidity for early 
next week.

late Thursday and Thursday night.  Due to the persistent mid-level 
warm air associated with upper ridge and limited Gulf moisture 
return into the Tennessee valley, instability along and ahead of the 
front will be limited. Overall, front will move across the area dry.

Main effects from front passage will be cooler 850mb temperatures 
for the weekend. Cooler and more seasonal temperatures are expected 
for Friday through Sunday.

For Friday, an inverted trough into western North Carolina will keep 
a slight chance of showers for southwest North Carolina.

Upper trough lifts for late Saturday with riding re-establishing 
itself for next Sunday.

Due to continued dry ground across much of the area, will remain on 
the warmer side of guidance for highs through the extended.

scenarios. KTRI has the best chances of being affected, and will 
go close to persistence with BR forecast for several hours. 
Thursday morning the vsby went down to 1/2 mile very briefly--will
take it down to 1SM this morning. At KTYS and KCHA might have 
some light fog briefly, but will keep them at P6SM, since they are
not in as favorable location as KTRI for this localized scenario.
By around 12z, the fog should mix out pretty quickly at KTRI as 
the sun warms the surface. This afternoon, storms are expected to

week...keeping moisture available...especially in areas south of 
I40. A weak boundary will move through the area on Wednesday...with 
scattered showers and thunderstorms possible in the afternoon. Lift 
will be weak...but enough instability will be present that can't 
count out convection developing. PW values are around the 90th 
percentile in far southern plateau...southern valley...and southwest 
NC...so would expect the greatest chance for development in these 
areas.

Behind the front...low level high pressure sets up over the Gulf 
Coast states...while an upper level trough and associated low 
pressure develop. Wednesday night...winds behind the frontal 
boundary will allow for northerly flow to briefly set up over the 
area through Thursday night with PW values decreasing to between the 
median average and 75th percentile. With instability also 
lowered...would expect only scattered showers and isolated 
thunderstorms to develop. 

By Friday morning...low level flow will transition to out of the 
east due to the flow around the low level high pressure. This will 
allow for greater warm air and moisture advection to areas south of 
I40 through Saturday. Upper level forcing will be weak Friday and 
Saturday...but enough moisture and instability will be present for 
weak diurnal showers and isolated thunderstorms to develop each 
afternoon. The greatest chance for this convection will be in areas 
south of I40 where the greatest advection is located. 

Sunday and Monday...the upper level trough will be east of the 
Appalachians...and moving towards Hurricane Maria which is expected 
to be off the FL coast. High pressure behind this trough will allow 
for mostly clear skies and dry weather to remain through the
weekend.

little movement from anything that does form.

out of the east...with diurnal showers and thunderstorms possible

slightly more moisture is present to warrant chance precip chances 
in areas south of I40 and slight chance precip chances in areas 
north of I40.

Little change in airmass through the extended will keep temperatures 
in the upper 70s to mid 80s each day. Temperatures could cool a 
couple of degrees behind the frontal boundary passage Wednesday into 
Thursday...with temperatures near normal through the end of the 
weekend.

Disturbance, now out in the middle of the Atlantic, about 12N/47W.

temperature will be about 1-3 degrees warmer on Saturday.

.LONG TERM (Saturday night through Friday)...

weekend and through the upcoming work week. Warm weather will be 
mostly brought on by a ridge of high pressure expected to sit over 
the southern United States/Mexico throughout the forecast. It will 
not be a particularly strong ridge, but will help keep widespread 
showers/thunderstorms out of the area. Temperatures through the long 
term portion of the forecast are expected to max out about 1-5 
degrees above normal for this time of year, and aiding this warmer 
weather will be the mostly sunny to partly cloudy skies as well. 
That being said there are a few chances for rain in the forecast...A 
few days we could see enough Gulf moisture get trapped under the 
ridge and warm enough temperatures that some showers/thunderstorms 
could develop over the higher terrain. More widespread rain chances 
will come in the second half of the work week as the ridge begins to 
break down as a trough moves in from the west. With the weakening 
ridge we could see some more widespread precipitation in the 
afternoon, but chances remain relatively low. Much better chances 
for rainfall will come just beyond the end of this 7-day forecast as 
the trough continues to move closer.

cloudy and seasonably cool day with highs in the 70s. The mass of
moisture over the region will be lifted into a pattern of widely 
scattered to scattered light showers with a greater likelihood of
seeing some of the light rain over the northern third of the 
forecast area. There will still be a little light rain around 
tonight; mainly in this same northern section but any 
precipitation will be fading away after midnight.

.LONG TERM (Friday through Wednesday)...The main story for the 
long term period will be the abrupt shift to abnormally warm 
temperatures over the weekend. A large high pressure ridge will be
over the Southeast through most of the period, providing dry 
conditions, mostly clear skies, and high temperatures that are 
expected to be 3-6 degrees above normal for mid-September - quite 
a change from the cool temperatures we have had so far this month.
Toward the end of the period, the models differ on the potential 
breakdown of the ridge, with the ECMWF being faster to do so that 
the GFS, and bring a front into the OH Valley. The latest trend 
suggests this front will stay well to our north as it runs into 
the Southeast ridge , so will drop the PoPs from Tuesday and have 
just a slight chance for Wednesday.

spell of below normal temps of late, above normal temps will return, 
with highs in the lower to mid 80s for most of the Valley for Friday 
through Tuesday. There is model disagreement on the handling of Jose 
and how fast the ridge breaks down next week. With uncertainty high, 
will maintain the previous forecast of slight chance PoPs on Monday 
and Tuesday associated with the suppression of the ridge and the 
approach of a weak front depicted by the ECMWF.

532 
FXUS64 KMRX 120851 AAA
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion...UPDATED
National Weather Service Morristown TN
451 AM EDT Tue Sep 12 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...Tropical depression Irma is over
East Central Alabama early this morning and will again be the main
driver of weather conditions over the forecast area today. The
higher resolution mesoscale models do a better job of showing how
important that expanse of higher terrain along the Tennessee and 
North Carolina border is in limiting rainfall intensity across 
much of the Great Valley when a strong easterly flow is present in
the region. Irma will provide those easterly winds today 
generating more warming and drying in the first few thousand feet 
off the surface. Therefore, tried to scale back pops a bit for 
showers today from Central East Tennessee northeast through the 
Tri-cities area. Maintained likely or categorical pops on higher 
terrain features and across much of Southeast Tennessee and 
Southwest North Carolina where upslope flow, and less mountainous 
terrain upstream won't allow for the adiabatic warming seen 
farther north through the Great Valley. The probability of 
precipitation will be gradually decreasing through the day and 
into the overnight hours for the entire region as Irma continues 
to drift away to the west. Wind speed will continue to be a factor
through late morning in the lower elevations and should continue 
a little while longer into the early afternoon for higher terrain.
Therefore, kept the wind advisory in place today. High 
temperatures will be well below normal in the 60s across much of 
Southeast Tennessee, Southwest North Carolina, and on the 
Cumberland Plateau today. It won't be quite as cool farther 
northeast through the valley with highs ranging from the upper 60s
to the lower and middle 70s.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday)...The mid/upper level 
circulation will track NE from West TN across the OH Valley on 
Wednesday and Wednesday night. Model soundings show deep moisture 
for the western half of our area, while the eastern half will be 
under a downslope southerly flow and under the dry slot of the 
jet. Thus there is expected to be a sharp gradient of rain chances
and QPF on Wednesday (likely west, slight chance east). As the 
circulation reaches OH, the flow turns more SW and the jet moves 
to our east, which should end the downslope flow and bring rising 
PoPs (likely) for the evening for northern sections. With little 
dynamic forcing and saturation below 500 mb, light rain/drizzle is
expected. Precip will end Thursday morning from SW to NE as the 
low pulls farther away. 

Through the rest of the forecast period, a large high pressure 
ridge will be building over the Midwest, with a gradually 
eastward movement. This will provide dry conditions and mostly 
clear skies each day, with temperatures warming closer to normal 
or slightly above normal for this time of year, in the upper 70s 
to mid 80s for highs.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
321 PM EDT Mon Sep 11 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tomorrow)...
Irma will continue to impact the area through Tuesday. Not much
change vs. previous forecast with regards to impacts for our area.
The low pressure center is expected to track across GA and AL
towards west TN through Tuesday. Winds will continue to increase 
through the rest of the afternoon and evening hours, topping out
with gusts over 50 mph across the highest terrain. Valley
locations will likely see gusts of 40-50 mph. A wind advisory
remains in effect through tomorrow afternoon for the entire
forecast area. Already seeing some gusts over 40mph in the higher
terrain of NE GA/SW NC, so will have to continue to monitor
observations throughout the evening to ensure gusts stay below
high wind warning criteria at the highest elevations. Latest QPF 
forecast from WPC indicates a period of heavier rain across the 
lower Cumberland Plateau from 00-06Z, so have increased storm 
total rainfall amounts slightly across this area to just around 3"
in Marion County. With this event being of a longer duration, 
river levels and soil moisture should be able to handle this 
amount without widespread flooding problems, although localized 
heavier amounts are possible and will need to be monitored. Drier 
air wrapping around the circulation and a continued downslope flow
off the mountains on Tuesday will result in lowering rain chances
and lighter precip for most areas.


.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...The remnants of 
Irma are expected to be centered around the MS Valley Tuesday 
night and will lift northeast Wednesday through Thursday night. We
should continue to see clouds/showers especially western portions
of the area Tue night into early Wednesday, then spreading across
the rest of the area later Wednesday and especially Wed night 
before diminishing from southwest to northeast Thursday/Thursday 
night. Will carry highest PoPs Wed night most areas. High pressure
surface and aloft is forecast to build in behind this system, 
with drier conditions expected for the Friday through Monday time 
frame.

373 
FXUS64 KMRX 110721
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
321 AM EDT Mon Sep 11 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today through Tuesday)...
Not much has changed in the expected impacts of Irma over East TN.
The low pressure center is expected to take a turn toward the NW
and track across SW GA to N AL to West TN through Tuesday.
Easterly low level winds north of the circulation will increase
sharply around midday today - up to 55 kts at 850 mb at 00Z - 
creating a downslope flow that will likely create a precip shadow 
for the northern and central TN Valley into the evening. The main 
change from previous forecasts will be to lower QPF amounts in 
that area. Southern Valley locations are still expected to have 
storm total amounts of 2-2.5 inches. With a duration of 12 hours 
or more, river levels and soil moisture should be able to handle 
this amount without widespread flooding problems, although 
localized heavier amounts are possible and will need to be 
monitored. The Wind Advisory will not be changed, although the 
northern and central Valley, SW VA, and northern Plateau will 
likely be on the low end of Advisory criteria (26 mph sustained or
40 mph gust). Dry air wrapping around the circulation and a 
continued downslope flow on Tuesday will result in lowering rain 
chances and much lighter precip for all areas.

.LONG TERM (Tuesday night through Sunday)...
The low pressure of the remnants of Irma are expected to be 
around the MS Valley Tuesday night through Wednesday morning. SW 
flow will be over the area from this low...keeping enough low and 
mid level clouds around for mostly cloudy skies through most of 
the day Wednesday. The low pressure will then begin to move to the
northeast By Wednesday night...moving close enough to the 
southern Appalachians to bring a brief period of moisture to the 
area. Scattered showers are possible moving southwest to northeast
through the area Wednesday night through Thursday morning. 

As the low pressure makes its way north of the area Thursday 
afternoon...low and mid level flow will transition to out of the 
west. This will limit the moisture advection to the area and allow 
for higher pressure to develop along the Gulf coast states. Plenty 
of dry air will then move into the upper levels...limiting cloud 
cover and allowing temperatures to slowly warm each day to near 
normal. Friday afternoon...enough instability is present for diurnal 
showers and isolated thunder along the higer elevations. 

Saturday and Sunday...a frontal boundary associated with a trough 
moving through the Great Lakes will begin to move through the MS 
Valley and approach the area. With this boundary to the west...and 
Jose forging a path through the Atlantic through the east...the 
southern Appalachians will be under high pressure. Clear skies and 
warm temperatures are expected through both days. 

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
Chattanooga Airport, TN             67  61  67  60 / 100 100  70  40 
Knoxville McGhee Tyson Airport, TN  67  60  75  60 /  90 100  30  30 
Oak Ridge, TN                       66  58  73  60 /  80 100  40  30 
Tri Cities Airport, TN              69  59  77  58 /  60  70  30  30 

&&

.MRX WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
NC...Wind Advisory from 11 AM this morning to 2 PM EDT Tuesday for

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
318 PM EDT Sun Sep 10 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and tomorrow)...
Quiet and pleasant weather will continue for one more day as 
sunny skies, dry air, and light winds out of the north continue to
be the main story. Once again temperatures will likely be similar
to what we saw yesterday. As we move into tonight and especially 
into tomorrow our weather pattern will start to be dominated by 
whatever remains of Hurricane Irma. Will likely begin to see an 
increase in mid/low level clouds tomorrow, and as we move into 
the afternoon hours the precipitation and winds will begin to pick
up. Precipitation will begin in the south and spread northward as
the afternoon continues. The winds are a bit tougher to time out,
especially with the more complex terrain in our forecast area. 
Current forecast soundings and models suggest that 850mb winds 
will be pretty strong (definitely in wind advisory criteria and 
some of the highest elevations could see high wind warning 
criteria met as well). Have the entire forecast area in a wind 
advisory tomorrow, but have the higher terrain of the Southern 
Appalachian mountains starting their wind advisory a bit earlier 
and continuing longer than the advisory down in the Valley 
counties. 

.LONG TERM (Tomorrow night through Saturday)...
Categorical and likely POPs to start the period as the now 
depression, formerly known as Irma, moves northward into Georgia 
and then Alabama Monday night. Moderate to locally heavy rainfall 
possible to start the night Monday but transitioning to 
light/moderate showers late in the night/early Tuesday morning as 
downsloping winds over our eastern mountains help to dry us out a 
little. Still looks like the southern valley and southwest NC will
see the highest rainfall totals Monday night with amounts from 1 
to 1.5 inches. NETN and SWVA should see the least with around a 
quarter of an inch. The central valley will see around half an 
inch. Again, some areas along the foothills may only end up with a
few tenths of an inch due to strong downsloping winds. 

A wind advisory has now been issued for our whole CWA as the wind-
field from the depression remains quite strong over our area, which 
is largely due to the tight pressure gradient that sets up because of 
an area of high pressure to our north and the depression to our 
west. Winds will gust between 30 and 40 mph across valley locations, 
40 to 50 mph across elevations above 3000 feet, and potentially up 
to 60 mph above 5000 feet. On Tuesday the center of the circulation 
drifts toward Memphis and showers become lighter and more 
intermittent across our area with winds settling down by Tuesday 
afternoon. Clouds and cool temps will remain across areas west of I-
75 with perhaps a peak of sunshine or two across far NETN and SWVA 
Tuesday afternoon as some drier air tries to work in. Because of 
this, the western portions of our CWA will have temps in the upper 
60s to low 70s while eastern areas will be in the mid to upper 70s. 

Tuesday night the low wobbles further west, brining potential 
clearing further west into our CWA. Lows will be in the upper 50s 
Tuesday night. The first half of Wednesday looks dry but then POP 
chances increase later in the day as the low begins to lift 
northward into Western KY. Far eastern areas, NETN and SWVA, should 
see a decent amount of sunshine early Wednesday before clouds take 
over late in the day. High temps trends on Wednesday similar to 
Tuesday. POPs and clouds increase for all areas Wednesday night into 
Thursday as the low begins to pull further east across KY. Still 
some low-end POPs in place on Friday as the low is generally 
centered across our area, although much weaker now. Temps on Friday 
back into the upper 70s. Slight chance POPs over the high terrain 
for Saturday and Sunday but dry elsewhere as high pressure is trying 
to work its way back into the area. Highs will be in the lower 80s 
with lows in the lower to mid 60s.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
307 AM EDT Sun Sep 10 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and tonight)...
One more pleasant day for East TN before we begin to feel the
effects of Irma's remains. Winds in the 925-700 mb layer will be
at an easterly direction, creating a downslope flow that will help
warm temps in the Valley a little. With this and mostly sunny
skies, highs should reach into the 75 to 80 range in most spots.
High clouds on the fringes of Irma may begin to increase late
tonight in southern portions of the area. 

.LONG TERM (Monday through Saturday)...
NHC has the track of Hurricane Irma moving through GA and across 
northern AL. Because of the increased time over land ahead of 
Irma's much anticipated arrival...wind speeds and moisture will be
slightly lower than our states to the south...and the time period
of heavy rain and gusty winds will therefore be slightly shorter 
than previously forecasted. 

Wind speeds and rain accumulation totals are expected to increase 
from east to west across the Southern Appalachians beginning early 
Monday afternoon. By Tuesday morning...the rainfall accumulation and 
wind speeds will have reached the peak values. The greatest chance 
for higher wind gusts and highest rain accumulation will be in areas 
south of I40...as well as the higher elevations of eastern TN. 
Prevailing winds of around 25-35 kts are expected...along gusts 
around 40-50 mph. Rainfall accumulation totals will be between 2-4 
inches with locally higher amounts possible if the rain bands bring 
strong showers across the same area. Areas north of I40 will be 
farther away from the center of the low...and with less dynamics and 
moisture. Wind speeds will be between 15-25 mph with gusts around 30-
40 mph. Rainfall accumulations will around 1-2 inches. With these 
wind speeds across the entire area, several trees and powerlines 
could be knocked down...as well as localized power outages. The 
rainfall accumulation totals could cause flooding 
problems...especailly in areas that do not drain well or have a 
history of flooding. 

The system then continues to weaken and move east...and will then 
take most of the moisture and lift with it temporarily...allowing 
for only light scattered showers to remain through late Tuesday 
night through much of Wednesday. Wednesday night through Thursday 
afternoon...models are fairly consistent on this low getting picked 
up by an upper level trough moving through the northern Ohio Valley. 
Rain chances will increase one last time from SW to NE as the 
remnants of Irma shoot to the NE and become an event of the past. 

Friday and Saturday...diurnal showers are possible...with the 
greatest chances on the Plateau and higher elevations of east 
TN...as well as NE TN and SW VA. Mid and low level flow will be from 
the SW...keeping a decent amount of moisture over the area. 

Temperatures will be at least 10 degrees below normal from Monday 
through Wednesday due to the cloud cover and rain showers. By 
Thursday...a gradual warming trend will be in place as clouds begin 
to clear and SW flow slowly brings warm and moist air to the area.

FXUS64 KMRX 091851
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
251 PM EDT Sat Sep 9 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today through tomorrow)...
We continue the quiet and pleasant weather today with similar
conditions to what we saw yesterday. Light winds, generally out of
the north, will help to keep things cool and dry with temperatures
expected to remain about 5 - 10 degrees below normal for this time
of year. Only a few minor tweaks were made to the short term
portion of the forecast.

.LONG TERM (Tomorrow night through Friday)...
The period starts off quiet but that quickly changes as we await 
Irma's remnants to advance northward into the East Tennessee 
Valley. Clear skies Sunday night with lows in the lower to mid 
50s. The latest model guidance, along with updates from the NHC, 
suggests that Irma drifts a little further west than in previous 
runs as it moves up through Georgia. Now the center of the 
circulation is forecast to cross over into Northern Alabama. This 
westward movement will affect the weather conditions we receive 
here in the E TN Valley which will be discussed below.


The first impacts we see from Irma, which will likely be a 
depression by the time it reaches us, will be from it's wind-field. 
The latest run of the NAM shows the winds picking up across our 
eastern mountains early monday morning. Clouds and precip chances 
begin to increase during the late morning hours and continue 
to do so through the rest of the day.

Winds: The highest winds look to occur 00z Tuesday through around 
15z Tuesday. Valley locations south of I-40 could see winds from 20 
to 25 mph with gusts up to 40 mph. Valley locations north of I-40 
could see winds from 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 30 mph. 
Elevations between 3000 and 5000 feet could see gusts between 40 and 
50 mph while elevations above 5000 feet could see gusts up to 60 
mph. There may also be a period where we see some mountain waves as 
the 850mb flow becomes perpendicular to our eastern mountains. There 
are still some uncertainties though with a mountain wave event 
because soundings show us losing the necessary inversion before the 
winds turn to allow for the preferred perpendicular component. If we 
were to get mountain waves it would occur sometime between 06z 
Tuesday and 15Z Tuesday for about a 6 hour period as this is when 
the winds are ideal. 

Precip: The highest POPs are in place beginning 00z Tuesday and 
lasting through about 15z Tuesday, coinciding with the highest winds. 
The latest westward shift may lower QPF amounts slightly across our 
area. It does still appear that the southern valley will see the 
higher precip amounts with SWNC seeing the highest. Current forecast 
is 2 to 3 inches across the southern valley and 2 to 4 across SWNC. 
Areas just north of I-40 1 to 2 inches but only half an inch to 1 
inch across portions of NETN and SWVA. As the event draws closer it 
does look some areas along and near the foothills of our eastern 
mountains may not end up with very much precip due to strong 
downsloping winds. The past few runs of the GFS and NAM have picked 
up on this and show little precip along the foothills north of I-40 
and up into NETN and SWVA. These favored downsloping areas could see 
as little as a few tenths of an inch of precip but we will have a 
better idea over the next few model runs.


POP chance drop Tuesday afternoon as showers become more 
intermittent. With the westward movement of the system, we may 
actually see peaks of sunshine late Tuesday as some drier air tries 
to work in across our area. The westward shift now keeps the early 
portion of Wednesday a little drier with the higher POP chances in 
place later in the day on Wednesday as the now area of the low 
pressure moves back to the east. We could see some sunshine early on 
Wednesday too. Better chances for showers on Thursday as the low 
moves further east. The same story continues on for Friday with the 
low not pulling out of the area until Friday night. As of now, 
Saturday looks like a pretty nice day. 

If the more western tracks holds, it would mean periods of lesser 
POP chances and cloud cover between Tuesday afternoon and Wednesday 
afternoon than previously forecast. We will continue to adjust based 
on the latest NHC track. Temperatures warm later in the period when 
the low pulls east.

.SHORT TERM (Today and Sunday)...

.LONG TERM (Sunday night through Friday)...
Irma is expected to weaken to winds that equal a strong Tropical 
Depression by the time the system reaches the Southern 
Appalachians. With the center of this low expected to around west 
central GA by Monday afternoon into the evening...winds will begin
to increase across the area. By Monday night...Irma approaches

Rain arrival will be slightly delayed from the increased wind 
speeds...with chances beginning along the higher elevations Monday 
night...and moving into the valley by early Tuesday morning. 
Expecting widespread rain showers through the day Tuesday...with the 
greatest accumulations of 2-4 inches expected through the day 
Tuesday. Localized flooding is possible across the entire 
area...with the greatest chance in areas south of I40.  

Tuesday night...the low pressure begins to fall apart with drier 
upper level air filtering into the area. At this point...the 
convection will become more diurnal in nature...with scattered 
showers expected Wednesday and Thursday afternoon. With the decrease 
in moisture...expect any rainfall accumulations to be a couple of 
tenths of an inch to half an inch over both days. By Friday 
night...the low tries to get picked up by a passing upper level 
trough over the Ohio Valley. 

Temperatures will cool to around 10 degrees below normal beginning 
Monday night...as the cloud cover increases and moisture arrives 
from Irma. These cooler temperatures will remain through Thursday... 
until the low is far enough to the west of the Southern Appalachians 
that SW flow around this low is able to bring more warm air and 
moisture advection to the area to warm temperatures to only a 
few degrees below normal for this time of year.

rivers and lakes, but widespread fog is not anticipated. On
Saturday, subsidence continues to result in a mostly clear sky.
850mb temperatures are expected to be a degree or two higher than

warmer than max temperatures on Friday. Still, highs should be 5-8
degrees below normal.

.LONG TERM (Saturday night through Friday)...
Pleasant conditions 
over the weekend with high pressure in control. Lows on Saturday 
night will be in the low 50s for most places along with clear skies. 
Plenty of sun again on Sunday with temperatures in the mid 70s for 
most areas. 

Monday starts off nice but conditions will slowly take a turn for the 
worse as the day progresses as Irma approaches from the south. By 
the time the initial rain bands make it into our area Irma will 
likely have become a depression by then. The first bands of rain 
look to move in late Monday afternoon/early evening. Monday night 
POPs increase to categorical/Likely as Irma moves northward through 
Georgia. The bulk of our precip looks like it will occur Monday 
night through Tuesday morning. During this time, areas north of I-40 
can generally expect to receive 1 to 2 inches of rain with isolated 
amounts up to 3. Areas south of I-40 can expect between 1.5 to 2.5 
with isolated amounts up to 3.5 inches. Some locations along the 
foothills may receive lesser rain amounts due to downsloping winds.
 
Winds will start to pick up with the onset of the initial rain band 
Monday night. Most valley locations will see gusts between 20 and 30 
mph while the higher elevations (3000 to 5000 feet) will see gusts 
up to 40 mph. However, elevations over 5000 feet could see gusts up 
to 50 mph. The highest winds will begin to subside late Tuesday 
morning but will remain breezy through the rest of the day. By 
Tuesday afternoon POP chances will begin to decrease from NE to SW 
as the circulation from Irma wobbles to the west and starts to 
become stretched out and elongated.

The circulation doesn't move much over the next few days but it is 
much weaker than when it first entered into our area. So from 
Tuesday night through Thursday night, expect chance POPs for most 
areas with intermittent rain showers, plenty of clouds, and below 
normal temperatures. By Friday remnants of Irma pull east of us, 
bringing out the sun along with rising temps. Temps on Friday will 
be in the upper 70s to near 80. The coolest temps of the period will 
occur on Tuesday and Wednesday, with highs in the upper 60s to near 
70 which is around 15 degrees below normal.

.LONG TERM (Saturday through Thursday)...

each day...reaching near normal by Sunday afternoon. 

Hurricane Irma still has a variable track and confidence is still 
low on the degree of impacts Irma will bring to the area. NHC 
currently has a track that moves across FL and GA before moving into 
middle TN. With this track...Irma will be over land enough to weaken 
the sustained winds by the time Irma reaches northern GA. 

With the track forecasting the center of Irma to move just to the SW 
of the Southern Plateau...the highest wind speeds and rainfall 
accumulation are expected to be located in areas south of 
I40...and the higher elevations of east TN. Winds will begin to 
increase late Monday morning into the afternoon...with rain 
chances increasing by Monday afternoon. By Tuesday morning...winds
are expected to reach their peak...lasting through much of the 
day. Winds of up to 30-40 mph are possible in area south of I40 
with gusts of around 50 mph. Areas north of I40 could still see 
winds of 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 40 mph. Tuesday 
night...winds will decrease as the remnants of Irma stall across 
the TN Valley. 

For rainfall...the rain is expected to last through Wednesday 
morning as Irma slows its movement. Rainfall accumulation totals of 
3-5 inches are possible across the area. Although the Southern 
Appalachians is moving into the driest time of year...and river 
levels have been at or below average for this time of 
year...localized flooding is a possibility especially in areas that 
receive several rainbands of heavier showers. Rain showers will 
become lighter and more scattered Wednesday afternoon through 
Thursday as an upper level trough moving through the Ohio Valley 
will influence the remnants of Irma and begin move all instability 
and lift east of the Appalachians.

Details on area and amount of wind speeds and rain totals will 
change and will udpate as each model run tracks Irma.

Moisture and clouds will increase through the weekend into Monday 
morning...as Hurricane Irma approaches the area.

Uncertainty in the track still remains for Hurricane Irma. 
Widespread showers are expected to begin to impact the Appalachians 
Monday...with area of coverage slowly moving westward through Monday 
night and Tuesday....with the biggest question being how far west 
through the Valley and Plateau these showers will reach.  Models 
have been consistent enough in bringing Irma across the Carolinas 
and close to the Southern Appalachians to warrant likely precip 
chances along SW VA...NE TN...eastern TN Valley...and SW NC 
beginning Tuesday. PW values are around 90th percentile Monday night 
through Tuesday...with consistent rain accumulation being the main 
threat. Instability is low...so only mention of thunder was to 
include slight chance for Tuesday afternoon.

607 
FXUS64 KMRX 051914
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
314 PM EDT Tue Sep 5 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Wednesday)...
Longwave trough deepens across the Eastern CONUS tonight and
Wednesday with an associated surface cold front expected to move
through the forecast area late tonight. Ahead of this front,
likely to categorical PoPs are expected. PW values of 1.8  2.0
inches across central and southern portions of the forecast area
this evening will combine with residual outflow boundaries, a pre-
frontal trough, frontal forcing, and our position within the right
front entrance of the upper-jet streak to promote strong lift
across the entire region with the focus for heavier precipitation
across central and southern portions of eastern Tennessee late 
this afternoon. May have some localized flooding with some of the 
heavier precipitation, especially if it begins to form and train 
along some of the remaining outflow boundaries from earlier 
convection. The severe weather threat is low, but with HRRR model 
forecast SBCAPE of up to 2000 J/Kg and effective shear of 20-30 kt
across central and southern portions of the area, we may have 
some damaging wind gusts with the strongest convection.

After sunset, most of the convection should be to our east with 
lingering rain showers until the front passes through between 06z 
and 12z tonight. Temperatures will remain mild early tonight but 
cool off late tonight and Wednesday morning as the front moves 
east and drier and cooler air begins to filter in. 

With the front east of us on Wednesday, will have slight chance
PoPs of a few light rain showers early in the day with drier
conditions in the afternoon. The only exception will be across the
TN/NC mountains where upslope flow and steep low-level lapse rates
may lead to some scattered rain showers across the higher terrain
on Wednesday afternoon. PW values behind the front drop quickly to
around 0.5  0.7 inches with dew points in the 40s and 50s by
Wednesday afternoon. The upper level trough across the region is
anomalously strong for this time of year in the 1st percentile of
climatology and this setup is expected to keep max temperatures
below guidance on Wednesday afternoon.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday Night through Tuesday)...
Deep upper trough presses slowly east and gradually deamplifies 
through the end of the week, pulling much cooler air into the 
region despite a healthy dose of sunshine in the expected dry 
northerly flow regime. Surface high pressure hangs on over the 
region with the lower level flow gradually shifting from northerly
to easterly moving into next week as the massive circulation of 
Irma comes into the picture as it transits Florida. However, it 
should be another great weekend in the mrx forecast area with an 
abundance of sunshine, thanks to dry air advection and subsidence 
ahead of the hurricane. A pleasant warming trend over the weekend 
will top out with temperatures a little closer to normal for early
September. On Monday and Tuesday, Irma builds slowly northeast 
toward the Carolina Piedmont with increasing moisture advection 
and lift. This strengthening easterly flow pattern typically 
results in relatively strong downsloping across the Appalachian 
Crest and diminished rain chances, however, used some increasing 
probabilities for showers due to uncertainty in the tropical 
system track, timing, and strength. The tropical system arrival is
still several days away and forecast changes are possible during 
the next few days.

chance for showers will slowly decrease from the west to east 
following the frontal boundary that will be continuing east of the 
Appalachians by mid morning on Monday. A deep trough following this 
boundary will then set up over the area bringing northwest flow and 
much cooler and drier air. Temperatures filtered in through this 
northwest flow will allow for almost 10-15 degrees below normal 
for this time of year. 

The deep trough will keep clear skies...temperatures below 
normal...and light winds through the end of the work week. By 
Saturday...the trough begins to break down and more zonal flow sets 
up over the area. Around this time...Irma makes its debut somewhere 
across the southern Florida peninsula. Models have only slight 
variation with the track...taking Hurricane Irma through 
Florida...and up to the Southern Appalachians. By Sunday...winds 
will shift to out of the east...and moisture from the Atlantic will 
begin to advect towards the mountains. Clouds will start to increase 
with the additional moisture. Monday brings the first chance for 
rain from Irma...which will have low chances of being Hurricane 
strength by the time impacts to our area begin. As Monday 
progresses...chances increase for showers and occassional 
thunderstorms...with the greatest chances remaining in the higher 
elevations of east TN and SW VA and NE TN. By Monday night in to 
Tuesday...the entire area could see showers and thunderstorms from 
Irma.

FXUS64 KMRX 041902
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
302 PM EDT Mon Sep 4 2017

.SHORT TERM...
With a clear sky and relatively weak wind, should see the boundary
layer cool quickly this evening decoupling the boundary layer from
the southwesterly flow aloft. This will limit winds and moisture 
advection at the surface as moisture advection continues above the
inversion. Clouds should increase late tonight as deeper moisture
arrives.

Ridging will continue to shift to the east as a deep trough moves
southeast into the Southern Appalachians on Tuesday. This will
bring a surface cold front into the area Tuesday afternoon. 
Southwesterly winds ahead of the front will advect moisture rich 
air with PW values of between 1.5  2.0 inches with the highest 
amounts across southern portions of the forecast area near 
Chattanooga and lower values across northeast TN and southwest VA.
Instability will also be highest across southern portions of the 
forecast area with MLCAPE between 1000-2000 J/Kg and effective 
shear of around 20-25 kt. This will support at least some 
ordinary/multicell convection Tuesday afternoon. With the 
combination of: (1) our region being in the right-front entrance 
region of the upper-level jet streak promoting upper-divergence, 
(2) a potent shortwave moving across the region and deepening the 
large-scale trough, and (3) a strong surface cold front providing 
a surface lifting mechanism, expect strong forcing and ascent 
with widespread rain and a few thunderstorms by Tuesday afternoon 
and evening. Max temperatures should be near to a few degrees 
below normal on Tuesday as a result of increasing cloud cover and 
precipitation during the afternoon.

.LONG TERM (Tuesday Night through Monday)...
H5 trough axis over the Great Lakes Tuesday night will help usher
in cooler air behind Tuesday's frontal passage. Precip generally 
ending during Wednesday. Temperatures expected to run below normal
for the period as low level flow remains generally northerly 
thanks to the slow trough and then due to the potential approach 
of Hurricane Irma to the southeastern states. Extended models 
still progging westward-moving Irma to take a fairly sharp right 
hand turn as it nears south Florida, thus running northward. In 
question is timing of the turn...but our new day 7 grids continue 
to show northeasterly winds with precip spreading in from NC. This
late-extended forecast is of course highly subject to Irma, whose
forecasted track and potential landfall is subject to change as 
the time approaches. Additional met data will begin to be 
routinely added to the models from here on, such as data from 
increased upper air soundings and from hurricane hunter aircraft.

us and as an upper level trough begins to push into the Ohio River 
Valley. Highs will be in the low to mid 80s which is normal for this 
time of year. Dewpoints also rise, allowing the air to feel not as 
crisp as it did today. Plenty of sun again tomorrow. Overall, a calm 
and tranquil short term period in store with near normal 
temperatures.


.LONG TERM...(Monday Night through Sunday)...H5 trough will drop out 
of Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes early in the extended period, 
sweeping a cold front through our region during Tuesday. Expect 
scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms Tuesday and Tuesday 
night, diminishing Wednesday. From Wednesday through Sunday, post 
frontal temperatures could persistently run 8 to 12 degrees below 
normal. Why such a persistent cool period? Because the cold H5 
trough will be slow to leave the eastern U.S., not doing so until 
the upcoming weekend. That's when things get further complicated. As 
the trough departs, the Bermuda High seemingly wants to nudge 
westward onto the Mid-Atlantic coast Sunday morning. This is 
significant because the underbelly of the Bermuda high has been the 
feature steering Hurricane Irma across the Atlantic, and at this 
time the long-range GFS and ECMWF bring Irma ashore between Myrtle 
Beach SC and Wilmington NC on Monday. Just how far westward she 
moves once inland will impact our weather late Monday and beyond. 
Bear in mind that these long-range model forecasts of landfall can 
experience much variation as the time draws near, and landfall 
itself is no certainty.

sunrise...the entire area should have enough dry air to see clear 
skies. Patchy fog development is likely overnight...especially in 
areas north of I 40 that see rain showers through the evening. 
Light winds and overcast skies should remain in these areas 
though...so will leave mention of dense fog for a later update. 
Sunday...high pressure and cooler weather will remain through the 
rest of the day.


.LONG TERM (Sunday night though Saturday)...Only one event to 
really focus on during the long term and that is the large upper-
trough and strong cold front set to move through 
Tuesday/Wednesday.

We start the period in weak NW flow as a trough pulls off to our NE. 
Lows will be around 3 to 5 degrees below normal under clear skies. 
On Monday the flow becomes zonal with highs near normal under mostly 
sunny skies. Lows warmer on Monday night as we began to return to a 
more southerly flow out ahead of our next system. Lows will be in 
the low to mid 60s, near normal. 

On Tuesday clouds begin to increase as a high amplitude upper-level 
trough begins to swing down into our area from the NW. This trough 
is quite robust for this time of year and will have strong upper 
level support as a 90 to 100kt 300mb jet rotates through the trough 
base, though the 850mb flow remains weak. As of now, it looks like 
most of Tuesday will be dry but with increasing chances for showers 
and storms as the day progresses. Highs will be in the in the mid 
80s, near normal. The best chances for precip will be during the 
overnight hours as the front approaches. There could be a few strong 
storms earlier in the evening but storms should weaken as the night 
goes on and we lose instability. The front pushes through Wednesday 
morning and exits during the afternoon hours. Much drier and cooler 
air rushes in behind the front along with decreasing clouds. Highs 
will only be near 70, around 15 degrees below normal.

On Thursday and Friday we remain under the influence of the upper 
trough with below normal temperatures. On Saturday higher pressure 
begins to build back in from the west as the trough lifts off to the 
NE. Temps will slowly warm from Thursday through Saturday.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...Mostly cloudy skies today so
