clouds and rain. Heaviest rain has been across the southeast
Tennessee mountains and southwest North Carolina. Rainfall amounts
of one to one and one half inches have occurred in this area. Showers
were developing more across central sections at mid afternoon and
should lift north and east the remainder of daylight hours. The 
surface low with Harvey was moving slowly northeast now located 
across northern Mississippi. Heavy rainfall was located mostly 
north and northeast of the center in parts of eastern 
Arkansas...Mississippi and southwest Tennessee. Other strong 
storms were over eastern Georgia and moving into western South 
Carolina. For the overnight period and Friday. Rainfall should
gradually decrease by this evening with sunset and then increase
from the west and southwest late tonight as the surface low from
Harvey moves into western and middle Tennessee. Still looks like
the forecast area will be on the eastern edge of the heavier
rainfall amounts as the system moves north into Kentucky Friday.
Rainfall amounts from after sunset tonight through Friday should 
be only about 0.50 to 1.50 inches...with isolated places around 2
inches. Some localized flooding still possible mainly plateau 
areas Friday.

Low to mid level cyclonic flow persisting around the remnants of 
Harvey as the system moves slowly NE across middle TN into KY 
will keep strong low-level shear over east to northeast TN and far
western VA. The considerable cloud cover and precipitation will 
give only weak lapse rates and limit destabilization. Even with 
small CAPE values the strength of the low-level shear will give a 
slight risk for a few tornadoes to occur across the region per Day
2 Severe Outlook. Temperatures tonight will stay warm mid 60s to
near 70 and highs Friday similar to today in the 70s.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...
The cyclonic circulation formerly known as Harvey will be 
located in central KY to start the period, with the dry slot over 
much of the TN Valley and a low level convergence zone extending 
E-SE across our SW VA and NE TN counties. This may keep the 
potential severe storms/tornadoes going into the evening. 
Decreasing shear and instability along with the deepening dry slot
will lowering chances of storms through the rest of Friday night.
The movement of the midlevel circulation along the upper OH River
will wrap moisture into our northern areas on Saturday, but with 
little forcing other than some weak instability under the trough. 
Will keep a chance of showers through Saturday, along with 
temperatures well below normal.

Surface high pressure across the TN Valley and a W-NW flow aloft 
will provide sunny and warmer conditions for Sunday and Monday, with 
highs getting closer to normal again on Monday. GFS and ECMWF agree 
on a longwave trough dropping into the Great Lakes on Tuesday, with 
a cold front nearing our area Tuesday night. A chance of rain will 
return with the front Tuesday afternoon and night, but the models 
diverge after this time. The ECMWF hangs the front over the 
Appalachians while cutting off a closed low at the base of the 
trough, keeping precip in our area through Thursday. The GFS is 
progressive and brings a dry and unseasonably cool air mass for 
Wednesday and Thursday. Confidence is low but will compromise by 
keeping a chance of rain into Wednesday but starting off Thursday 
dry.

National Weather Service Morristown TN

.SHORT TERM (Tonight through Friday)... 
The remnants of Harvey will be tracking from LA to eastern KY 
through this period, spreading deep moisture into the TN Valley 
beginning this evening. The band of rain on our southern border is 
associated with isentropic lift, which the models prog to spread 
northward through our area overnight. No lightning is currently 
observed in this band, and is unlikely to develop overnight, so the 
forecast will carry moderate showers but no thunderstorms tonight. 
Radar estimated rain amounts across AL/GA are between 0.5-1 inch, 
and the southern half of our area is expected to be in that range 
through tonight, with less for northern sections where the southerly 
flow and isentropic lift will be weaker. 

The southerly flow on the east side of Harvey will strengthen on 
Thursday as the remnant low tracks into MS, and the associated warm 
from lifts northward into the southern TN Valley. This will help 
increase surface-based instability and 0-3 km wind shear, especially 
south, raising our thunderstorm chances and giving a slight chance 
of severe storms with damaging wind gusts and isolated tornadoes 
near the frontal boundary. Coverage of storms is expected to be more 
discrete compated to tonight, but cells may be capabale of producing 
locally heavy rainfall, with training cells causing localized 
flooding. This threat will continue into Friday night as the low 
center tracks across Middle TN and the southerly LLJ picks up to 
near 50 kts, although CAPE will be less. Winds in the higher 
elevations could be an issue Thursday night/Friday, and will need 
to be monitored for Wind Advisory criteria as we get closer. We 
should see decreasing rain chances through Friday as the low moves
into KY and a mid- upper level dry slot moves over the area.

Rainfall amounts through Friday are expected to be in the 1-2 inch 
range for most of the area, with the lower end of that range for 
northern sections and the higher end for southern sections. However, 
as noted above, localized amounts could be much higher if discrete 
cells train over the same areas. Flooding problems are not expected 
to be widespread at this time.

.LONG TERM (Friday night through Wednesday)...
The weakening tropical circulation will be shifting slowly 
northeast up the Northern Ohio River Valley generating a few more 
showers and thunderstorms Friday night into Saturday. A northern 
stream upper trough will be dropping southeast into the Eastern 
Lakes and Extreme Northeastern States on Sunday picking up the old
circulation and shoving it out to sea by Sunday allowing for a 
drier regime both Sunday and Monday with a westerly flow 
developing. Kept the trend of increasing pops for convection 
Tuesday into Wednesday with deeper moisture advancing north out of
the Gulf of Mexico ahead of another synoptic cold front due into 
the area later Tuesday into Wednesday. A gradual warming trend is 
in the works with temperatures returning closer to normal by the 
beginning of the new work week.

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...Over the Southern Appalachian
Region...an upper trough will lift northward with the flow aloft
becoming zonal during the short term. This should allow low level
moisture to slowly increase across the area. With diurnal heating
and orographic lift...may see isolated convection develop over
higher terrain this afternoon. Otherwise...it should be a quiet
and dry day with highs near to slightly below normal. Lingering
convection may continue into the evening hours across the eastern
mountains...then towards morning...a few showers to our south may
push a bit northward and into far southern areas. But overall... 
most locations will be dry tonight with lows in the 60s to around
70 across most valley locations.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday)...Rain chances will 
continue for every period in the long term portion of the forecast
with the upper level trough being the synoptic force behind early
PoP chances. Trough will slowly move eastward, just to our north,
and in response low level winds will begin to pick up out of the 
south bringing in additional Gulf moisture. Aiding in this 
increase in moisture will be Harvey, as models are coming into 
better agreement that it will be a partial player in the upcoming 
weather in our area. Most models are in agreement that Harvey will
slowly spin to the east and north passing through the Memphis 
area and increasing low level winds out of the south. These moist 
low level winds will experience some upslope flow leading to 
cloudy/rainy weather across the Gulf Coast states and even into 
our forecast area. What this means for us is that rainfall chances
will continue through the forecast with the highest chances being
in the south and decreasing as you head further north. During the
middle of the week as this is going on we could see brief periods
of heavy rain since this will be a very moisture rich environment
across the Southeast United States. Could see some rounds of 
thunderstorms but widespread severe weather is not anticipated at 
this time with the clouds helping to keep temperatures down and 
weak synoptic forcing as well. 

Models begin to diverge in the synoptic solutions as we 
move towards the end of the week. ECMWF wants Harvey to get caught 
up in the upper level flow and move further east quicker and move 
precipitation out of our area faster, while the GFS keeps Harvey 
tracking further north and the southerly flow present over us with a 
longer duration of thunderstorms out of the Gulf. So forecast 
certainty goes down towards the weekend until models come into 
better agreement.

with regards to where Harvey will move for at least the second 
half of the workweek. Consensus takes Harvey almost directly due 
north across Louisiana and into the Mississippi River Valley for 
Thursday and Friday as it slowly gets picked up by the upper level
trough. This would bring a steady stream of Gulf moisture flowing
into our area and consistent cloud cover and PoPs. Some of this 
rain could be heavy at times with PWATS surging into the 
1.75-2.00" range by Thursday afternoon. Model solutions diverge by
Friday afternoon with the ECMWF having an upper level trough pick
up the remnants of Harvey, quickly swinging the system north 
across the Ohio Valley on Saturday, and leaving our area dry under
weak NW flow for basically the remainder of the extended period. 
In contrast, the GFS has the remnants moving much slower, and 
would keep a steady flow of moisture coming up into the Tennessee 
Valley through the weekend. For now, have split the difference and
kept chance PoPs in through the weekend.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...

Seeing a few more showers currently than previously anticipated and 
have increased PoPs in the near term to account for this. There is a 
surface trough across the area with some low level convergence. 
Several synoptic features of note on the current water vapor imagery 
across the CONUS. Tropical Storm Harvey continues to spin nearly 
stationary across SE Texas with a highly amplified ridge across the 
Western CONUS. There is a closed low spinning slowly northward 
across the Florida Peninsula with another shortwave trough diving 
southeastward out of the Northern Plains into the Mid-Mississippi 
River Valley. Closer to home, the flow is northwesterly to westerly 
aloft ahead of the shortwave trough approaching from the northwest. 
PW values are near average for this time of the year in the 1.4-1.6
inch range. As previously mentioned, there will continue to be a 
few isolated to scattered diurnal showers and storms throughout 
the remainder of the afternoon and evening thanks to the low level
convergence. Tropical Storm Harvey and the system across Florida 
are really cutting off the deep moisture flow from the region and 
expect mostly dry conditions throughout the short-term forecast. 
Overnight lows will be a little bit cooler than last night with 
drier easterly to southeasterly flow setting up. Lows will 
generally be in the upper 50s to low 60s. 

Tropical Storm Harvey to the southeast and the system currently 
across Florida will cut off any deep moisture advection ahead of the 
approaching system on Monday. A jet streak will develop to the north 
as the trough pivots across the Great Lakes. The atmosphere will 
saturate in the upper and mid-levels with cloud cover increasing 
throughout the day. The PW values will tick up slightly but the 
moisture transport is just not in place ahead of this system and 
only have a small mention of PoPs late in the day for the Northern 
Plateau. Dropped high temperatures by a couple of degrees with the 
increased cloud cover. Forecast highs are in the upper 70s to mid 
80s. 

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Saturday)...

An upper level trough will move across the Great Lakes and swing 
a frontal boundary through the Ohio Valley Monday night through 
Tuesday night. At the same time...a low pressure system will move 
along the east coast...bringing a small amount of wrap around 
moisture to the northern part of the area. The frontal boundary 
will bring lift...though moisture and instability will be limited.
Scattered showers and isolated thunderstorms are possible Tuesday
afternoon through the evening...with the greatest chance for 
development in the higher elevations. 

Wednesday through Thursday night...a deep upper level trough over 
southern Canada will move another trough through the Ohio Valley. 
Diurnal showers and thunderstorms will be possible Wednesday 
afternoon. Moisture and instability will remain limited...due to the 
low level flow remaining chaotic instead of steady out of the 
southwest. Thursday afternoon...scattered showers and thunderstorms 
are possible again as the frontal boundary moves through. Winds are 
expected to be light so any convection should be short lived. 

Friday through Sunday...low level high pressure will develop over 
the southeastern US. The remnants of Harvey are expected to move to 
the north...remaining east of the MS Valley. With the flow around 
Harvey, combined with the flow around the high pressure...more 
moisture and slightly warmer air are expected to begin to 
transition to the TN Valley. Have kept in scattered showers and 
thunderstorms each day...mainly in the afternoon and early evening
to account for any instability that may be created.

FXUS64 KMRX 261906
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
306 PM EDT Sat Aug 26 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Sunday)...
With the remnants of Harvey nearly stationary in Texas and a
shortwave trough across the western Great Lakes, we are stuck in a
benign weather pattern across the Tennessee Valley and Southern
Appalachians. We'll see just a few high clouds tonight after most
of the diurnal cumulus dissipates with evening cooling. Temperatures
should be near normal for this time of year with only some light 
patchy fog in sheltered river valleys.

Sunday is more of the same as high clouds stream across the area
and temperatures are near normal for this time of year. Thickness
values and 850mb temperatures are nearly identical to Saturday so
max temperatures should be similar once again. There will be some
additional low-level moisture across southern portions of the CWA
as well as slightly lower 500mb heights, so we may see a few
additional diurnally forced showers or an isolated thunderstorm on
Sunday afternoon across the higher terrain features.

.LONG TERM (Sunday night through Saturday night)...
An upper level trough and associated frontal boundary will 
approach the area Sunday night through Tuesday night. Not 
expecting much in the way of diurnal convection on Monday...due to
the low and mid level winds remaining chaotic and lacking the 
southerly flow bringing increase in moisture and warm air 
advection. Would not count out a light stray shower to move across
the higher elevations...but instability should remain limited. 

Tuesday afternoon through Tuesday night...the frontal boundary is 
expected to move through the area. At the same time...a low pressure 
system strengthens off the eastern coast of Florida and moves up the 
east coast...causing wrap around moisture to move into the area from 
the northeast. The boundary should provide decent lift...though the 
atmosphere will still be weak for much development besides showers 
and a low chance for isolated thunderstorms.  

By Wednesday...any remaining moisture and convection should quickly 
move east of the Appalachians as the frontal boundary moves off 
the eastern coast...and the low pressure system moves into the 
Atlantic. The remainder of Wednesday is expected to be mostly 
cloudy with temperatures dropping a couple of degrees for 
Wednesday night with northwest flow and drier and cooler air 
filtering in to the area. 

Another low pressure system will swing a front through the area 
Thursday into Thursday night...but due to the previous northwest 
flow and lack of lift with the weak front...not expecting much 
coverage or intensity with any convection that does develop. Looking 
at more scattered showers with isolated thunder possible. By 
Friday...southwest flow returns to the area bringing moisture and 
warm air advection...thus allowing for a slight increase in 
temperatures ahead of an approaching system by the end of the 
weekend.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
314 AM EDT Sat Aug 26 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...
Once again, over the next 24 hours, we can expect to see pretty 
similar weather compared to the previous 24 hours. Early this 
morning a few locations are reporting low dew point depressions so
there's a chance for isolated fog in low lying areas near bodies 
of water. Weak troughing overhead will allow for some clouds to 
move in keeping temperatures similar to what we saw yesterday 
which was slightly below normal for this time of year. 

High resolution models indicating we could see some shower
development in the higher terrain in the afternoon/evening hours.
Environment doesn't look very conducive to see thunderstorms, but
a stray clap of thunder can't be ruled out at this time. If storms
do form they would likely stick to the higher terrain and remain
very isolated, while most people will enjoy another pleasant day
like we have for the past several days.

.LONG TERM (Sunday through Friday)...
Sunday still looks relatively nice but maybe some increased cloud
cover across the Southern Valley. Sunday will again feature some 
slight and chance POPs in for the elevated areas. Temps slightly 
warmer, in the mid 80s with lows in the lower 60s. The arrival of 
Monday's trough and front appeared to have slowed down a bit in 
the lasted model runs, thus keeping us drier. The trough and low 
also look much weaker now compared to previous runs. Highs will be
in the low to mid 80s with lows in the low to mid 60s. POP 
chances begin to increase late Monday night and into Tuesday as 
the low wobbles closer. Looks like the weak low over our area 
prevents us from seeing in affects from the tropical system coming
into the Carolina Coast. Chance POPs in for most areas Tuesday 
with the low and frontal boundary across our area. The boundary 
hangs in across the area into Wednesday allowing for chance POPs 
to continue. Wednesday night into Thursday the low lifts off to 
our NE but the the old boundary remains stretched across our area.
Also during this period, it looks like moisture from Harvey 
begins to reach up into the Tennessee Valley. Old boundary still 
looks to be present and added moisture will again allow for chance
POPs, with the same theme continuing into Friday. 

At this point it is really tough to say what will happen with Harvey 
due to ever changing model solutions. Latest runs suggest Harvey's 
remnants never even moves across our area but yet slowly dissipate 
across the state of Texas. Will continue to watch the trends.

So the overall theme is clouds with chances of rain through much of 
the period with highs a few degrees below normal and lows starting 
out below normal but returning to normal toward the end of the 
period.

621 
FXUS64 KMRX 251839
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
239 PM EDT Fri Aug 25 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Saturday)...
High pressure remains centered to our north tonight with only a
few passing cirrus expected in a northwesterly upper-level flow.
With a dry boundary layer and light breeze, expect any fog to be
localized to sheltered river valleys as has been the case the past
couple of nights. Low temperatures will generally be near to 
slightly below normal for this time of year.

Trough axis across the Northeast CONUS pivots eastward on Saturday
allowing some subtle ridging across the area. However, thickness
values and 850mb temperatures will be similar to Friday, so max
temperatures should be similar once again. Models hinting at the 
potential for some showers or thunderstorms across the higher 
elevations of the TN/NC mountains on Saturday afternoon as diurnal
surface heating and an upslope flow leads to some marginal 
forcing along the terrain for slight chance PoPs. Think the 
potential for showers or thunderstorms will be very low because 
(1) soundings indicate a stable thermal layer around 700-850mb, 
(2) most of the instability for diurnal convection will be on the 
NC side of the mountains, (3) instability is not impressive and expected
to only be around 1000 J/kg or less, and (4) effective shear for 
storm organization and maintenance is low around 10-20 kts. Most 
areas should stay dry and enjoy another pleasant weather day.

.LONG TERM (Saturday night through Friday night)...
Overall confidence in the long term is low...mainly due to 
consistency in timing differences between all the weather features
this coming week. Several low pressure systems try to develop 
across the eastern half of the US...and where they move and how 
close to the Southern Appalachians will impact the amount of rain 
and cloud cover over the area. The initial concern is a low 
pressure developing across the Great Lakes region...swinging a 
frontal boundary through the area beginning Sunday night through 
Monday. Models are now coming in tune with a stronger low pressure
system (not as strong as Hurricane Harvey) developing off the 
eastern coast of Florida...and moving up the east coast. Between 
all of these low pressure systems...our area will be under an area
of weak lift...light winds...and low moisture advection through 
the first half of the work week. 

A weak boundary will approach the area from the northwest Sunday 
through Monday...though winds are light and chaotic...and PW values 
are less than half the normal value for this time of year. At this 
time...not expecting any diurnal showers or thunderstorms to develop 
ahead of this frontal boundary due to lack of lift and moisture. 
Monday night through Tuesday...the low pressure system developing 
off the coast of Florida will have moved up towards the 
Carolinas...and wrap around from this low pressure will bring 
moisture to areas north of I40...causing scattered showers and 
isolated thunder. From here...models are inconsistent on how close 
this low pressure system moves to the coast...as well as how strong 
the low pressure system becomes. With the frontal boundary from the 
weekend now over the area...combined with the possibility of wrap 
around moisture...kept chance precipitation in for scattered showers 
and thunderstorms through the middle of the work week. 

By Wednesday and Thursday...a few models try to bring the remnants 
of Hurricane Harvey across the Mississippi Valley and towards the 
Southern Appalachians...while other models let Hurricane Harvey 
weaken and rest over central Texas. Regardless...winds will shift to 
out of the Southwest...bringing slightly warmer temperatures and 
more moisture advection to the area. With an increased chance for 
lift...moisture...and stronger winds...have kept in chance 
precipitation through the end of the extended.

our area. The additional moisture plus old stationary boundary will

National Weather Service Morristown TN
314 PM EDT Thu Aug 24 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Friday)...
High pressure remains in control leading to clear conditions and
light winds tonight. With dry air in place, efficient radiational
cooling will take place leading to low temperatures about 5-7
degrees below normal. Expect any fog development tonight to 
remain localized around some of the river valleys because of the 
dry boundary layer.

Friday is expected to be very similar to Thursday. High pressure
remains centered to our north with light winds out of the NE. A
shortwave trough across the Great Lakes will transition eastward
across the Northeast CONUS reinforcing a longwave trough across
the Eastern CONUS. Forecast 1000mb-500mb thickness values of
568dam-574dam and 850mb temperatures of 13C-16C are almost
identical to Thursday from north to south across the forecast
area. Therefore, expect max temperature to be very similar to
Thursday with highs across southern portions of the area being
about a degree warmer on Friday with slightly higher 850mb
temperatures expected to return in these areas. High temperatures
will be near to slightly below normal.

.LONG TERM (Friday night through Thursday)...
For Friday night through Sunday...surface ridging across the 
southern Appalachians and Tennessee Valley will continue. Only 
chance of rain will be near the spine of the Appalachians due to 
upslope flow into western North Carolina. Instability and moisture
are limited, so will only call for isolated showers. 
Otherwise...dry conditions.

For Monday and Tuesday, an upper level trough digging southeast 
across the western Great Lakes into the Ohio Valley. This system 
will increase chances of convection over the area. Model soundings 
show enough CAPE to warrant inclusion of thunderstorms for the 
afternoon/early evening hours.

For Wednesday and Thursday, models begin to differ in respect to how 
moisture from remnants of Harvey move northeast into the Tennessee 
Valley. Also frontal boundary becomes quasi-stationary somewhere 
over the southern Tennessee Valley/northern Gulf coast states. Will 
maintain a chance of showers, but confidence is low. 

For the latter half of next week, we will need to watch the movement 
of remnants of Harvey closely since heavy rainfall is possible.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Surface high pressure building in from the north will combine with
upper level northwest flow to create a pleasant day with fall- 
like temperatures, low dewpoints, and plenty of sunshine. Highs 
will top out in the upper 70s to mid 80s this afternoon with RH 
values dipping into the 40s. Under clear skies, lows tonight will
drop into the mid 50s to lower 60s.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...
Our beautiful fall-like weather continues to start the period. 
Friday will feature high temps in the upper 70s to low 80s with 
plenty of sunshine along with low dewpoints. Lows will generally 
be in the upper 50s to near 60 Friday night. This beautiful 
weather continues into Saturday with most areas dry but will 
maintain slight/chance POPs across our eastern mountains. Highs 
and lows similar to Friday. By Sunday we start to get a little 
more moisture to work back into the area along with an approaching
upper-level trough out of the Ohio River Valley. Upper trough 
allows for weak upper-level forcing across the area. Forcing plus 
moisture return will allow for an increase in POP chances and 
coverage for Sunday, chances still not overly high though. Temps 
still relatively unchanged. 

Now attention turns to Harvey; forecast models in a little better 
agreement now on how they handle this system. On Monday the upper
trough and closed low drop further down into our neck of the 
woods bringing a weak front along with it. This will bring 
increasing chances for POPs across the CWA. The latest run of the 
GFS is more similar to the Euro now. Both models show the trough, 
closed low, and stalled out front hanging in across our area 
through Wednesday due to a brief period of Omega blocking in 
place. It's interesting that a tropical system out in the Atlantic
breaks the block across New England and allows the weak, closed, 
low across our area to finally move northeast which in turn allows
Harvey to finally progress northeast. So for now, chance POPs in 
place Monday through Wednesday along with plenty of clouds and 
still cool temps. At this point, Harvey doesn't really begin to 
affect our area until after this long-term period.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
242 PM EDT Wed Aug 23 2017

.SHORT TERM (This Afternoon through Thursday)...

A quiet weather pattern is setting up over the short-term forecast. 
The cold front is now to the east of the Appalachian Mountains with 
drier air advecting in from the northwest. There were a few showers 
earlier this morning across the higher elevations but not seeing 
much in the way of radar returns currently. Visible satellite 
indicates a field of cu across the region but nothing that looks 
impressive. For now, have continued a small mention of precip. for 
the higher elevations over the next couple of hours with dry 
conditions forecast afterward. 

PW values will take a significant drop tonight with cold and dry air 
advection moving into the region. Values will range from 0.6-0.8 
inches. These values are below the 10th percentile for late August. 
Therefore, not expecting any precipitation overnight. There could be 
some areas of patchy fog with clear skies and light winds overnight. 
Low temperatures will be cooler than normal ranging from the mid 
50s to mid 60s. The drier air advecting in should limit any 
widespread fog issues. The atmosphere remains under the same 
regime during the day on Thursday. Temperatures will warm quickly 
with plenty of insolation but will top out below normal in the mid
70s to mid 80s. 

.LONG TERM (Thursday night through Wednesday)...

At the beginning of this forecast period, we are on the southern 
end of an upper level NW flow, while at the surface, in the wake 
of the cold front, high pressure and north winds continue to build
into the area, resulting in dry weather. However, all eyes are 
focused on the western Gulf of Mexico where Harvey is forecast to 
be off the TexMex coasts, but in particular for the SE US, where 
Harvey will be located toward the end of this forecast period and 
beyond.

Back to the early parts of the forecast--the dry weather looks to 
continue area-wide through Friday night, then it looks like moisture 
might build back along the eastern mountains to give a chance of 
showers there for Saturday and Saturday night, then by Sunday enough 
moisture will return to the area to have a chance of showers and 
storms over the rest of the area as well.  Low level moisture will 
continue over the area through the remainder of the forecast with 
chances of showers and storms.

There is agreement that by the end of this forecast period on 
Wednesday that Harvey would still be well west of here.  The longer 
it takes to move east, the less impact it would have, even if it 
moves directly through the area.  We will need to keep up on the 
latest trends for both the timing and the path of this tropical 
system. Harvey will likely help continue to feed moisture northward, 
even well to the east, but there will likely be some dry slots 
behind areas of lift, that will be deeper in the details as well. 
Right now, will continue with "chance" POPs for these periods.

Cold front continues to push through the area today, bringing

frontal passage this afternoon, skies will clear out and much more

Highs today will be about 10 degrees cooler than the last few

anticipated overnight with very little moisture present.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...
Thursday and Friday continue to look fantastic, a true taste of 
fall in August, behind the departed front. Both days will feature 
abundant sunshine with highs generally in the low 80s and 
dewpoints in the mid to upper 50s. If that won't do it for you, 
head up to Newfound Gap or Mt LeConte where temperatures will be 
in the upper 50s to low 60s! Lows overnight Thursday and Friday 
will generally be in the upper 50s. 

POP chances return on Saturday and Sunday as we start to get 
moisture return flow into the area. Overall chances aren't too high 
though so the weekend doesn't look to be a complete washout. Most 
areas should stay dry Saturday but low-end chance POPs in for most 
areas by Sunday as moisture continues to build in from the south 
due to the remnants of Harvey across the Gulf Coast States. Temps 
remain in the low 80s for both days with lows in the lower 60s. The 
forecast after the weekend is quite complex and have very low 
confidence at this point on when/how Harvey interacts with incoming 
trough. Latest run of the Euro doesn't show the remains of Harvey 
moving into our area until Wednesday, beyond this forecast period, 
while the GFS shows it moving in on Monday. The timing of this 
system all depends on the trough interaction and it's very hard to 
say at this point when exactly Harvey will get picked up by the 
trough. At this point, will go with chance POPs for the Monday 
through Tuesday period as a broadbrush attempt. POP chances will 
become more refined as we get closer to the event and hopefully 
start seeing better model consensus.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
246 PM EDT Tue Aug 22 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...A cold front will move into 
the region overnight, and will exit to our south and by early 
Wednesday afternoon.  Best forcing for showers and thunderstorms 
looks to be mid/late tonight with better upper support and a 
prefrontal trough.  Will carry likely PoPs northwest and chance 
elsewhere. May be some lingering showers or thunderstorms at least 
first part of Wednesday until the front moves through, but will go 
with lower PoPs.  Drier air will be moving in late behind the front 
along with increasing sunshine and lowering humidity.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday Night through Tuesday)...
Long term forecast starts off with trough axis extending SE from New 
England across Western VA and into Western NC. With trough axis to 
our east, dry air funnels in for a glorious Thursday and Friday. Dew 
points dipping into the middle to upper 50s area wide on Thursday 
will gradually rebound into the lower 60s by Saturday. Daytime highs 
will be about 4-7 degrees below late August normals while the 
overnight lows reach even deeper below norms at 6-9 degrees cooler. 
Temps are in very good agreement with both NAM and GFS MOS, which 
have been consistent with the late August cool down.

Things begin to get a bit more complicated over the weekend and into 
the early part of next week. Twin tropical systems, one the remnants 
of Harvey, will enter the Gulf of Mexico Wednesday and approach the 
TX coast by Saturday. The other, a tropical disturbance moving 
toward the SE coast of FL, will drift northward over the next 
several days with the potential of being located off the SE coast of 
the US by the weekend. With Harvey remnant helping to pump Gulf 
moisture northward, current fcst begins to raise POP chances across 
the area Sunday through the end of the fcst pd. Latest GFS has 
slowed forward progress of the Gulf system, aka Harvey remnants, 
bringing it more in line with the ECMWF soln. If correct, likely 
onset for best pcpn chances will be later Sunday into Sunday night. 
Additional consideration is general model consensus which suggests 
that the Atlantic feature will intensify for the early part of next 
week as it rides around the western periphery of the subtropical 
ridge off the SE US coast. If this should verify, our area could 
find itself in a subsidence zone between those two systems which 
would greatly change the current fcst, keeping things fairly dry 
here for the beginning of the work week. Will need to continue 
monitoring evolution of both those features as the work week 
progresses.

anticipate much of a severe weather threat beyond general 
thunderstorm hazards.

disturbances off of the East Coast. Dry PWs of 0.7-1.0 inch look 
possible late Thursday through Friday which would be around the 10th 
percentile for this time of year. Should have a mostly dry Thursday 
and a dry Friday with temperatures expected to be below normal

184 
FXUS64 KMRX 200722
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
322 AM EDT Sun Aug 20 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...Main concern early this morning
and early Monday morning will be patchy fog, some locally dense, 
near area lakes and streams due to steam fog development.

Upper and surface ridging will be the rule for Today and Tonight.
Forecast soundings show a fairly strong mid-level inversion which
will essentially cap convection from developing today. A fairly 
hot day is in store with a warming temperature profile.

.LONG TERM...
We should start the week hot and mostly dry. On Monday (Eclipse 
Day), a strong 500mb ridge will expand with heights expected to be
around 594-596 dm which is near the 97th-99th percentile compared
to climatology for this time of year. Subsidence aloft will act 
to dry the air column and limit clouds and convection. Cannot rule
out about 10 percent PoPs around the higher terrain where 
differential heating will create a valley-mountain circulation 
with rising air across the higher elevations and sinking air 
across the Tennessee Valley. Models is good agreement tonight with
only very limited convection anticipated across the higher 
terrain features. Effective deep layer shear is very weak around 
10 kts or less which means any ordinary convective development 
would not be well maintained and would dissipate quickly.

The total solar eclipse will have some unique impacts on our diurnal 
weather on Monday. Decreasing incoming solar radiation during the 
mid-afternoon as the eclipse reaches its max for our area between 
17z-20z will have several effects. Hourly temperatures are expected 
to drop 2-8 degrees during maximum eclipse with the greatest drop in 
temperatures occurring within the path of totality. High 
temperatures expected to be slightly cooler by a degree or two as 
well. With near surface temperature reductions, may actually start 
to see a boundary layer profile similar to evenings near the path of 
totality where a stable or neutral thermal layer forms near the 
surface. This would likely further limit convection and cumulus 
development during the hours around the eclipse, especially near the 
path of totality. Even for local winds, may see some brief mesoscale 
wind patterns due to the total solar eclipse where a weak divergent 
flow occurs near the path of totality.

Overall, it is still looking like good viewing conditions for the 
area with mostly clear skies across the valley and additional 
cumulus/partly cloud skies across the higher terrain. At this point, 
only few, to at most scattered, cirrus would be expected. After the 
eclipse has ended on Monday afternoon, temperatures will quickly 
rebound with highs in the upper 80s to lower 90s. Heat index values 
will be in the 90-95 degree range on Monday afternoon. With the hot 
and sunny weather, it's important for anyone spending a lot of time 
outdoors on Monday to stay hydrated, find shade, and use sunscreen 
because of very high UV index values of 8-10 around midday before 
the solar eclipse even begins.

The ridge breaks down on Tuesday as an upper-level trough 
approaches. Model solutions in good agreement with a cold front 
moving through the area on Wednesday with increasing PoPs late 
Tuesday night and likely PoPs on Wednesday. May have a few lingering 
showers across the mountains on Thursday before high pressure builds 
in late week with dry weather expected. With troughing in place, 
expect cooler, below normal temperatures late next week behind the 
cold front.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
308 AM EDT Sat Aug 19 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Surface high pressure and a drying upper level northwest flow 
will result in calm, pleasant conditions today. Some patchy fog is
possible around sunrise this morning, but it is not expected to 
become widespread. Otherwise, skies will be mostly sunny with 
light winds and highs generally in the 80s.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Friday)...
For the second half of the weekend, an upper-level ridge begins 
to build on Sunday increasing max temperatures by 1-3 degrees 
compared to Saturday. With the drier low-level airmass and a 
building ridge, anticipate dry and pleasant conditions with highs 
in the mid 80s to low 90s and lower humidity.

Taking a look at Monday (Eclipse Day) the 500mb ridge will continue 
to expand with heights expected to be around 594-596 dm which is 
near the 95th-98th percentile compared to climatology for this time 
of year. Subsidence aloft will act to dry the air column and limit 
clouds and convection. Cannot rule out about 10-20 percent PoPs 
around the higher terrain where differential heating could act as a 
forcing mechanism for convection. Models are showing the potential 
for convection along the mountains, and to a lesser extent, the 
plateau with the NAM being most vigorous with convective 
development. Taking a closer look at soundings, the 0z NAM sounding 
shows cooler mid-levels as opposed to the 0Z GFS which has a more
typical sounding for a strong summer ridge with subsidence and 
associated warmer mid-levels. Based on the very strong ridge for 
Monday, believe that the NAM is over-doing convection and trended 
toward the drier GFS and ECMWF solutions. Further, effective deep 
layer shear is very low around 5 kts which means any ordinary 
convective development would not be able to be maintained for very
long. As has been mentioned previously, it will be interesting to
see the effects of decreasing incoming solar radiation during the
mid-afternoon on Monday as the eclipse reaches its max for our 
area between 17z-20z. Hourly temperatures are expected to drop 2-8
degrees during maximum eclipse with the greatest drop in 
temperatures occurring within the path of totality. High 
temperatures may even be slightly cooler by a degree or two than 
on a similar day without a total solar eclipse. With near surface 
temperature reductions, may actually start to see a boundary layer
profile similar to evenings near the path of totality where a 
stable or neutral thermal layer forms near the surface. This would
likely further limit convection and cumulus development during 
the hours around the eclipse and this was reflected in the 
forecast. Overall, it is still looking like good viewing 
conditions for the area. After the eclipse has ended on Monday 
afternoon, temperatures will quickly rebound with highs in the 
upper 80s to lower 90s. Heat index values will be in the 90-95 
degree range on Monday afternoon. It will be a very hot and mostly
sunny day, so anyone spending a lot of time outdoors on Monday 
needs to stay hydrated, find shade, and use sunscreen with very 
high UV index values of 8-10 around midday before the solar 
eclipse even begins. 

The ridge will break down and rain chances will increase through 
midweek. PoPs increase late Tuesday and Tuesday night with likely 
PoPs on Wednesday as a cold front moves through the area and 
troughing deepens across the region. Long term models are actually 
in good agreement with this system. Drier air is expected to move
in behind the front, but we may continue to see some additional 
clouds and rain showers on Thursday primarily across the 
mountains. Temperatures late next week expected to be cooler than 
average with troughing across the Eastern U.S.

Scattered showers will push across the area this morning along 
and ahead of the boundary. Just a few rumbles of thunder, if any,
will accompany these showers with very little instability to work
with. With PWAT values of 1.75 to 2 inches, could see some brief 
heavy rain with this morning's showers however their progressive 
nature should preclude any flooding issues. Clearing skies are 
expected this afternoon as drier air works into the area. Highs 
will be a few degrees cooler today due to the northwest flow, 
staying in the 80s areawide. For tonight, with clear skies and 
drier air overhead temperatures will dip into the 60s in most 
locations.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday)...
We start the long term period with much drier air across the 
forecast area in the wake of a cold front. A shortwave trough will
swing through the Ohio River Valley on Saturday, but with limited
lift and dry air in place, expect no precipitation and only a few
additional clouds. PW values will only be in the 0.8-1.0 range on
Saturday which is near the 10th percentile for this time of year.
An upper-level ridge begins to build in on Sunday increasing 
temperatures by 1-3 degrees compared to Saturday. With the drier 
low- level airmass and a building ridge, anticipate dry and 
pleasant conditions with highs in the mid 80s to low 90s and low 
humidity through the weekend.

The ridge continues to expand on Monday (Eclipse Day) with 500mb 
heights around 594-596 dm which is near the 95th percentile for this 
time of year. Subsidence aloft will act to dry the air column and 
limit clouds and convection. Still cannot rule out about 10-20 
percent PoPs, especially around the higher terrain where 
differential heating could play a role as a forcing mechanism for 
convection. However, effective deep layer shear is less than 10 kts 
which means any convective development would have a difficult time 
sustaining itself. It will also be interesting to see the effects of 
decreasing incoming solar radiation during the mid-afternoon on 
Monday. We may actually start to see a boundary layer profile 
similar to evenings around the path of totality where a stable or 
neutral thermal layer forms near the surface. This would help to 
limit convection and cumulus development. Thoughts are that between 
(1) the building ridge and associated subsidence, (2) weak shear, 
and (3) decrease in boundary layer heating between 17z-20z on 
Monday, it looks to be mostly dry with a mostly clear to partly 
cloudy sky leading to good eclipse viewing conditions. Temperatures 
will be very warm for this time of year, and without the eclipse, 
highs would be several degree warmer. The eclipse will act to drop 
temperatures between 2-8 degrees during max coverage with the 
largest temperature drops occurring along the path of totality. With 
dew points in the upper 60s to lower 70s, expect heat index values 
to be in the 90-95 degree range on Monday afternoon.

Rain chances will increase through the middle of the week and peak 
on Wednesday/Wednesday night as the ridge is replaced by troughing 
and a cold front moves southward across the area. Long term models 
are currently in good agreement with frontal passage occurring late 
Wednesday and Wednesday night with likely PoPs along and ahead of 
this front. Behind the cold front, much drier and cooler air settles 
over the region late week.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
251 PM EDT Thu Aug 17 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today through Friday)...Scattered showers and
thunderstorms will continue to move through the area this
afternoon and evening as a front approaches from the NW. Limited 
instability and high PW values over 2 in many areas will cause the
greatest threat from any convection to be heavy rain. 
Tonight...models try to bring a break in the activity...before a 
line develops and passes through just ahead of the frontal 
passage. With the amount of lift available...have left in slight 
chance to chance precip through the entire night to account for 
isolated showers developing...mainly over the plateau and higher 
elevations. No severe weather is expected.

Friday...The front moves east of the Appalachians by late
morning...with any lingering light showers dissipating shortly 
after. Clouds will be slow to clear...especially in the low
levels...as mid and upper level dry air advect into the area
through the early afternoon. Temperatures will be a few degrees 
cooler than today due to the NW flow. 


.LONG TERM (Friday night through Wednesday)...
With the frontal boundary moving off to our southeast by Friday 
afternoon/evening we will see a drop off in cloud coverage and 
precipitation chances as we head into the weekend. Mostly sunny 
skies and quiet weather will be the main story through the weekend 
as drier westerly/northwesterly winds take over. With the clear 
skies temperature will be able to slowly increase by a couple of 
degrees each day this weekend. As we move into next week the ridge 
will begin to build in strength a bit leading to warmer 
temperatures, but extra terrestrial objects will cause temperatures 
to be a bit cooler on Monday...

Monday (Eclipse day): Latest model runs are coming in a bit drier 
than before with only a few blotches of precipitation hinted at in 
our area. This set up is pretty typical for this time of year in 
this part of the country. So we would expect to see some afternoon 
cloud development which could produce a few isolated 
showers/thunderstorms. But with the eclipse moving through in the 
afternoon some of the diurnal heating from the sun will be offset 
leading to a likely decrease in cloud coverage during the eclipse. 
Right now it looks like Monday afternoon should be mostly sunny with 
great viewing for the majority of people. But unfortunately, there 
may be a few unhappy onlookers as there is the possibility that a 
rogue cloud could pass over parts of the area obscuring the view. 
Temperatures will be affected by the eclipse, but to what extent is 
the big question. some preliminary experimental computer simulations 
suggest that we could see a decrease in temperatures of up to 5-7 
degrees. Have gone ahead and adjusted hourly temperatures for the 
time frame of the eclipse and have lowered maximum temperatures by a 
couple of degrees over the area (and a bit more in the path of 
totality).

We remain dry for a couple more days before another frontal boundary 
pushes through in the second half of the work week. This will lead 
to another round of showers and thunderstorms in our area and cooler 
temperatures as we head towards the weekend.

FXUS64 KMRX 170700
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
300 AM EDT Thu Aug 17 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...
An upper-level ridge centered across the Gulf Coast will remain in
place for much of the day Thursday resulting in a typical summer 
pattern across the region. The combination of forcing mechanisms 
due to terrain based differential heating and upper-level 
divergence due to a 200-300mb jet streak will act to position 
highest PoPs across northeast Tennessee, southwest Virginia, and 
across the TN/NC mountains. Modest MLCAPE of 1000-2000 J/Kg and 
effective bulk shear of 10-15 kts means that the risk of severe 
weather is low with mainly ordinary convection expected. However, 
the atmosphere remains very moist with PWs of 1.8-2.0 inches, so 
some rain showers and thunderstorms may produce heavy rainfall. 
High temperatures are once again expected to be several degrees 
above normal.

The upper-level ridge will finally start to break down Thursday
night in response to an approaching trough and surface cold front
with chance PoPs across the area. Highest PoPs on Thursday night
expected to be across western portions of the CWA after midnight.
With increasing cloud cover and a very moist boundary layer, low
temperatures are forecast to be 5-8 degrees above normal on
Thursday night.

.LONG TERM (Friday through Wednesday)...
A cold front will be moving into the forecast area on Friday as a
shortwave trough passes to the north across the Great Lakes. PW 
values ahead of the boundary will be in the 1.9-2.1 inch range. 
These values are in excess of the 90th percentile for mid-August. 
The timing of this front continues to be late morning into the 
early afternoon. Due to the timing of the front, SBCAPE values 
will only increase into the 750-1500 J/Kg range with 0-6 km Bulk 
Shear values in the 10-15 range with the upper level trough 
passing well to the north. Therefore, not expecting any strong to 
severe storms with this frontal passage.

PW values will crash behind the boundary with much drier air 
advecting in from the northwest. Chances for showers and storms will 
come to an end from northwest to southeast during the afternoon and 
evening on Friday. PW values by Saturday morning will be in the 0.7-
0.9 inch range, which are around the 10th percentile for mid-August. 
Another mid-level shortwave trough swings across the Ohio River 
Valley on Saturday, but with the lack of lift, only expect a slight 
increase in cloud cover. Overall, the weekend is forecast to be dry 
with highs in the mid 80s to low 90s both Saturday and Sunday with 
sunny to partly sunny skies. An upper level ridge across the 
Atlantic builds westward on Sunday. Temperatures will be 3-5 degrees 
warmer on Sunday than on Saturday with the increasing heights aloft.

On Monday (Eclipse Day) start to see some weak southerly return flow 
with surface high pressure across the Atlantic. In the upper levels, 
the ridge continues to expand across the area with upper level 
heights in the 594-596 dm range. This is a typical late summer time 
pattern across the area. The main questions continue to be about 
cloud cover and precipitation chances. Based on the latest model 
trends with the further amplification of the ridge these chances 
have gone down to around 10-20 percent. The lack of insolation 
from the sun during the Eclipse will act to decrease these chances
as well and beginning to think based on the latest trends that 
viewing will be good throughout the forecast area. Temperatures 
will warm quickly into the early afternoon and beginning to 
plateau as the eclipse begins and will decrease by 2-8 degrees 
during the peak of totality. Without the eclipse expect highs 
would be in the low 90s areawide with the strength of the ridge 
but have forecast highs in the mid to upper 80s across most of the
area at this time. 

Chances for showers and storms will increase on Tuesday and 
Wednesday as the ridge begins to dampens with an upper level trough 
passing to the north. Temperatures during this timeframe will be 
near normal.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
320 AM EDT Wed Aug 16 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...
Ridging continues to build in on Wednesday with relatively weak 
upper-level flow across the area. A weak boundary will move 
through the area on Wednesday afternoon advecting higher moisture 
and providing a forcing mechanism for showers and thunderstorms to
develop. With ridging in place and weak synoptic scale forcing, 
believe that showers and thunderstorms should not be widespread 
and will mainly develop and be confined to the higher elevations with
chance PoPs primarily in the afternoon. PWs will remain near 
1.8-2.0 inches, so heavy rainfall would be expected with some 
convection. With ridging in place and sufficient sunshine, expect 
high temperatures to be several degrees above normal.

Showers and thunderstorms should decrease in coverage with the
loss of daytime heating after 0z. Depending on exact cloud cover,
lows should be near dew point temperatures with patchy fog
expected near areas that received measurable rainfall on
Wednesday.

.LONG TERM (Thursday through Tuesday)...
A moist airmass will be in place on Thursday with PW values in the 
1.8-2.1 inch range. These values are above the 90th percentile for 
mid-August. The Gulf Coast ridge will begin to flatten some 
during this timeframe as an upper level trough moves into the 
Great Lakes Region. Due to this, expect the coverage of showers 
and storms will be a bit more widespread than the average diurnal 
activity. Due to this, have PoPs in the 40-60 percent range for 
Thursday. Continued with elevated PoPs during the overnight period
as well as a cold front approaches from the northwest. 

The latest model guidance is a bit quicker with the frontal passage 
late Friday morning into the early afternoon. Drier air will begin 
to push into the area by the end of the day with PoPs decreasing 
from northwest to southeast throughout the day. SBCAPE values will 
range from around 1000-2000 J/Kg ahead of the boundary and 0-6 km 
Bulk Shear values in the 10-20 kts range with the trough passing 
well to the north. Therefore, not expecting any strong to severe 
storms at this time. 

The front will stall to the south of the forecast area on Saturday. 
Another upper level trough will dive out of the Northern Plains into 
the Ohio River Valley on Saturday. PW values by this time will be in 
the 0.9-1.2 inch range and do not expect there will be enough 
moisture for any showers to develop. Therefore, have left the 
forecast dry during the day on Saturday. On Sunday, a ridge tries to 
build in from the west as the aforementioned trough exits the East 
Coast. Temperatures will increase with the increasing heights aloft 
with small chances for afternoon showers and storms along the higher 
elevations. 

On Monday (Eclipse Day) the forecast favors a climatological typical 
late summer day. Not seeing any signals of significant synoptic lift. 
Moisture will be on the rise with chances for diurnally driven 
showers and storms during the afternoon. It will be interesting to 
see how the lower temperatures from the Eclipse may limit the 
coverage of these showers and storms and have decreased PoPs during 
this timeframe slightly below the SuperBlend PoPs but still have 
PoPs in the 20-30 range.

Friday with weak westerly waves moving across the region. PW values

These values are in the 75th-95th percentile for mid-August. Timing 
of each shortwave trough is difficult but with these higher PW 
values raised daytime PoPs a bit above the average diurnal coverage. 
Continued at least some low end mention of PoPs during overnight 
period as well. The higher heights aloft will push temperatures 
closer to average values for mid-August with highs in the mid 80 to 
low 90s during this timeframe and lows will be above normal in the 
upper 60s to mid 70s. 

The ridge will breakdown late Friday into early Saturday as a 
shortwave trough passes to the north across the Great Lakes. The 
models are in fairly good agreement with a frontal passage late 
Friday into early saturday. Due to this, have the highest PoPs of 
the extended forecast late Friday. A more amplified trough will dive 
southeastward out of the Northern Plains into the Ohio River Valley 
on Saturday. The questions is how much moisture will remain behind 
the boundary. Both models indicate enough lift and moisture to 
continue with at least 20-30 PoPs. 

As for the day of the Eclipse, neither the GFS or ECMWF have a 
strong synoptic signal for precipitation with weak flow and ridging 
aloft. However, it looks as though a surface boundary exists across 
the area which could lead to a bit more coverage in afternoon 
showers and storms then the typical diurnal activity. Based on this, 
have gone with 20-30 PoPs for now with temperatures near normal for 
mid-August with highs in the mid to upper 80s.

Dewpoints in the 50s are well back to the northwest into Southern
Illinois and Indiana. With the elevated dewpoints and recent 
rainfall, expect patchy fog across the area this morning but not 
expecting any widespread dense fog issues.

Drier air will begin to filter into the area today with PW values 
dropping down into the 1.3-1.7 inch range with the higher values 
across the mountains. Northwesterly flow behind the front and a weak 
low amplitude shortwave trough will lead to a few showers and storms 
later this afternoon across the higher elevations of the Southern 
Appalachians. The lack of lift and slightly drier air should keep 
most of the valley locations dry. High temperatures will be near to 
slightly below normal today with reading generally in the 80s. For 
tonight, expect coverage of showers and storms will decrease 
slightly with lows in the mid 60s to low 70s.

.LONG TERM (Monday through Saturday)...

Little change in the extended forecast from what we've seen in 
the past week or so. Just a very active weather pattern for August
complete with several short waves riding along a storm track 
across the Mid South and Southern Appalachian region. Deep 
moisture and instability in the vicinity of a synoptic frontal 
boundary with the periodic upper level enhancement will keep a 
semi-permanent thirty to fifty percent chance for showers and 
thunderstorms going through the week. There may be a brief break 
in the action about Tuesday night into Wednesday. Max and min 
temperatures should be near normal much of the period however, the
models indicate a little warmer air building in from the west for
the final three days of the forecast.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
313 AM EDT Thu Aug 10 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today through Saturday night)...
The pattern through this period will change very little, with a
broad trough over the eastern CONUS and a moist air mass remaining
in place. The timing of the best rain chances will depend on small
disturbances in the flow that the models typically do not resolve
well, so confidence in the details is low, particularly outside
the first 24 hours. A diurnal trend to convection will be favored.

Today will feature likely PoPs as a midlevel shortwave trough 
that is currently near the MS River will track across our area 
this afternoon. Weak instability with tall/skinny CAPE profiles 
and PW near 2 inches may make for a threat of locally heavy rain
and minor flooding issues, but no severe threat. Friday looks much
the same but with better dynamics and wind shear as an upper jet 
streak dips into the OH Valley, so PoPs in the likely range will
continue, as will the heavy rain threat.

On Saturday there will be a weak surface boundary moving through 
during the day that will require chance PoPs for the area, but a 
more northwesterly flow in the 850-700 mb layer should lead to 
some drying aloft and thus lower rain chances compared to today
and Friday. Afternoon high temperatures will continue to be 
slightly below normal through Saturday.

.LONG TERM (Sunday through Wednesday)...
It still appears that there will be a chance for convection to 
start the new week with plenty of moisture and a long wave trough 
over the Eastern U.S. along with at least a couple shorter 
wavelength features progged to shift southeast across the Ohio 
Valley and Central Appalachians. Perhaps the probability of 
precipitation will be a little higher Monday and Monday night as 
an associated cool front builds south across the forecast area. 
The boundary will still be moving slowly south through the viewing
area on Tuesday, so kept some decent chance pops going for this 
period. The boundary is expected to be far enough south of the 
area by Wednesday to lower the chance for a shower or 
thunderstorm. Max and min temperatures will be close to normal 
through the long term.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
246 AM EDT Wed Aug 9 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today through Friday night)...
The pattern across the region through this period will feature
ample low level moisture with a weak flow - a pattern that the 
models generally do not handle well, and thus there is quite a bit
of divergence between them. 

For today, as high pressure drifts east across OH into MD, we 
should see an increasing S-SE flow in the low levels that will
advect moisture into the area. Southern sections and the mountains
will be favored for afternoon convection as northern sections will
have a downslope wind component and thus greater stability. More
sunshine and downsloping may give higher temps north than south
today. 

Models show some agreement on the passage of a shortwave trough on
Thursday that will bring enhanced rain chances to the entire 
area, mainly in the afternoon. PoPs will rise to likely this 
period as PW values rise above normal ahead of the trough. At this
point, the models diverge. The NAM shows a second, stronger 
shortwave trough following closely behind on Friday, with a 
surface low tracking across KY Friday night. The GFS and SREF show
a more diurnal trend to rain chances on Friday with weak forcing
within the broad upper trough. Will stick closer to the latter 
solution for the current forecast given the lack of confidence in 
the fairly strong forcing shown by the NAM.

.LONG TERM (Saturday through Tuesday)...
The period should be a little more unsettled than we usually see 
in the middle of August in the Mid South. A mean upper level 
trough holds its position over the Eastern states through the 
weekend into the early part of the work week. The probability of 
showers and thunderstorms will gradually increase Sunday into 
Monday as moisture builds across the Southern Appalachian region 
in advance of a relatively significant cool front expected to slip
just south of the forecast area by Tuesday morning. Temperatures 
will remain near normal in the middle 80s while lows hold a few 
degrees above normal in the upper 60s and lower 70s in the more 
humid airmass over the weekend. It will be a couple degrees cooler
with the frontal boundary in the area Monday and Tuesday.

FXUS64 KMRX 040710

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
310 AM EDT Fri Aug 4 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and tonight)...
A low pressure system tracking across the upper Great Lakes region
today will bring a cold front toward our area by the evening.
Isolated to scattered showers may be possible in the morning, but
the main period of storms will begin in the early afternoon as a
pre-frontal trough moves into the Cumberland Plateau, with peak
forcing in the 18-22Z time frame as the upper jet dips into KY/WV.
Instability is modest through the day as is shear, so the threat 
of severe storms appears low but cannot be ruled out entirely. 
Precip chances will decrease in the evening as the upper level 
forcing exits, with isolated to scattered storms possible until 
the surface cold front exits around 06Z. 

.LONG TERM (Saturday through Thursday)...
First part of the weekend looks to be dry as the frontal boundary is 
pushed off to our southeast and keeps the moisture away for a brief 
period of time. With the lack of moisture the skies will clear 
through most of the weekend and Sunday will most likely be the 
warmest day of this forecast with, but even then temperatures are 
expected to be near, or just below normal for this time of year. 

The clear skies won't last for very long as broad troughing and some 
shortwaves in the upper atmosphere zip along a frontal boundary that 
is expected to stall out over us at the beginning of the work week. 
This is not a very strong system, but with the frontal boundary 
expected to slowly meander north/south over the area for several 
days this upcoming week we will likely see mostly cloudy skies and 
prolonged periods of rain chances. Models are having a bit of a 
difficult time in determining the location of the boundary and 
therefore the precipitation associated with it, so broadbrush rain 
chances have been put into the forecast. Hopefully these will be 
trimmed and refined as we move forward in time and models come into 
better agreement. These increased rain chances come with increased 
cloudiness and the temperatures in our area are expected to remain 
below normal for this entire 7-day forecast. Most of the valley 
locations will likely see highs in the upper 70s to mid 80s.

skies.

.LONG TERM...
We will be in somewhat of a trough pattern through the long term. We 
start the period under the influence of a weak, non-amplified, upper-
level trough. Enough upper-level jet energy and moisture in place 
that diurnal terrain based storms look possible during the 
afternoon Wednesday, with even a chance for an isolated storm down
in the valley. Some of this activity may linger into the night 
Wednesday due to the mid and upper-level support still in place. 
Highs will be in the mid to upper 80s with lows in lower to mid 
60s. By Thursday we have a stronger wave dropping down into the 
Northern Plains that will help to amplify the pre-existing trough.
Our weather will remain relatively unchanged though, with diurnal
showers and storms possible. 

By Friday the trough becomes even more amplified as a now well 
defined closed low moves across the Great Lakes region. There are 
timing differences with this system as the GFS has the pre-frontal 
showers and storms moving through during the day on Friday and ECMWF 
holds it off until Friday night. Storm strength will depend on 
timing. In general, there does look to be enough instability and 
shear with this system to warrant a few strong to severe storms, but 
that all depends on timing. Front pushes into our area late Fri 
night/Saturday depending on what model you prefer. Will have likely 
POPs for Friday and Friday night. Could be some lingering showers 
through the day on Saturday depending on where the front is. Highs 
on Friday will be in the low to mid 80s with lows in the lower to 
mid 60s. Cooler highs on Saturday as we start to get some cooler and 
drier air moving in behind the front. Highs will be in the upper 70s 
to lower 80s with lows in the upper 50s low 60s. Still some chances 
for showers and storms on Sunday as the ECMWF shows the front washed 
out across the area, which could provide focus for precip. Another 
wave rotates through the trough on Monday into Tuesday which will 
give us another shot at showers and storms. Highs will be in the low 
80s Monday and upper 80s Tuesday.

.LONG TERM...

over the eastern U.S. and at the surface our area is still under the

frontal system works its way through the Plains and Miss Valley 
and induces a return flow from the Gulf as our surface ridge stays
put. It looks like around Friday the front will pass through with
showers and storms along and ahead of it. Instability for Friday 
looks iffy at best now for any threat of severe storms. Right now 
the timing looks like the main line of storms might hit at night 
when instability would be lower as well. The front looks like it 
will not surge through the area, so it might hang up close enough 
to not completely get rid of the POPs in the eastern most areas. 
For this post-frontal precip, will just go with showers.

storms with the frontal boundary. However, models show limiting 
factor may be instability. Will need to watch the evolution of this 
system closely, especially given the unusual strength of the upper 
trough for this time of the year.

For Saturday/Sunday, frontal boundary moves south of the area with 
return of drier west/northwest flow. ECMWF and GFS have differences 
in respect of moisture return into the Tennessee Valley for Sunday, 
but for now will trend toward the drier solution.

across the Central and Western CONUS. Closer to home, seeing dry

with the ridge expanding into the area. PW values are near the

forecast. Overnight lows will range from around 5-10 degrees below
normal tonight. May even see some lows near record values. The 
record low for Tri-Cities for July 31st is 55 degrees set in 1993 
and the forecast low is currently 57. 

The dry airmass and mostly sunny skies should lead to a quick warm 
up during the day on Monday. Highs will climb up into the mid to 
upper 80s across most valley locations but the lower humidity will 
continue with dewpoints in the upper 50s and low 60s. 

.LONG TERM (Monday night through Sunday)...

Dry northwest flow aloft and surface ridging will keep the region 
rain-free with limited cloud cover on Monday night and Tuesday. 
Surface ridging weakens on Wednesday and Thursday with a gradual 
increase in moisture and instability. A weak 500mb shortwave will 
move into the region but dynamics are quite limited across our area 
with best lift and moisture to our south. May still see a small 
chance of general ordinary convection across the higher terrain of 
the mountains and plateau.

An anomalously deep upper trough will approach/move across the area 
on Friday and Saturday with a cold front at the surface. Timing has 
improved since yesterday with the GFS coming into better agreement 
with the ECMWF solution moving the cold front through our area 
Friday night and early Saturday. The best lift and moisture is 
expected to be just ahead of this front with likely PoPs late Friday 
and Friday night. Depending on timing and mesoscale details which 
will have to be fine tuned later, a few thunderstorms could be 
strong with such a deep trough in place. May still have a few rain 
showers along the eastern Tennessee mountains and southwest Virginia 
early Saturday. Gradual clearing is expected behind the front with 
drier conditions by Saturday night and Sunday.

.SHORT TERM (This Afternoon through Sunday)...

A much more pleasant day across the Southern Appalachians with 
surface dewpoints this afternoon in the upper 50s to mid 60s and 
temperatures in the upper 70s to mid 80s. Current water vapor 
imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicates a trough along the 
Carolina coast with northerly to northwesterly flow aloft across the 
forecast area. Drier air is filtering in behind the departing front 
with PW values currently in the 0.9-1.1 inch range. There have been 
some low level clouds today across the region especially across SW 
VA and NE TN. The northwesterly flow in the low levels has also lead 
to some clouds from orographic lift along the mountains. The cooler 
and drier air will continue to advect in overnight with forecast 
lows in the mid 50s to mid 60s. PW values will continue to drop on 
Sunday to near minimum values observed for late July. Therefore, 
expect cooler than normal conditions with mostly sunny skies. 

.LONG TERM (Sunday night through Saturday)...

Longwave troughing across the East Coast will bring a dry northerly 
flow across the Southern Appalachians and Tennessee Valley early 
this week. Surface high pressure and dry air will keep conditions 
mostly clear for Monday and Tuesday. Daytime highs on Monday will be 
a couple of degrees below normal with daytime highs closer to 
seasonal normals on Tuesday and Wednesday as troughing exits and 
heights rise. Nighttime lows will be several degrees below normal 
through Wednesday with calm winds and dry air at the surface. It 
will be very nice for this time of year with low humidity.

Expect a few shortwaves moving through the region through mid to 
late week. Expect activity in our area on Wednesday to be largely 
suppressed with the best lift and moisture to our south along the 
Gulf Coast. PoPs will slowly be on the increase on Thursday and 
especially Friday as low level moisture will be on the increase, 
height falls provide support for ascent as troughing starts to 
develop across the Eastern CONUS, and a surface cold front drops 
south from the Ohio River Valley. However, there is uncertainty with 
how quickly the surface cold front and trough axis will move east of 
the area. The ECMWF brings the cold front quickly through Friday 
night and early Saturday with dry conditions by Saturday afternoon. 
The GFS favors a slower solution with a wetter weekend. Based on 
current guidance, best rain chances look to be Friday through 
Saturday. Based on synoptic setup, next weekend would be expected to 
have temperatures back below normal.

broad/weak ridging and dry northerly flow dominate the pattern. At 
the surface, high pressure will gradually shift Southeast through 
Wednesday keeping low level moisture out of the region. Daytime 
highs start the week about 2-4 degrees below normal before climbing 
back to normal by midweek. Overnight lows remain 2-5 degrees below

in place.

Area Forecast Discussion...update
National Weather Service Morristown TN 
730 PM EDT Fri Jul 28 2017

.UPDATE...Updated forecast package to remove late afternoon period.

.SHORT TERM (This Afternoon through Saturday)...

Scattered to numerous shower and storms currently across the 
forecast area as a lead shortwave trough moves ahead of a cold 
front. The best coverage early this afternoon is across NE TN and SW 
VA. There have been a few rumbles of thunder with this activity but 
not seeing any widespread thunder presently. Radar estimates of 
rainfall range from 0.5-1.0 inch in the heavier downpours and have 
not seen any flooding issues so far. PW values are elevated across 
the area with readings in the 2.0-2.3 inch range. Expect there will 
be a few areas with localized flash flooding issues this afternoon 
and evening. Most locations have seen less than a tenth of an inch 
with 3-hr FFG values around 2-3 inches and do not expect any 
widespread flooding issues. 

As the front progresses through the forecast area later this 
afternoon and evening, expect an increase in the coverage of showers 
and storms across the region. Current radar imagery indicates this 
beginning across Middle TN and Kentucky. Widespread cloud cover has 
kept temperatures down in the mid 70s to low 80s and only expect 
SBCAPE values in the 500-1000 J/Kg range as the front moves in. Deep 
layer shear will increase into the 25-35 kt range. Therefore, there 
could still be a couple of strong to marginally severe storms with 
gusty winds being the main threat but confidence is rather low due 
to the limiting factors. 

The front is forecast to move through the area this evening and into 
the overnight hours. Expect to see some precipitation linger across 
the mountains overnight with some weak orographic lift from the 
northwesterly flow behind the departing front. However, the main 
theme will be drier and cooler conditions late tonight into 
Saturday. PW values on Saturday will drop down into the 0.8-1.0 inch 
range which is near the 10th percentile for late July. Lower 
dewpoints in the low to mid 60s will make for a much more pleasant 
day with highs in the upper 70s to mid 80s.

.LONG TERM (Saturday night through Friday)...

It should be a quiet start to the long term period with the 
longwave trough axis to our east and a dry northerly flow aloft. 
At the surface, high pressure will be in control leading to ample 
sunshine and clear conditions for late this weekend through the 
first half of the week. This will result in temperatures slightly 
below normal with low humidity. This will be a rare treat for late
July.

Shortwave trough moves through the region on Wednesday, but limited 
moisture will still keep precipitation chances low. An approaching 
longwave trough and increasing moisture will lead to some chance 
PoPs on Thursday and Friday. 

Guidance is in very good agreement through the long term showing dry 
weather early in the week and troughing becoming more dominant once 
again by next weekend with rain chances on the rebound.
