National Weather Service Morristown TN
335 AM EDT Tue May 23 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...
Latest water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicates  
shortwave trough over northern Alabama/Georgia that will continue 
to move NE into central NC by this afternoon. Stalled surface 
front is along the SE TN border extending NE into SW NC this 
morning. 

Combination of this shortwave and the surface boundary is helping  
to enhance rainfall out ahead of it, mainly over NE Georgia and 
Western Carolina this morning. As steady rain is beginning to wind
down across the southern Valley and Plateau, expect this pcpn 
shield to continue to move NE through today with greatest pcpn 
potential in our area continuing along the western slopes of the 
Appalachian Mtns in East TN through mid day. POPs decrease to 
chance area wide by this evening ahead of an approaching front 
that will once again bring another round of pcpn by Wednesday 
morning.

Latest 12 hour MRMS pcpn total indicates greatest rainfall 
amounts of 0.5 to 1.0 inches over portions of Polk and Monroe 
counties in SE TN with radar indicating more spotty areas of pcpn 
moving into those areas for this morning. With models indicating
some middle level drying behind the shortwave this afternoon, PWs
dropping to near 1.0 inch, additional rainfall potential for this
area over the next 24 hours should be limited to 0.5 inches or 
less. With expected 24 hour totals well below current flash flood
guidance, do not expect to see any flooding issues through the 
period.

Continued cloud cover and pcpn will keep temperatures slightly
below or about 4-6 degrees cooler than late May normals and in 
very close agreement with NAM/GFS MOS as well as the Super Blend.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday)...
Main feature will be a deep upper trough digging southeast into 
the Tennessee Valley for Wednesday. Strong upper jet will rotate 
out of the trough across the east Tennessee Valley during the day 
Wednesday producing strong upper divergence. The strong forcing 
along with marginal instability will produce widespread showers 
and thunderstorms. Main concern in the morning will be locally 
heavy rainfall. Depending if enough breaks occur behind this 
initial wave, scattered storms will likely develop later in the 
day. Given the cold air aloft associated with upper trough 
producing low WBZ, some of these storms could produce hail from 
the mid-afternoon through early evening.

For Thursday, upper trough axis will be moving east of the area, but 
cold air aloft remains across southwest Virginia/northeast 
Tennessee. Scattered showers and thunderstorms are expected to 
redevelop there with small hail once again possible given the low 
WBZ.

For Thursday night and Friday, upper trough moves east of the area 
with weak ridging developing across the region. Mostly dry 
conditions are expected with warmer temperatures.

For Saturday, southerly flow returns pulling a moist/unstable air 
back into the region. Isentropic lift along with jet energy will 
focus the instability to produce scattered thunderstorms. Some of 
these storms could be strong to severe with the main concern being 
downbursts damaging winds and hail.

For Sunday and Monday, confidence is low on timing of convection. 
GFS wants to develop a MCS over the mid-Mississippi Valley Saturday 
night, then move across the Tennessee Valley. Concerned for active 
severe storms for Sunday and Monday due to favorable jet dynamics. 
Later shifts will need to watch closely for this 
development/evolution.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
300 PM EDT Sun May 21 2017

.SHORT TERM (This Afternoon through Monday)...

Widespread showers continue this afternoon across NE TN and SW VA as 
a shortwave trough moves through the Southern Appalachians. 
Rainfall totals today were a little lighter than forecast with 
amounts generally under an inch with radar estimates of up to 1.5 
inches in portions of Clay and Cherokee counties in North 
Carolina. So far, there have been no reports of flooding and do 
not anticipate any issues at this time. The cold front is still 
back to the west of Nashville and there are some showers 
developing along the Plateau ahead of the front. Expect this 
activity will be more scattered and have chance PoPs for much of 
the evening and overnight hours. SBCAPE values are currently up 
into the 1000-1500 J/Kg range across middle TN with more stable 
values to the east from the widespread cloud cover today. Expect a
few rumbles of thunder will be possible this afternoon and into 
the overnight but expect any chance for a strong to marginally 
severe storm is low. Due to this, went ahead and updated the HWO 
to include no hazards. Even with the recent rainfall, 3-hr FFG 
values are still in excess of 2 inches across most of the area. 
The cold front will make swift progress to the east tonight as 
shortwave trough rotates around the broader low across the Great 
Lakes and Ohio River Valley. PoPs will decrease from west to east 
late tonight. The front looks to get held up along the mountains 
tomorrow with lingering showers in the higher elevations on 
Monday. Noticeably cooler and drier air is forecast on Monday. 
Dewpoints will drop down into the upper 40s to mid 50s with highs 
in the mid to upper 70s across most valley locations.

.LONG TERM (Monday night through Saturday)...

Unfortunately models are still not in great agreement with how to 
handle the weather systems in the early to middle parts of the work 
week. They do agree that a surface low will slide up the stalled out 
frontal boundary and will bring precipitation wherever that low 
decides to traverse. However there is some discrepancy on the 
strength and especially the timing of the low as it moves through. 
GFS wants to move a quick moving low through that brings rain to the 
Southern Appalachian Mountains and the Eastern Tennessee Valley, the 
NAM wants to move the same low through but spread precipitation all 
the way west into Middle Tennessee, while the ECMWF has a very weak 
low but keeps the boundary closer to us so we see a longer period of 
sustained rainfall. So at this point confidence is very low with how 
much rain and how long rain will last through the middle of the 
week. Have gone with at least low end precipitation chances through 
the middle of the week, but will hopefully be able to trim chances 
as the models come into better agreement.

After taking a break from precipitation another system will move 
through the second half of the work week. Depending on the track of 
the upper level low in this system we could get wrap around 
precipitation all the way into Thursday night, although it would 
likely be pretty light QPF-wise. Temperatures will then begin to 
rebound at the end of the week before a shortwave zips through and 
looks to bring precipitation chances to the region over the weekend.

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...
Latest water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis shows
continued eastward progression of the upper level ridge that we 
have enjoyed for the past few days. In it's place, closed upper 
low over SW Minnesota extends trough axis SE into the Mississippi 
Gulf Coast. The persistent deep layer SW flow ahead of the trough 
axis continues to pump unseasonably moist air into the area with 
model generated PW values of 1.5 - 1.7 inches remaining at or 
above the 90th percentile through much of the period. So far in 
this current pcpn event, areas south of I-40 and west of I-75 have
generally seen about 0.75 inches of pcpn with some localized 
radar estimates in excess of 2.0 inches for Saturday. Expect these
types of pcpn amounts to shift NE through today ahead of the 
approaching front by Monday morning. With flash flood guidance of 
2.0 - 4.0 inches in the SE portion of the area to 1.5 - 3.0 inches
in SW Virginia, the potential for localized flash flooding, 
particularly in NE TN and SW VA is something to monitor.

Forecast for the first half of today is a bit difficult, given the
poor comparison of model pcpn to actual radar this morning. The 
HRRR, which had been doing fairly well for the past few days, 
seems to be overdoing pcpn this morning. Similarly, NAM12, GFS, 
and SREF are struggling with the diurnal waning of pcpn. Given 
this situation, have decided to back off on morning POPs slightly 
as it looks like guidance is overplaying it for now. However, this
lack of pcpn to start the day will likely allow for more 
afternoon showers and tstms area wide ahead of the front and as 
indicated in most of the models as well. Therefore did trend the 
afternoon and evening POPs upward a little bit to reflect greater 
rain chances and in fair agreement with NAM MOS guidance for later
today. 

Pcpn begins to wind down tonight with frontal passage just beyond
the end of the period. Expect temperatures near normal today under
mostly cloudy skies area wide with overnight lows tonight also
dropping to near seasonal values ahead of the front on Monday.

.LONG TERM (Monday through Saturday)...
Monday morning cold front will be along or near the Southern 
Appalachians so expect western areas to be out of the 
precipitation and skies become mostly sunny. Eastern areas may 
have a few showers and a possible thunderstorm linger into the 
afternoon. A low pressure area is expected to form along the front
late in the day over AL which may keep some clouds and 
precipitation along the Appalachians. As this low develops and 
moves northeast clouds will return quickly overnight Monday night 
and continue Tuesday. NAM model is most aggressive developing the 
low farther southwest and bringing more precipitation into the 
region Monday night and Tuesday with surface low moving up through
the southern Appalachians. GFS farther south and slower with low 
and moves it east of the mountains late Monday night into Tuesday.
This would be much drier for forecast area. Have gone with 
overall drier solution but have higher rain chances south and east
Monday night and Tuesday. From Tuesday night through Thursday 
upper level trough digs south over the Eastern states bringing in 
more showers and isolated thunderstorms and much cooler 
temperatures as short wave energy rotates through. Highs Monday be
mostly mid 70s to lower 80s near normal but fall to the mid 60s 
to lower 70s Wednesday and Thursday. The upper trough begins to 
lift out Thursday night which will end showers. A warming trend 
Friday and Saturday as higher pressure rebuilds.

FXUS64 KMRX 201922

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
322 PM EDT Sat May 20 2017

.SHORT TERM (This Afternoon through Sunday)...

The upper level ridge has held strong across the forecast area today 
with only a couple of isolated showers/storms so far. Expect this 
will continue to be the story throughout the remainder of the 
afternoon with the main surge of moisture expected after sunset tonight. 
Over the last hour or so, storms have pulsed up to severe limits 
at times across NE TN and SW VA and expect this will be possible 
over the next couple of hours. Current water vapor imagery and RAP
upper air analysis indicates a closed low spinning across the 
Central Plains with a ridge stretching northward from the Carolina
coast into the Great Lakes. Another shortwave trough can be noted
moving northward across Mississippi. The surge of moisture will 
occur with this wave with PW values increasing into the 1.6-1.8 
inch range later tonight into early Sunday morning. These values 
are near the maximum value observed for mid-May and have increased
the PoPs and QPF values during the overnight timeframe. Due to 
highly saturated nature of the atmosphere, mid-level and upper 
level lapse rates are not overly impressive and are near moist 
adiabatic. Therefore, expect the chance for any strong to 
marginally severe storms overnight is very low at this time but 
there could still be a stronger storm or two with gusty winds 
being the main threat. The high PW values and persistent moisture 
advection ahead of the front will lead to QPF values in excess of 
2 inches in a few locations and expect localized flooding will be 
possible. Currently 3-hr FFG is over 3 inches for most locations 
and will forgo issuing a Flash Flood Watch but will continue to 
monitor things throughout the overnight hours and into the day on 
Sunday.

The cold front will remain to the west of the area throughout the 
day on Sunday with showers and storms continuing. PW values remain 
elevated in the 1.5-1.7 inch range. Therefore, have continued with 
70-90 PoPs. Once again, SBCAPE values should remain below 1000 J/Kg 
during the day on Sunday with 0-6 km Bulk Shear values around 20-30 
Kts. Overall, this would suggest maybe a stronger storm or two again 
but no severe weather is anticipated. Widespread cloud cover and 
precipitation will lead to cooler temperatures on Sunday and have 
reduced highs by a couple of degrees with highs generally in the mid 
to upper 70s for most valley locations.

.LONG TERM (Sunday night through Thursday)...

Cold front will be sweeping through the area overnight Sunday 
night into Monday morning and as it moves through precipitation 
will come to an end Monday from the west to the east. We will get 
a quick peak of sunshine on Monday as drier air comes in behind 
the front, but this will not last for too long before out next 
system. Unfortunately the long term models diverge on how to 
handle this next system. They all forecast a surface low to slide 
northward along the stalled frontal boundary, but they disagree on
the strength/timing of the low. This leads to discrepancies with 
how much precipitation might move into our area. Best chances look
to be in the Southern Appalachian Mountains and to their 
southeast, but we can't rule out widespread precipitation moving 
into the Tennessee Valley. If this system does bring widespread 
rain to our area we could get flooding depending on how much 
precipitation falls this weekend. At this time went with lower end
precipitation chances since models haven't really been consistent
with this system, and will adjust as we get closer. 

A secondary front will move through Wednesday/Thursday and bring 
another round of rain to the area. This system looks to move through 
quickly and dosen't look to bring much in the way of widespread 
thunderstorms. After continuously cooler temperatures with these few 
systems we will see our "coldest" day on Thursday with 
temperatures expected to be about 10 degrees below normal. A quick
warmup will begin at the end of the work week and into the 
weekend getting us back above normal.

National Weather Service Morristown TN

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...
Latest water vapor and RAP upper air analysis indicate broad
shortwave trough in the NW Gulf of Mexico this morning with a 
well defined upper level low over NE Colorado. Meanwhile, the 
upper level ridge axis extends N from Florida across Michigan. 

The Gulf shortwave will ride NE along the western edge of the
ridge today where it looks to merge with an impulse ejecting from
the base of the Colorado upper low as they move into SE TN late 
today. Although best dynamics and instability lies west of the 
area through today, deep moisture, coupled with modest MLCAPE on 
the order of 1000 J/kg and a surface trough lifting NE out of 
Alabama and Mississippi late today should help to ignite some late
afternoon and evening convection primarily over the southern 
third of the area. This surface trough is then expected to 
continue to push NE across the area overnight tonight with showers
and thunderstorms spreading NE into the central and northern 
Valley by Sunday morning.

The ECMWF, GFS, and NAM are all indicating a deep layer moisture
surge into the southern valley by this evening which reaches into
the central valley by morning. With PWs reaching above 1.5 inches,
which is above the 90th percentile for this time of year, much of
the central and southern areas could get a fairly decent rainfall
through tonight with 24 hour totals as high as 0.75 inches fcst
with some guidance even higher (SREF Plumes as high as 1.0
inches). Additionally, locally higher totals to over an inch in
thunderstorms across the southern valleys are possible by Sunday
morning. Areas in the northern Valley and SW Virginia will likely
see minimal totals of around 0.25 inches by Sunday morning.

.LONG TERM (Sunday Through Friday)... 
Precipitation chances really start to ramp up as we move into 
Saturday night/Sunday. As the front approaches the wind fields 
start to turn more southerly and increase in speed, bringing in in
more moisture to our area. On Saturday evening/night there is 
moderate CAPE available for storms to work with, but not much in 
the way of mid/low level shear. So we could see a few storms pulse
up quickly and threaten to produce strong gusty winds or some 
hail, but widespread severe weather is not anticipated on Saturday
(nor Sunday). As the front actually gets closer the precipitation
should become more widespread with the best chances for rain all 
week coming on Sunday/Sunday night. Will have to monitor 
precipitation amounts on Sunday as PWAT values of around 1.5" or 
higher, putting us into the 90th percentile for this time of year.
Some places could see several rounds of thunderstorms run over 
them leading to localized flooding.

Once we get into the work week things quiet down as the 
precipitation will exit off to the east throughout the day and 
temperatures are expected to be around normal. There will only be a 
brief lull in precipitation before a second system zips through the 
area. This one should move through quickly and only bring a round of 
rain on Tuesday night/Wednesday. It will also cool temperatures 
down, with highs on Thursday struggling to make it to the 70's. 
Quiet weather is then expected through the rest of the work week.

towards higher POPS in the mountains and plateau areas for the

in the valley during that time. 

Regardless of shortwave or terrain induced convection today,
MLCAPE approaching 2000 J/Kg along with 0-6KM shear values on the
order of 20 kts, and DCAPE in excess of 1000 J/kg could lead to an
isolated storm or two becoming strong to severe. Although the 
overall threat is very marginal, main concern would likely come 
from strong gusty winds and hail in the area mainly north of I-40 
having the greatest likelihood of stronger storms. Threat 
diminishes some as we move further south across the area.

Any showers and thunderstorms should rapidly end after sunset with
a quiet night expected. Both max and min temps fcst are about 6-9
degrees above normal, and in agreement with the SuperBlend which 
has been performing fairly well of late. This is generally about a
degree or two below MET/MAV guidance for the maximum and about a 
degree above guidance for the minimum. 


.LONG TERM (Saturday through Thursday)...
Upper level ridge tries to build back north Saturday so decreased
pops some south with only chance pops north. Also should be last 
hot day with temperatures near to above 90 lowest elevations. Low 
pressure area over northern Missouri and cold front to the south 
will move east during the day. Best instability and lift will be 
to the Northwest of the forecast area over the lower Ohio Valley 
and western Tennessee Valley. Isolated to scattered storms will 
still be possible with more showers and storms occurring across 
the north. As cold front approaches Saturday night and Sunday 
there will be more significant coverage of precipitation. The 
front will move slowly across the area Sunday and Sunday night 
into Monday. Some locally heavy rainfall amounts across southern 
sections Sunday and Sunday night over 2 inches possible. A few 
stronger storms are possible Sunday but the main threat will be 
heavy rainfall. Behind the front Monday night there will be a dry 
night but Tuesday into Thursday another front will move through 
with continued rain chances. Temperatures will be much cooler 
Wednesday and Thursday as A cool upper level trough moves into the
eastern states. Lows Wednesday night will drop into the 40s to 
lower 50s.

.SHORT TERM (This Afternoon through Friday)...

Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicates 
that the ridge is now out over the Atlantic with a shortwave trough 
passing well to the north across the Great Lakes. A more robust 
closed low is located across the Rockies and has lead to a high 
risk being issued by SPC for portions of the Southern Plains. 

Another hot afternoon across the Southern Appalachians with most 
temperatures as of 3 pm in the 80s. Most of the precipitation 
activity so far has been limited to isolated to scattered showers 
along the Plateau. Recent visible satellite imagery indicates some 
towering cu along the Appalachians and expect isolated to scattered 
precip. to begin there shortly. SBCAPE values are currently around 
1500-2000 J/Kg with 0-6 km bulk shear of 20-30 kts. expect there 
could still be a few strong to marginally severe storms this 
afternoon with gusty winds and marginally severe sized hail being 
the main threats. So far, convection has remained in check early 
this afternoon. A boundary can be noted on visible satellite imagery 
stretching from SW Mississippi northeastward to SE Kentucky and this 
has been where most of the convective activity has been. Therefore, 
the highest PoPs this afternoon continue to be along the Plateau. 

Timing of the highest PoPs remains a challenge. The NAM, GFS, and 
ECMWF indicate a weak shortwave trough moving through the area late 
tonight into early tomorrow morning. With this solution, widespread 
showers and storms will be possible throughout much of the morning 
on Friday. PW values are forecast to increase during this timeframe 
to 1.4-1.5 inch range, which is around the 90th percentile for mid-
May. The Hi-Res models show less activity in the morning with more 
diurnal showers and storms during the afternoon. Based on the latest 
guidance, have slightly higher PoPs during the morning, but have at 
least some mention of showers and storms throughout the day. 
Regardless of the timing, it looks like there will still be the 
chance for a few strong to marginally severe storms on Friday with 
gusty winds and small hail being the main threats. In addition, 
lowered high temperatures by 2-3 degrees to account for the higher 
PoPs and cloud cover. Although, highs will still top out int he low 
to mid 80s on Friday.

.LONG TERM (Friday night through Wednesday)...

Still under the influence of the ridge as we head into the weekend, 
leading to one more day of hot temperatures reaching near or above 
90 in many locations on Saturday. Could see some precipitation this 
day due to the warm temperatures with the best chances being in our 
northern counties near a mostly stationary boundary. Ridge will 
begin to be shoved off to our east by the next system (low 
pressure/cold front). This system will bring the best chances of 
rain to our area, with Sunday looking to be the wettest. We could 
see showers and thunderstorms in the afternoons over this weekend, 
with strong winds and hail being the main concerns...But at this 
point the forecast model soundings aren't supportive of a widespread 
severe weather outbreak. 

The front should push through on Monday and we will finally cool 
down with temperatures expected to be much closer to normal for this 
time of year. We take a bit of a break from precipitation behind the 
front as well, but not for long as another system will be knocking 
on our door by the middle of the work week. This system looks to 
move through much quicker with the best chances of showers to be 
Tuesday night/Wednesday. This round of precipitation looks to be 
mostly just rain as there will be very little CAPE available to help 
produce thunderstorms in our area. We will be dry at the end of next 
week with temperatures behind this second system expected to be 
several degrees below normal.

in the 60s. 

The upper level trough will pass well to the north across the Great 
Lakes on Thursday. Continued weak southwesterly flow will aid in 
advecting in slightly higher moisture values with PW values 
increasing into the 1.2-1.4 inch range, which is around the 75th 
percentile for mid-May. Additionally, the forecast area will be in

providing some weak synoptic lift for isolated to scattered showers 
and storms during the day on Thursday. Increased PoPs slightly from 
the previous forecast with best chances across the higher 
elevations. Expect there could be a stronger storm or two with

generally in the mid to upper 80s.

.LONG TERM (Thursday night through Wednesday)...

help trigger showers and thunderstorms for Thursday through 
Saturday. With plenty of moisture, marginal instability, and a bit
of shear, SPC has placed our forecast area in a marginal risk for
severe storms. A cold front will approach the area on Sunday. 
With with better forcing and a bit of instability and shear, we 
should see a better chance for thunderstorms on Sunday. Behind the
frontal passage, surface high pressure will build in for early 
next week. This is also the point where models begin to vary 
significantly. The GFS keeps us mainly dry through early Wednesday
with a cold front hung up across the Plains and the associated 
low almost into Canada. In contrast, the ECMWF is much wetter 
across our area, with the low centered further south and more 
progressive, resulting in a chance of showers and storms as early 
as Tuesday. To account for these differences, I have included low 
end PoPs for the timeframe.

develop in the mid afternoon through the evening beginning on 
Thursday -- with coverage increasing each day. Given some 30-40 kts 
of bulk shear and some high CAPE amounts (MLCAPE 3000 j/kg and 
MUCAPE 4000 J/kg), the risk for strong to severe storms with 
damaging winds and hail will exist each day. This activity will 
initiate on and favor the high terrain of the Mountains and Plateau, 
but could easily drift into the Valley later in the day. 

As mentioned, a strong upper-level storm system will shift into the 
Mississippi and Tennessee Valley from the Plains Saturday Night into 
Sunday. The cold front itself will push into the region on Sunday 
afternoon/evening, bringing a chance for stronger and more organized 
thunderstorms. Given the progged shear and instability, some more 
widespread strong to severe storms are possible depending on the 
exact timing of the front. In addition, locally heavy rainfall will 
be possible given the abundant moisture and potential for training 
of this activity. The front and base of the trough will push east 
out of the area on Monday, resulting in a cool down early next week -
- with highs returning to the mid to upper 70s and lows in the 50s.

During this time we will see dry conditions and above normal 
temperatures. Wednesday night into Thursday an upper level short 
wave moves up into the Great Lakes, forcing our ridge of high 
pressure to our east. Trailing moisture with this wave will enter 
our area on Thursday and allow for a slight chance of afternoon 
showers and storms across portions of the high terrain. On Friday 
POP chances increase to low-end chance across the CWA as an upper 
level trough moves into the plains and forces our ridge of high 
pressure further east and out to sea. High pressure further east 
should get rid of enough subsidence to warrant the low end chance 
across the area for afternoon showers and storms. Saturday looks 
very similar to Friday as the trough doesn't advance very much 
eastward. Sunday, however, the trough moves into the Ohio River 
Valley allowing some upper level divergence to move in. Increased 
moisture and lift gives us our best shot of precip through the 
period. Have high-end chance POPs in place for showers and storms 
on Sunday. 

Overall, fairly dry week with precip chances increasing by next 
weekend and above normal temps as we experience summer-like weather 
in mid-May.

.LONG TERM (Thursday through Tuesday)... Upper-level subtropical 
ridge will continue to remain centered over the Northern Gulf 
Coast on Thursday, helping to keep a front and any associated 
convection generally to the north and east of the forecast area 
once again. However, a few scattered strong storms may drift into 
the northern Plateau, upper east TN, and far southwest VA during 
the afternoon and evening. Breezy SW winds and abundant sunshine 
over much of the area will result in the warmest day so far in 
over a week with highs reaching to mid to upper 80s across parts 
of the Central/Southern Valley. 

The aforementioned ridge quickly breaks down late Thursday night 
into Friday as quick-moving upper-trough over the central Plains 
pushes a strong cold front into the lower Mississippi River and 
eventually the Tennessee Valley by the afternoon. This front will 
serve as a focus for lines/areas of showers and thunderstorms. 
Progged instability will be limited, but a window of 1000+ J/kg 
MLCAPE values seems possible in the mid to late afternoon coinciding 
with some 60+ kts of bulk shear values from this strong frontal 
system. As a result, a few strong to marginally severe storms will 
be possible, with damaging straight-line winds and locally heavy 
rainfall being the main threats. The cold front should clear the 
area by late Friday night, resulting in a clearing trend by Saturday 
morning. NW flow will keep temperatures quite cool in the upper 60s 
to lower 70s in most spots -- before dry air and surface ridge 
builds in for early next week. This will result in a warming trend 
back into the 80s by Monday and Tuesday, along with plenty of 
sunshine to close out the forecast period.

The morning hours will see the greatest coverage in rainfall, but
good chances for an additional round of scattered showers and 
thunderstorms will exist again in the afternoon. Given the

of Morristown, TN -- though a few rogue storms are not out of the
question across the region late in the day.

and near the front, allowing for a sunny day across most of the 
central and southern valleys. These sunny conditions, along with a
building high -- and breezy/gusty gradient SW winds will push the
mercury well into the 80s across most of the region. Some modest 
instabilty, shear, and the orientation of the front will allow 
for a strong storm or two in the afternoon as well -- mainly along
and NE of the I-26 corridor. Clouds and precipitation will then 
dissipate for the overnight hours -- but a mild night is expected 
with lows in the mid 50s to lower 60s. 

.LONG TERM /Wednesday through Monday/...
Generally quiet weather to start the long term portion of the 
forecast with a quasi-stationary frontal boundary expected to 
still be draped across (or just north of) our forecast area. The 
positioning of the boundary will be important to follow as it will
be the concentration point for shower and thunderstorm chances 
through the second half of the work week. Latest model trends are 
showing the boundary to be in our northern areas, and if they 
continue to push the boundary a bit further north the

Low will finally sweep through Friday into Saturday bringing the 
best chances for precipitation and thunderstorms. The passing system 
will also usher in cooler temperatures with highs on Friday expected 
to be about 10 degrees cooler than they were on Thursday. Some 
lingering precipitation and clouds will be possible through 
Saturday but the second half of the weekend should be dry. A slow 
warming trend will begin with temperatures expected to be near 
normal for the start of the next work week.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
343 AM EDT Sun May 7 2017

.SHORT TERM /Today and Tonight/...
The combination of a moist boundary layer from earlier rainfall, a
clearing sky and weakening winds has allowed widespread patchy 
fog development across the region early this morning. This fog is 
favoring sheltered valleys and locations near lakes/rivers (where 
some locally dense fog may be possible). Will continue monitor 
trends over the next couple of hours to see if an SPS or advisory 
is warranted early this morning. 

High pressure will quickly build in from the west today at the
surface, though the area will remain under NW flow aloft (which
will help to reinforce the cooler air mass). Still, thanks to
ample sunshine, drier air, and some increased heights, highs will
climb back into the 60s to around 70 degrees in most areas. A
welcome change to the very cool and damp conditions observed
yesterday. A tight pressure gradient may result in some breezy
conditions as well -- particularly along the mountains in the
afternoon/evening. 

Overnight, the combination of an unseasonably cool air mass, a 
mostly clear sky, and light winds will allow temperatures to dip 
into the mid 30s across the sheltered valleys of Southwest 
Virginia. Frost development is expected late tonight into the 
predawn hours Monday morning, before dissipating after sunrise.
Thus, a Frost Advisory was needed for that area between 2 AM to 8
AM early Monday morning. Elsewhere, a cool night is still expected
with lows in the 40s.  

.LONG TERM /Monday through Saturday/...
It will be dry and clear to start the extended forecast period; 
however, we will still be under northwest flow, which will help 
keep highs relatively cool on Monday, in the 60s and 70s across 
the area. A nearly stationary boundary will stretch across the 
northern part of the forecast area and remain there through 
midweek. This front will provide the focus for some weak clipper 
systems to cycle through, bringing a chance for showers and a few 
rumbles of thunder at times through Wednesday night. For the most 
part, the best chance for rain during this timeframe will be 
across the north (closer to the boundary), with areas further 
south staying sunnier with a much lower chance for rain. 
Temperatures will also rebound, moderating back to near to 
slightly above normal for this time of year. A more organized 
system will approach the area Thursday into Friday, bringing a 
better chance for rain and thunderstorms for the entire forecast 
area. This system will push east of the forecast area Friday night
into Saturday, with some lingering rain and clouds possible 
Saturday morning. Temperatures will drop a bit again behind this 
system, with highs in the 70s for Friday into the weekend.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
332 AM EDT Sat May 6 2017

.SHORT TERM /Today and Tonight/...
Slow moving upper-low continues to dominate the weather across the
region -- and will promote a cool, wet, and windy day across the
Southern Appalachian region. Early this morning, areas of light 
rain showers will gradually shift off to the east as the initial
trough shifts east of the mountains. However, clouds will linger
through the day -- and winds will increase as well thanks to the
very strong pressure gradient. After 18z, a secondary shortwave
will rotate south from the parent low (located over the upper Ohio
Valley). This feature will serve to kick of another round of
widespread showers and scattered thunderstorms during the
afternoon and evening. South of I-40 there will be some decent
shear to work with -- thanks to a 40 kt 850 LLJ and some modest
instabilty with MLCAPE values around 500-700 J/kg in the 
afternoon (if some breaks in the clouds can occur). As a result, 
strong to marginally severe storms will be possible in this area 
late this evening and evening. 

The remaining activity will taper off after sunset and over time
clouds will dissipate and push east as dry air moves in after 06z.
This may allow for some partial clearing and perhaps mostly clear
to clear sky for most areas after 09z. This will result in
temperatures dropping into the upper 30s to mid 40s -- a some
localized patchy frost in the usual frost pocket areas where 
winds decouple and colder air drains to. 

.LONG TERM /Sunday through Friday/...
Conditions improve on Sunday as dry, chilly northwest flow moves 
in behind the departing low. Skies should be mostly sunny, but 
highs will be in the upper 50s to upper 60s. Clear skies overnight
will help temperatures drop into the mid 30s to lower 40s. The 
same pattern continues on Monday with highs just a few degrees 
warmer, but still well below normal for early May. Lows will again
be cool Monday night, in the mid 40s to lower 50s at most 
locations. Upper flow becomes more zonal for the remainder of the 
week as a weak upper ridge builds in, and temperatures will 
moderate back to near normal values in the 70s and lower 80s. 
However, a stationary boundary will remain parked overhead or just
to our north from Tuesday through Thursday, bringing a bit more 
cloud cover and the chance for showers and scattered thunderstorms
along the boundary. Another upper trough will build into the 
eastern US for late Thursday into Friday, bringing the best chance
for showers and thunderstorms on Friday as a shortwave ripples 
through the base of the trough. The rain and clouds for Friday 
will keep temperatures a few degrees cooler -- topping out in the 
low to mid 70s in most locations.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
318 AM EDT Fri May 5 2017

.SHORT TERM /Today and Tonight/...
A deepening upper-level low pressure system will bring big changes
to the eastern Tennessee Valley and Southern Appalachian region
today -- as rain, cloud cover, and colder air will promote 
temperatures in the low to mid 50s! These high temperatures may be
the lowest ever recorded for a few spots on May 5th and highs 
will be 20 or so degrees below normal in many areas. This upper- 
low will slowly spread across the region, bringing with it some 
light rain showers that will increase throughout the day. Thus, a 
cold gloomly, rain will persist through the afternoon and into the
evening as this feature tracks toward the mountains. As a result,
have gone with some high likely to categorical PoPs, especially 
in the afternoon. Thereafter, PoPs will taper off from west to 
east as the front shifts east overnight. The northerly wind will 
keep temperatures from falling off too much -- though a few 
snowflakes are possible along the highest terrain. 


.LONG TERM /Saturday through Thursday/...
Cooler than normal conditions will continue for the majority of 
the extended forecast period. A shortwave and cold front will push
through the area on Saturday, resulting in a continued chance for
showers and maybe a thunderstorm or two during the afternoon. 
With minimal instability but decent shear and a low freezing level
for this time of year, it looks like a few of these storms may 
produce some small hail or breezy conditions. 

With such a low freezing level, despite it being the beginning of 
May, there's a chance for some light snow to mix in at the higher 
elevations both Saturday and Sunday morning. No accumulation is 
expected, but the highest peaks could see some flakes flying.

This system should exit the area by Sunday morning, resulting in a 
few dry but cool days with upper level troughing remaining overhead. 
Highs Sunday and Monday will be below 70 in most locations. 
Temperatures will warm gradually from here, with the upper trough 
finally lifting and a weak upper ridge building for the second half 
of the week. It will become more unsettled by Wednesday as well with 
a couple rounds of showers and isolated thunderstorms moving through.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
329 PM EDT Thu May 4 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tomorrow)...

Deep low pressure center will continue to slide eastward tonight 
with the center of the low moving across the area tomorrow. Gusty 
winds tonight will continue a little while longer than what was 
previously forecast. Have extended the high wind warning until 2 AM 
EDT. Broke up the wind advisory into two different segments to try 
and capture the event better. Have the Southern Valley in a wind 
advisory that will expire at 10 PM EDT and the rest of the forecast 
area in an advisory that will expire at 2 AM EDT, the same time as 
the high wind warning expiration. We haven't seen too much precip 
thus far today but that will change tonight when heavier bands of 
precip enter the area from out of Middle TN. There could even be a 
few isolated thunderstorms with the best chances being from the 
Central Valley and southward. These heavier showers move in between 
6 and 8 PM across the Plateau and into the East TN Valley between 8 
and 10 pm and NETN and SWVA between 10 PM and midnight. Generally, 
looking like rainfall amounts from half an inch to one inch will be 
possible with the one inch amounts more likely across our eastern 
mountains. Lows overnight will be in the lower to mid 50s.

Tomorrow expect more of the same as the center of the low rotates 
across the area. Winds won't be nearly as high but it will still be 
a cloudy and breezy day across the forecast area with wind gusts 
between 15 and 20 mph. Expecting on and off showers through the day 
but the amounts will be very light with rainfall amounts of a few 
tenths of an inch expected. Highs tomorrow will be around 15 to 20 
degrees below normal with highs in the mid to upper 50s.



.LONG TERM...(Tomorrow night through Wednesday)...

Low pressure system will still be slowly spinning through northeast 
of us. Wrap around precipitation will continue to be in the area 
through much of the weekend before this system exits the region. 
With the cloudy conditions and the winds coming out of the northwest 
we will see well below normal temperatures through the weekend and 
into next week. Weekend temperatures are forecasted to be roughly 5-
10 degrees below normal for this time of year. As this system moves 
out a shortwave trough and a cold front will dive out of the north 
on Saturday, this could help spark a round of thunderstorms. 
Forecast soundings show that there will be very little CAPE to work 
with (generally less than 500 J/Kg) but quite a bit of shear in the 
atmosphere (over 50 knots of 0-6 km). With how cold the temperatures 
are expected to be the freezing level will be pretty low, especially 
for this time of year (maybe 4-6 kft). This means that any small 
hail that is created in these storms could possibly make it to the 
ground before melting. While this is possible am currently not 
expecting widespread hail or any type of severe weather with these 
storms, but some small hail and breezy conditions can't be ruled out.

Along with these very cold temperatures comes the possibility to see 
some light snow in the tops of the mountains over the weekend. 
Saturday morning has the better chance of precipitation (compared to 
Sunday morning) and the freezing level will be hovering around 5,000 
feet, so the very highest elevations could see a brief switchover to 
the white stuff. 

After this system finally exits the area we should have a pretty 
quite first half of the work week as temperatures slowly rebound 
back to near normal.

FXUS64 KMRX 040814

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
414 AM EDT Thu May 4 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
A deepening low pressure area over the lower Mississippi Valley 
with associated front will move east northeast across the 
Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians later today and 
tonight. South to southeast winds will increase this morning with 
winds gusting to 45 mph in most locations and as high as 65 to 70 
mph in the foothills of the Appalachians. Showers were moving into
southeast Tennessee this morning with isolated thunderstorms 
occurring earlier across southern middle Tennessee. A large 
complex of storms along the Louisiana coast to Florida panhandle 
is expected to move east across Florida and southern Georgia 
through the morning. An upper low over southern MO...northern AR 
will help to enhance lift and increase instability as it moves 
into the Tennessee Valley this afternoon. The clouds associated 
with the complex of storms to the south will move out of the area 
by this afternoon and some partial clearing should develop with 
the surface low and ahead of the upper low. This should allow for 
enough destabilization for convection to develop. With the strong 
low level winds and shear a few strong storms with damaging winds 
are possible during the late afternoon and early evening hours. 
Rain chances will be highest in the south and lowest northeast 
where down sloping will allow for warmer temperatures into the mid
70s and fewer clouds until late in the day. Tonight there will be
a slight chance of thunderstorms until surface low moves east and
winds will shift to the southwest. Lows tonight will be cooler in
the upper 40s to lower 50s. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...
The 544-546 dm upper level closed low will be overhead on Friday.
These lower heights aloft, cloudy and rainy conditions will lead 
to a much cooler than average day on Friday. Light showers will be
widespread throughout the day. Based on the latest raw guidance 
cut back highs by 3-4 degrees compared to the previous forecast 
with highs in the upper 40s to mid 50s. The closed low will lift 
to the northeast Friday night but the cool and rainy conditions 
will persist into the overnight hours with lows in the mid 30s to 
mid 40s by Saturday morning. There is also a small chance for some
light snow in the mountains above 4500-5000 feet early Saturday. 
No accumulations are expected at this time.

A shortwave trough embedded in the northwesterly flow will rotate 
around the backside of the departing longwave trough. A cold front 
will dive southward out of the Great Lakes region into the Southern 
Appalachians on Saturday. Models do indicate some marginal 
instability with values in the 250-500 J/Kg range. PW values are 
only around 0.6-0.8 inches which is below normal for early May. The 
deep layer shear is impressive with over 60 kts of 0-6 km bulk 
shear. The freezing level is fairly low for early May in the 5-8
thousand foot range. Therefore, any storm that forms could 
quickly develop small hail. For now, it appears that any storm 
that forms could become strong with small hail and gusty winds but
the threat for severe weather is too low at this time to mention 
in the HWO. The cold front will move through late Saturday 
bringing in a reinforcing shot of colder air. There will once 
again be a small chance of light snow for elevations above 
4500-5000 feet early Sunday morning. Lighter winds Sunday night 
into Monday morning will lead to ideal radiational cooling 
conditions and there could be some patchy frost across the cooler 
locations in SW VA and NE TN. For now, confidence is not high 
enough to mention in the HWO.

The upper level pattern remains relatively stagnant moving into next 
week. The closed low will remain located across the Northeastern 
U.S. with a ridge across the Central U.S. Heights will slowly 
increase throughout the week as the ridge slowly builds to the east. 
Highs on Monday will be in the 60s and 70s with 80s forecast by 
Wednesday. The northwesterly flow throughout the extended will 
feature a few weak upper level shortwave troughs but the lack of 
moisture should keep the forecast dry.

FXUS64 KMRX 031931

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
331 PM EDT Wed May 3 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Thursday)...
Latest water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis beginning 
to show a well defined upper level trough over the northern plains
that will continue to drive southeast before becoming closed-off 
over West TN by tomorrow afternoon, then drifting eastward over 
Middle TN through tomorrow evening.

Current surface analysis indicates surface high centered over
southern Michigan with ridge axis south across east TN this 
afternoon. Surface low and associated frontal boundary across 
Arkansas and North Texas this afternoon will begin to push 
eastward overnight with surface low becoming located over Middle 
TN by tomorrow afternoon as cold front trails southward into 
Alabama. Ahead of the frontal boundary, models are indicating a 
pre-frontal band of convection that will reach into our area 
overnight with greatest pcpn chances over Plateau and southern 
tier counties through tomorrow morning. Following this, frontal 
pcpn through the day on Thursday will elevate pcpn chances over 
much of the area. However, strong downslope flow over the East TN 
mountains will help to hold off best pcpn from the northern third 
of the area east of I-75 and north of I-40 until late morning to 
early afternoon.

Biggest concern with this system is the very strong winds expected
ahead of the front on Thursday. Last few NAM runs has been 
trending upward with respect to 850 mb wind speeds. Latest run 
shows a very solid area of 70+ kts winds extending across the East
TN mtns from Monroe to Greene counties by late morning. Moderate 
negative omega on the lee side of the mountains in East TN, 
coupled with a very favorable ducting layer both present by 
Thursday afternoon, lead to the potential for a very strong 
mountain wave event for the area. Therefore a High Wind Warning 
was issued for those areas beginning overnight tonight.

.LONG TERM (Thursday Night through Wednesday)...
An active weather pattern through the extended.

For Thursday night and Friday, a deep upper trough will move across 
the Tennessee valley and southern Appalachians. Strong dynamics will 
continue to move across the area Thursday evening with limited 
instability. Will call for widespread showers with only a chance of 
thunder. These showers will be capable of bringing the stronger 
boundary layer winds down to the surface.

The strong low-level jet will also produce windy conditions, 
especially across the mountains. Later shifts may need to extend 
wind advisory and warning into the early morning hours Friday.

For Friday and Friday night, unusually cold upper low will be across 
the southern Appalachians producing chilly conditions with scattered 
to widespread showers. Across the highest elevations of the Smoky 
Mountains, temperature profile will be cold enough to mix with and 
change the precipitation to snow at elevations at or above 4 kft.
Minor snow accumulations are possible at Mount Leconte.

For Saturday, another short-wave short-wave will dig into the Ohio 
Valley and central/southern Appalachians. Feel enough daytime 
heating and boundary layer moisture to produce enough instability 
for scattered/broken showers and thunderstorms. Freezing level will 
be quite low and enough hail CAPE to warrant the potential of hail. 
Also, plenty of mid-level dry air to produce strong gusty winds, 
possibly damaging. Will include in the HWO the potential of strong 
to possibly severe storms during the afternoon/early evening.

For Sunday through Tuesday, upper trough moves east allowing upper 
and surface ridging to develop. Mostly dry conditions and a warm-up 
is expected.

074 
FXUS64 KMRX 030801
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
401 AM EDT Wed May 3 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Skies are clear across the forecast area early this morning. Winds
are light and temperatures were in the mid 40s to mid 50s. High 
pressure will slowly shift to the east today as low pressure over 
west Texas moves into the Mississippi Valley. Skies will be mostly
sunny most of the day with temperatures warming into the mid 70s 
to lower 80s. Clouds will increase tonight as a warm front moves 
north across the eastern Tennessee valley. Moisture and instability
will increase with showers and a few thunderstorms developing to 
the south and moving into southern Tennessee later tonight and 
spreading north. Winds will also increase from the south to 
southeast with gusts over 30 mph over the southern plateau and 
eastern Tennessee mountains after midnight.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...
A deep closed low will be approaching the forecast area from the 
west to start the day on Thursday. Models indicate that the 
surface low will be sub 1000 mb. In response low-level southerly 
to southeasterly winds will increase. The wind direction and 
synoptic setup will favor a mountain wave event along the TN/NC 
line and into the foothills. Wind gusts of 60 mph can be expected 
in these locations. For the remainder of the forecast area, winds 
will increase thanks to the deepening system. Therefore, went 
ahead and issued a wind advisory for all of the forecast area. 
Confidence is fairly high at this point for sustained winds in the
20-30 mph range with gusts up to 45 mph during the day on 
Thursday. 

The strong low level and upper level flow will create a favorable 
shear profile for strong to severe storms to form. However, there 
will be several limiting factors. Cloud cover and showers will be 
present Thursday morning as isentropic lift increases ahead of an 
approaching warm front. The downsloping winds will delay these 
showers in the valley until later in the day. In addition, the 
SBCAPE values are forecast to be below 300 J/Kg across the area. The 
latest SREF guidance only suggest around a 20-30 % chance of SBCAPE 
values of 500 J/Kg or greater across the Southern Valley with lower 
values elsewhere. Model soundings also indicate mid-level and upper 
level lapse rates closer to moist adiabatic. Overall, the chances 
for any strong or severe storms appears to be low but will continue 
with a low end mention of strong storms in the HWO. Again, the main 
impact will be the gradient winds. These winds will be strong enough 
to bring down a few trees and cause some sporadic power outages, 
especially across the higher elevations and the foothills. 

The focus will then shift to the much cooler temperatures forecast 
late in the week and over the weekend. The cold front will race to 
the east Thursday night into Friday morning as strong cold air 
advection, for early May, wraps around the system. The closed low 
will be directly overhead on Friday. For the forecast, expect 
numerous light showers across the region and widespread cloud cover. 
Some raw model guidance indicates that highs will not make it to 50. 
For now, have not gone that cold but did bump down highs by 2-3 
degrees from the previous forecast. The column will be cold enough 
for some snow showers late Friday night into early Saturday morning 
for locations above 4500-5000 feet. No accumulations are expected at 
this time. The upper level low will begin to lift out on Saturday. 

The pattern becomes stagnant late in the weekend and into early next 
week with the closed low located over the Great Lakes and a ridge 
along the Rocky Mountains and Northern Plains. Several northwesterly 
shortwave troughs will rotate around the backside of the trough. One 
of these will bring a reinforcing shot of cold air late Saturday 
into early Sunday. Rain chances will come to an end behind this 
front. Despite the cold air advection, temperatures will warm into 
the upper 50s to low 70s due to the plentiful supply of insolation 
Sunday afternoon. Sunday and Monday mornings will be the coldest 
during the forecast period with lows ranging from the mid 30s to 
upper 40s. 

The upper level pattern remains relatively unchanged going into next 
week. The closed low will remain quasi-stationary across the Eastern 
CONUS with a ridge across the Central CONUS. The forecast area will 
remain under northwesterly flow aloft with mostly dry and cooler 
than normal conditions forecast for the extended portion of the 
forecast. Lows next week will generally be in the 40s/50s with highs 
in the 60s/70s.

the Plains.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...

this period things will be ramping up with the approach of the next 
storm system from the west. Looks like we will have a high wind 
event in the Appalachian and foothills from Wednesday night through 
Thursday.  On Thursday if instability can work far enough north we 
might have a chance of severe storms--best chances south of our 
area, but could spread into our area--plenty of dynamics; 
instability is still questionable.  Best moisture might be aloft as 
low level jet brings moisture into the area, while surface warm 
front stays to our south. Will see how that develops as it gets 
closer.

After the cold front passes Thursday night much colder air will rush 
into the area, with enough moisture for precipitation through 
Saturday night and possibly some light, wet snow at times in the 
higher elevations--mainly Friday night through Saturday night.  At 
this time, looks too warm for measurable snow, but will keep 
watching. After this area clears out it will be turning drier, but 
the eastern trough looks like it will be slow to move out, so we 
will stay with below average temps through the end of the forecast 
next Tuesday.

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...

The cold front is now to the east and near the Atlantic Seaboard.
Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicate a
deep closed low slowly progressing northeastward across the Great
Lakes. A broad area of low pressure exists at the surface under 
this low. Southwesterly to westerly winds are still gusty at times
with a strong pressure gradient across the region. This continued
mixing and wrap around cloud cover will keep temperatures a few 
degrees warmer than previously thought this morning. Regardless, 
temperatures are still noticeably cooler than the last couple of 
mornings.

Wrap around cloud cover will begin to lift out to the north and east 
shortly after sunrise with mostly sunny skies expected throughout 
much of the day. Deep mixing and the strong pressure gradient will 
lead to gusty westerly winds today. Expect gusts will be around 
advisory criteria and issued a wind advisory for NE TN, SW VA, and 
the mountains for late this morning into the afternoon. The heart of 
the cold air advection will pass to the north today. Therefore, with 
mostly sunny skies and gusty westerly winds temperatures will warm 
into the 70s across most locations. Winds will begin to diminish 
this evening into the overnight hours as a surface ridge builds in 
from the west. Light winds and clear skies will allow for 
radiational cooling with temperatures dropping down into the mid 40s 
to low 50s tonight.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday)...

High pressure early Wednesday will give way to increasing clouds 
late and Wednesday evening as lower pressure moves across the 
Tennessee and Ohio Valleys and an upper low develops in its wake. 
Increasing rain chances south and west Wednesday night then reaching 
eastern areas by Thursday. Moderate instability will trigger some 
thunderstorms Thursday. With strong pressure gradient and slow 
movement of the system strong south to southeast winds will develop 
late Wednesday night and continue Thursday. A wind advisory may be

any thunderstorm development the stronger winds may reach the 
surface so a strong storm or two could occur. Warm temperatures 
Wednesday and mild lows Wednesday night will be followed by much 
cooler temperatures Thursday with increased clouds and precipitation 
as low pressure moves slowly east. Friday and Saturday much colder 
conditions as Upper low moves slowly from Tennessee and Ohio Valleys 
northeast toward the mid Atlantic and northeast states. There will 
be a chance of a few snow showers in the highest elevations late 
Friday night as lows reach into the 30s. Highs Friday will be in the 
mid 40s higher mountains to 50s lower elevations and then 50s and 
60s Saturday. Showers will continue with the upper low through 
Saturday night. Sunday and Monday Skies will clear with warming 
temperatures.

temperatures expected to be generally around normal for this time of 
year across the area. Our next system that looks to provide 
precipitation will be a low expected to slowly spin just north of 
our area. This low will bring along with it a warm front over the 
area ahead of the main low and the cold front it drags along. The 
weak warm front ahead of the system could bring precipitation as 
early as Wednesday evening/night, but the majority of the 
precipitation will hold off until Thursday. The highest 
precipitation chances with this system will come on Thursday evening 
as the low spins to our north. Models show the track of the upper 
low expected to move through eastern Kentucky which would put us in 
good position to get some wrap around moisture as this system heads 
out. After this system moves out the models hint at a ripple of 
energy moving in from the northwest over the weekend, so will 
mention low end precipitation chances into the weekend even though 
most locations might remain dry. After that we start to see drier 
northwest flow for the end of the weekend and into next week.

666 
FXUS64 KMRX 010729
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
329 AM EDT Mon May 1 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...

Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicates 
an amplified pattern across the CONUS with a closed low across 
the Central PLains and a ridge along both the Atlantic and Pacific
coasts. At the surface, a low pressure center can be seen across 
Illinois with a cold front stretching southward to near New 
Orleans. Widespread showers and a few embedded thunderstorms are 
present ahead of the boundary stretching all the way from the 
Great Lakes southward to the northern Gulf of Mexico. Closer to 
home, most of the precipitation has come in the form of scattered 
showers with limited instability. This will change throughout the 
day today with the chance for a few strong to severe storms across
NE TN and SW VA. 

For the morning, expect numerous showers with a few embedded 
thunderstorms across western portions of the area as the front 
slowly progresses to the east. Expect precipitation will come to an 
end for the western half off the area by noon. Models vary a good
bit on the amount of instability across NE TN and SW VA later 
this morning into early this afternoon. The NAM is by far the most
aggressive with SBCAPE values around 1500 J/KG at Tri- Cities 
around 18z. The GFS is much more conservative around 400-500 J/Kg 
or so with the RAP around 1000 J/Kg. The one thing not in question
is the low-level wind field and deep layer shear overall will be 
favorable for strong to severe storms. The main question is how 
much will the ongoing precipitation, cloud cover and timing of the
system hinder or help the amount of instability available later 
today. Cooler temperatures aloft will move in as the closed tracks
into the Great Lakes with height falls across the region. 
Additionally, the window of time for any strong to severe storms 
should be fairly small from around 10 am-4 pm today. The threat 
area will also be small and limited to locations along and east of
a Gatlinburg to Morristown to Jonesville line. The main threat 
from these storms will be damaging straight line winds. The threat
for a tornado appears very low with the winds veering around to 
the southwest as the instability values begin to increase. 

The pressure gradient along the boundary will be strong throughout 
the day and extended the wind advisory through 00z. The winds are 
not overly strong now but should see some stronger winds begin to 
mix down to the surface later this morning and into the afternoon. 

Much drier and cooler air will push in behind the front this 
afternoon and into the overnight hours. This can be seen currently 
on water vapor imagery across the Lower Mississippi River Valley. PW 
values will drop down to around 0.5 inches as drier air advects in 
behind the system. Temperatures will be noticeably cooler late 
tonight into Tuesday morning with lows dropping down into the mid 
40s and low 50s across most locations.

.LONG TERM (Tuesday through Sunday)...

Cooler and drier air will be moving in on Tuesday behind a 
departing cold front. Afternoon temperatures will be near seasonal
norms. Only concern on Tuesday will be continued breezy...gusty 
winds over the region. The winds will slowly decrease over the 
area throughout the day as the 850MB jet pulls out. This quiet 
weather pattern will not be around long as the next system 
approaches the area late Wednesday into Wednesday night. A weak 
warm front will lift across the area on Wednesday and could see a 
few isolated showers or storms develop late in the afternoon. A 
cold front will soon follow and bring the main band of convection 
across the area Wednesday night into Thursday. Behind the 
front...we will remain in an unsettle weather pattern as the upper
low push in for continue chance of showers and thunderstorms 
Thursday night into Friday. Precip chances will decrease for the 
weekend as the upper low moves northeast and out of the area with 
only minor wrap around showers to deal with.

.SHORT TERM (tonight through Monday)...A boundary will continue 
to approach the area from the west. Short term models seem to have
a better handle on this system...with rain beginning between 4 
and 6 pm for southern plateau and southern TN...and moving SW to 
NE through the night and early Monday morning. Instability is weak
with this system...but winds throughout the lower and mid levels 
are around 40 kts or stronger. If any storm cores can access these
winds and pull them to the surface...damaging winds will cause 
possible downed trees and powerlines across the area. PW values in
the southern Plateau and southern valley are around 1.2 to 1.4 
which is around the 90th percentile for this time of year. This 
system could produce locally heavy rainfall...with localized 
flooding possible in the slower areas of this line.

Overnight temperatures will be several degrees above normal due 
to the cloud cover and S to SW warm air and moisture advection 
that remains. 

A strong low level jet will move through the area overnight through 
tomorrow afternoon. Winds with this system could gust to around 40 
mph...with gusts of around 50 mph possible in the higher elevations. 
Have issued a wind advisory for the entire area. With the recent 
rainfall...could expect the possibility of a couple of trees 
down...especially with the higher wind gusts. The system should move 
east of the area by afternoon on Monday...with a few lingering light 
scattered showers possible through the early evening. Temperatures 
Monday will be a degree or two below normal with W to NW flow behind 
the departing boundary.

.LONG TERM (Monday Night through Sunday)...By Monday night, the 
cold front will be pushing east of the area, and dry, more 
seasonable weather will be returning. It may still be a bit breezy
on Tuesday behind the frontal passage, especially across the 
higher terrain along the mountains. By Wednesday, our next weather
system will be strengthening over the central US and will bring 
rain and thunderstorm chances to our forecast area for Wednesday 
night in Thursday. The system will continue to strengthen on 
Thursday as it drags a cold front across our area, and the upper 
low will take its time exiting the Mid-South. Wraparound moisture 
on the back side of the low will result in a continuing 
shower/isolated tstorm chances for the area on Friday and Friday 
night. Conditions should gradually improve on Saturday with the 
low finally lifting out of the area. The second half of the 
weekend looks pleasant with sunny skies and seasonable 
temperatures.

low spinning across the Southern Plains with a ridge just off the 
Carolina coast. At the surface, a low pressure center is currently
near Tulsa, Oklahoma with a warm front stretch to the east along 
the Ohio River Valley and a cold front extending southward into S 
Texas. IR satellite imagery shows a large area of showers and 
storms ahead of the cold front across Arkansas and stretching 
southwards into SE Texas. 

Expect a few areas of patchy fog to start off the day that will 
quickly mix out shortly after sunrise. Model soundings suggest that 
the CAP will be stronger today and a bit more elevated in the 750-
650 mb range. Therefore, not expecting any shower or storms outside 
of the higher elevations. Winds will begin to increase as the 
pressure gradient tightens from the approaching front. Winds in 
the mountains late in the day could approach wind advisory 
criteria but have decided to hold off on an advisory for now. 
Temperatures will once again top out well above normal for late 
April with highs in the 80s for most locations. 

Models have come into pretty good agreement with the timing of the 
system overnight tonight into Monday morning. Expect the line of 
shower/storms will be weakening as they move into a more stable and 
capped environment. Model soundings indicate the atmosphere will 
saturate late tonight but SBCAPE values are generally less than 500 
J/Kg with some weak capping continuing throughout the overnight 
hours. The low level wind field is very impressive with an 850 mb 
jet of around 55-60 kts. Expect a couple of storms will be strong 
enough to transport these winds down to the ground despite the 
limiting factors. Therefore, the main threat with these storms will 
be damaging straight line winds. The low-level shear profile is 
generally uni-directional and the storms will be weakening as they 
move into the forecast area and think the chance for a tornado is 
very low. Flooding should not be an issue with the line of showers 
and storms moving through the area rather quickly. The main 
timeframe for strong to severe storms will be from around 
midnight to 8 am Monday morning.

Clearing conditions are expected by Monday afternoon with cooler 
temperatures behind the front. Highs on Monday will be much more 
pleasant in the upper 60s to mid 70s as cold air advects in behind 
the departing system.

.LONG TERM (Monday Night through Saturday)...

A cold front and associated shower and thunderstorm activity will
be pulling away from the area Monday night for generally dry 
conditions. However...850MB winds will remain elevated and 
breezy...gusty winds will continue over the region through the 
night. These breezy winds will bring in cooler near normal 
temperatures. Surface high pressure and zonal flow aloft on 
Tuesday will provide a quiet and dry weather day. Then...we will 
quickly move into an active weather pattern Wednesday through the 
end of the period. Model consistency isn't great but there is some
general agreement. The basic pattern appears to be a weak warm 
front lifting through around Wednesday... followed quickly by a 
cold front Thursday and the upper low slowly moving across the 
area around the Friday/Saturday time frame. This general scenario 
will keep at least chance pops in place through the end of the 
extended with the best chance of convection expected on around 
Thursday.

.SHORT TERM(Today and Tonight)...

Current IR satellite imagery indicates an elongated E-W area of 
showers and storms stretching along a stalled frontal boundary from 
Oklahoma to Maryland. Fortunately this activity is forecast to 
remain to the north of the area. IR imagery does indicate the cirrus 
shield is expanding southward from the showers/storms and expect 
some high clouds to start the day. Current water vapor imagery also 
notes strong moisture convergence near the Ozarks stretching to the 
Ohio River Valley. Closer to home, an upper level ridge sits just to 
the east of the Florida peninsula. This upper level feature will be 
the main focus throughout the short-term forecast for the Southern 
Appalachians. 

This morning should not start out as foggy as yesterday. High clouds 
and slightly higher winds will hinder fog formation. The main 
challenge once again will be PoPs. The cap will remain in place 
around 700-800 mb but is forecast to be a bit weaker today. There is 
not much to speak of in the way of lift with the ridge being the 
main weather influence. In addition, the surface front will remain 
to the north of the forecast area as well. The weaker cap should 
allow for a few isolated to scattered summer-like afternoon 
shower/storms with the better chances in the higher elevations. The 
main story will be the record breaking high temperatures forecast 
today. The higher heights aloft and insolation will push 
temperatures up into the upper 80a and low 90s for most valley 
locations. The record for Knoxville is 88 degrees set back in 
1872 during the Grant Administration. The records for CHA and TRI 
are a bit more recent. See the data below for more information.

Knoxville    88 set in 1872     Forecast High 90
Chattanooga  88 set in 1942     Forecast High 90
Tri-Cities   86 set in 1996     Forecast High 90

.LONG TERM (Sunday through Friday)...

An upper ridge of high pressure will shift eastward on 
Sunday...allowing for slightly cooler but still well above normal 
temperatures. Limited diurnal convection is possible late in the 
afternoon but this activity should remain confined to higher 
elevations. Will see a pattern change Sunday night into Monday as 
a cold front approaches from the west. A line of showers and 
thunderstorms is expected to develop and move through the region 
ahead of the front. A strong 60 to 70 KT jet will accompany the 
front and will provide widespread breezy and gusty 
conditions...and also may allow for a stray thunderstorms to 
generate significant winds. By Tuesday...the frontal boundary will
be well to our east for a dry day with near normal temperatures. 
Model consistency becomes poor and confidence is low Wednesday 
through the end of the extended. Overall...the pattern looks 
unsettled with an area of low pressure moving through and the 
approach of an upper trough. The best chance for precip through 
this period currently looks like Thursday and will keep likely 
pops in place with decreasing chances into Friday.

suppress most afternoon convection outside the mountains.

to lose its grip on the area, but should again be well into the 
80s at most locations. A strong low pressure system will track 
northwest of the forecast area Sunday/Sunday night, bringing a 
chance for some thunderstorms for our area Sunday night into 
Monday as the associated cold front pushes through. Frontal 
passage timing should limit instability and does not appear 
favorable for a large severe threat. However, a marginal wind 
threat appears possible with a low level jet overhead maxing out 
around 65kts.

The frontal passage on Monday will bring temperatures back into the 
70s for the first half of the workweek. Upper level flow becomes 
more zonal as well, with a fast moving weak shortwave bringing a 
brief chance of showers to the far northern part of the forecast 
area on Tuesday night/Wednesday. Another trough will approach the 
area Wednesday into Thursday, bringing the next chance for 
widespread precipitation to the region.

thunderstorm or two at the end of the work week. That warm front 
will advance well north of the forecast area later Friday night 
into Saturday as an amplifying long wave trough presses slowly 
northeast out of the Mountain West through the Great Lakes Sunday 
into Monday. As this occurs, a deepening mid latitude cyclone will
drag a significant cold front through the Southern Appalachian 
Region with an increasing probability of showers and thunderstorms
Sunday night into Monday. Beautiful above normal warmth is in

typical early Spring temperatures by Monday.

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Tuesday)...As an upper low slowly tracks
northeast across the Carolinas tonight...a few isolated light
showers may rotate into far northern and eastern areas.
Otherwise...high pressure building in will provide a quiet night
with dry conditions. The area flooding and river levels will
continue to recede over the next several hours but will see a few
locations with ongoing areal flooding and river flooding through
at least the evening hours. With recent rainfall...expect patchy
fog to develop across the region late tonight. Improved conditions
are expected on Tuesday with the high pressure in control for a
dry day with decreasing clouds and warmer temperatures.

.LONG TERM (Tuesday Night through Monday)...
Upper level ridge is finally allowed to build in across the area for 
Tuesday night and Wednesday before being forced east by approaching 
shortwave trough which drops SE out of Colorado and into lower 
Mississippi Valley by Thursday morning before lifting NE across 
middle TN Thursday night. Flow aloft remains predominately SW 
through the weekend, before the next, stronger shortwave drops SE 
out of the Rockies by Monday.

Models are in fair agreement on the timing of the frontal system on 
Thursday with best rain chances expected in the afternoon and early 
evening before this boundary quickly washes out by Friday morning. 
Both GFS and NAM now indicating enough instability/shear Thursday 
afternoon that strong to isolated severe storms could be possible. 
MLCAPE values range from 800-1400 J/kg by afternoon with bulk shear 
on the order 30-35 kt which will allow for some organization of any 
storms that develop. As with most severe weather in East TN, timing 
is everything, slightly earlier/later and enough instability may not 
be available. At this point, it certainly bears watching over the 
next few days.

Friday will see a warm front push NE through the area that will 
increase POPs through Friday night, before some drying in advance of 
our next cold front on Monday which, at present, looks like it is 
being handled consistently in the GFS, ECMWF, and the GFS Ensemble. 
This system is expected to once again bring a widespread round of 
pcpn to the area.
