National Weather Service Morristown TN
246 AM EDT Mon Apr 24 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and tonight)...
Precip in our area has shown a diminishing trend overnight, and this 
is expected to continue through the morning as the stronger lift 
with the upper jet streak shifts east and low level moisture 
advection stays mainly on the east side of the mountains. A 
downslope flow in the northern half of the area should also help 
keep QPF amounts relatively modest today, which will help improve 
the ongoing flooding situation (or at least not make it much worse). 
With the threat of flash flooding ending, the Flash Flood Watch will 
be canceled. 

The closed low over northern AL will drift SE across GA today and
be located near the SC coast tonight. Moisture wrapping around 
the low will maintain overcast cloud cover for most of the area 
today. Forecast soundings show deep saturation remains into this 
evening at TRI, but the aforementioned downslope flow and lack of 
synoptic QG forcing should produce just scattered coverage of 
light showers this afternoon and evening. A few breaks in the 
clouds may develop near CHA late today, and may help temps get 
into the upper 60s.

.LONG TERM (Tuesday through Sunday)...
With the low pressure system off to our east and the skies clearing 
out, we will finally start to dry out from this weekends rainfall. 
With the ridge building in and the sun shinning we will quickly warm 
up the first half of the work week, with highs expected to be in the 
80's for most people by Wednesday. Warm and dry conditions will 
continue for several days before our next system brings a bit of a 
cool down and another chance for showers and thunderstorms. After the 
initial front moves through on Thursday night/Friday morning the 
models start to diverge. The GFS shows that the area remains mostly 
dry through the rest of the 7-day forecast with ridging building 
leading to warmer temperatures and clearer skies. The ECMWF wants to 
stretch the front out over us and have it linger over the area for a 
while. This would lead to continuous shower/thunderstorm chances 
into the weekend before drying out. Will keep low end precipitation 
chances in the forecast until better model consistency begins to take 
shape. Another frontal system will be knocking on our doorstep at 
the very end of this forecast, which should bring another round of 
widespread showers and thunderstorms to the area early next week.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
307 PM EDT Sun Apr 23 2017

.SHORT TERM /Tonight and Monday/...
A widespread flooding areal flood event is underway across the
eastern Tennessee Valley and Southern Appalachian region this
afternoon. Abundant moisture is combining with a slow moving cold
front and strong upper-level storm system to generate several 
rounds of light to moderate, steady precipitation. Over the last 
24 to 36 hours, the region has seen 2 to 4 inches of rain, with a 
few localized amounts of 5 to 6 inches. The hardest hit areas have
been along the Cumberland Plateau, the Cumberland Mountains of 
Southwest Virginia, and much of Southeast Tennessee. However, all 
areas are experiencing rampant flooding along creeks/streams, low 
water crossings, poor drainage areas -- which has resulted in 
numerous road closures. As a result, a Flood Warning is in effect 
for the entire CWA until 6:30 PM. This will need to be reassessed 
by the evening shift at that time. 

Latest runs of the HRRR/RAP indicate this activity beginning to
wane across the southern areas between 21-00z as a dry slot moves
in. However, locations across the Northern Plateau,
Central/Northern Valleys and the NC/VA/TN mountains may see
several more hours of light to moderate rainfall. This could
result in an additional 1 to 2 inches in some spots where heavy
training occurs. Eventually, some tapering off will occur --
roughly from 03-09z west to east. However, this may be a slow
process, so have expanded the watch for eastern areas until 12z
Monday. Some significant flooding issues may occur in these areas,
so travel is discouraged unless necessary. 

Clouds and light rain will linger into the morning hours --
especially over upper East Tennessee and Southwest Virginia. Any 
flooding issues may linger as well -- so use caution on the 
morning rush hour commute. Temperatures will be slow to climb 
given the cloud cover, so highs in the low to mid 60s will be 
common. 

.LONG TERM /Monday Night through Sunday/...
A few lingering showers are expected to slowly exit the area on 
Monday as a upper low tracks along the east coast. High pressure 
will build in late Monday into Monday night for a quite weather 
pattern for mid week. The high will dominate area weather through 
Wednesday for dry conditions and warmer temperatures. Models 
beginning to show better consistency with a cold front moving in 
around Thursday...bringing our next chance of showers and 
thunderstorms. Model consistency deteriorates after Thursday...but
models do indicate a weak boundary moving through the region 
around the Friday time frame providing a chance for additional 
convective activity. Then...current model runs build a ridge of 
high pressure over the area for Saturday and the next system 
beginning to approach the area on Sunday.

eastern Counties.

the cool side today.

.LONG TERM (Monday through Saturday)...

by early Monday. We could continue to see some wrap around 
precipitation in Southwest Virginia and along the Southern 
Appalachian Mountains through Monday and into Monday evening, but

will be knocking on our door, a frontal boundary moving in from the

been disagreement with how much strength and moisture this system 
will have as it moves through. Current model runs suggest that it 
maintains it's strength and moves through Thursday bringing 
widespread showers and thunderstorms. After this system moves 
through we will quickly dry out and ridging will once again start to 
take place leading to another warm up in temperatures.

FXUS64 KMRX 221922

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
322 PM EDT Sat Apr 22 2017

.SHORT TERM /Tonight and Sunday/...
Another round of showers and thunderstorms have begun to fire west
of the MRX CWA across Middle TN and into portions of the northern
Plateau. This activity is firing along the remnant boundary/front
in place roughly along the I-40 corridor. North of I-40, which has
remained overcast and wet for most of the day, a capped, more 
stable environment remains in place. However, places along and 
south of the I-40/I-81 corridor have seen some sunshine over the 
last 2-3 hours. This has helped destabilize things, with MLCAPE 
values in the 1000-1500 J/kg range across the Southern Plateau and
Valley -- and in the 500-1000 J/kg across the central Valley and 
along the Great Smoky Mountains. 

As a result, am expecting the potential for some strong to
marginally severe storms - particularly in Slight Risk area
between 4 to 9 PM EDT this afternoon and evening. The main threats
with this activity will be straight-line damaging winds, along
with some marginally severe hail. However, the primary impact from
this activity will be the threat for locally heavy rainfall and 
flash flooding -- along with a risk for lightning for the folks 
with outdoor plans.

As mentioned, there is a favorable set-up for flash flooding
tonight into Sunday, particularly across the northern Plateau and
portions of southwest Virginia and far northeast Tennessee which
has already seen heavy rain today and last night (1-2 inches), 
and could see an additional 2-3 inches through Sunday evening.
Adding to the threat are high PWAT values up to 1.5 inches, a deep
warm cloud layer with some CAPE to work with, and the potential
for training for the mean flow potentially moving parallel to the
boundary overnight. Then, another round(s) of locally heavy 
showers will re-develop and move across portions of East Tennessee
and Southwest Virginia tomorrow ahead of the upper-low passage as
it moves across the state on Sunday. There is really not a
specific time more favored for rainfall Sunday, though things
should begin to die down as the feature moves east after 21z.

As a result, have maintained the Flash Flood Watch for the entire
region until 21z on Sunday. May have to look at extending this in
time based on model and radar trends this evening and overnight. 


.LONG TERM /Sunday Night through Saturday/...
Residual showers will slowly exit the Southern Appalachian Region
Sunday night into Monday as an upper level low pulls away from 
the area. High pressure builds in late Monday into Tuesday for dry
conditions and a warming trended for mid week. Model consistency 
quite poor Thursday through the rest of the period...but overall 
trend is for an unsettled end of the period with a weakening 
frontal boundary progged to move through on Thursday and another 
system approaching the area around the Friday/Saturday time frame.

.SHORT TERM (Today through Sunday)...For early this morning, areas
of convection is moving northeast across the Tennessee valley due
a series of waves moving along a frontal boundary over the area.
The HRRR model shows these area of convection slowly weakening
this morning and mainly staying over the northern half of the
area.

Active weather next 48 hours with a series of jet streaks 
enhancing the divergence aloft over the area. A frontal boundary 
across the Tennessee valley will be strengthen by the circulation 
around these jets. Fronto-genetic forcing along with increasing 
moisture/instability this afternoon will produce widespread 
showers and thunderstorms. MLCAPES of 1500 J/kg and PWs around 1.4
inches (which is near the daily max) will produce very heavy rains
with the storms. Enough hail CAPE and mid-level dry air/850mb jet
of 35kts to produce hail up to quarter size and potential of
damaging winds with the stronger storms.

For tonight, approaching and deepening upper trough over the mid-
section of the nation will once again enhance the divergence aloft
over the Tennessee Valley. Even though the frontal boundary will
move south of the area, the pressure falls associated with the jet
dynamics will produce an inverted surface trough across the
southern Appalachians late Saturday night and Sunday. This
boundary will focus around round of showers with heavy rains.

Due to the persistent heavy rains, training of cells along these
boundaries and climatology very high PWs, there is a potential of
flash flooding. Have issued a Flash Flood Watch for flash flooding
for the entire area from mid-afternoon through Sunday afternoon.
Later shifts will need to especially watch the burn scar area in
Sevier county.

Warm today, but plenty of clouds and rain showers Sunday will keep
temperatures cooler.

.LONG TERM (Sunday Night through Friday)...
Low pressure system will be slowly moving south and east of us as
we head into the last portion of the weekend. We could see some 
wrap around showers Sunday night into Monday, with the best 
chances being along the Southern Appalachian Mountains. As the low
continues to move to the east a ridge will start to build in from
the west. This ridge will dry us out and help along a warming 
trend that will continue through the work week. Another frontal 
system will make a run at our area in the second half of the work 
week, but recent model runs suggest that this may fizzle out 
before it can bring any widespread precipitation to our area. By 
the end of the work week, models suggest that temperatures across 
the area will be in the 80's with some locations possibly flirting
with 90 degrees.

night into early Sunday. With deep moisture in place...flooding is
expected to the main threat. A few showers may linger into Monday
across far northern and eastern locations as the system pulls 
away from the area. High pressure builds in late Monday into 
Tuesday for a return to dry and warm conditions for mid week. 
Model consistency becomes poor and confidence is low by the end of
the extended but the trend is for the next system to move in 
around Thursday/Friday time frame.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
330 AM EDT Fri Apr 21 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...A weak wave is moving across the
northern half of the area producing scattered showers and isolated
thunder. This wave will exit the area early this morning.

A frontal boundary will move into the northern half of Tennessee
and southwest Virginia by this afternoon. Airmass along and ahead
of the boundary will become unstable with MLCAPES of 1000-1300
J/Kg. Due to dry air in the mid-levels and below cloud base,
isolated strong to damaging winds are possible with the stronger
storms. Hail CAPE will be enough to support isolated hail up to
quarter size. PWs will increase to 1.35 inches which is near the
90th percentile of climatology. Since storm motions will be nearly
parallel with the frontal boundary, training of thunderstorms with
heavy rain is possible. Localized flash flooding is a concern.

The convection will weaken by sunset, but given frontal boundary
across the area, scattered convection will remain through the
night.

.LONG TERM (Saturday through Thursday)...
Frontal boundary will still be stalled out in our vicinity as we 
start the weekend. Current forecasts have it draped across the 
Kentucky/Tennessee border by Saturday morning. Along this boundary
(especially south of it) there will be good chances to see 
thunderstorms on Saturday. High PWAT values of over 1.25 inches 
will combine with CAPE values of over 1000 J/Kg and decent shear 
through the atmosphere. This combination will lend itself to 
possibly seeing some strong to possibly severe storms Saturday. 
The biggest threat with a few storms would be strong winds.. 
Additionally winds in the mid to upper levels of the atmosphere 
will be moving generally west to east, parallel to the boundary at
the surface. This will increase the chances of training storms 
and we could see some flooding problems if several storms move 
over the same area. 

Precipitation chances will stick around through the weekend as the 
low pressure system slowly swings south of us before moving off the 
Atlantic seaboard. As this system slides along the stationary 
boundary near us rain wrapped up with the low will continue through 
Monday night. Another frontal system will make a run at us from the 
northwest but a strengthening high pressure system will build in 
from off the East Coast. This high pressure system will win out and 
we will see several days of clear skies and very warm temperatures. 
Towards the end of the work week high temperatures are expected to 
be around the mid 80's for most of our forecast area.

FXUS64 KMRX 201854
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
254 PM EDT Thu Apr 20 2017

.Short term (Tonight and Friday)...
Scattered convection firing along the Plateau and Mountains will 
continue to develop this afternoon in an increasingly moist and
less unstable environment. SBCAPE values are progged to be around
1000-1500 J/kg this afternoon, with MLCAPE values progged to be 
as high as 700-800 J/kg by 21-22z timeframe. There is very little 
shear to work with, so am not expecting very much organization 
with this activity (which will favor the high terrain thanks to 
some added orrographic lift). However, a localized strong storm is
possible - with gusty winds and small hail being the main 
threats. PWATs are progged to be around 1.2", so a quick heavy 
downpous will also accompany any activity that develops.

These storms should die quickly with the loss of heating, resulting
in a mostly/partly clear evening. However, clouds will quickly be
on the increase after midnight as a weak front drops south out of
KY late tonight into Friday morning. This will generate another 
round of slower moving showers and storms progged to move into the
northern half of the region between 09-15z. The main threats with
this activty will be localized flooding due to the slow-moving 
nature of these storms -- as well as gusty winds and some small 
hail. A better threat for scattered severe storms may evolve south
of I-40 south (which will be precip free longer) as the 
atmosphere destablizes in the afternoon thanks to some better 
heating. The front will sag south providing a focus for more 
organized convection there between 18-00z. 


.Long term (Friday night through Thursday)...Friday night...the 
boundary that remains over the area through Friday moves north...
with a low pressure system and associated front approaching the 
southern Appalachians from the west. Scattered rain showers will 
continue through Friday night in to early Saturday morning with 
just enough instability to include a slight chance of thunder 
in the forecast.

Saturday...rain chances begin increasing through the morning 
with enough lift...instability...and moisture for scattered 
showers and thunderstorms to become more widespread through 
the early afternoon. With minimal wind shear...high PW values 
and weak lift...strong storms will be possible with a low chance 
for isolated severe. By Saturday evening...the low level winds 
shift from SW to W...with low level warm air advection and moisture 
decreasing. As cooler drier air moves in to the area through 
Saturday night...thunder becomes limited...with only scattered 
light showers remaining through the night.

Sunday...cooler and drier air will continue to advect in to the 
area behind the low pressure with enough wrap around moisture to 
keep light scattered showers in the forecast through the afternoon. 
Temperatures will be several degrees below normal as opposed to 
several degrees above normal that has been occurring for several 
days. By Sunday late afternoon...the low pressure will be well 
east of the Appalachians...with rain chances quickly diminishing.

Sunday night through Thursday...a weak ridge moves over the area. 
The NW flow slowly shifts to the W and then SW through the 
beginning of the work week...with a gradual warming trend to 
temperatures through the rest of the extended. Mostly clear 
skies and dry weather will be present.

FXUS64 KMRX 200735
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
335 AM EDT Thu Apr 20 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Patchy fog/low stratus is possible early this morning due to
partly clear skies and residual ground moisture from this week's
rain. Some isolated showers are possible this morning, but most
areas should stay dry into this afternoon. Scattered showers and
thunderstorms are expected to develop this afternoon with winds
out of the south-southwest advecting Gulf moisture into the area
(PWATS near 1") and a bit of instability (MLCAPE values generally
under 800 J/kg). With very little shear to work with and the only
forcing being orographic lift, we're not expecting many strong
storms, but there is the potential for an isolated strong to
severe storm producing some strong winds or small hail. Again, 
with the orographic lift being pretty much the only forcing, the 
best chance for storms will be over the higher elevations. 
Convection will fizzle out after sunset. Tonight should be mainly 
dry, but northern portions of the forecast area will begin seeing 
increased cloud cover and potentially a shower/thunderstorm as a 
frontal boundary slowly approaches the area. Temperatures will be 
quite warm today, reaching the lower 80s in many locations. Lows 
tonight will hover near 60 degrees.


.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...
Zonal flow aloft dominates Friday and Saturday ahead of a digging
Plains trough that swings through the area Sunday with weak 
ridging behind it through Wednesday. At the surface, frontal 
boundary approaches the area Friday morning becoming nearly 
stationary across the area Friday night. Boundary then begins to 
lift north Saturday ahead of a well defined low pressure system 
that will finally kick east of the area on Sunday afternoon and 
allow for high pressure and an extended period of drier conditions
through Wednesday.

Frontal boundary on Friday will serve as a focusing mechanism for 
showers and thunderstorms once again. With model indicated PWs of 
1.4 inches, MLCAPE values nearing 1000 J/kg and sufficient deep 
layer shear, some of these storms could become organized enough to 
produce an isolated strong to locally severe threat across the area. 
Additionally, orientation of sfc boundary parallel to the deep layer 
flow could cause training cells and the possibility of heavy 
rainfall in training cells. 

Rain threat will persist overnight Friday before diminishing some 
over the southern half of the area early Saturday as warm front 
ahead of the approaching low Saturday night, shifts north of the 
area. This is followed by another potential bout with severe 
thunderstorms Saturday night as a 30-40 kt low level jet develops 
ahead of the approaching front. As the upper level trough begins to 
rotate through the area, some shortwave energy and sufficient deep 
layer shear could once again act to support a primary threat of 
large hail and damaging winds. Although, latest consensus of models 
indicates that greatest threat for severe will likely lie further 
west over NW Mississippi and the southern third of Middle TN, low 
level forcing of the associated front could act as a focal point 
for severe weather as it moves through East TN Saturday night.

Forecast then sees a prolonged period of clearer skies and drier 
conditions Monday through Wednesday. With a surface ridge nosing 
southeast from New England and an upper level ridge finally able to 
establish itself over the area, we can expect seasonal temperatures 
gradually warming about 4-8 degrees above normal by Wednesday.

indication of weak to moderate instability available for convection.

rainfall could be rather heavy with some training; especially north

afternoon into the evening hours. The chance for rain will remain

but would likely decrease through the daylight hours Saturday

become severe later in the day Saturday into the evening hours as a 
strengthening low level jet pulls higher dewpoint air north into the 
Southern Appalachian Region. At this time, model depiction indicates 
sufficient instability for storms; however, shear should be rather 
strong with the 35 to 40 kt low level jet building into the area 
Saturday evening. The convective precipitation wraps up later 
Saturday night with a decent chance of showers on Sunday as a 
healthy amount of short wave energy rotates through the base of the 
Eastern U.S. long wave trough. The forecast area finally gets a 
chance to dry out Monday through Wednesday with some upper level

National Weather Service Morristown TN
323 AM EDT Wed Apr 19 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Patchy fog is possible this morning as a soupy airmass remains in
place overhead, but clouds should limit radiative cooling and 
dense fog development. 

Scattered showers will continue tomorrow with the stationary
boundary remaining nearby and moisture remaining in place. With
the shortwave disturbance pushing east, shower activity should
be less widespread than the past few days. Precipitation will
taper off from southwest to northeast throughout the day and into
tonight, and we could see some breaks in the clouds by late 
afternoon. Skies will clear a bit overnight and with a moist 
boundary layer, patchy fog will again be possible.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...
Zonal flow aloft looks to continue across the area through the 
early portion of the weekend. An approaching front during the 
latter part of Thursday will once again stall as it moves across 
our area on Friday. A stronger shortwave moving out of the Rockies
Friday and into West TN on Saturday will finally begin to dig a 
trough over the SE US that will drive the front east of our area 
late Sunday. With this, we can expect to see a continued unsettled
weather pattern persisting into the weekend before we dry out on 
Monday and Tuesday. 

The nearly stationary boundary that has been effecting our weather 
over the last several days finally lifts N of the area Thursday. 
This should allow for lower POPs across much of the area, excluding 
SW VA and NE TN, for most of the day. Thursday night sees next front 
approaching from the W with increasing deep layer moisture moving 
into the area overnight into Friday. POPs once again increase across 
much of the area Friday through Saturday as this next front begins 
to stall out across the area. The digging trough finally pushes the 
boundary east of the area by Sunday afternoon with a drying trend 
expected for Monday and Tuesday. 

Models look to be in very good agreement on upcoming large scale 
evolution of the stalling front Friday and Saturday and the digging 
SE trough on Sunday. Unfortunately, as has been the case over the 
last few days, the devil is in the details. With a nearly stationary 
boundary draped over the area Friday through Saturday, we could once 
again expect periods of rain, rainshowers, and even thunderstorms 
dependent upon exact frontal location and the timing of any 
shortwave features propagating through the area. Currently there is 
not enough fine detailed agreement between the models to more 
precise with weekend POPs which may be more reasonable to believe 
will see periods of active wx followed by some lulls prior to the 
frontal passage on Sunday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
311 AM EDT Tue Apr 18 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...
Latest water vapor and RAP upper air analysis indicate a few
upstream shortwave troughs...one along the TN-AL border...and a 
second over northeast AR...and yet a third over eastern TX this 
morning. At the surface, nearly stationary frontal boundary south 
of the area over northern GA, AL, MS will begin to lift northward 
back across the area through tonight. 

Combination of the northward progressing front along with the
three successive shortwaves lifting northeast across the area 
will serve to produce continued unsettled weather area wide 
through tonight. NAM seems to have the best handle on the current 
situation given that it initializes with little to no pcpn 
anywhere across the area, a fact supported by current radars 
across the SE US. Other guidance including SREF and GFS initialize
with fairly widespread pcpn across much of TN and northern GA, 
AL, MS this morning and in an area dominated by clear air returns 
on the radar. Based on this, forecast tends toward the NAM 
solution through tonight.

One thing that NAM, GFS, and SREF are in very good agreement on is
the amount of QPF across the area through tonight. With both
NAM/GFS indicating PWs on the order of 1.2-1.4 inches across the
area, we are very close to the maximum average values for this
time of year. As such, we can expect to once again see some very
heavy localized rainfall, similar to yesterday where portions of
our Plateau counties saw rainfall amounts on the order of 2 inches
or more in spots. Given already rain soaked ground and current 3
hour flash flood guidance on the order of 2-3 inches across much
of the area, localized flooding may once again become an issue
later today and tonight for some areas. 

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday)...
Unsettled weather pattern continues into the extended period with
a frontal boundary lingering near our area for Wednesday. This 
boundary will provide a focus for showers and thunderstorms with 
decent moisture and instability remaining overhead. Things should 
briefly dry out a bit for Wednesday night, but clouds and rain 
chances increase again on Thursday ahead of another approaching 
cold front as moisture surges back into the area. Models have 
slowed down frontal passage timing quite a bit, bringing it 
through midday Friday into Friday evening along with a better 
chance of showers and thunderstorms. A closed upper low is 
forecast to affect the region over the weekend, bringing continued
unsettled weather and perhaps the chance for some stronger 
showers and thunderstorms and heavy rain as the system pushes 
through. There's still some differences on exact timing and low 
track from model to model, but the general consensus at this point
is the front blowing through early to midday Sunday. For now, 
this is where I've placed the highest PoPs and best chance for 
thunderstorms, but this will become better refined as the event 
nears and timing may change. Behind the frontal passage, some 
wraparound moisture on the back side of the low may trigger some 
scattered showers and cloudy skies for Monday. Temperatures will 
be warm this week, with highs in the upper 70s to lower 80s. 
Behind this weekend's system, temperatures will drop down into the
upper 60s/lower 70s range for Sunday and Monday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
319 AM EDT Mon Apr 17 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...
Latest water vapor imagery continues to indicate zonal flow across
the Ohio Valley and Mid-South this morning. Surface front 
currently analyzed across the Ohio Valley with shower activity SE 
of the boundary across Middle TN and Central/Western KY. These 
showers are diminishing in coverage and intensity as they drift 
eastward toward the northern Plateau.

Front is expected to drop very slowly SE across the East TN Valley  
today bringing with it a period of unsettled weather with showers 
likely and thunderstorms possible throughout the day. Although 
there is sufficient instability for strong thunderstorm activity, 
the shear/helicity are weak to non-existent and should eliminate 
any potential for severe storms this afternoon. The threat of 
localized heavy rainfall is possible with this event. Model PWs, 
particularly over the southern valley approach the seasonal 
maximum values for middle April at around 1.2 to 1.3 inches. 
Couple this with a boundary becoming nearly stationary by tonight,
and some isolated portions of the southern valley could see 
rainfall totals approaching nearly 1 inch over the next 24 hours. 
More generally however, expect much of the area south of I-40 to 
see on the order of 0.6 inches of pcpn while elsewhere pcpn 
amounts should be on the order of 0.4 inches. The good news, is 
that with much of the area now falling about 1-2 inches behind in 
total rainfall for this year, this event should bring some much 
needed help in order to cut into the deficit.

Main axis of pcpn should continue to push further S by this
evening  with areas of SW VA and extreme NE TN likely beginning 
to dry out by early tonight. Meanwhile portions of SE TN could 
continue to see periods of showers and maybe a thunderstorm all 
the way into Tuesday morning as the front struggles to make much 
southward progress and gets hung up across the southern TN Valley 
tonight. 


.LONG TERM (Tuesday through Sunday)...
Stationary front will lie across the southern part of the forecast 
area early Tuesday with shortwave energy moving from west to east 
across the area during the day and overnight. Both NAM and GFS have 
best chance of showers and thunderstorms across the southern part of 
the area. Will keep likely pops across this area decreasing at night 
after loss of heating. Temperatures only 60s mountains and across 
southwest Virginia but lower to mid 70s elsewhere. Wednesday higher 
pressure to the east strengthens and the front will slowly shift 
east of the forecast area and weaken. Still with heating of the day 
scattered showers and thunderstorms will occur. Highs are expected 
to be a few degrees warmer too. Thursday will see more sun and only 
a 20 to 30 percent chance of showers/storms ahead of another front 
moving into the Tennessee Valley from the northwest. Temperatures 
mostly lower to mid 80s. The front will move through Thursday night 
and Friday. Cooling temperatures back down to the upper 60s to upper 
70s. A stronger front will approach late Saturday into Sunday from 
the southwest. A surface low should move just to the northwest into 
Kentucky Sunday. This system may bring a threat for severe 
thunderstorms but the timing is still difficult to predict this many 
days out.

.SHORT TERM (This Afternoon through Monday)...

Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicates 
mostly zonal flow across the Southern Appalachians with a trough to 
the northwest across the Northern Plains. At the surface, a cold 
front stretches from near Chicago to the southwest near Amarillo, 
TX. Seeing a few showers and storms breaking out to the south of 
this boundary on regional radar imagery. Closer to home, there have 
a been a few showers across the Northern Plateau and SW VA but 
coverage has been limited. PW values are currently around an inch 
and not seeing much in the way of substantial lift. Therefore, 
expect coverage will remain limited the remainder of the afternoon 
and into the evening.

The front will make some decent progress to the south during the 
overnight hours as the trough currently across the Northern Plains 
moves into the Great Lakes Region. PoPs will increase late tonight 
into Monday morning from northwest to southeast. Models do indicate 
that the front will slow tomorrow and may remain just to the north 
of the forecast area throughout the day. Regardless, wide spread 
showers and storms are forecast tomorrow with PoPs in the likely 
category during the afternoon. Lapse rates are not very impressive 
but model soundings do show some skinny SBCAPE values up to 1500 
J/Kg. The main lift will be well to the north but there could be a 
stronger storm or two with some gusty winds possible. PW values 
ahead of the front will also increase into the 1.5 inch range near 
the maximum value observed for mid-April. Due to this increased PoPs 
during the day on Monday. With the widespread cloud cover and 
precipitation, temperatures will be a bit cooler and range from the 
upper 60s to mid 70s.

.LONG TERM (Monday night through Saturday)...

Shower and thunderstorm activity will continue as the nearly 
stationary boundary sits over us. A few ripples of energy will make 
their way eastwards across this feature and will help to bring more 
widespread shower and thunderstorm activity to the area. Atmosphere 
looks to support thunderstorms, especially during the 
afternoon/evening hours, but forecast soundings don't show that 
there should be enough CAPE/shear for widespread severe weather. 
Generally expect most locations will see a few rumbles of thunder 
and some garden variety thunderstorms through most of the work week. 
As we move into the middle/late part of the work week the moisture 
becomes more limited and the shower/thunderstorm activity should 
weaken and decrease in coverage. Chances for more storms pick back 
up as a weak front moves in at the end of the week. This front also 
looks to stall out over us and will likely remain over us for a 
brief period of time before yet another system quickly sweeps 
through over the weekend. Right now this weekend system looks to 
bring the best chances for widespread precipitation, but the timing 
is difficult to pin down as models are still in disagreement with 
the strength and speed of this system.

Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicate an

northeastward towards the Southern Appalachians. At the surface, a 
cold front is now to the south and east of the area stretching north-

counties in SW NC. Therefore, have continued with s slight chance of

evening. 

The surface high will pass to the north tonight with dry conditions 
forecast to continue. Overnight lows will range from the mid 40s to 
mid 50s. An upper level ridge will build northeast from the Northern 
Gulf on Thursday with an upper level trough passing across Great 
lakes into the Mid-Atlantic. It looks as through there will be 
enough moisture return from the departing surface high to mention a 
slight chance for afternoon showers across the higher elevations of 
the Smokies with the rest of the forecast area remaining dry. 
Forecast highs on Friday will top out in the mid 70s to low 80s for 
most valley locations.

.LONG TERM (Thursday night through Wednesday)...

Models are in fairly good agreement for the extended period. 
Upper ridge remains in place over the area through Saturday, 
resulting in warm, mainly dry days with sunshine. There does 
appear to be enough instability over the area on Friday to spark a
few isolated afternoon thunderstorms, especially along the 
mountains and higher terrain, but the majority of the area should 
remain rain-free. Moisture will begin to surge back into the area 
on Sunday as the ridge shifts east and southwest flow helps pull 
Gulf moisture back into the region. By Sunday afternoon, scattered
showers and thunderstorms are possible. A cold front will 
approach the area late Sunday into Monday, bringing an even better
chance for widespread showers and thunderstorms. This front will 
stall just south of the Tennessee border for Tuesday into 
Wednesday, remaining a focus for showers and thunderstorms as a 
shortwave ripples through and helps maintain instability and 
moisture across the area.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
316 PM EDT Thu Apr 6 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Friday)... 
The large closed low to our north will continue to slowly make 
its way east across the Mid Atlantic region tonight and off the 
coast on Friday. Cold temperatures aloft and deep moisture under 
the low will keep scattered to numerous showers going across our 
area this evening, with the mountains seeing additional snow 
accumulation aided by a 30 kt NW upslope flow, mainly above 3000 
ft. So far we have had reports of around an inch in the higher 
elevations, and with another inch or two possible overnight, the 
Winter Weather Advisory will continue. Valley wind gusts are 
expected to diminsh with sunset, so the expiration time for the 
Wind Advisory at 03Z looks good, with the mountains maintaining 
the Advisory until 08Z. Cloud cover and winds overnight should
keep most spots above freezing tonight, except for the areas that
are under the Winter Weather Advisory.

The gradual departure of the upper low will result in decreasing 
precip chances and clearing skies through the day tomorrow from the 
SW to NE. Temperatures will be well below normal, with highs in the 
upper 40s north to upper 50s south.

.LONG TERM (Friday night through Thursday)... 
Friday night cold upper low moves away from the region and out into 
the Mid-Atlantic. Skies will become clear and winds will gradually 
decrease. Cold air advection will continue for the evening and 
temperatures will fall to near or below freezing after midnight. As 
the winds die down enough later Friday night...frost will form so 
have set up a freeze watch for the northern plateau...northeast 
Tennessee...southwest Virginia and the eastern Tennessee 
mountains...including southwest North Carolina. Outside of the 
freezing areas lows will be just above freezing with widespread 
frost. Higher pressure over the Mississippi Valley Friday night will 
build east and bring much warmer temperatures to the area Saturday 
with highs in the 60s. Saturday night another cool to cold night 
with frost again in the northeast and mountains. Sunday much warmer 
with south to southwest winds returning and highs in the 70s. Monday 
the surface high shifts to the east coast with moisture increasing. 
The next cold front approaches from the west Tuesday and will pass 
through Tuesday night with a chance of showers and thunderstorms. 
Mild temperatures Tuesday then slight cooling Wednesday and Thursday 
behind the front.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
322 AM EDT Thu Apr 6 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and tonight)...
Main frontal boundary is off to our east but we will still see
some colder showers behind this system. The colder showers in the
valley will be spotty and last through much of the day today. In
the higher elevations temperatures will be cold enough to where
rain showers will likely switch over to snow showers.
Accumulations should be pretty minor in most populated locations,
but the peaks of the mountains will potentially get enough to
warrant a winter weather advisory. In addition to this a low level
jet will pick up today behind the system and cause gusty winds
today across the area. The higher elevations will likely get the
strongest winds so a wind advisory is in effect for the mountains
as well.

.LONG TERM (Tomorrow through Wednesday)...
The upper-low that will bring a much colder air mass into the 
region, will gradually shift away from the Tennessee Valley on 
Friday toward the Mid-Atlantic region. However, a strong pressure 
gradient will help keep winds on the breezy side for most of the day 
(through likely below Advisory-level). Additionally, the strong NW 
flow will help reinforce a cold air mass. Some light snow showers 
will continue along the mountains through the day -- through there 
will be little accumulation. The real story will be the drier air 
moving in later in the evening, which will help create a clear sky 
Friday night. Due to the clear, dry, and calm conditions, a 
freeze/frost is likely over most of the region by Saturday morning. 
After a chilly (but slightly warmer day on Saturday), a significant 
warming trend will begin on Sunday as winds veer to the south and 
high pressure builds in. Highs will return to the mid to upper 70s 
through early next week. Another front and shot at precipitation 
will move in by Tuesday/Wednesday, with the potential for a few 
strong thunderstorms as well. 

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

FXUS64 KMRX 051952
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
352 PM EDT Wed Apr 5 2017

.SHORT TERM (This Evening through Friday)...Deep upper trough will
move into the Ohio Valley overnight and Thursday. Jet streaks move
around the upper low will continue to enhance the divergence aloft
over the Tennessee Valley through this evening. The upper trough
is inducing broad pressure falls over the Ohio/Tennessee Valleys.
The pressure falls is increasing the low-level jet over the area
deepening/strengthening the shear over the region, and pulling
moisture and better instability north. 

Significant tornado parameter has increased to near 2 over the
Plateau and southeast Tennessee. HAIL CAPES near 700 j/kg and
lower freezing levels is producing an environment for large hail
up to Golfball. Downdraft CAPES, mid-level dry air and high DCP
suggest an environment for damaging winds. End result, besides the
potential of tornadoes, large hail and damaging winds are a big
concern through this evening.

The convection will end from west (CHA around 01Z, TYS around 03Z,
and TRI around 06Z), and then wrap-around moisture and instability
will pull showers back into the area toward daybreak Thursday. A
good deal of low-level instabilty, moisture, and cyclonic flow
around upper trough will produce widespread showers. The
temperature profile will be cold enough for a transition to snow
across the highest elevations (around 4kt), then lower during the
day (around 2500 feet) by Thursday evening. Scattered snow showers
will continue across the orographic areas for Thursday night and
Friday morning. 

Besides the rain/snow showers, strong cold air advection will
produce windy conditions Thursday. Later shifts may need to issue
a wind advisory for tomorrow.

Due to concerns with hikers and vacationers across the Smoky
Mountains, residents of High Knob will issue a winter weather
advisory there beginning daybreak Thursday through day break
Friday.

.LONG TERM (Friday night through Wednesday)...
Much quieter weather expected through this period of the 
forecast. To start the period we could still be dealing with a few
lingering flurries across the highest peaks with NW still still 
in place. Not expecting any accumulation as this will be the tail 
end of the snow. Continued NW flow will also allow for gusty winds
to remain across the higher elevations into Friday night. 
However, the trough pushes east overnight into Saturday morning 
thus ending NW flow and high pressure begins to build in from the 
west. The biggest concern will be the cold temps that will occur 
across the area overnight. Lows will be in the mid 30s across much
of the Central and Southern Valley. NETN and SWVA will see lows 
right around freezing to a degree or two below freezing. It 
doesn't look like a hard freeze at this point but sensitive plants
may need to be brought inside.

High pressure quickly builds into the region for the weekend which 
will bring a welcomed warning trend. Highs on Saturday will be in 
the low to mid 60s and back into the low to mid 70s by Sunday. It 
does look like some upper level moisture rounds the ridge and 
streams down into our area for both Saturday and Sunday so high 
clouds look to be in place. Lows on Saturday night will be in the 
upper 30s to lower 40s and mid and upper 40s for Sunday night. 
Temperatures look even warmer Monday as an area of high pressure 
develops to our southeast. This returns us to southerly flow and 
bumps temps up into the mid to upper 70s. On Tuesday/Tuesday night 
we have a cold front approaching from the west that will provide us 
our next chance of showers and a possibly a few storms. The low is 
up across the Great Lakes with the front stretching all the down to 
the Gulf Coast States. Wednesday looks cooler behind the front with 
highs back down into the upper 60s.

829 
FXUS64 KMRX 050742
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
342 AM EDT Wed Apr 5 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and tonight)...
Weather story of the day will be the 2 rounds of storms that will
move through our area.

First round will be storms moving up from the south and possibly
into our area. The strongest of this thunderstorm activity should
remain to our south, but the far southeast Tennessee/southwest
North Carolina could see strong storms as well. Current high 
resolution models depict that thunderstorm activity will likely 
stay to our east with these daytime storms, but some storm 
activity could break a bit west and head west of the Southern 
Appalachian mountains. Also of concern with this early convection 
will be the potential for storms to lay our a convective front 
that advances northward as the day progresses. If this happens, 
wherever that boundary sets up could act as a focus for increased 
storm and severe threat later in the day.

But the bigger threat will come later in the day as the front
approaches from the west in the evening hours. Before going into
details it must be noted that models have been handling this event
very poorly with little run-to-run consistency and constant
disagreement within the various models, so forecast confidence on
the exact details of this event are very low. Best environment for
severe thunderstorm potential will be in our western counties
along the Cumberland Plateau down towards Chattanooga, and as you
head further east the environment becomes less favorable. In our
western counties good instability of around 1000-2000 J/kg will be
present as the storms move in. This will combine with good shear
in the mid and low levels to provide fuel to see strong and severe
storms. Right now the biggest difference between the models is
with how much instabilty and CINH is present. The GFS is more
bullish on the CAPE values while leaving us essentially uncapped,
which would lead to much stronger and more widespread storms.
While the NAM is weaker and keeps us capped, and delays storms
developing ahead of the main front. In addition to all these
concerns, it seems that storms south of us are firing earlier 
than anticipated and the line of storms currently across Arkansas 
is staying together longer than models predicted. This again leads
to decreased confidence as we move forward today. 

All that being said the biggest threats we are expecting today is
hail up to the size of baseballs, strong winds, and tornadoes
cannot be ruled out. The highest chances to see these will be in
our western counties and around the Chattanooga area. Once the
front moves through overnight thunderstorms will end and we will
switch over to rain showers.

.LONG TERM (Tomorrow through Tuesday)...
A big change will be ushered in by early Thursday morning in wake
of the cold frontal passage as much colder air will move into the
Southern Appalachians. Sounding/profiles indicate the 
melting/freezing level will drop quickly over the course of the 
morning, to 4000 ft
-- and later that afternoon to 2500 ft. This will change any 
light rain showers over to snow along these high terrain areas. 
There will be some enhanced synoptic lift as the low passes 
through the region Thursday afternoon, night and into Friday 
morning, along with an orographic lift component as well. Thus, 
over the 36 to 48 hour period -- between 3 to 6 inches is possible
above 4000 in the Great Smoky Mountains and 1 to 3 inches over 
2500 across the mountains of East Tennessee and Southwest 
Virginia. 

These snows could cause some hazard travel conditions across the 
mountains for tourists as well as dangerous conditions for hikers in 
the mountains. A Winter Weather Advisory will be needed to address 
this by next period. Will hold off since the onset and peak are 
still around 30 hours out. In addition to the snow, we will have 
monitor for the potential for a wind advisory along the East 
Tennessee Mountains Thursday and especially Thursday Night as 
sustained winds in the 20 to 30 mph range, with gusts to 50 mph will 
be possible along the high terrain.  

The upper-low will also bring cold air into the region, resulting in 
a frost late Thursday night and a freeze for parts of the area on 
Friday night. Then, this storm system will pull away from the area 
on Saturday, resulting in a warming trend as winds veer to the south 
and high pressure builds in. Highs will return to the mid to upper 
70s by Sunday and Monday. Another front and shot at precipitation 
will move in by Tuesday/Wednesday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
340 PM EDT Tue Apr 4 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Wednesday)...The second half of the 
short term could be active with strong to severe convection 
developing in association with a deepening Midwest low pressure 
system. As usual, there is a little uncertainty in terms of the 
strength of the convection due to stabilizing effects with the 
passage of a morning system ripping northeast out of the Gulf 
States. If this morning system affects the forecast area with just
a glancing blow and rides a little farther south of the region, 
there could be more instability available for the afternoon when 
the powerful system cold front builds into the Southern 
Appalachian region. Instability is acceptable with this storm 
system, but shear appears to be rather strong with 40-50 kts in 
the 0-6km layer. Damaging straight line winds and hail would be 
the most likely mode of severe weather on Wednesday, but there 
could also be an isolated tornado due to adequate helicity values.
The strong southerly flow should enable max temps to rise well 
into the 70s prior to the main convective episode building in 
during the afternoon and evening. 

.LONG TERM (Wednesday night through Tuesday)...Some big changes 
in the forecast regarding snow for Thursday into Thursday night 
but we have to start with the severe weather first.

To start the period we will still likely be dealing with some form 
of severe weather across the area. The event should be winding down 
but the threat for a few strong to severe storms will persist until 
around 10pm/midnight. The main threats during this time will still 
be large hail and damaging winds but an isolated tornado can't be 
ruled out due to plenty of shear along with some remaining 
instability in place. Winds will still be gusty in the evening prior 
to the frontal passage due to a stout 850 mb jet. The actual cold 
front sweeps through around midnight and will begin to usher in much 
colder air into the region. Lows on Wednesday night will fall into 
mid 40s. After the frontal passage we have a break in precip before 
wrap around moisture enters into the area on the back side of the 
low that is located across the Ohio River Valley. 

The latest model data shows good snow potential on Thursday into 
Thursday night across the higher elevations. Both the NAM and GFS 
show moisture extending up to -15 deg C with the freezing level 
starting out around 5500 feet at 09Z Thursday. Freezing level drops 
through the day and the sounding profiles remain moist. Stout NW 
flow will also enhance snow across the higher elevations due to 
orographic lift. By 18z Thursday the snow/rain line should be down 
around 3500 feet and by 00z down around 3K feet. During the day we 
do see CAPE values high enough to suggest possible snow banding in 
the high terrain. Any area that gets under one of these bands could 
pick up quick accumulations; which could lead to isolated higher 
totals. The better moisture will begin to gradually taper off after 
00z but the upslope snow machine should still be pretty healthy as 
strong NW flow continues into the night. Expecting snow showers 
across the higher elevations to last well into the night on Thursday 
with some isolated areas of snow showers still across the higher 
peaks into Friday morning/early afternoon. Lows overnight will be in 
the lower to upper 30s. Some valley locations across Northeast TN 
and SWVA could see a few hours of light snow early Friday morning 
but will quickly switch back over to rain shortly after sunrise. Not 
expecting any accumulation or travel issues across lower elevations. 
All precip finally pulls out later Friday afternoon. Highs on Friday 
will be quite chilly with upper 40s near 50 north to mid to upper 
50s south.

Current thinking is that areas above 4000 feet will see between 3 to 
6 inches of snowfall from early Thursday morning through Friday 
morning. Areas between 3000 to 4000 feet will see 2 to 4 inches and 
2500 feet to 3000 feet 1 to 3 inches. Due to the snowfall still 
being several periods out will send out an SPS to highlight for now. 

Friday night we will see the coldest temps of the period with lows 
in the upper 20s to lower 30s north, low to mid 30s Central Valley, 
and mid 30s Southern Valley. The good news is that ridging quickly 
builds back in on Saturday and we see a nice rebound in temps. Highs 
will be in the upper 50s to mid 60s. Saturday night is milder with 
most locations above freezing. The warming trend continues for 
Sunday and Monday with highs back into the 70s. Our next system 
approaches on Tuesday with another shot at showers and a few storms.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
321 AM EDT Tue Apr 4 2017

.SHORT TERM /Today and Tonight/...
A few areas of showers continue to move across the region early
this morning as a weak shortwave passes through the Southern
Appalachian region. Some BKN/OVC decks of mid-level clouds will
linger into the mid-morning hours, but they should quickly
dissipate by midday as drier air quickly moves into the area from
the southwest. This will result in a sunny to mostly sunny day
over the afternoon and evening hours -- and combined with breezy
SW flow, push highs into the mid to upper 70s. Cloud coiver will
gradually increase overnight as a warm front pushes toward the 
region from the southwest. In general, think that a mostly clear
sky is likely across all but the far southern areas for most of
the night. Latest model guidance wants to keep any precipitation
out of the area until after 12z, so have adjusted the forecast
accordingly. Temperatures will stay mild, despite the clear sky
due to breezy SW and increased boundary layer moiature. 

.LONG TERM /Wednesday through Monday/...
Biggest weather story for this forecast will be the severe weather 
expected to roll through the region on Wednesday, and the colder air 
behind this system that could bring some very light snow to the 
higher elevations.

Main system driving the potential severe weather will be a low 
moving out of the plains and towards the Great Lakes region. Ahead 
of this low a warm front should be somewhere in our vicinity and 
locations south of this will have the best chances to see strong to 
severe storms on Wednesday. Models are depicting convection starting 
south of us early on Wednesday and moving northeastward as the day 
progresses. This daytime convection will likely cause the strongest 
storms of the day across the southeast United States. Models are 
showing that most of this stuff stays to our south, but we can't 
rule out the possibilty that some storms move into far southeast 
Tennessee/southwest North Carolina. During this time there should be 
good CAPE to work with (around 1000-2000 J/kg in the southern 
counties of TN/NC) and good shear as well (20-30kts SFC-1km/60kts 
SFC-6km). High resolution models show that the strongest activity 
should stay to our south, but it will be worth keeping an eye on 
this early convection. Even if we don't get strong to severe storms 
with this first round, any storms could help stabilize our 
atmosphere in preparation for the front and more storms expected to 
move through later Wednesday night. 

If the storms don't stabilize the atmosphere we will remain primed to 
see strong to severe storms along and ahead of the front as it moves 
through. Current models show that the storms along the front will 
likely move into the Cumberland Plateau/Chattanooga in the late 
afternoon and move east of the forecast area a little after 
midnight. The main threats associated with the storms will be strong 
straight-line winds and large hail, but an isolated tornado cannot 
be ruled out. Once the front has moved through our area overnight 
the severe threat will come to and end.

As the low moves northeast of us the 850mb jet on the backside will 
get cranking out of the north/west and could cause strong winds in 
the higher elevations along the Southern Appalachian Mountains on 
Thursday into Friday. This time frame will need to be monitored and 
as it gets closer a wind advisory might be warranted. 

The final weather possible with this front will be some potential 
light snow in the higher elevations Thursday/Friday night. Wrap 
around moisture will cause cloudy weather and some additional 
showers through the end of the work week. Since the front will cause 
us to drop about 20 degrees colder after it moves through the 
overnight lows in the higher elevations will get low enough that a 
brief switch-over to snow is possible Thursday night and Friday 
night. Any snow during this time would be brief before switching 
back over to rain and accumulations would be minimal (if any). 

Whew...

Much quieter weather and a warming trend will then set up for the 
weekend and into next week. Drier air from the northwest will lead 
to generally sunny skies and mid level ridging building in will help 
get temperatures back into the 70's by Sunday. Our next chance for 
precipitation will come mid-week as a front/shortwave combination 
moves through the area.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
337 PM EDT Mon Apr 3 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Tuesday)...The pressure center of rather
dynamic Spring storm system moves northeast into the Eastern 
Great Lakes by the end of the period. Some drier air is building 
east behind the initial short wave that is generating the moderate
to heavy showers currently nearing the eastern edge of the 
forecast area this afternoon. The downward motion and drying 
should allow for a few hours of quiet weather before the main 
upper level trough and surface cool front swing across the 
forecast area overnight. There could be a few more showers with 
these features overnight. While there could be a thunderstorm, 
instability will be in short supply so don't expect anything more 
than widely scattered coverage in terms of convection. Tuesday 
should be a most pleasant day with a return to sunshine and a warm
southwesterly flow. The insolation and warm advection should lead
to high temperatures in the mid and upper 70s. 

.LONG TERM (Tuesday night through Monday)...Main focus through 
the long term period will be the potential for strong to severe 
storms on Wednesday, followed by much colder air for Thursday and 
Friday with light snow across the higher elevations.

The period starts off quiet as we are in between systems. Lows 
Tuesday night will be around 10 degrees above normal due to good 
southerly flow and cloud cover. On Wednesday we have another deep 
trough that moves in from the west with a low that tracks through 
the Ohio River Valley. Currently, SPC has the whole area under a 
slight risk in their day 3 outlook. There is still quite a bit of 
uncertainty due to model differences. The latest NAM suggests 
early morning activity moves into the area and stabilizes the 
atmosphere. The NAM does show destabilization later in the 
afternoon and early evening but the destabilized layer is elevated 
while the surface is stable. The NAM then shows a line of convection 
to our west which moves in during the evening hours. This scenario 
would be more of a hail and wind threat due to the stable surface 
layer. The GFS is quite a bit different, it keeps the morning 
activity to our south and allows the area to become more unstable as 
well as surface based storms. This scenario would allow for 
afternoon showers and storms to develop with the threats being hail, 
wind, along with an isolated tornado due to good shear and surface 
based sounding profiles. Will have to continue to monitor the 
potential for storms on Wednesday as newer model runs come in. 
Besides the storms, the 850 mb jet is quite strong on Wednesday and 
breezy and gusty winds can be expected through the day. A wind 
advisory may be needed across the higher elevations as we get closer 
to the event.

Sharp cold front moves through overnight with lows dipping down into 
the mid and upper 40s. Much colder air moves in for Thursday with 
wrap around moisture swinging into the area. Highs on Thursday will 
only be in the lower 50s north and upper 50s south with rain showers 
across much of the CWA. Precip continues overnight and will 
changeover to snow across the higher elevations. There could be a 
brief window where light snow showers occur early Friday morning 
across the Northern Plateau, Northeast TN, and Southwest Virginia 
but quickly changes back to rain shortly after sunrise. Friday will 
be the coldest day of the period with highs around 10 to 15 degrees 
below normal. Light rain showers continue across the northern areas 
through the day before eventually tapering off Friday night. Friday 
night will be the coldest of the period with lows in the low to mid 
30s across the lower elevations.

Conditions rapidly improve through the rest of the period as high 
pressure begins to build back in on Saturday with highs back in the 
low to mid 60s. The warming trend continues Sunday and Monday with 
highs in the 70s.

FXUS64 KMRX 030833
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
433 AM EDT Mon Apr 3 2017

.SHORT TERM /Today and Tonight/...
Slow moving cold front tracking from the Mid-South into the
Tennessee Valley and Southern Appalachian region later today.
Along/ahead of this front, a broad area of moderate to locally
heavy rain showers and isolated thunderstorms is slowly making 
it's way NNE across Middle Tennessee and Northern Alabama. By 12z,
this activity should begin to make it into the Southern 
Cumberland Plateau. This activity will move across the region from
the mid-morning hours through mid afternoon (13-20z).

The latest runs of the HRRR indicated the possibility of some 
semi-organized line segments with some of the thunderstorms that 
will develop and track along and south of I-40. Some localized 
damaging wind gusts are possible thanks to the strong 
directional/speed shear in place, but instability will be quite 
limited this morning. Still, enough may exist in the afternoon, to
get some localized severe storms, especially along the Mountains 
and in far southwest North Carolina. Additionally, strong gradient
winds along the Mountains are expected to develop early this 
morning through the late afternoon, which has prompted a Wind 
Advisory. 

In addition to the winds, the slow-moving nature of these storms
and PWAT values around 1.5-1.6 inches will allow for the potential
for locally heavy rainfall and some flooding along the mountains
and SW North Carolina.  

As mentioned, this activity will taper off west of I-75 by midday
and early afternoon, and along the mountains by 19-20z.
Thereafter, another round of scattered showers and storms is
possible early this evening and into the overnight hours as the
base of the trough -- and the true cold front moves into the
region. A strong storm will be possible, but do think the severe
threat will be very low after sunset. Have kept slight chance to
chance PoPs for the overnight period to account for this
possibilty. The clouds and moisture will allow temperatures to
stay mild -- in the 50s to lower 60s in most spots by Tuesday
morning. 

.LONG TERM /Tuesday through Sunday/...
Some lingering light showers will be possible across far 
northeastern Tennessee and southwest Virginia to start the 
extended period as Monday's system slowly exits the area. 
Conditions should be dry for Tuesday afternoon and night, but the 
next major system will be quickly strengthening and approaching 
the forecast area.

This system will rapidly build through the Mississippi Valley on 
Wednesday before the center of the low slides northeast into the 
Great Lakes region by Wednesday evening. For us, a surface warm 
front will push from south to north across the forecast area on 
Wednesday. This will put our area in a broad warm sector, and 
southerly flow will be advecting warm, moist, unstable air into the 
area by early Wednesday afternoon. Combined with strong deep/low 
layer shear and decent forcing, this will provide a favorable 
environment for storms to develop during the afternoon and evening 
hours. For those of you who like numbers, forecast soundings from 
both the GFS and NAM indicate MLCAPE values well over 1000J/kg, SFC-
1km shear values of 20+kts, and SFC-6km shear values of 60+kts 
across the southern Tennessee Valley. Of course, there are still 
some uncertainties with this event that could limit or enhance the 
severe weather threat. First, there are still some model differences 
with regards to exact low track and timing. This would affect when 
and for how long our area is in the warm sector. Second, there are 
still questions whether moist unstable air will be able to return to 
the area quickly enough in the wake of today's system. Third, it is 
again possible that ongoing convection closer to the Gulf Coast may 
cut off some of the northward flow of warm, moist air. For now, SPC 
has outlooked our area for a slight risk of severe storms, 
specifically mentioning the uncertainty and the potential for 
discreet supercells to form late Wednesday afternoon into Wednesday 
evening. Storm potential should quickly end Wednesday night as a 
strong cold front pushes through.

Strong north-northwest flow will set up behind the frontal passage, 
ushering much colder air into the region. Temperatures will be much 
colder than earlier in the week, with highs in the low to mid 50s on 
Thursday and mid 40s to lower 50s on Friday. Lows will drop into the 
30s Friday and Saturday morning, with temperatures in the 20s across 
the higher terrain. The deep trough will remain overhead for 
Thursday into Friday with several shortwaves rotating through, 
providing reinforcing shots of cooler air and moisture. This will 
result in cold rain showers on Thursday and the potential for high 
elevation snow showers Friday and Saturday morning.

Ridging will build in for the weekend, drying out the area and 
bringing a return to more seasonable temperatures and sunny skies.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
329 PM EDT Sun Apr 2 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Monday)... 
Rather benign night in store for East TN, SW VA, and SW NC with 
overnight lows expected to be about 10 degree above normal. 
Increasing cloud cover is expected by morning in advance of the 
next frontal system.

Tomorrow brings a fairly solid rain chance area wide with main
weather event being the possibility of some strong to severe 
convection mainly across the area south of I-40 mainly during the 
afternoon. Although bulk of instability is elevated with SBCAPEs 
during the day really struggling to reach 1000 j/kg, northward 
progression of a warm frontal boundary may serve as a focusing 
mechanism for any potential severe weather. Strong shear, on the 
order of 30-40 kts in the SFC-1KM layer and 50-60 kts in the SFC-
3km layer, coupled with effective SRH values in the 500-700 m2/s2 
range, are certainly sufficient to support organized strong to 
severe convection during the afternoon and evening hours. Main 
threat looks to be winds across most of the area with a small 
chance for an isolated tornado possible across the southern border
counties of TN and both SW NC counties. 

One thing that will bear close watching with this potential event
will be where and when convection develops south of our area early
Monday. GFS, ECMWF, and SREF all indicate convection to our south
and even southeast by Monday afternoon. Given this scenario, best
low level inflow of moisture, heat and hence instability would be
cut-off from much of our area. NAM soln however is a little 
slower with the eastward propagation of convection overnight 
tonight and therefore allows for greater low-level instability to 
develop by afternoon further supporting strong to severe activity 
in our area. 

A wind advisory will be issued for the mountain zones of East
Tennessee from late tonight into Tuesday afternoon as a rather
broad 50-60 KT 850 mb jet pushes NE across the area through the
early afternoon. Although sustained winds should likely remain
below advisory criteria, do expect gusts to reach advisory levels
over the higher elevations of the advisory area during that time. 

.LONG TERM (Monday Night through Sunday)...
Early week system will be exiting very slowly across the Eastern 
Great Lakes and Northeastern states. A significant amount of moist
air will be building across the region with some upslope westerly
flow generating widespread showers well through Monday night and 
possibly into the early part of Tuesday. We should be able to 
enjoy about 18-24 hours of dry weather but the next major system 
will building quickly through the Mississippi Valley on its way 
toward the Eastern Great Lakes 12z Wednesday into 12z Thursday and
this period looks rather active again with a decent possibility 
of more convection. There is still some uncertainty about the 
intensity and scope of thunderstorm development with both the 
European and GFS indicating the best inflow of moist and unstable 
air may be cut off by rather intense convection developing further
south across Dixie. The upper trough associated with this mid 
week system is progged to continue deepening well into Friday with
several short wave features rotating around a closed low 
circulation generating Thursday into Friday night with sufficient 
cold air building in with a strong northerly flow for the 
production of snow showers in the higher terrain. A drying 
northwesterly flow and ridging should allow for a dry weekend with
a most welcome warming trend.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
359 AM EDT Sun Apr 2 2017

.SHORT TERM /Today and Tonight/...
An upper-level ridge axis will rotate directly over the eastern
Tennessee Valley today, promoting a mostly sunny and warm day.
Southerly winds increase by the afternoon as the pressure 
gradient tightens thanks to an approaching storm system off to the
west. The combination of dry conditions, ample sunshine, and 
these winds will push highs in the 75 to 80 degree range over much
of the Valley this afternoon. 

A clear evening will then allow temperatures to drop quickly, but
high clouds ahead of an MCS moving into the lower Mississippi 
Valley will quickly move into the Southern Valley by late 
evening/midnight. These clouds will become denser and gradually 
lower as moisture increases. A few isolated showers will be 
possible late tonight along the NC/TN mountains thanks to 
orographic and weak isentropic lift. However, most areas will 
remain dry, with just the increased cloud cover to deal with. 

These clouds and a stout downslope wind will serve to keep 
temperatures around 15-20 degrees warmer tonight. The 
aforementioned winds may approach advisory criteria along the 
terrain, but did not have enough confidence that they will reach 
that criteria as of this package. However, the downsloping winds 
will certainly keep temperatures on the mild side for later 
tonight.

.LONG TERM /Monday through Saturday/...
The active spring weather pattern will continue through the 
extended period with a couple systems cycling through the forecast
area next week. 

The next storm system will approach our area on Monday. A cold front 
associated with this system will push through Monday afternoon and 
evening. Favorable frontal passage timing combined with decent 
instability and plenty of shear should result in convection in the 
warm sector ahead of the front. However, there still is some 
uncertainty whether convection closer to the Gulf of Mexico will cut 
off northern moisture transport -- which would greatly limit the 
potential for severe weather across our forecast area. Given this 
uncertainty, SPC has outlooked the majority of our area in a 
marginal risk for Monday, with the northern edge of the slight risk 
just clipping the southeastern Tennessee border and North Carolina 
counties. Additionally, strong low level warm air advection and 
strong forcing could lead to some decent rainfall amounts with these 
storms and some locations (especially across the southern half of 
our forecast area) could see 1-3" of rain. WPC has outlooked much of 
our forecast area in a marginal risk for excessive rainfall to 
reflect this potential. As the front pushes off the east coast on 
Tuesday, there will be enough moisture on the back side of the 
system for scattered showers across the north. 

Another stronger system will approach the Mississippi Valley on 
Wednesday. A deep trough will set up over the central US as the 
surface low pressure system continues to strengthupper level en. Our 
area should enjoy some morning sunshine and another day of warm 
temperatures o n Wednesday. Rain/thunderstorm chances increase 
during the afternoon and evening hours as a surface warm front moves 
from south to north across the forecast area and strong southerly 
flow streams moisture into the area. There looks to be plenty of 
instability, shear, and moisture in the warm sector to support 
convection across the area before a strong cold frontal passage 
early Thursday morning.

Strong northwest flow will set up behind the frontal passage for 
Thursday into Friday, ushering much colder air into the region. 
Highs Thursday and Friday will be about 20 degrees cooler than 
Wednesday, struggling to reach 60 in most locations. Lows will drop 
into the lower 40s and 30s for late week, and there's the potential 
for subfreezing temperatures, especially across the higher terrain. 
Enough moisture will linger behind this system for showers to 
continue Thursday into Friday, with a reinforcing shortwave or two 
cycling through the base of the upper trough. With overnight lows 
below freezing, high elevation snow showers are possible Friday and 
Saturday mornings, but these snow showers should have little impact.

.Short Term (Today)...Warm southerly winds will increase low level

.LONG TERM (Tonight through Wednesday)...A negative upper trough
will move across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys tonight and early
Friday morning. A series of jet streaks exiting the upper trough
will produce divergence aloft over the region late today through
early Friday morning. These circulation around this jets will
enhance the fronto-genetic forcing overnight. 

Models show the airmass becoming moderately unstable with MLCAPES
of 1000-1500 J/Kg with Hail CAPEs of 150-300 J/kg. Shear/SR
Helicity does become quite strong with favorable values for
rotating updrafts with incoming storms. LCL heights lower
overnight as well. Models show a 850mb jet of 40-50kts overnight. Given
these parameters, isolated tornadoes are a concern with the main 
threat being damaging winds up to 60 mph and hail of 0.5 to 1
inch.

SPC has placed essentially the entire area under a slight risk of
severe thundestorms, even though the western/southern half of the
area seems to have the greatest threat.

Given the low-level jet and favorable thermodynamic profile,
strong winds are expected across the mountains and foothills for
tonight. Have issued a wind advisory for these locations.

For Friday, after early more showers (thunder northeast), models
show plenty of boundary layer moisture remaining keep the area
under mostly cloudy sky. Enough low-level instability to keep
chance showers going, especially for the orographic lift areas.

For this weekend, upper and surface ridging will produce a dry and
warm Saturday and Sunday.

Next strong upper trough will move into the area for early next
week. This system also has strong upper jet forcing with potential
of widespread showers and scattered storms.

evening through Friday morning. 

.LONG TERM (Tomorrow night through Tuesday)...

Main line of storms will be pushing through Middle Tennessee 
tomorrow evening and heading towards us. Right now the models are 
depicting the main line to move into our western counties sometime 
around midnight (or maybe a bit before). Best chance for severe 
storms will be ones that form to our west and maintain strength as 
they move into our western counties. The decent amount of shear in 
the mid to low levels could help maintain storm intensity, with 
strong straight-line winds being the main threat. Can't rule out 
large hail and a possible tornado in our area, but the chances are 
much lower for them. Storms will quickly lose strength as they move 
through our area as the instability and shear quickly decreases the 
further east you move. 

The low level jet that is aiding the strength and shear of these 
storms will eventually have a southeasterly component across the 
Southern Appalachian Mountains leading to a possible mountain wave 
event tomorrow night. Direction of the winds isn't exactly like a 
traditional mountain wave event, but we have strong enough winds in 
the low levels so some locations should experience the strong winds.

We'll take a break from precipitation and warm up through the 
weekend ahead of our next system. Models are in a bit of 
disagreement on the strength and timing of this next system, but it 
looks like another round of showers and thunderstorms will accompany 
it the first half of the next work week.

.Long Term (Wednesday through Monday)...Progressive pattern will
