over west Texas, resulting in warm ridging and fair weather across 
our area Wed and Wed night. As the trough lifts northeastward, it 
will push through the next frontal system Thursday and Thur night, 
with showers likely and scattered thunder. The core of the trough 
will pass Friday, keeping precip chances in the area Friday and Fri 
night. Then fair weather returns thanks to H5 ridging between the 
departing system and the next southern Rockies/west Texas H5 trough 
over the weekend. Yes, this means a great Spring weekend is shaping 
up. Models diverge on the timing of the ejection of that late-period 
trough, but it will probably bring increasing chances of showers and 
a few thunderstorms during the early part of the next work week.

811 
FXUS64 KMRX 271913
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
313 PM EDT Mon Mar 27 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tomorrow)...
Shortwave crosses the forecast area tonight, bringing a continued
threat of showers and thunderstorms. With SFC-6km shear of 
30-35kts and MLCAPE values maxing out around 1500J/kg, localized
damaging winds are possible with these storms through at least
midnight -- especially across the Cumberland Plateau. SPC has
outlooked this area for a slight risk of severe storms today.
Through the rest of the afternoon/evening hours, there is also the
potential for some of the storms to produce some small hail with
hail CAPEs up to 300J/kg. The storms this afternoon/early evening
will be more isolated with coverage increasing later this evening
as storm mode becomes more linear and clusters of storms congeal
into more of a line. Severe threat should decrease overnight as
well as the atmosphere becomes more stable. 

This system will slowly exit the area on Tuesday, with showers and
maybe an isolated rumble or two of thunder expected for at least 
the morning hours. By the afternoon, upper level ridging will
begin to build in for the west, and skies should gradually clear
through the afternoon and evening hours.


.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...
The front will have moved south and east of our area Tuesday 
evening, with a surface high over the Great Lakes extending 
southward while a ridge aloft builds in from the west. The 
progression of this ridge will provide dry weather and mild 
temperatures through Thursday morning. 

The models have some differences with the next system that may bring 
showers and storms to the area from Thursday afternoon through 
Friday. The ECMWF and GFS Ensemble Mean agree on a closed low over 
the Plains that becomes an open wave after it crosses the MS River 
and tracks NE along the OH River. The GFS maintains the closed low 
and takes it due east along the TN/KY border. A southerly low 
level flow ahead of it will likely result in downslope 
warming/drying that will delay precip in our northeastern half on 
Thursday afternoon, with isolated/scattered showers possible south
and west. The ECMWF/Ensemble solution is preferred, which focuses
the highest precip chances late Thursday night and ends precip 
Friday afternoon. Upper jet positioning near the Gulf Coast and 
the limited northward extend of the 850 mb theta-e ridge into 
AL/GA suggests the greatest severe threat will be to our south 
with this system, with only a low threat for our area. The 
expected overnight timing will further limit instability. With 
these uncertainties, will maintain PoPs in the likely range for 
now with a chance of thunderstorms. 

The pattern remains amplified through the rest of the forecast, with 
a ridge providing a dry weekend with near normal temperatures. The 
models depict another closed low crossing the southern Plains and 
Ozarks on Monday, although with some big differences in timing. Will 
start Monday with a chance of showers and thunderstorms.

round of showers and thunderstorms to the region. Shortwave pushes

only stretch of dry weather for Wednesday into Thursday.

begin to diverge with the ECMWF progressing the system slightly

chances increase once again for Thursday into Friday with more

forecast area.

.LONG TERM...Saturday night through Friday)...Overall...expect a

there are some discrepancies, as expected, between models, they are 
in relatively good agreement through about Tuesday. A cold front 
will approach the area Saturday night into Sunday.  With weak 
instability and decent 850mb winds, there will be a chance for some 
thunderstorms overnight Saturday. Daytime heating on Sunday will 
help to further destabilize the environment with forecast afternoon 
SBCAPE values of 500-1000 J/kg, and when combined with dewpoints in 
the upper 50s and forecast 0-6km shear values of 20-30kts, this 
should be enough to trigger isolated to scattered thunderstorms. At 
this point, SPC has our forecast area outlooked for a marginal risk 
of severe storms for Sunday, with the main concerns being isolated 
damaging winds and potentially some hail with the strongest 
updrafts. This system pulls away from the area Sunday night, but we 
will have only a brief break in rain chances before the next system 
moves in for Monday/Tuesday.

A weak shortwave will push east from the Great Plains on Monday, 
bringing another round of showers and potentially some thunderstorms 
to the area. Wednesday and Thursday look like potentially the driest 
days of the week, with weak ridging overhead as another system for 
late week digs into south-central US and strengthens. A warm frontal 
boundary associated with this closed low will approach the area late 
Thursday, and will serve as a focus for showers and thunderstorms on 
Friday.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Tuesday night)...Thursday night 
through Saturday morning...High pressure off the east coast will 
continue to move out in to the Atlantic. At the same time...a low 
pressure system over the Great Plains will approach the mid MS 
Valley. Our area being between the high and low pressure...SW flow 
will increase beginning Friday morning...bringing an increase in 
warm and moist air advection. Temperatures Friday and Saturday will 
be several degrees warmer than normal...and cloud cover will 
increase along with the moisture advection. 

Saturday afternoon through Sunday afternoon...the low pressure will 
begin a sharp N to NE climb towards the Great Lakes with another low 
pressure system and associated trough developing in its wake. A 
boundary that approaches the area Saturday afternoon will cause 
scattered showers and thunderstorms to develop in areas generally 
south of I40...moving to the north. Instability is low and winds 
will be fairly unidirectional and gusty through the midlevels. PW 
values are above normal for this time of year...especially in areas 
south of I40. With the atmospheric profile...not expecting any 
severe threats to be low. However...gusty winds and flooding rains 
could be a concern...especially with the flow moving parallel to the 
boundary...storms could easily train over the same area causing the 
flooding. 

Sunday night through Tuesday night...The low pressure will move off 
to the NE...with only a slight chance for light scattered lingering 
showers over NE TN and SW VA through Sunday night. Behind the low 
pressure...flow continues from the S and SW...with the moisture and 
warm air advection continuing. Temperatures will remain several 
degrees above normal. The next low pressure system and associated 
trough will move through the area Monday afternoon through Tuesday 
night...keeping scattered showers over the area each period.

.SHORT TERM (This Evening through Wednesday)...HRRR model

entrance region of the jet. This forcing with increasing 
instability will produce severe thunderstorms. The dry air in the

with good hail CAPE (values near 1000 J/kg and SHIP up to 2.5) 
will set the stage for damaging winds and large hail.

Carolina. Timeframe for severe weather is between 20-23Z. Give the
hail/wind parameters, hail sizes up to Golfball size and wind
speeds to 70 mph are possible.

anticipated by 03z, then dissipated around 06Z. Afterwards, plenty
of the dry air to clear sky out for Wednesday morning.

Severe thunderstorm Watch will be out soon.

Long term starts out dry as slow moving cold front finally pushes
through the area. Models are in fair agreement that the boundary,
just south of the area will continue to slightly elevate pcpn 
chances over far SE TN and all of our SW NC counties through 
Thursday. 

Middle level ridge amplifies across the area Friday into Saturday 
with daytime highs climbing about 10 degrees above normal by 
Saturday. Models are in fair agreement on the strength and location 
of the next low pressure system Saturday and Sunday, although ECMWF 
is a bit more progressive with the frontal boundary pushing it 
through the area by Sunday evening while the GFS is much slower. 
Current POP fcst is a blend of both solutions which brings in higher 
POP by Saturday afternoon and holds onto those POPs until overnight 
Sunday. Based on current models and ensemble fcsts, suspect greatest 
pcpn chances will likely be on Sunday.

A secondary system begins to move into the area pretty quickly 
behind the weekend system on Monday. Once again models remain in 
fair agreement on the track of low center and associated cold front 
with our area falling under a broad area of low pressure out ahead 
of the front and continued chance for showers and maybe a 
thunderstorm Monday and Tuesday as the front seems to stall across 
the area late in the period. With steady low level warm advection, 
area will likely see daytime high temperatures remain at about 10 
degrees above normal for the early part of the new work week.

should be east of the region by Sunday evening. However, the upper
level flow remains southwesterly behind the weekend system with

the long term. The good news in the extended is the warming trend

highs in the low to mid 70s and lows in the low to mid 50s.

FXUS64 KMRX 201911 AAA
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion...UPDATED
National Weather Service Morristown TN
311 PM EDT Mon Mar 20 2017

UPDATED FOR LONG TERM DISCUSSION

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)... 
A 850-700 mb shortwave trough over MI/WI/IA is progged to track 
SE across the Ohio Valley today and reach the central Appalachians
this evening. Ahead of it, a 850 mb theta-e gradient/warm front 
will cross the area this morning, and associated isentropic lift 
will bring broken clouds for most of the morning and early 
afternoon. Warm advection and partial sun today should bring temps
into the 60s in most spots, with lower 70s near CHA. The best 
lift and moisture with the trough stays north of our area closer 
to the upper jet, but we will see increasing moisture and 
instability through the day as the theta-e axis shifts south into 
KY/SW VA. Precip chances will rise across northern areas this 
evening but will keep coverage scattered due to limited moisture 
and fairly weak lift in our area - the categorical POPs of the GFS
MOS seem overdone. Elevated instability will be present and 
warrant a mention of isolated thunderstorms tonight.


.LONG TERM (Tuesday Night through Monday)...
Front will be slow to progress Tuesday night becoming nearly 
stationary across the area. Ample deep moisture, model PWs at 
about the 90th percentile, coupled with potential training of 
storms along the boundary and we could see some isolated heavy 
downpours during the overnight. Current flash flood guidance 
across much of the area is at roughly 1.5 inches in an hour and 2 
to 2.5 inches over three hours. Latest model QPF guidance seems to
be indicating highest pcpn amounts on the order of an inch or so,
therefore would expect mainly localized flooding issues to be 
possible in this event. Also, south of the front, over the 
southern third of East Tennessee and SW Virginia, instability 
Tuesday night remains a bit elevated with CAPE values of 500-750 
J/kg. This, along with sufficient shear could lead to a few 
organized thunderstorms and some possible training thunderstorms 
across this area, mainly during the first half of the overnight.

After some residual POPs from the slowly moving front on Wednesday, 
we then dry out across the area into Saturday. At the same time, we 
will once again start to warm above seasonal normals for the weekend 
and beyond. Next frontal system moves into the area Saturday 
increasing POPs through Sunday before pushing east of the area on 
Monday. With warming temperatures, some model indicated instability, 
and increasing shear with the approaching system on Saturday, 
prospects of some strong thunderstorms are possible Saturday and 
Sunday with this next system.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
305 PM EDT Mon Mar 20 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Tuesday)...A band of convection currently
moving through the Ohio Valley will work into the Central
Appalachian area this evening. The tail end of this convection
will brush across northern areas of the MRX CWA during the rest of
the afternoon and evening hours. Then...the frontal boundary the
convection developed along will slowly drop south and move into
the Southern Appalachian Region during the short term. Additional
convection is expected to form along the frontal boundary for
scattered showers and thunderstorms moving through the area
Tuesday morning. With increased low level moisture and daytime
heating...the air mass across the region will become marginally
unstable Tuesday afternoon. Additional convection is expected to
develop for the afternoon hours and a stray storm could become
strong or potentially severe. 

.LONG TERM (Tuesday through Sunday)...Front will be knocking on 
our door by early Tuesday with precipitation chances continuing 
ahead of the front. Front will struggle to continue moving south 
during the day on Tuesday and will likely act as the focus for 
convection over our area as the day progresses. Along and south of
the front we will destabilize enough to where we could see strong
to possibly severe storms in our area. Forecast soundings are 
showing 1000-2000 J/kg of CAPE available with the higher amounts 
further south in Southeast Tennessee/Southwest North Carolina. 
There is a moderate amount of shear in the mid to low levels to 
work with as well south of the front. Right now the environment 
south of the front looks to support hail and strong winds as the 
primary threat in the strongest storms on Tuesday. As the sun sets
and the front continues to push south storms will transition to 
rain showers overnight and slowly diminish as we move into 
Wednesday.

After the rain ends a slow warm up will begin the second half of the 
work week and into the weekend. There will still be some moisture in 
the atmosphere over us during the time, but there appears to be no 
major forcing that would allow it to precipitate. Better chances for 
precipitation will come with our next system, a low pressure system 
and cold front expected to quickly swing through at the end of the 
weekend into early next week. Currently the models are actually in 
decent agreement that precipitation chances will ramp back up on 
Saturday evening and continue through Sunday night. They do however 
differ on the exact track of the associated low and how much 
instability we will have to work with, but right now it looks like a 
decent chance that thunderstorms will accompany this system.

sunshine for most of the day will warm the region about 10 degrees
higher than last night in the mid 60s to lower 70s. Clouds will 
stream in from the west late in the day ahead of the next storm 
system, but this should have little impact on heating. 

.LONG TERM /Monday Night through Sunday/...

(mainly for areas along and north of I-40 through the remainder of 
the evening hours). A cold front will then sweeps south into the 
region between 00-03z, bringing a line of strong showers to the 
region. This activity will gradually drop south to the I-40 corridor 
around 06z, and then areas to the south between 06-12z. QPF totals 
will be around 1/2 to 3/4 of an inch in some areas given the 
slightly heavier precipitation and the slow moving nature of the 
storms. Drier air will quickly filter into the region in wake of the 
front after 12z, with significant clearing going on by 15z. The 
combination of WSW flow and ample sunshine will warm the Valley into 
the mid to upper 60s. Late in the period -- clouds will filter into 
SW VA and far NE Tennessee ahead of the next frontal boundary. 
However, the forecast will remain fry through 00z.

.SHORT TERM (Today and tonight)...
Current precip associated with a shortwave trough and jet entrance
region will be exiting the area early this morning, with drier air
aloft working its way in from the NW later this morning. However,
the surface front lags behind, and will not move through our area
until the afternoon. Low level moisture preceding the front and
falling midlevel temps under the closed upper low will help
regenerate showers and possibly an isolated thunderstorm in the
early afternoon, mainly in northern sections. SW VA and NE TN
remain under the influence of the closed low through tonight,
which will keep isolated showers going. The delay of the surface
front until the afternoon will allow temps to reach the 60s in
most spots, and around 70 south where there will be greater
clearing. It will be breezy today as a surface low deepens over
VA and some clearing enhances boundary layer mixing, but it should
stay below wind advisory levels. The current wind advisory will be
canceled as current obs do not support it continuing. 

.LONG TERM (Sunday through Friday)...
Generally quiet weather to end the weekend and begin the work 
week as a ridge starts building in from the west and dry air 
continues to move in from the northwest. Warming trend continues 
for the first few days of the long term portion of the forecast 
leading to our warmest day on Tuesday where high temperatures will
top out in the 60's (and possibly even the low 70's in Southeast 
Tennessee). The next system that will bring a good chance for 
widespread precipitation will be a cold front diving in from the 
north Monday into Tuesday. Warmer temperatures ahead of the front 
will allow us to become unstable enough to where we can see 
showers and thunderstorms along and ahead of the front. Models are
forecasting for the boundary to bog down near the Gulf Coast and 
depending on the exact location of the boundary we could see some 
isentropic lift leading to continuing rain chances into the second
half of the work week. Boundary will then eventually get pushed 
east of us to make way for our next system (a front quickly moving
in from the west) which current models have moving in Saturday 
into Sunday.

the mid to upper 60s. Late in the period -- clouds will filter into 
SW VA and far NE Tennessee ahead of the next frontal boundary. 
However, the forecast will remain dry through 00z. 


.LONG TERM /Saturday Night through Friday/...
Saturday night...cooler...drier air with northwest flow aloft 
will filter in behind an exiting cold front. An upper low to our 
north will rotate in minimal low level moisture with the upslope 
flow. A few isolated light showers and even a few flurries may 
develop over far northern locations and eastern mountains. Little 
to no snow accumulation is expected over high elevations. The rest
of the area will remain dry. Surface high pressure will build in 
on Sunday and Monday for dry conditions and abundant daytime 
sunshine will allow afternoon temperatures to warm to near normal 
levels. Will transition back to an unsettle weather pattern for 
Monday night and Tuesday as a cold front moves in and becomes 
stretched across the area. Weak instability could create 
widespread showers and a slight chance of thunderstorms Monday 
night. With the continued frontal boundary across the 
area...expect to see widespread showers and a slight chance of 
thunderstorms continuing over the region through Tuesday. The 
temperatures profile looks warm enough for an all rain event. A 
few showers will linger into Tuesday night and Wednesday as the 
frontal boundary slowly slides south of the area. Model 
consistency drops by the end of the extended and confidence become
quite low. However...current trend is for the boundary to quickly
rebound back across the area around the Thursday/Friday time 
frame as a warm front for another round of showers.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
High pressure will remain in control today with mostly sunny
skies. Will let wind chill advisory and freeze warning ride
through late this morning with current air temps in the upper
teens to mid 20s across the Tennessee Valley. Already seeing some
temperatures in the single digits along the spine of the Smokies,
so it will not take much wind at all to drop wind chills below
zero. Temperatures will rebound after sunrise and highs should
reach the 40s and lower 50s across most of the area under
abundant sunshine. (The exception again will be the higher 
elevations where temps will remain in the upper 20s to 30s. 
Surface high pressure slides east tonight, and mid and high clouds
will gradually move in, ahead of our next weather system. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday through through Wednesday)...
Next upper low dives SE out of Canada on Friday then off the Middle 
Atlantic coast by Saturday. Models in fair agreement on timing of 
the associated surface system which will drop into the area by 
Friday evening with fropa by Saturday afternoon. Timing of pcpn 
arrival ahead of the front now looks to be late enough that chances 
for any frozen pcpn in NE TN and SW VA will be very low as even the 
higher terrain should have enough time to warm up before it starts. 
Similarly, latest model runs indicate that moisture is long gone 
before the low levels can cool down enough for any snow showers 
behind the front. However, will still keep some light snow showers
and flurries in fcst for Saturday night over highest elevations 
of SW VA and NE TN during that time as at least SREF and GFS 
continue to show some pcpn in those areas overnight. 

Upper ridge then builds back across the area by Sunday night before 
next system begins to flatten out that ridge by Monday afternoon. As 
pattern becomes broadly zonal across much of the eastern US on 
Tuesday, models are indicating an east to west frontal feature 
draped across the area through Tuesday night that could keep weather 
unsettled and increase pcpn chances into Wednesday morning.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
346 PM EDT Wed Mar 15 2017

.SHORT TERM /Tonight through Thursday/...
A cold, northwest wind will continue reinforcing a bitterly cold 
arctic air mass. The combination of a clear sky and this cold air 
will allow temperatures to plummett after sunset well below 
freezing -- eventually bottoming out into the mid teens to lower 
20s across the Valley. A freeze warning is in effect to address 
this potential for a widespread, killing freeze. In addition, 
winds along the East Tennessee Mountains will remain in the 10 to 
15 mph range, and combined with bitterly cold air cause wind chill
values to drop to dangerously low levels in the -5 to -15 degree 
range. By late morning these products will expire as temperatures 
warm due to solar heating. A warmer day is expected as highs will 
peak in the 40s to lower 50s. 

.LONG TERM /Thursday Night through Wednesday/...
The cold pattern continues over the eastern states as yet another
upper trough builds southeast out of the central Canadian 
provinces Friday into Saturday. A cold front will accompany the 
feature and most of the precipitation will be in the form of rain 
showers; however, if the precip moves in too fast on Friday, the 
low level airmass may be too cold in the higher terrain for rain 
so will have to mix in a couple snow showers and then at the end 
of the event as the airmass is drying out on Saturday night, there
may be another couple flurries. Dry northwest flow and ridging 
keeps the forecast area dry Sunday into Sunday night. However, the
upper trough and cold front moves into the area later Monday 
night into Tuesday with some more rain showers followed by a 
another period of dry cold advection on Wednesday.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Still seeing some bands of snow showers on radar early this
morning across mainly SW Virginia and NE Tennessee. Some bursts 
of heavier snow are possible in these bands, and a dusting of snow
is possible on some roadways across SW Virginia for the morning 
commute. Bands should fizzle out later this morning. Surface high
pressure builds across the area today, and cloud cover will
decrease from southwest to northeast throughout the day, but it 
will remain cold with temperatures struggling to reach freezing by
noon. Highs today will vary from around 40 degrees in the 
southern TN valley to the mid 20s across the higher elevations. 
The brisk northwest wind will continue and even increase a bit 
today as daytime mixing occurs. Temperatures drop back down below 
freezing after sunset tonight and once again will bottom out in 
the upper teens to lower 20s.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...
Models are in relatively good agreement on the timing of the next 
frontal boundary for Friday Night and Saturday. Only difference is 
that NAM remains a bit slower than both GFS and ECMWF regarding 
onset of any precipitation. Currently tending toward NAM soln for 
pcpn timing overnight Friday into Saturday based on the low level 
dry air that looks to remain anchored across the area at least into 
Friday afternoon. Once front moves through by Saturday evening, 
expect another cold surge, albeit not as potent as the current air 
mass, into Sunday morning. With temperatures falling below freezing 
overnight Saturday and Sunday highs expected to be about 10 degrees 
below normal, residual moisture could fall as snow by Sunday 
morning. This snow event would be confined to the higher elevations 
of SW VA and NE TN with no accumulations expected, as most of the 
moisture is gone prior to the cold air arriving. Beyond Sunday, next 
frontal system drops into the area Tuesday with increasing pcpn 
chances through the day Tuesday and into Tuesday night ahead of the 
actual frontal boundary.

.SHORT TERM (Today into tomorrow)...
Overcast skies have helped to keep temperatures down today, and 
light precipitation continues to wrap around the low off the east
coast. This very light precipitation will likely continue in at 
least parts of our area overnight and into early tomorrow. Since 
this is a weak northwest flow event locations in the valley will 
likely only see a few drizzles of rain or a few flurries in the 
sky with no accumulation on the ground. Some locations in the 
higher terrain could see some very slow and light accumulations 
today into tonight, with possibly a couple of inches at the peaks 
of the mountains. Tonight will be very cold as the air continues 
to funnel in from our northwest and we get some clearing of the 
clouds overnight. With the lower temperatures we saw today I have 
gone ahead and made the freeze warning begin a couple of hours 
earlier than the previous issuance. Temperatures during the day 
tomorrow will likely be similar to what we experienced today.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...
Models are in decent agreement overall, although still 
differences in the details. Forecast confidence is about average 
for this time of year. Will be very cold Wednesday night and a 
freeze warning will be needed, but will not issue at this time to 
avoid confusion with headlines. Will keep mention in HWO. Will see
some moderation of temps Thursday, then moisture will start to 
return on Friday ahead of next frontal system. GFS very fast with 
precip return even bringing light precip north Thursday night, but
will lean toward slower NAM/ECMWF solutions given the dry air in 
place near the surface. Front pushes through Friday night/early 
Saturday along with showers, then another batch of colder air will
move in behind the front. This colder air will not be quite as 
cold as this most recent cold outbreak, however. After a dry 
Sunday, moisture will return again early in the week ahead of yet 
another frontal system.

612 
FXUS64 KMRX 140726
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
326 AM EDT Tue Mar 14 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)... 
Latest water vapor and RAP upper air analysis shows potent upper 
level low over the western Great Lakes with a very strong 
shortwave trough over Eastern GA this morning. As the Great Lakes
low drops further SE into Western PA by tonight, the shortwave 
trough will move rapidly off the East Coast to help deepen the 
sfc low associated with the Northeast Blizzard today. 

At the surface, cold front that is ushering in some of the coldest
temperatures yet this winter is beginning to approach the TN-NC 
border this morning. As such, the best deep moisture is now 
shifting east of the area. However, a few potent shortwave spokes 
rotating around the Great Lakes upper low coupled with wrap around
moisture from the deepening East Coast bomb will continue to 
squeeze out some valley rainshowers and higher elevation
snowshowers through the day today. Pcpn will primarily be found in
valley locations north of I-40 and in elevations above 3000 ft
everywhere in the area. Although valley locations may see some 
evening and overnight snow in showers, no accumulation is
expected. All pcpn winds down by Wednesday morning with 
accumulations of up to 1-3 inches still possible in the higher 
elevations of the Smoky Mountains and SW VA through that time.

Temperatures tonight will drop into the lower 20s and upper teens 
across much of the area putting the overnight lows in the top 10 
for this winter season. As for record low territory, not gonna 
happen. It was 15 March 1993 that saw lows of 11, 6, and 1 in 
Chattanooga, Knoxville, and Tri-Cities respectively behind the now
infamous Super Storm. Either way, we are looking at a solid freeze
across the area tonight.


.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday)...
Models are in good agreement for much of the extended period. 
Main story is cold conditions continuing through Friday morning. 
Daytime temperatures Wednesday will struggle to reach the mid 30s 
in places. Temperatures will drop well below freezing most nights.
Freeze warning will be needed for Wednesday night with 
temperatures dipping into the teens, but to avoid confusion with 
active winter weather advisory and Tuesday night's freeze warning,
will wait until a later shift to issue. Temperatures will rebound
by Friday, with southwest flow ushering warmer, more moist air 
into the region. A cold front will approach the area Friday 
evening into Saturday, bringing the next chance for rain showers. 
Temperatures should remain above freezing during this frontal 
passage, but a wintry mix is possible later Saturday across SW VA 
and NE TN as the system exits the area and cooler air filters back
into the area on a northwest wind. The weekend should be pleasant
with mostly sunny skies and highs in the 50s. Monday will be even
warmer, with highs in the 60s and increasing cloud cover, ahead 
of the next approaching system.

FXUS64 KMRX 130845

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
445 AM EDT Mon Mar 13 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today through Tuesday)...
Yet another rather potent late season winter storm will effect our
area through the period. System is expected to bring primarily
cold rain into the East Tennessee Valley while portions of SW
Virginia and higher elevations in East Tennessee will likely see
accumulations of up to 4 inches with this event. Models are in
surprisingly good agreement on the track and deepening of this
system off the east coast on Tuesday. Consequently, models are
also in fairly good agreement that initial and subsequent wrap
around moisture that will allow for an extended period of frozen 
precip mainly across our higher elevations until very late on 
Tuesday. Although we are in an airmass producing temperatures well
below normal, guidance continues to suggest Valley locations will
remain warm enough to make this an all rain event. However, higher
elevations will certainly see accumulations during this extended 
event. 

.LONG TERM (Tuesday night through Sunday)...  
Upper low over the eastern Great Lakes will keep Northwest flow 
across region Tuesday night with snow showers mainly higher 
elevations with light accumulations to continue. Lower elevations 
may see a few tenths across northeast Tennessee and southwest 
Virginia. NAM model moves moisture out quickly Tuesday evening while 
GFS and European hold onto it through the night. Skies will clear 
from southwest to northeast as the night progresses and temperatures 
will drop into the teens and 20s. Have kept temperatures close to 
extended guidance MAV numbers. Lingering cloud cover and strong NW 
Winds may keep temperatures up across Northeast Tennessee and 
southwest Virginia. An arctic air mass will move in from Canada 
Wednesday with frigid temperatures for this time of year. Highs will 
struggle to reach 20 in the high mountains and be only mid 20s to 
mid 30s northeast and upper 30s to lower 40s southeast. Cold air 
advection will continue overnight Wednesday night with another hard 
freeze. Lows will be in the teens to lower 20s areawide. Thursday 
upper trough begins to shift east with much warmer temperatures in 
the mid 30s to upper 40s but still well below normal. Friday morning 
will be the last cold morning below freezing lower 20s to lower 30s. 
The cold high pressure area will shift east and clouds increase 
ahead of a cold front. Temperatures will warm more to the mid 40s to 
mid 50s. A brief period of snow is possible northern sections early 
Friday but no accumulation expected. The cold front will move 
through the eastern Tennessee valley Saturday with higher pressure 
moving back in Sunday. Temperatures over the weekend will stay 
warmer in the 50s to lower 60s....

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
311 PM EDT Sun Mar 12 2017

.Short term (tonight and tomorrow)...

High pressure and mostly clear skies will be present through the 
early morning Monday. Low temperatures overnight will be below 
normal for this time of year...though will struggle to get much 
below freezing in many areas. Will keep the freeze warning going 
overnight...though low level winds will shift to the southwest 
early Monday morning behind the high pressure...starting to bring 
advection of warmer and more moist air to the area. 

A low pressure system will approach from the NW...causing scattered 
showers to begin by late morning/early afternoon. Little to no 
instability is expected...with dry mid and upper levels...so only a 
few tenths of an inch rainfall accumulation is expected. 
Temperatures Monday will be in the mid to upper 40s...several 
degrees below normal.

.LONG TERM... 

Cold and cloudy weather will continue tomorrow 
night as the front/low sweep through and move east of us. 
Precipitation chances will continue during this time, but most 
places will likely just see rain. In the valley temperatures near 
the surface should remain warm enough to see all liquid, but we 
could see some decent accumulations in the higher elevations of 
the Southern Appalachian Mountains. Can't rule out a little bit of
light snowfall in some of the northern valley locations during 
the coldest parts of the night, but overall it looks like 
temperatures will remain warm enough that the vast majority of the
population just sees rain with this event. Wrap- around moisture 
could help continue very light sprinkle/flurry chances in far NE 
Tennessee/SW Virginia (mostly the higher elevations) through 
Tuesday night, but most places will see precipitation end by mid 
day on Tuesday. 

Cold air will continue to pour in from the northwest leading to 
several very cold days/nights, with the coldest temperatures all 
week expected on Wednesday/Wednesday night. Temperatures will likely 
be in the 20/30's during the daytime and drop down into the teens 
overnight. We will see a slow warming trend towards the end of the 
work week ahead of our next system. Timing is still off with the 
models for this next system, but they generally agree that we should 
be warm enough to see only rain outside of the mountainous areas. We 
will finally warm up to around normal temperatures at the end of the 
weekend with some places seeing 60 on Sunday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
441 AM EDT Sun Mar 12 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...
Current radar trend indicates that last significant band of snow  
is moving eastward along the TN-GA border into NC-SC this 
morning. Further north there are some radar bands moving across
the Central Valley, but any snow there is really struggling to
reach the ground in such dry low level air. Current dew points 
are into the single digits across NE TN and into the lower teens 
across the Central Valley N of I-40 this morning. 

Was able to cancel the winter weather advisory for NW counties in
the advisory area as only an additional chance of flurries exists
in the dry air surge southward. Will let the southern tier
counties along with the mountain zones expire on time with snow
already on the ground in those areas and an additional light 
dusting possible before the event ends at 12Z. 

After this late winter system moves out this morning, forecast
calls for unseasonably cold and dry through tonight ahead of yet
another late winter system. With overnight temperatures dropping
quickly under clear skies tonight, will need yet another freeze
warning for all of the Central Valley northward as well as SW NC
and some portions of the Southern Plateau where temperatures will
drop to below 30 degrees (about 10-15 degree below normal) by
early Monday morning.

.LONG TERM (Monday through Saturday)...
Continued cold weather this week as upper trough stays over eastern 
third of the country. Next system to spread clouds and precipitation 
from Monday through Wednesday. Also a cooling trend through mid week 
as upper low over Quebec on Monday drops south and southeast toward 
the mid atlantic Wednesday. At the surface a low pressure area over 
Missouri Monday morning and cold front will quickly move into the 
Tennessee Valley by evening. With cold temperatures early Monday as 
precipitation starts there may be a little snow mixed in before 
temperatures warm ahead of the front. Rain will spread in from west 
to east with light snowfall amounts only at the highest elevations 
of east Tennessee. Monday night as temperatures cool aloft behind 
front higher elevations may see a couple inches of snow from 
southeast Tennessee north into southwest Virginia but temperatures 
in the lower elevations will stay in the mid to upper 30s with no 
accumulations expected. Tuesday and Tuesday night as the upper low 
drops south and southeast. Higher elevations will see more snow with 
Northwest flow aloft but lower elevations will be to warm Tuesday. 
Lower elevations in the northeast sections may see a few tenths of 
an inch of snow Tuesday night and early Wednesday before the upper 
low shifts east and northeast. Then on the back side of the system 
much colder air will bring lows down into the teens and 20s early 
Wednesday and Thursday. Also even as skies clear Wednesday highs 
will only reach the 30s to lower 40s...and 20s in the mountains. 
Temperatures begin to warm Thursday back into the 40s...30s higher 
elevations. Late Friday another system will drop southeast from the 
northern Plains. This system will be warmer as temperatures Friday 
and Saturday will be in the upper 40s and 50s. Precipitation will 
stay as mostly rain. A little snow is possible in the higher 
elevations overnight Friday night into Saturday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
304 PM EST Sat Mar 11 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight through Sunday)...

Overcast clouds and scattered light precip through the day has 
kept temperatures across the TN valley and plateau from reaching 
in the lower 40s. With the lack of warming through the day...have 
gone with temperatures in the mid to upper 20s overnight. Will 
keep the Freeze Warning going from 12 AM EST through 10 AM EDT 
across the area where these temperatures will be several degrees 
below normal for this time of year. 

Tonight...the system will continue to move east...with scattered 
light rain showers expected through the evening. Colder air 
advecting in...combined with the sun setting...will allow for the 
scattered light rain to change over to snow. Light snow showers are 
expected through Sunday morning. Models are diverging on the exact 
position of this system through the early morning...though they 
are still keeping on to enough moisture and lift for snow 
accumulations...ranging from 1-2 inches in areas I40 and south. 
Areas in the higher elevations of east TN could see around 2-4 
inches as slight NW mid level winds will keep upslope flow over 
east TN. Have kept the Winter Weather Advisory going from 7 PM EST
tonight through 8 AM EDT Sunday morning.

Sunday...enough dry air will filter in behind this system for snow 
showers to end by mid morning. High temperatures on Monday are 
expected to warm quickly in to the mid to upper 40s as high pressure 
moves in for Sunday. 

.LONG TERM (Sunday night through Friday)...

Main weather story will be the front and associated winter weather 
as it moves through our area. Believe that most of the populated 
locations will see minimal snowfall amounts as most of this system 
will hopefully be rain as the brunt of it moves through the forecast 
area on Monday night. However in the higher elevations of far 
Northeast Tennessee and Southwest Virginia it might remain cold 
enough the the majority of the system falls as snow. If this does 
occur they could see several inches of accumulations in the highest 
terrain. Down in the valley amounts will be much less with a dusting 
to an inch likely in northeast TN/southwest VA. Confidence is still 
somewhat low as models are disagreeing with how much moisture to 
bring in ahead of the front. 

After this system moves through cold temperatures will remain 
through the rest of the forecast. Another system with the potential 
for winter weather will move in out of the west next weekend, but 
timing differences in the models make this one a bit tricky to feel 
confident about at this time.

FXUS64 KMRX 110905
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
405 AM EST Sat Mar 11 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today through Sunday)...
The forecast questions for the period is "How much snow and where
will  it fall?", both of which seem to trending downward and 
southward respectively. Latest few runs of all available models 
continue to trend towards less moisture and a more southern track.
Current guidance suggests a dusting to less than an inch north of
I-40 in the East TN Valley and Northern Plateau while areas 
further south may see an inch in the Valley increasing up to 2 
inches in the higher elevations of the the Southern Plateau. 
Additionally, areas in the foothills along the Appalachian 
Mountains of East TN and SW NC will likely see 1 to 3 inches total
with some isolated higher elevations seeing accumulations of up 
to 4 inches. 

Forecast confidence is fairly high with the timing of the snow
being  mainly in the 0-12Z time frame with best moisture centered
around 6Z tonight. Forecast confidence is somewhat lower on 
precise location of snowfall totals as the east to west 
orientation of the event sets up a rather sharp moisture and 
therefore snowfall gradient. In these situations...location is 
everything. A small shift north or south and the central valley 
could see 1 to 2 inches during the overnight with the southern 
third of the area getting a slightly lesser amount. 

One area where confidence IS growing would be the forecast for  
the Northern Plateau, SW Virginia, and NE Tennessee. These areas 
look like they will be out of play for this event. There is just 
no moisture available to work with and with consensus of models 
keeping moisture well south of that area for the event, would not 
expect a sudden shift that far north for best QPF. 


.LONG TERM (Sunday Night through Friday)...
Another cold night Sunday night with clear skies and light winds. 
Lows once again lower to mid 20s northeast Tennessee and southwest 
Virginia to upper 20s to lower 30s elsewhere. A low pressure area 
over the mid Mississippi Valley early Monday will bring moisture up 
from the south as low pressure along a cold front in the northern 
Gulf and another low off the Southeast Coast along the front deepen 
and begin to move northeast. As the low moves into the Ohio Valley 
late Monday precipitation will increase over the forecast area. 
There could be a little snow early before changing to rain...except 
the higher mountains. Accumulations will be light during the day 
Monday but could be a couple inches in the northeast Tennessee 
mountains. Monday night and early Tuesday as cold front approaches 
with surface low moving across the Ohio Valley and upper trough digs 
south. This will be the best time for accumulations. Temperatures in 
the lower elevations will be just above freezing so accumulation 
does not look to be significant. However higher elevations could see 
a few inches. Also as surface low moves northeast cold air on back 
side of low and with upper trough some upslope snow will occur 
Tuesday and Tuesday night and even early Wednesday across southwest 
Virginia. Temperatures will be cool Tuesday and will drop even 
farther early Wednesday into the upper teens to upper 20s. Snow 
showers linger across northeast Tennessee and southwest Virginia 
Wednesday. Very cold high pressure builds down over the southern 
Appalachians Wednesday night and Thursday. Lows again 15 to 20 
northeast sections and 20 to 25 south half. Thursday highs only 30s 
mountains and parts of southwest Virginia to 40s elsewhere. Several 
degrees warmer Thursday night. Flow becomes more zonal by Friday 
with warmer temperatures but another weak system drops down from the 
northwest bringing in mostly rain.

818 
FXUS64 KMRX 101955
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
255 PM EST Fri Mar 10 2017

.SHORT TERM (This Evening through Sunday)...A ridge of high
pressure will settle into the Tennessee Valley and southern
Appalachians tonight. Dry airmass, clear sky, and light/calm winds
will allow temperatures to drop into the 20s with a hard freeze
most locations. Since Fruit trees and berries are susceptible to
freeze damage, a freeze warning has been issued for late tonight
and early Saturday morning.

Main forecast concern is a storm system coming from the central
Plains into the southern Appalachians late Saturday through early
Sunday morning. Models have been inconsistent with lack of run-
to-run continuity. The latest NAM is the most aggressive with the
GFS the least. Models show best chance of 4 inch snowfall remains
across the far eastern Tennessee Mountains, thus will continue the
watch there, but will hold off expanding due to lack of
confidence. Advisory snowfall possible elsewhere.

Another night of freezing temperatures/hard freeze most locations
by early Sunday morning.

For Sunday, dry air quickly returns with sky becoming mostly
sunny. 

For fire weather purpose, low afternoon relative humidity is
expected both Saturday and Sunday.

.LONG TERM (Sunday night through Friday)...
Mostly clear skies on Sunday afternoon and high temperatures 
expected to be near 50 across most of the area will combine to 
help erode most of the snow that fell in the valley. But the sunny
skies and warming temperatures won't last for to long as our next
system makes it's way towards our area. A cold front will move 
out of the west towards the area and bring another chance for 
winter precipitation. There is model discrepancies with when the 
moisture and precipitation will start in our area. The ECMWF has 
the low off to our south much closer to the coast and brings 
moisture in sooner Tuesday morning leading to earlier and heavier 
snowfall. The GFS wants to keep the low further off the coast and 
holds back the moisture until the main precipitation band moves in
with the front. If this is correct we will likely be warm enough 
to where we see mostly rain, whereas the ECWMF solution would 
trend towards more snowfall than rain for our area. Best time for 
snow would be around the 00z time frame as that is when there is 
the most moisture available in the dendritic growth zone. However 
at this time temperatures might not have dropped low enough near 
the surface to produce snow unless the evaporative cooling helps 
bring the temperature down quickly. After 00Z drier air in the mid
levels moves in and dries out the dendritic growth zone leading 
to lower snowfall production potential from the atmosphere. At 
this time confidence is pretty low for this system since the 
models are unsure of how to handle the moisture over our area and 
since our temperatures for some places will be at or above around 
freezing at the surface for the time of best snowfall potential, 
this also lends towards a less confident forecast. 

Colder and drier northwest flow will set up behind the system 
leading to a continued period of below average temperatures for the 
second half of the work week. Another system moves in towards the 
weekend, but at this time it looks like temperatures will be warm 
enough that it should be mostly rain.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Convection has winded down for the night as left over showers

of up to one inch in heavy showers over NE TN and SW VA have 
caused some localized flooding issues, as per a spotter report. 
Based on pcpn trend, have issued a pair of urban and small stream 
advisories for those areas set to expire by 12Z this 
morning...although declining radar trend may allow for an earlier 
cancellation. 

Expect gradual clearing by this afternoon as the cold front 
currently extending SW from central West Virginia into NW Tennessee 
finally pushes east of the area by afternoon. Temperatures will then 
begin to fall by this evening, dropping to near and below freezing 
under clear skies across much of the area. A hard freeze is expected 
for SW Virginia, NE Tennessee and the Northern Plateau counties and 
a freeze warning has been issued for those areas. Elsewhere 
temperatures will teeter near freezing in a light overnight breeze. 
Guidance is split at around the freezing mark for the southern half 
of the area, therefore went with consensus for current fcst. A 
second look this afternoon may result in a greater southern extent 
to the freeze warning at that time.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday)...An active pattern for
the next several days as cold air mass from central Canada moves 
across the southeast Saturday while an upper level disturbance 
moves southeast from the mid Mississippi Valley then into the 
Tennessee Valley and across the southern Appalachians Saturday 
night and Sunday morning. NAM model is faster and much stronger 
with this system and forms a weak surface low across the southeast
states Saturday night into early Sunday. GFS Model trending a 
little slower with precipitation start on Saturday which would 
have temperatures warm more than NAM. Have kept highs closer to 
GFS/MAV numbers. For Saturday night lowered snowfall amounts first
6 hours and raised last 6 hours. Best chance for accumulations 
will be after sunset to mid morning Sunday. Have issued a Winter 
Storm Watch for the eastern Tennessee Mountains for 4 to possibly 
9 inches. Lower elevations of the valley and plateau are expected
to get from about 1 to 3 inches with lower amounts extreme south.
Precipitation ends by late morning Sunday and skies clear. 
Another cold night Sunday night with lows mid 20s to lower 30s. 
From Monday through Thursday a cold upper trough digs south from 
the plains Monday bringing a chance of rain and snow during the 
day and snow overnight keeping temperatures cold especially in the
mountains. A deep surface low may form over the Ohio Valley as 
this system moves northeast bringing in more cold temperatures and
wrap around rain and snow showers Tuesday and Tuesday night. 
Wednesday through early Thursday a brief break from the 
precipitation. Then a more southern system forming across the 
Mississippi Valley spreads more clouds and rain in Thursday.

FXUS64 KMRX 092003
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
303 PM EST Thu Mar 9 2017

.Short Term...(This Evening through Friday)...A strong upper level 
jet will move across the Ohio Valley overnight placing the Tennessee 
Valley and southern Appalachians under the favored Right Entrance 
Region. Strong and deep omega is noted over the region between 06-
09Z enhancing the fronto-genetic forcing along a cold frontal 
boundary. Forecast soundings show elevated instability, especially 
across TYS and CHA. 

Enough instability and strength of fronto-genetic forcing to produce 
a band of showers and thunderstorms early Friday morning. The strong 
upper level jet will also induce a low-level jet of 50-55kts, so any 
thunderstorms may have some locally strong/gusty winds. Small hail 
is also possible with the stronger storms across the southern half 
of the area.

Besides the storms, low-level jet will produce windy conditions over 
the higher elevations of the Smoky Mountains, so will issue a wind 
advisory there between 05-15Z Friday.

For Friday, scattered showers will end quickly as drier air moves 
into the region with sky becoming mostly sunny/partly cloudy during 
the afternoon. Much cooler air will be the rule.

.Long Term...(Friday night through Wednesday)...
Much colder air will continue to flow into our from the northwest
as we move into the weekend setting us up for some winter 
precipitation Saturday night into Sunday. A shortwave will be 
diving out of the northern Great Plains towards our area and a low
south of us tracks to the northeast. In addition there will be 
atmospheric divergence above us as we sit in the right rear 
quadrant of an upper level jet leading to another favorable 
synoptic ingredient. Precipitation will move in from the 
west/northwest Saturday night and will initially begin as rain for
most of the forecast area. As temperatures drop overnight it will
transition to snow...Forecast soundings suggest that the 
transition will come relatively quickly once temperatures drop low
enough and we should hopefully not really see much in the way of 
icy precipitation. With recent warm temperatures the ground will 
be pretty warm which could help melt initial snowfall... However, 
with this event occurring at night and some moderate to even 
briefly heavy snowfall the melting process on the surface could 
quickly end. There is a wide model spread when it comes to 
snowfall totals which leads to a decreased confidence in this 
aspect of the forecast. The NAM and the GFS are more bullish with 
snowfall amounts while the SREF and ECMWF are lighter. NAM/GFS 
have more moisture in the atmosphere to work with and also have 
moderate to heavy snowfall around midnight through the early 
morning hours. Have not bitten off on the higher amounts since 
model spread is pretty wide and with the (very few) winter events 
this year the GFS/NAM have tended to back off a bit as the event 
draws closer. Snow should quickly exit our area by midday on 
Sunday and we should actually be able to see the sun for a while. 

Another trough will swing through the northern part of the country 
and a front will sweep through Monday night/Tuesday. This will bring 
another round winter weather, but model differences on the timing of 
the track of this system make confidence pretty low for the Monday 
night/Tuesday system. We will dry out again after this second 
system, but the cooler temperatures will stick around through the 
end of the work week.

National Weather Service Morristown TN

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...

With dewpoints mixing out and temperatures climbing, RH values are 
currently around 20 percent across the area. Additionally, seeing
some wind gusts in the 20 to 25 kt range. Will continue to forgo 
a SPS or RFW due to the recent widespread rainfall. Current water 
vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicates a broad trough
across the CONUS with a more substantial shortwave trough across 
the Northeastern U.S. At the surface, a cold front is located 
along the Eastern Seaboard with high pressure across the 
Southeastern U.S. Further to the northwest, there is a cold front 
stretching across the Great Lakes region into the Central Plains. 
The surface high will shift to the east tonight with light 
southerly flow returning by sunrise. Lows tonight will range from 
low 30s to low 40s. Expect the coldest temperatures will be in the
sheltered valleys of NE TN and SW VA. 

For Thursday, will see the boundary to the north slow and may be 
even retreat some to the north across the Ohio River Valley. Warm 
air advection will take over in the low levels with high 
temperatures rising into the mid 60s to low 70s. Deep mixing will 
occur again on Thursday with RH values dropping down to around 25 
percent with winds of around 5-15 mph. These values are borderline 
for fire weather products. For now, will forgo a SPS but could see 
this being needed for tomorrow afternoon. 

.LONG TERM (Thursday night through Wednesday)...

Forecast confidence is below average for much of the extended 
period with differences between forecast models and even 
individual runs of models. A cold front will swing through 
Thursday night/early Friday, bringing the chance for some showers 
for mainly the first half of Friday. Colder air will move in 
behind the front, then models show an upper trough swinging across
the area and a weak surface low moving by to our south late 
Saturday through early Sunday. While the system may initially 
start out as rain, thermal profiles suggest a quick changeover to 
snow after sunset Saturday night. Accumulating snow will be 
possible, especially north of I-40 and in the mountains. Areas 
south of I-40 may see some accumulating snow, but confidence is 
much too low at this point to indicate anything more than a 
rain/snow mix. It appears that the last few runs of the GFS and 
ECMWF have trended cooler, indicating a better potential for snow 
in our forecast area, but there's still plenty of time for finer 
details to change. Keep in mind, this event is still 4 days out, 
and the energy for this system is still out over the Pacific Ocean
where observing equipment for model initial conditions is sparse.
Details remain uncertain. Will continue the mention of possible 
snow in the HWO. System moves well east of our forecast area by 
late Sunday, and Monday looks dry. The main story for next week 
will be cooler temperatures, especially overnight, with hard 
freezes possible for a couple nights in a row. Another front with 
limited moisture is forecast to push through Monday night into 
Tuesday, and temperatures will remain cold enough overnight for 
some flakes to mix in at higher elevations.

FXUS64 KMRX 072021
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
321 PM EST Tue Mar 7 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...
Scattered showers continue across the forecast area with leading 
edge of more solid area of showers and embedded thunderstorms now 
moving across plateau. Stronger south to southwest winds in the 
Knoxville area have gusted to 35 to 40 mph. Winds with the storms 
expected to be about 30 to 40 mph along and ahead of the line. 
Temperatures have reached into the mid to upper 60s ahead of the 
main line and have dropped back down into the 50s on the plateau. 
Will keep chance of thunderstorms in for next few hours with main 
line and high rain chances. Wind advisory will be reissued for late 
afternoon into early evening. May be able to be cancelled early 
after storms move into the Appalachians. By mid evening showers will 
begin to taper off and winds will shift to to the northwest. Expect 
lows to be fairly uniform in the upper 30s to lower 40s. Wednesday 
higher pressure and mostly sunny skies with brisk west to northwest 
winds. Highs near to slightly above normal Wednesday.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...
A ridge of high pressure and zonal flow aloft for Wednesday 
night and Thursday producing dry conditions and warm afternoon 
conditions. For Thursday night and Friday morning, a frontal 
boundary will move across the Tennessee Valley and southern 
Appalachians. Due to the persistent ridging into the Gulf of 
Mexico, this boundary will be moisture starved with only light 
showers anticipated. However, much cooler temperatures will spill 
into the Region as a cold airmass moves into the Ohio/Tennessee 
Valleys. 

Main concern for the extended is the potential of wintry conditions 
for southern Virginia, northern third of Tennessee, and far eastern 
Tennessee Mountains for Saturday night and Sunday. This is still 
several days out, but models show a strong 300mb jet moving across 
the Ohio Valley/mid-Appalachian region placing our area into the 
favored Right Entrance of the jet. Even though we have warm air 
advection at 06z Sunday, models show strong cooling of the 
vertical column which suggest strong forcing. 

Looking at the vertical cross-section, strong ageostrophic vertical 
circulation noted over the area so good diabatic cooling 
anticipated. Forecast soundings over southwest Virginia look snowy, 
so will need to watch over the next several days for the potential 
of Wintry conditions for Saturday night and Sunday (especially 
morning).

For Monday and Tuesday, zonal flow returns with another system 
possible.

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Monday)...
The shortwave trough now over AR/LA will move across our area

quite dry, and the onset of measureable precip in our area will 
likely be near midnight. Precip amounts should be light as lift is
weak overnight, probably less than a tenth of an inch in most
spots. The trough exits Monday morning. Behind it, there will be 
very little forcing or instability to produce rain showers 
through the day, although midlevel saturation remains and should 
give mostly cloudy skies. Thus, highs will be a bit cooler than
today, in the lower to mid 60s.

.LONG TERM (Monday night through Sunday)...
A brief dry period early Monday night as most of the energy 
associated with approaching cold front moving into the Mississippi 
and Ohio valleys stays far to the west and northwest closer to the 
front. Lows will be mild though...close to 50 degrees. Winds will be 
somewhat gusty on the plateau from the south at 10 to 15 mph with 
gusts to 30 mph. More steady rainfall in the form of showers will 
spread across the region Tuesday. The best instability and forcing 
will stay over the lower Ohio valley and western Tennessee Valley 
Tuesday then weaken or shift mostly south of the area by late 
afternoon and evening. The NAM model is hinting at some stronger 
storms developing over the southern part of the forecast area 
Tuesday evening but at this time not thinking severe. Will have high 
rain chances Tuesday and Tuesday night. Rain moves out Wednesday as 
high pressure builds in. Thursday will again be mostly sunny. 
Thursday night through Sunday pattern again becomes unsettled as 
front drops down from the north and northwest Thursday night and 
Friday with a few showers. This front may pass through but then 
stays in the vicinity Saturday into Sunday. A better chance for 
showers will occur Saturday night. A few storms possible Saturday 
afternoon and evening and again Sunday. The mild pattern continues 
with above average lows and highs through next weekend.

.LONG TERM (Sunday through Friday)...
The week starts out with relatively decent weather as an 
amplified ridge slides slowly east to the Eastern Seaboard by 12z

western sections of the forecast area through late Monday night. 
However, probability of precipitation in the form of rain showers 
will increase on Tuesday as a cold front makes progress across the
Ohio Valley and Mid South region. Kept a scenario going which 
includes at least a chance for convection across western and 
southern sections of the viewing area, but model forecasts do not 
depict a great deal of instability with this system at this time. 
Went closer to a faster GFS vs. ECMWF fropa which rapidly drops 
off pops Tuesday night in time for a dry Wednesday. In fact, was 
able to keep rain out of much of the remainder of the extended 
forecast with more ridging and dry advection. It looks like 
temperatures will be a few degrees above normal through much of 
the long term; with the exception of Wednesday and Thursday where 
maxes and mins will be near climatological normal for early March 
in the wake of the mid week frontal passage.

A reinforcing shot of cold air will move in tonight with a cold
front. Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis
indicates a broad upper level trough from the Northern Plains 
eastward to the Northeastern U.S. A shortwave trough is forecast 
to rotate through the Central and Southern Appalachians late 
tonight into early tomorrow. This trough along with the surface 
front will provide enough lift for a few light snow 
showers/flurries late tonight into early tomorrow morning. Model 
soundings indicate a brief period of low level saturation around 
200-250 mb deep across NE TN and SW VA centered around 12z. PW 
values increase to around 0.3 inches. Due to this, there was 
enough evidence to increase PoPs some late tonight into early 
tomorrow morning. Additionally, stretched them a bit further to 
the south with a few flurries possible as far south as Knoxville. 
However, the lack of moisture and the brief window will lead to 
trace amounts up to half an inch in the higher elevations in SW VA
and extreme NE TN. These values are below thresholds for any 
winter weather products. Additionally, will forgo an SPS with 
amounts more than a dusting being limited to the aforementioned 
higher elevations.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
249 PM EST Thu Mar 2 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Friday)...
The channeled vort max on the western side of the Eastern
Canada/Conus longwave trough will be dropping into the Ohio
Valley/Ern KY/WV tonight. Models agree that it will squeeze out
some precip in SW VA after midnight and into Friday morning, but
they differ on how much and the timing. The NAM and GFS depict
over one inch in Wise and Russell counties. This seems a bit
too high given the lack of moisture that will precede the system,
and its fast movement. Less than 0.1 liquid QPF seems more 
realistic, which is what the SREF shows. Will have some light snow
accumulations in SW VA and NE TN mountains, but less than 1 inch
max.

Veering 850 mb winds behind the exiting shortwave trough will
reenforce cold advection across the area tomorrow. As a result, 
highs should be a few degrees colder than today, in the upper 40s 
to mid 50s. It will be breezy as well, with 10-20 mph W-NW winds,
which combined with RH in the 20-30% range in the afternoon, 
could cause some concerns for fire interests. 

.Long Term (Friday night through Thursday)...
After cold temperatures Friday the mercury will tumble down into 
the 20s with another killing frost. High pressure in southern 
Canada today will settle over the eastern states friday night and 
early Saturday with clear skies...a dry airmass and light winds 
for ideal radiational cooling. A quick warmup will resume Saturday
with highs 5-10 degrees warmer than Friday. Winds switch to the 
southwest Saturday. The high pressure area shifts east with 
continued warming into the upper 50s to lower 60s. On Monday the 
surface high will be off the east coast. Increasing moisture with 
southerly flow off the gulf will bring clouds back and a slight 
chance of showers Plateau and southern valley. Monday night and 
Tuesday best rain chances with some instability Tuesday increasing
risk for thunderstorms. Precipitation will end early Wednesday as
cold front moves east of region. Decreasing clouds later 
Wednesday as higher pressure moves back in and continues Thursday.
Temperatures will be near to a few degrees above normal for the 
period Monday through Thursday...mostly upper 50s to mid 60s at 
lower elevations.

south and ingredients are primed to see some strong to severe
thunderstorms. Model forecast soundings are showing CAPE values
generally in the 500-1500 J/Kg range across our area. Hi-
resolution models are struggling a bit with the timing of when the
front will move into the plateau counties, but generally expect it
to move in late morning or early afternoon. With the strong low
level jet and lots of shear to work with the main threat with the
line of storms will be damaging winds. However, with moderate CAPE
values we also cannot rule out large hail or a few tornadoes in
our area.

Main line of storms should be east of our area by the evening
hours and definitely east of us before tomorrow morning. Overnight
lows behind this system will be much colder with some places
flirting with freezing temperatures tonight.

.Long Term (Thursday through Tuesday)...
Strong NW flow will result in the reinforcement of a colder, drier 
air mass behind the cold front on Thursday. There should be plenty 
of sunshine by the afternoon, but this will do little to help 
counteract the cold air advection taking place. Another weak 
shortwave will pass through Thursday night into Friday, bringing in 
a secondary push of colder air. Highs on Friday will struggle to 
climb out of the 40s in most places. High pressure will slide into 
the region Friday night into Saturday, maintaining the dry weather --
 with abundant sunshine expected for the weekend and warmer 
temperatures as winds veer back to the SW. The next opportunity for 
precipitation may be very late in the period on Monday/Tuesday time 
period, with just scattered showers expected.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
336 PM EST Tue Feb 28 2017

.SHORT TERM (This Evening through Wednesday)...A jet streak moving
across the Ohio Valley has increased the isentropic lift over the
area producing widespread showers. Enough elevated instability to
produce scattered thunderstorms as well. This jet streak will move
east of the area this evening with decreasing convection chances.

Most of the night only a low chance of showers and possible
thunder. Main action will occur Wednesday afternoon/early evening.
A strong upper jet will move across the Ohio valley with an
another jet moving through the lower Tennessee valley. These jets
will produce divergence aloft of the region with good upper
forcing along a pre-frontal surface trough. 

This surface trough will move across during the area with the
airmass becoming sufficiently unstable (MLCAPES of near 1000
J/Kg) so widespread thunderstorms anticipated. Due to increasing
low-level jet in response to upper jet dynamics, the 850mb winds
increase to 60kts+. The strong low-level jet combined with mid-
level drying will set the stage for widespread damaging wind
event. Derecho Composite Parameter values above 1 are likely based
off SPC Ensembles.  

Enough speed shear to warrant a low chance of tornadoes as well
especially near any book-end vortices and/or notches. Marginal
severe hail is also possible.

The best time-frame for severe weather will be between Noon and 6
PM ET.

Besides the thunderstorms winds, strong low-level jet will produce
windy conditions tonight across the higher elevations and area-
wide for Wednesday.

.Long Term (Wednesday Night through Tuesday)...
The fast moving line of strong to severe storms will be exiting 
the area at the beginning of the long-term forecast and have PoPs 
coming to an end around 06z. Some of the model guidance is even 
quicker and could see an end to the rain chances closer to 00-03z 
Thursday if trends continue. 

Cooler and drier air will advect in behind the departing system. PW 
values will range from 0.1-0.2 inches on Thursday. These values are 
near the minimum observed for early March. The high temperatures on 
Thursday will be 15-20 degrees cooler than on Wednesday with highs 
generally in the 50s. A dry cold front will move through the 
forecast area late Thursday into early Friday bringing in a 
reinforcing shot of colder air. PW values increase slightly ahead of 
this boundary into the 0.2-0.4 inch range but it still looks too dry 
for precipitation. The latest model trends have shown precip. moving 
further south, potentially into SW VA, but have left the forecast 
dry for now. Low temperatures Friday morning will be just below to 
near freezing for most locations with the cold air advection. 
Adjusted highs down below guidance for Friday with the heart of the 
cold air advection overhead with forecast highs ranging from upper 
30s to low 50s. The coldest morning will be on Saturday with the 
surface high located overhead with ideal radiational cooling 
conditions. Expect a widespread freeze Saturday morning with lows 
ranging from the low 20s to the low 30s. 

Temperatures will moderate over the weekend and into early next week 
with a broad upper level ridge across the region. Highs will top out 
in the 60s for most valley locations Sunday and Monday. Rain chances 
will return late Monday as a warm front lifts northward across the 
area with another system approaching the forecast area near mid-week.

597 
FXUS64 KMRX 280912
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
412 AM EST Tue Feb 28 2017

.SHORT TERM /Today and Tonight/...
A warm front will move northeast into the region, coinciding with
a weak shortwave trough/ripple tracking across the Ohio/Tennessee
Valleys later this afternoon. This feature will bringing with it 
a warmer/moist air mass in it's wake as well as opportunities for
scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms from the late 
morning through the evening hours (supported by the latest runs of
the RAP/HRRR). The best chance for precipitation will be during 
the afternoon, with the highest PoPs favoring the Plateau and 
Southern/Central Valleys. Strong downsloping winds along the 
mountains will lessen coverage and QPF amounts along the immediate
mountains and foothills. Low instabilty will significantly limit 
any severe threat for today, other than a couple strong storms 
along the Plateau later in the afternoon.

Overnight, a 850 mb jet will begin to intensify as it moves into
the region ahead an amplifying trough and it's associated cold
front to the west. These strong southerly winds will result in
advisory level concerns along the Great Smoky Mountains late
tonight and across the entire region on Wednesday (addressed in
the section below). The winds will also help to maintain the warm,
moist air mass in place, setting the for a potential severe
weather outbreak on Wednesday (Also addressed below). Main impact
overnight will be with temperatures as lows will remain in the mid
50s to lower 60s, with similarly high dewpoints. Strong/severe
storms will fire along the cold front along the Mississippi River,
with some remnants of which may approach the Plateau late 
tonight, so have higher PoPs and a thunder mention there. 


.LONG TERM /Wednesday through Monday/...
Biggest weather event of concern will be the chance for severe 
weather as a trough moves across the northern plains and a surface 
low moves through the Great Lakes Region with it, and this system 
drags a cold front through our area on Wednesday. We could have some 
ongoing convection Tuesday night into Wednesday morning which could 
help stabilize the atmosphere and alter the chances for severe 
weather. Soundings suggest that any ongoing convection would be 
pretty weak and could wain in the overnight hours as dry air in the 
mid levels hinders convection, and we could get some cloud clearing 
during the day. If this hindrance does occur then the atmosphere 
should be primed for much stronger storms as we roll into Wednesday 
and the front moves closer to our area. Best timing for the 
strongest storms still seems to be the afternoon hours till a bit 
after sunset. During this time mid level jet will put us in the 
favored region for some upper level support and the low level jet 
will be cranking from early in the morning until the front moves 
through. Low level jet speeds of 50-60+ knots will help create 
strong shear as well as strong pre-frontal winds on Wednesday. 
Forecast models indicate the possibility of 500-1500 J/kg of CAPE 
depending on the model and location in our forecast area. This 
combined with strong 0-1km and 0-6km shear will lead to a good 
possibility to see damaging winds from a line of severe 
thunderstorms. In addition with this set up we could also see large 
hail and a few tornadoes as well. 

As the front exits overnight we will cool down quite a bit as drier 
air pours into our area. Highs on Thursday will be about 20 degrees 
cooler than they will be on Wednesday before the front moves 
through. These colder temperatures will last through the end of the 
week and into the weekend and overnight lows on Thursday night and 
Friday night will likely get below freezing. These temperatures will 
be unfortunate for some of the plants out there that have started to 
bloom due to the recent extraordinarily warm February we 
experienced. Ridging will build back in over the area and a warming 
trend will begin over the weekend and into next week, with another 
chance for precipitation coming at the tail end of the 7-day 
forecast.
