AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
240 PM EST Mon Feb 27 2017

.SHORT TERM Tonight and Tuesday...

The upper trough that provided light rain earlier today mostly 
over the southern TN Valley was translating into NC. The majority 
of light rainfall has moved east of the forecast area. Therefore, 
mostly dry conditions will occur during the first part of tonight.
There will be another shortwave approaching the forecast area, 
however, warm air advection and strong southerly flow will occur 
ahead of that system. Expect increasing rain showers after 2am ET.
By noon, scattered thunderstorms will be more common along the 
Plateau with increasing instability. Thunderstorms will spread 
eastward through the afternoon. At this time, these thunderstorms 
will bring brief heavy rain and wind gusts to 40 mph.

.LONG TERM (Tuesday Night through Monday)...

The main focus for the long-term forecast will be the risk for 
severe weather Wednesday afternoon and evening. 

A deep upper level trough will traverse across the Great Plains 
Tuesday night into Wednesday with a surface low tracking from the 
Oklahoma panhandle to near Chicago by Wednesday morning. There are 
some questions about how much convection will be ongoing at the 
beginning of the long-term period. Model soundings indicate dry air 
in the mid-levels with a cap in place most of the overnight hours 
Tuesday into Wednesday morning. For now, have backed off on PoPs a 
bit during this timeframe. 

The main line of severe storms will approach the area during the 
early afternoon on Wednesday. There are still some minor timing 
differences but the noon to 8 pm timeframe looks to be pretty good. 
A sub-tropical 300mb jet max of around 120-130 kts will be located 
over the Lower Mississippi River Valley Wednesday afternoon putting 
the forecast area in the favored left exit region of the jet. A low 
level jet of around 50-60 kts will develop as the cold front 
approaches. A warm and moist airmass will advect northward across 
the forecast area with upper 50s to low 60s dewpoints. These higher 
dewpoints will yield SBCAPE values of around 500-1000 J/Kg depending 
on model run variability. Low level 0-1 km SRH is around 300-400 
m2/s2 but most of this is speed shear with little change in 
direction in the low-levels with deep layer 0-6 km shear around 50-
70 kts. All of these parameters point to a line of severe storms 
with damaging winds being the main threat. The low-level shear 
suggests that an isolated tornado cannot be ruled out. 

Much drier air will advect in quickly behind the departing system on 
Wednesday night. Therefore, decreased the PoPs Wednesday night into 
Thursday morning. PW values drop down into the 0.1-0.2 inch range. 
Highs will be about 15-20 degrees cooler on Thursday in the 50s. A 
dry front will move through the forecast area late Thursday night 
brining in a reinforcing shot of cold air. Adjusted highs slightly 
below guidance for Friday with the heart of the cold air over the 
region during this timeframe. The coldest morning of the forecast 
period will occur on Saturday morning with the surface high pressure 
centered overhead. Lows will drop down into the mid 20 to low 30s 
with a widespread freeze anticipated Friday morning. Broad ridging 
will be in place over the weekend with temperatures at or slightly 
above average. Next chances for rain looks to come early in the work 
week.

FXUS64 KMRX 270923
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
423 AM EST Mon Feb 27 2017

.SHORT TERM /Today and Tonight/...
A weak shortwave trough/upper-level disturbance is approaching the
eastern Tennessee Valley early this morning. Latest satellite
trends show mid/high clouds quickly moving into the region, with
BKN/OVC decks of some lower clouds expected by late morning into
the afternoon. Some light rain showers (with perhaps a rumble or
two of thunder) will accompany this feature today, though QPF 
amounts will be light. The best coverage of precipitation will be
along the Plateau and the Southern Plateau/Valley during the
afternoon. Locations across NE TN/SW VA may actually be a few
degrees warmer today comparatively due to some breaks in the 
clouds and the lack of precipitation. 

Later tonight, the upper-trough over the Great Basin will continue
to amplify, placing the region underneath a southwesterly Gulf 
moisture fetch. Thus, an additional round of scattered showers is 
expected later tonight over a good portion of the eastern 
Tennessee Valley thanks to a weak warm front in the vicinity and 
isentropic lift. Downslope winds along the high terrain will 
become breezy/gusty overnight (but should stay below Advisory 
criteria). However, these winds will cutback on precipitation 
along the Mountains and points NE, so have tried to depict the 
highest rain chances favoring Knoxville and points south and west.
 

.LONG TERM /Tuesday through Sunday/...
An upper level trough just entering the Pacific NW this morning 
will deepen as it slowly makes its way east through midweek. This 
will result in warm, moist air overriding a cooler airmass in 
place across the Southern Appalachians. The associated warm front 
will push north across our forecast area on Tuesday, and provide 
enough lift to trigger scattered showers and even a few 
thunderstorms Tuesday afternoon and evening. Our area will be 
firmly in the warm sector by Tuesday afternoon, and temperatures 
will reflect this -- rising into the upper 60s/lower 70s Tuesday 
and Wednesday. 

The main event for our area will be on Wednesday as a strong cold 
front sweeps through the area. Models indicate the potential for 
severe weather on Wednesday, but there are still some differences in 
the exact timing of the frontal passage, with the GFS bringing it 
through midday, and the NAM/ECMWF during the afternoon/evening. 
Regardless, with dewpoints in the upper 50s/lower 60s, bulk shear 
values of 70+kt, 700-500 mb lapse rates betweeen 7.0-8.0 C/km, and 
decent instability (500+ J/kg in the GFS and 1000+ J/kg in the
NAM) -- this event has the potential to be significant. As such, 
SPC has the area west of a line extending from the TN/KY/VA border
- Knoxville - the TN/NC/GA border outlooked for an Enhanced Risk 
of severe storms on Wednesday and a mention of severe 
storms/damaging winds has been added to the gridded forecast. It 
still looks like the main threat at this time will be damaging 
winds with a squall line/broken line segments, but there is the 
potential for supercells to form ahead of the main line.

The cold front pushes east of the forecast area overnight Wednesday. 
Another round of cooler, drier air rushes into the area for the 
second half of the workweek and Saturday under surface high pressure 
and northwest flow aloft. High pressure moves off the coast on 
Sunday, and southwest flow once again begins ushers warmer, more 
moist Gulf air into the area.

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Tomorrow)... 
Surface high pressure centered over the area this afternoon will 
begin to shift NE off the Middle Atlantic coast by Monday morning.
Meanwhile, latest water vapor and RAP upper air analysis 
indicates a shortwave trough embedded within the larger scale 
zonal flow over central Kansas this afternoon, will move rapidly 
east across the area by Monday evening. 

Although current visible imagery indicated perfectly clear skies  
across much of the area this afternoon, a broad area of middle and
upper level cloudiness will move in ahead of the disturbance 
overnight tonight. This will cut off radiational cooling after 
midnight and will keep temperatures above freezing for a large 
portion of the area tonight. This is in slight contrast to the 
latest GFS and NAM MOS guidance that continue to suggest 
subfreezing temperatures throughout the area, exception being CHA 
and points south and west.

With passage of this disturbance late tomorrow, areas in the SW
corner of the CWA will have likely chance of pcpn by the end of
the day while the remainder of the area will see only a slight
chance of pcpn into the afternoon hours. With the current low
level air mass being so dry (dewpoints below 40 degree for much of
the day on Monday) any appreciable pcpn will have to wait until
beyond the fcst period. 

.LONG TERM (Tomorrow Night through Sunday)... An upper level 
trough will make it's way slowly east from the Western U.S. 
through the Mississippi Valley through mid week. As it does so, 
warm and moist air will override a cooler air mass in place across
the Southern Appalachians. Scattered showers and even a few 
thunderstorms will occur in this warm frontal push into the 
Southern Appalachian region. But the big event will be on 
Wednesday into Wednesday evening as another strong cold front 
sweeps through the Eastern U.S. Sufficient instability and shear 
will be available for storm strengthening with this feature, and 
the thunderstorms that accompany this frontal passage could become
severe. The front should move across the Appalachian spine later 
Wednesday night with drier and cooler air streaming back into the 
region on northwesterly winds. The remainder of the forecast will 
be dry with a gradual warming trend into the weekend as the low 
level ridge shifts east to the Southeast Atlantic Coast.

A cold front is quickly moving into the eastern Tennessee early

afternoon, helping to reinforce this cooler air mass. However, 
sustained winds in the 15 to 25 mph range will be below advisory 
criteria. 

Overnight, a clear and calmer night will make for good radiational
cooler in the evening. A hard freeze is expected over much of the
Valley, with lows in the mid to upper 20s. Thus, readings will be
some 50 degrees cooler than the high temperatures recorded 
earlier on Friday. Quite the difference in air mass!

.LONG TERM /Sunday through Friday/...
Models start out with good agreement for the long term period, 
with surface high pressure in control for Sunday and zonal flow 
aloft. High pressure slides off the east coast Sunday night, and 
flow becomes more southwesterly for Monday. Moisture will work 
into the area by Monday afternoon and showers will develop for 
Monday into Tuesday. From here, we start to see some model 
differences, but the general forecast consensus is pretty good. 
The atmosphere will destabilize on Tuesday with a warm front 
approaching the area, which may help spark some thunderstorms 
during the day. The better chance for convection will be Tuesday 
night into Wednesday, with our area sitting in the warm sector 
ahead of another relatively strong cold front that will cross the 
area later Wednesday afternoon and overnight. Kept the remainder 
of the long term dry with high pressure building in and northwest 
flow setting up. Models do indicate a shortwave crossing north of

to SW VA, but odds are too low to include at this point.

.SHORT TERM...
Upper level low centered over central Iowa this afternoon will
lift NE toward the Great Lakes overnight tonight. At the surface,
associated 995 mb low centered over central Illinois will also 
lift NE into the eastern Great Lakes by Saturday morning. 
Associated cold front moving toward the Mississippi Valley this 
afternoon will push east across TN tonight before moving east of 
the area Saturday morning. 

Ahead of the front, an intensifying LLJ will move across the
Plateau and into the Tennessee Valley during the overnight hours.
Over the Plateau, ML CAPE of 700-900 J/kg coupled with bulk shear
values of 45-60 kts will allow the line of convection to remain 
organized with the real possibility of some strong to severe 
storms as it pushes through the area during the overnight. Timing 
looks to be a little more delayed than previous model runs with 
both hires HRRR and RAP13 indicating that convection will push 
through the area during mainly the midnight to 6 am time frame. 
This agrees well with the NAM that has also slowed the progression
of this front as well. With presence of the near unidirectional 
wind profiles, strong to severe straight line winds look to be the
dominant threat with this event. Any overnight severe weather 
event poses an additional risk. Given that people are not as 
connected to latest weather information as they typically are 
during normal waking hours, people should be extra diligent to 
ensure they have access to the latest watch and warning 
information from the NWS. 

Further east of the front tonight in the eastern portions of the 
cwa, a tightening pressure gradient is expected to increase winds
for areas of the Smoky Mtns above 3000 ft in Cocke, Sevier, and 
Blount counties. These winds will decrease with the frontal 
passage on Saturday morning. A Wind Advisory has been issued for 
the those areas from 7 pm tonight until 7 am on Saturday.

As the front moves out on Saturday conditions should gradually
improve through the afternoon. Gusty west winds and a daytime high
in the lower to middle 50s that will slowly drop during the day
will make it feel a bit more like winter. Especially after the 
record breaking late week warmth we have been experiencing. With 
the gusty winds tomorrow, consideration was given to a wind 
advisory behind the front, but 850 mb winds weaken precipitously 
by afternoon. However, do expect to see marginal advisory level
gusts, particularly near mid-day and a Special Weather Statement 
may be necessary by morning to alert users to the winds gusting 25
to 35 mph behind the front.

.LONG TERM...The long term forecast 
will follow the slower ECMWF modeling rather than the quicker GFS 
suggestion of a frontal passage for the week ahead. Dry and cold 
advection brings an end to the precipitation Saturday night with a 
zonal westerly flow regime gradually becoming southerly again ahead 
of another amplified long wave Mid America trough at mid week. In 
this scenario, isentropic lift with a moist, southerly component 
will lead to the development of showers Monday into Tuesday. The 
atmosphere will be destabilizing in the moistening pattern by 
Tuesday and so some thunderstorms could be part of the mix at this 
time. But the better chance for convection will be Tuesday night 
into Wednesday ahead of another relatively strong cold front due in 
the Southern Appalachian Region later Wednesday afternoon and 
evening. Kept the remainder of the long term dry behind this system 
with a prevailing west to northwesterly flow building in with higher 
surface pressure. The new week's temperature forecast features 
another most pleasant warm up into mid week with highs back in the 
upper 60s and lower 70s followed by a return to more typical early 
March weather.

247 
FXUS64 KMRX 240855
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
355 AM EST Fri Feb 24 2017

.SHORT TERM /Today and Tonight/...
A strong frontal system is poised to impact the region over the 
next 24 hours, bringing with it the potential for strong to severe
thunderstorms later tonight -- and a much cooler air mass heading
into Saturday in it's wake (addressed in the next section). Ahead
of the front, breezy gradient winds from the south will help 
bring Gulf moisture into the region. In addition, this warm air 
advection and the insolation from the sun will help to warm us to 
near or above record high values by the afternoon. Most areas will
peak in the mid to upper 70s, though I would not be shocked if a 
few areas across the southern Valley and along the immediate 
valleys near the foothills of the Smokies hit the 80 degree mark 
(thanks to downslope warming). 

The area will remain capped through the afternoon and evening as 
the front remains well to the west. Then between 00-06z an 
intensifying 850 mb jet will rotate across the Plateau and Valley 
in association with a prefrontal trough. These features will play 
a big role in whether convection will develop late in the evening 
and linger after the midnight hours across the eastern Tennessee 
Valley. Some modest instability will develop by 21-03z, with 
plenty of wind shear to provide lift and organization to any thing
that does develop. The combination of around 800-1200 j/kg of ML 
CAPE and the 40-50 kts of bulk shear will allow a line of 
organized storms to develop and remain strong to severe as they 
move across the region between 03-09z. The primary threat with 
this activity will be damaging straight line winds and some 
marginally severe hail. Although a brief tornado or two cannot be
ruled out, the presence of a pre-existing boundary will play a 
big role in realizing this threat. More veered/unidirectional wind
profiles do favor line segments and damaging straight-line winds 
much more so over tornadoes at this time.

In addition, as the LLJ ramps up overnight, strong gradient winds 
will be felt over the Great Smoky Mountain zones of Cocke, 
Sevier, and Blount Counties. Thus, we have issued an Advisory for
those zones from 00-12z on Saturday. 


.LONG TERM /Saturday through Thursday/...
Cold front will be pushing east of the forecast area by Saturday 
morning. High pressure builds in Saturday, bringing sunshine and 
generally dry conditions. West winds will be steady at 10-15kt and
will help usher cooler air and more seasonable temperatures into 
the Tennessee Valley. Highs on Saturday will be 10-20 degrees 
cooler than Friday, ranging from the upper 40s across the 
Cumberland Plateau to the mid 50s in the Tennessee Valley. Very 
minimal lingering moisture behind the cold front combined with 
upslope flow may keep some light showers possible across the NE 
higher elevations through Saturday night. As cooler air rushes in 
behind the frontal passage and temperatures drop below freezing 
after sunset Saturday, a few snowflakes may even mix in, but no 
accumulation is expected. High pressure remains in place for 
Sunday with another day of sunny skies and seasonable 
temperatures. 

High pressure slides off the east coast Sunday night, 
and upper level flow becomes more southwesterly, helping to advect 
warmer air back into the region ahead of a fast-moving shortwave 
that will bring the next chance for showers. There's still some 
differences in model solutions, but the general picture is a short 
wave lifting out of the Southern Plains, bringing scattered showers 
to mainly the southern half of the forecast area Monday afternoon. A 
warm frontal boundary will lift north and cross our area 
Tuesday/Tuesday night. It's still a few days out and details will 
better resolve themselves as the days pass, but at this point it 
looks like this could bring another round of potentially severe 
thunderstorms to the area Tuesday into Tuesday night. The warm front 
would provide a focus for convection, and the GFS is currently 
showing a 50kt+ 850mb jet, CAPE values of 500-1000 J/kg, and PWATs 
maxing out at 1.3". For now, it's something we'll be keeping our 
eyes on, and thunder's been added to the grids. The cold front is 
progged to push through the area on Wednesday, and should spark a 
more organized line of thunderstorms as it moves through.

High pressure builds back in for Thursday, bringing drier, cooler 
conditions and mostly sunny skies.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
313 PM EST Thu Feb 23 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Tomorrow)... 
Latest water vapor and RAP upper level analysis indicate ridge 
axis building NE across the area this afternoon ahead of a 
deepening Plains trough. This ridge axis will further amplify 
through the day Friday as it shifts east of the area ahead of our 
next frontal system Friday night.

At the surface, ridge of high pressure noses SW from central North
Carolina into central Alabama and Mississippi. Next surface front 
currently extends SW from the Great Lakes SW across central 
Illinois and into northern Oklahoma. As the surface front 
continues to slowly push east through Friday, gradient winds 
aiding with low level warm air advection along with modest rising 
heights aloft will allow for temperatures to climb into possible
record territory by the afternoon. 

Current forecast calls for breaking records at Chattanooga,
Knoxville, and Tri-Cities tomorrow. Guidance suggests that the 
Tri-Cities record is most likely to fall as both NAM/GFS MOS are 
3-4 degrees above the record set in 1982. As for Knoxville and 
Chattanooga, both of which set records in 1890, guidance is at and
slightly above the record for both sites. The one caveat with this
is that MOS guidance has had a warm bias of around 1-3 degrees 
for all three sites over the past few days. If that continues, 
then we may only approach and not break these records. However, 
thoughts are that we will see minimal fog overnight due to 
slightly increasing low level winds. This will allow for quicker 
start to daytime heating across much of the area. Coupled with 
fcsted strong southerly winds by afternoon and we may reach those 
records.

Finally, with increasing southerly low-level winds, we could
approach wind advisory levels. However, strongest 850 mb core will
remain west of the area through the afternoon but may clip our
northwest Plateau counties by early evening hours as an 850 mb 
jet core lies just to the west of our area at that time. 
Presently, however, only the GFS has 850 MB winds in excess of 40 
kts at that time, and it indicates an 850 jet core of 50 kts over
south central Kentucky during the evening hours. 

.LONG TERM (Tomorrow Night Through Thursday)... 
The early weekend storm system drives east from the Mississippi 
Valley through the Appalachians through the first twenty four 
hours of the extended period. Convection will be building across 
the forecast area Friday night into early Saturday morning. It 
still looks like thunderstorms could be rather strong or even 
become severe in another healthy shear but weakly unstable 
environment. The best period of possibly strong storms would be 
around 00-05z Saturday and mainly over western sections of the 
forecast area. The main threat would be straight line winds and 
large hail, however some decent helicity values were noted on the 
Cumberland Plateau early in the event so there is a limited chance
for a brief tornado in this area. The showers and thunderstorms 
gradually end from west to east later Friday night into Saturday 
morning with a nice, dry high pressure regime building in for 
later Saturday afternoon through Sunday evening. The next system 
is a fast moving short wave that rips rapidly northeast out of the
Southern Plains with a surge of moisture and warm air in warm 
frontal fashion, generating scattered showers across the region. 
Because there are some model differences in the early part of the 
work week in association with this wave, chance pops were broad 
brushed in from Monday into Tuesday night. By Wednesday, a deeper 
trough edges it's way into the Eastern U.S. driving another 
relatively strong cold front into the Southern Appalachians. This 
looks like another convective episode with a decent chance of 
rain. Highest pops were placed on the daytime period Wednesday 
with decreasing pops and colder temperatures Wednesday night into 
Thursday. The warmest period of the extended will be in the warm 
air advection pattern Monday through Wednesday where more above 
normal temperatures will be seen.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
358 AM EST Thu Feb 23 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Dense fog has formed overnight
after skies cleared late Wednesday and moisture lingered from day
time rainfall. Winds are light area wide. Temperatures are in the
mid 40s to lower 50s. Will continue Dense Fog Advisory through
10 AM EST. High pressure was located off the Atlantic Coast with 
low pressure over Florida and a cold front across the Great Lakes 
extending through the Mid Mississippi Valley. The weak pressure 
gradient over the Forecast Area will tighten up by late morning as
the sun warms the atmosphere with fog dissipating and light south
to southeast winds developing as cold front to the northwest 
moves into the Ohio Valley. Temperatures will warm into the upper 
60s to mid 70s as skies become partly to possibly mostly sunny 
once the low level moisture gets mixed out. Tonight another mild 
night with some patchy fog and lows in the upper 40s to mid 50s. 
As deepening surface low moves from the central Plains to the Mid
Mississippi Valley. Light south winds will continue overnight.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...
An active period of weather forecast over the long-term forecast.
The main focus will be the possibility of severe storms late 
Friday night into early Saturday morning. At the beginning of the 
period a robust upper level low will be traversing the Central 
Plains into the Mid-Mississippi River Valley. A surface low will 
track from near Kansas City to Chicago during the day Friday. 
Strong low level southerly flow will advect in warm air and 
moisture to the Southern Appalachians. Temperatures are forecast 
to be at and even above record values. Please see the records 
below for more information.

Chattanooga: 77 set in 1890
Knoxville:   76 set in 1890
Tri-Cities:  72 set in 1982

A cap will be in place around 700-800 mb and should keep any 
convection from forming throughout the day. Winds will increase to 
near advisory criteria during the timeframe with the tightening 
pressure gradient from the approaching cold front. 

The main focus for severe weather will come from roughly 9 pm Friday 
through 4 am Saturday. There are still some timing issues to work 
out but the consensus is that this will be overnight event. Models 
indicate a low level jet of 45-55 kts around 02z-07z Saturday. Model 
soundings indicate SBCAPE values of around 500-1000 J/Kg. These 
soundings also show some unrealistic decoupling and these values 
could be slightly underdone. The 0-1 KM SRH will be around 200-300 
m2/s with deep layer 0-6 km shear around 50-60 kts. It looks as 
though the highest threat area will be north of I-40 and west of I-
75 where the best combination of shear and instability well be. 
However, can not rule out severe weather across any location in the 
forecast area. The line should begin to weaken in the 2am-6am 
timeframe as the low level jet lifts out to the northeast and the 
instability begins to wane. For now, it appears that all modes of 
severe weather will be possible, especially in the area of highest 
risk mentioned above. Due to the low level shear, can not rule out 
an isolated tornado and will go ahead and add this to the HWO.

Much cooler and drier air will filter in behind the front on 
Saturday with noticeably cooler temperatures. Northwesterly winds 
will also be near advisory criteria on Saturday as well. The GFS 
indicates a few wrap around showers across SW VA and NE TN. The GFS 
soundings are fairly dry with PW values dropping to around a quarter 
of an inch. Therefore, lowered PoPs during this timeframe. 
Additionally, this was the timeframe where some light snow 
shower/flurries were mentioned but based on the latest guidance this 
is looking less likely. 

A widespread freeze is anticipated Sunday morning and this could 
pose an issue to any sensitive vegetation that has begin to bloom due 
to the recent warm weather. Mid to upper 20s will be possible across 
SW VA and the higher elevations. Dry conditions will feature on 
Sunday with surface high pressure shifting to the east. 

Models are in fairly good agreement with widespread showers 
developing on Monday ahead of an advancing warm front. Isentropic 
lift ahead of this boundary will create widespread precipitation. 
There is some difference about how far north the boundary 
progresses. The GFS indicates that the boundary will move into 
southern portions of the area with a few strong thunderstorms 
possible. The ECMWF keeps the boundary to the south with just 
showers. For now, will side more toward the ECMWF with just showers 
mentioned in the forecast. This warm front will eventually lift 
through the area by Tuesday with another system expected to move in 
on Wednesday. The system on Wednesday could bring another round of 
strong to severe storms to the area but this is well out in the 
extended and will not mention it in the HWO at this time.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
306 PM EST Wed Feb 22 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Tomorrow)...
Latest water vapor and RAP upper level analysis continues to show
rather strong middle level circulation moving eastward across the
Northern Gulf of Mexico and Northern Florida. As this feature 
moves out, Atlantic surface ridge builds westward tonight. 
Residual low level moisture and calm to very light winds will 
likely lead to fog across the area, with some locations possibly 
seeing dense fog during the latter portion of the overnight hours.

Shortwave trough aloft will ride east across Kentucky and West
Virginia through the day tomorrow. With it, prospects of some 
light pcpn across the Northern Plateau counties, NE Tennessee, and
SW Virginia are possible for the afternoon hours. Any pcpn with 
this feature should be rather short-lived before the shortwave 
exits the area to the NE by the evening hours.

Temperatures tonight and tomorrow will remain nearly 20 degrees
above seasonal normals. This in a month that is already ranking
within the top ten warmest Februaries on record for Chattanooga,
Knoxville, and Tri-Cities.


.LONG TERM (Thursday Night through Wednesday)...
Another warm day on Friday with highs topping out in the 70's and
some places will be pushing 80 degrees. In fact we could see all 
3 climate sites break record high temperatures for this day, 
here's the data for the 24th.

Chattanooga: 77 set in 1890
Knoxville:   76 set in 1890
Tri-Cities:  72 set in 1982

This warming will all happen ahead of our next system which could 
produce severe weather in our area. That system is a low moving 
across the central plains states and into the Great Lakes region 
with a cold front being dragged along with it. Increasing southerly 
winds ahead of the front will bring in warm air and the increasing 
speed of the low level jet will help produce good shear in our area. 
0-1 km and 0-6 km shear values are strong which will help lead to 
strong winds as the primary severe threat in our area. CAPE values 
will be pretty good as well (in the 500-1000 J/kg range), but a cap 
could inhibit some convection from forming ahead of the main line. 
Biggest threat for our area will be with the main line passing 
through late Friday night through early Saturday morning. 

Once the front passes through it will force temperatures to drop and 
highs on Saturday will be about 15 - 20 degrees colder than they 
were on Friday, but we will STILL be a few degrees above normal even 
after this front passes through (going to show how warm we've been 
lately).

We could potentially see a light snow flurry or two in the higher 
elevations Saturday night into Sunday, but minimal accumulations 
would be expected. Unfortunately many locations will see sub 
freezing or near freezing temperatures which could kill off early 
growth due to the recent warm temperatures. We start to warm back up 
and will see another round of showers early next week.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
409 AM EST Wed Feb 22 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Upper low over Mississippi
will move slowly southeast into the northeast Gulf today.
Isentropic lift will continue this morning and afternoon and
trigger light showers across much of the forecast area. A weak
surface trough over Kentucky into middle Tennessee will also act
to enhance the shower activity. Rainfall amounts will be
light...heaviest near the Tennessee border and across southwest
Virginia. Skies will stay mostly cloudy. Mild temperatures this
morning in the mid 50s will rise to the mid and upper 60s this
afternoon. Tonight showers will end as upper low moves southeast.
Low level moisture will remain with mostly cloudy skies and mild
temperatures in the lower to mid 50s.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...
The main focus for the long-term forecast will be on the severe 
weather expected to impact the area late Friday into early 
Saturday morning. 

On Thursday, an upper level trough will move out of the Rocky 
Mountains with lee cyclogenesis. A warm front will extend eastward 
from the surface low in Colorado to the Ohio River Valley. This will 
put the forecast area in the warm sector. PW values will be around 
an inch on Thursday. These values are around the 90th percentile for 
late February. There is a weak mid-level trough that moves through 
but not seeing much in the way of lift. Therefore, went ahead and 
trimmed back PoPs on Thursday to mainly just the higher elevations 
and only have around 20 percent there. Temperatures will continue to 
be well above normal with highs in the upper 60s to mid 70s. Mid-
level ridging will build in Thursday night into Friday morning ahead 
of the next approaching trough. The small PoPs will come to an end 
and expect dry conditions during the overnight period. Southerly 
flow will begin to pick up overnight as the pressure gradient 
tightens as a cold front races across the Central and Southern 
Plains. These southerly winds will keep overnight lows up in the 50s 
across most of the forecast area. 

On Friday, the focus will shift to the possibilty of severe 
storms. Currently, it appears that most of the day Friday will be 
dry with the ridge still providing some influence. In addition, 
model soundings indicate a cap throughout much of the day with drier 
air in the mid-levels. Temperatures will once again top out near 
record values with highs in the 70s. Southerly winds will also be 
strong throughout the day and approach advisory level criteria. 
Expect the cap aloft and the linear forcing will keep most of the 
convection along a line just ahead of the front. The NAM and GFS 
indicate a surge in the low level jet around 03-06z Saturday up into 
the 45-55 kt range. In addition, the strong warm air and moisture 
advection will produce SBCAPE values in the 500-1000 J/Kg range 
during the overnight hours. The strong upper level flow aloft will 
lead to 0-6 km bulk shear values of 50-60 kts. Strong jet dynamics 
will also setup at this time as a speed max rotates through the base 
of the trough. The low level 0-1 km SRH will range from around 200-
300 m2/s2. Some model soundings indicate that the boundary layer 
will decouple and produce lower instability values, however, this is 
unrealistic given the strong southerly flow.  Therefore, have sided 
more towards the NAM since it shows less decoupling. At this time it 
appears the highest risk for severe weather would be from roughly 10 
pm - 6am late Friday night into early Saturday with damaging winds 
being the main threat.

Much drier and colder air will advect into the Southern Appalachians 
on Saturday into Saturday night. So cold in fact, models indicate 
some light snow possible across the higher elevations Saturday night 
across the higher elevation. With the recent warm weather, flowers 
and plants have been blooming and it looks like a widespread freeze 
will occur Sunday morning. The cooler conditions will be short-lived 
as a warm front lift across the area early next week. Rain showers 
will be possible Monday night into Tuesday as the front lifts 
northward with highs on Tuesday in the mid to upper 60s.

little instability present, a low to slight chance PoP will be 
carried in the afternoon, favoring NE sections where soundings 
show a weaker capping inversion. 

A strengthening low in the lee of the Rockies on Thursday night will 
provide a deep S-SW flow across the TN Valley on Friday.  The jet 
streak rotating around the base of the closed upper low will move 
into West and Middle TN Friday night, becoming favorably
positioned to provide strong upper divergence. Frontogentic 
forcing in the jet exit region peaks over our area around 06Z 
Saturday. The overnight timing will mean limited instability, but 
given the strong dynamic forcing and high shear that may be 
present, there appears to at least be some potential for severe 
storms at this point. Will add a mention of this to the HWO.

High temps will peak in the lower to mid 70s on Friday before colder 
air arrives behind the front on Saturday. Still, it will not be a 
bitterly cold air mass, with highs in the mid/upper 50s Saturday and 
lows in the 30s Saturday night. The next chance of rain appears to 
come on Monday as a cold front sags slowly southward across the OH 
Valley and a series of weak disturbances move through a nearly zonal 
flow aloft.

forecast. Models indicate that 500 dm heights are already in excess

does not look like it will be the warmest day of the year

sites). Forecast highs are also still a couple of degrees below 
records for the day. The record for today are 78 for Chattanooga 
in 1986, 75 for Knoxville in 1986, and 75 for the Tri-Cities in 
2014. Current forecast highs are 74, 72, 72 for Chattanooga, 
Knoxville, and the Tri-Cities respectively. Much above normal

.LONG TERM (Tuesday through Sunday...

The extended will begin with unseasonably warm temperatures and 
the approach of a weakening cold front. Models have had a 
difficult time with the front in regards to timing...strength and 
amount of moisture available. While there continues to be some 
discrepancy in the details...the overall trend is for increasing 
clouds Tuesday with a few possible isolated showers beginning to 
push in late in the afternoon. The main band of showers should 
move through Tuesday night. Available moisture and strength now 
look sufficient enough for widespread showers across the area and 
have increased pops to likely category. The showers should slowly 
exit the area on Wednesday. Models have also had problems 
resolving the weather pattern for Thursday...current thinking 
brings in a weak short wave for a slight chance of showers and 
even a possible rumble of thunder. Another cold front is progged 
into the the region on Friday/Friday night. Timing has been an 
issue with this feature as well. Current model runs are trending 
towards a Friday night frontal passage. Warm...moist air will be 
in place ahead of the system and should allow the atmosphere to 
become at least weakly unstable. Could see a some scattered 
convection develop well ahead of the front for Friday afternoon. 
However...the main activity currently looks to occur Friday night.
Overnight ...the stability should be limited...but still expect 
to see some thunderstorm activity. Behind the front for Saturday 
and Sunday... temperatures will fall to near normal levels. A few 
scattered showers may linger into Saturday morning but 
otherwise...high pressure will build in for dry conditions.

the chance for showers, and with this warm, moist airmass in place,

system. It should be clear and colder tonight with some radiation
occurring under clear to partly cloudy skies.

.LONG TERM (Thursday through Tuesday)...A dry NW flow aloft in 
advance of a building Midwest ridge will be over the area on 
Thursday, while surface high pressure will be drifting east along 
the Gulf coast. This will provide mostly clear skies and a warming
trend into Friday. Near normal highs can be expected Thursday, 
warming to highs 5-10 degrees above normal on Friday.

The mid/upper ridge axis moves to our east on Saturday as a closed 
low tracks into the MS Valley. Rain chances will increase through 
the day on Saturday ahead of this system as it tracks across TN/KY 
through the night.  The setup of the upper jet and 850 mb theta-E 
appears to favor convection along the Gulf Coast that may 
significantly cut off moisture in our area, so PoPs Saturday 
afternoon and night will be kept in the chance range, and QPF 
appears light. Current timing of the system may keep a slight chance 
of rain into Sunday morning. 

A large ridge builds over the Southeast on Monday. This will bring 
mild temperatures and sunny skies, and highs on Monday are expected 
to reach the upper 60s to lower 70s. The GFS and ECMWF differ on the 
timing of the next system, with the ECMWF being more progressive in 
pushing a cold front toward the area. The size of the preceding 
ridge suggests the slower GFS may be the better solution, but with 
some uncertainty, will have a slight chance PoP for Tuesday to 
maintain forecast continuity.

FXUS64 KMRX 141943

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
243 PM EST Tue Feb 14 2017

.SHORT TERM (This Afternoon through Wednesday)...

Current radar imagery indicates an area of precipitation just north 
of I-40 progressing eastward. The low-levels remain dry across the 
area with surface dewpoints in the teens and 20s. Wet-bulbing in the 
low levels is leading to a few reports of light sleet from time to 
time with temperatures in the 40s to low 50s. In addition, seeing 
radar returns diminish as they progress eastward into the drier air. 
Therefore, any precipitation that occurs this afternoon and evening 
will be light with amounts of a couple of hundredths at most. 

Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicate two 
troughs of interest. The first is a closed low across the Southern 
Plains with the second moving southeast out of Canada into the Great 
Lakes. At the surface, low pressure is centered near the 
Texas/Louisiana line with a warm front stretching to the east just 
inland along the northern Gulf Coast. To the north, an arctic 
boundary is moving southward into the Northern Plains and Great 
Lakes. These two upper level features and surface features will be 
the main players over the short-term forecast. 

Overnight, the surface low will track to near Columbus, MS around 
midnight. Strong isentropic lift along the north side of the warm 
front will eventually saturate the low levels of the atmosphere with 
widespread precipitation expected after midnight. At this point, the 
arctic boundary will push southward into the Ohio River Valley. This 
system is taking a climatologically favored track for a widespread 
snowfall across the forecast area but the surface temperatures 
remain too warm for any snowfall outside of the higher elevations. 
The freezing level begins to drop after midnight as the arctic 
boundary nudges into the area. Expect to see a mixture of rain/snow 
develop in the mountains for elevations generally above 3 kft just 
after midnight. Eventually, should see a period of all snow for the 
higher elevations after 3-4 am or so with some minor accumulations 
of wet snow. For now, expect amounts will be around 1-2 inches for 
elevations above 3 kft. Regardless, lows should only be around 32-33 
degrees and do not anticipate any major travel issues and will go 
with a SPS for now. As for the valley, expect all rain with amounts 
ranging from 0.25-0.50 inches. 

Slightly cooler temperatures are expected tomorrow with highs in the 
upper 30s to upper 40s. A few snow showers will persist thanks to 
northwest flow across the mountains but will come to an end by the 
afternoon.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday Night through Tuesday)...

The long term fcst sees two periods of unsettled weather with a 
gradual warming trend which will bring daytime highs and overnight 
lows to about 15 degrees above normal by the the early part of next 
week.

First period of pcpn looks to move into the SW portions of the area 
Saturday afternoon then spread NE through the evening hours. Models 
are in fair agreement for this event which is tied to a middle to 
upper level low ejecting NE out of Texas. The best moisture with 
this system as it tracks NE across the area is confined to the 
middle levels. With little moisture inflow in the lower levels, 
models suggest less than 0.2 inches of rainfall with this quickly 
moving system that will exit the area during the overnight hours of 
Saturday night. 

Rather strong ridge then follows on Monday becoming amplified over 
much of the SE US as the next mid to upper low, in a fairly steady 
progression of pacific lows, begins to push eastward across Northern 
Mexico. There is fair model agreement on the progression of the mid 
to upper feature, however interaction between the northern and 
southern streams in the model is a much lower confidence event. As a 
northern stream shortwave attempts to weaken the ridge and allow for 
the associated surface front to sneak into the area by late in the 
period, the models diverge greatly. With split in guidance on 
whether boundary can push far enough south to be a weather maker, 
have trended toward slight chance POPS across the southern two-
thirds of the area for now which is in fair agreement with GFS 
Ensemble and ECMWF while the GFS continues to keep things dry across 
the area at that time.

.SHORT TERM (Today through Thursday night)...
The low pressure system over TX/NM will track east today and

by Wednesday morning. Midlevel clouds ahead of this system are
already moving across Middle TN, and will give mostly cloudy skies
for our area today. Low level dry air and weak lift should result

time the surface to 700 mb low crosses the MS Valley and QG
forcing strengthens. Initally the freezing level is well above
mountain top level, but with evaporative cooling, it rapidly drops
to around 3000 ft by 06Z across northern sections. Thus the higher
elevations of NE TN and SW VA could start seeing snow as early as
midnight. The best lift occurs in the 06Z to 12Z window as the
models depict midlevel frontogenesis occurring as the northern and
southern stream systems merge. Precip should start to diminish
after 12Z with rapid drying aloft behind the departing trough.
There are uncertainties with this system, mainly relating to the
timing of precip onset and how quickly temperatures will drop to
change to snow in the mountains, as well as QPF. 1-3 inches of
snow may be possible above 3000 ft, but will allow the day shift
to evaluate the need for any Winter Weather Advisories. 

The rest of the period will be dry with a NW flow and a building
ridge across the Deep South, with temperatures slightly cooler
than normal.

.LONG TERM (Friday through Monday)...
Model depictions of the long term are relatively similar with 
rather pleasant weather expected in terms of another period of 
mild temperatures. The period starts out dry on Friday with a 
short wave ridge moving away from the region. However, a weak 
short wave builds across the southeast states on Saturday 
producing a few showers. Specifics on exact timing of this feature
are typically uncertain six days out. Therefore, some small 
chance pops were broadbrushed across two twelve hour periods here.
Superblend moves this wave out of the area for a dry Sunday 
through daytime period Monday while significant amplification 
develops with a major league upper ridge preceding a healthy short
wave trough, due into the Southeastern U.S. Monday night into 
Tuesday. Temperatures should be very nice during the long term 
with maxes a good ten to twelve degrees above normal while lows 
will be about five to ten degrees milder than typical mid February
minimums.

bulb effect to pcpn type.

than the Wednesday system, and once again, these February

US amplifies ahead of next pacific deep layer low approaching from 
northern Mexico. With temperatures running about 15-20 degrees above 
normal, it looks to be a very unseasonable start to the work week.

.SHORT TERM /Tonight and Monday/...
A cold front is moving through the eastern Tennessee Valley this
afternoon. Ahead of the front, a prefrontal trough has triggered
some scattered showers that are quickly racing through the Valley
and across the Mountains into NC. Ahead of the front, very mild,
near record to record high temperatures are prevailing, with many
stations peaking in the 70s. A big change is coming behind the
front as colder and drier air is moving in. Winds will quickly
veer to the NW with the frontal passage, and between 00-03z, the
clouds will dissipate as drier air filters in. The result will be
a mostly clear night, allowing temperatures to drop close to the
freezing mark across much of the Valley by sunrise. Additionally,
very breezy/gusty NW winds are expected due to the tight pressure
gradient. Along the high terrain of far NE TN and SW NC, a Wind
Advisory is warranted which is in effect from 00-18z Monday. The
breezy winds will continue on Monday, reinforcing the cooler and
drier air mass. This will keep highs near seasonable levels in the
mid to upper 50s for Monday, despite the abundant sunshine. 

.LONG TERM /Monday Night through Sunday/...
An upper ridge will remain in control through Tuesday for dry 
conditions and seasonal temperatures. The main system of concern 
through the extended will be a low pressure system moving in 
around the Wednesday time frame. Model consistency has been quite 
poor in regards to timing and track of this system and confidence 
low on details. However...the overall trend brings isolated to 
scattered showers into the area Tuesday evening with the main band
moving in late Tuesday night into early Wednesday morning...then 
lingering showers Wednesday afternoon as the system exits the 
area. Temperature profile looks warm enough for a mainly rain 
event with a mix of rain and snow possible over northern areas and
across higher elevations...mainly during late night/early morning
hours. Cool and dry northwest flow on Thursday and Friday will 
provide generally dry conditions with near seasonal temperatures. 
An upper level ridge builds in for a dry weekend with warmer 
temperatures.

.SHORT TERM (Today and tonight)...
Showers have started to move into the area, but the models have

will remain shallow and forcing/instability will be weak. Through

to scattered showers, with the most likely time for rain coming 
around 18Z when convergence along a pre-frontal trough moves 
through. Given the expected overcast cloud cover, will cut a few
degrees off high temps shown by MOS, but TRI's record of 68 should
still be easily broken.

Frontal passage occurs this evening between 21Z and 00Z, followed
by clearing skies and strong cold advection. Lows tonight will
fall into the upper 20s to mid 30s. Winds will be gusty through
the night, but below advisory criteria on our side of the
mountains in the NW flow pattern.

.LONG TERM (Monday through Saturday)...
A mostly dry forecast for the upcoming work week and into next 
weekend. Dry and cool northwest flow will be well established by 
Monday leading to near normal temperatures under sunny skies. The 
only decent chance for precipitation in the long term will come on 
Tuesday into Wednesday as a split system moves through the United 
States. As mentioned in previous forecast discussions models have 
disagreed with how to handle this system but are slowly starting to 
trend towards each other. Right now it appears that the better 
chance for precipitation will come from the trough moving across the 
Southern United States. Depending on the exact track/speed we could 
see precipitation start Tuesday night and continue through Wednesday 
night. Best chances will be in our southern counties closer to the 
track of the low. There is some indication in the models that the 
northern system could have moisture dip down far enough to the south 
that we get some in our area, and it could combine with cold 
temperatures to bring a chance for light precipitation in the higher 
elevations. 

After these systems and the fronts associated with them move on 
through we will clear the sky out and maintain temperatures 
relatively near normal through the rest of the work week. Ridging 
starts to build in over the weekend and we will once again see 
temperatures rising into the 60's in the Valley.

Valley quickly after sunrise -- and all the way into the mid 60s 
to lower 70s by 18z or so. This could produce near record high 
temperatures in a few locations across SW VA and NE TN. Another 
round of showers are expected on Sunday as a cold front approaches
the region from the west. The timing of the front looks to be 
between 18-21z along the plateau and 21-00z across the rest of the
Valley. In it's wake, cold air advection will take place, along 
with some drier air (and an end to the precipitation). 



.LONG TERM /Sunday Night through Saturday/...
Not much change in the long term forecast over the past few days.
To start the period we have a cold front moving through the area,
which should be east of us shortly after the period begins. As of
now, it looks like it takes a while for temperatures to drop 
behind the front so by the time it is cold enough for snow any 
lingering moisture will already be gone. So have removed all snow 
chances from forecast for Sunday night. Flow quickly shifts to 
northwest behind front and breezy winds can be expected across the
higher elevations, along with cooler and much drier air moving 
in. Monday will feature plenty of sunshine but we will see about a
15 to 20 degree temperature drop. High temps will be in the upper
40s to mid 50s. Expect increasing cloud cover on Tuesday as our 
next system approaches, but a dry forecast still in store. Highs 
will be in the lower to mid 50s. 

Timing is a little better for our mid-week system but with still the 
same model disagreement on track as seen in previous runs. Upper low 
begins approaching the area Tuesday night and moves through 
Wednesday but the GFS continues to keep the low south, leaving us 
precip free. The ECMWF continues to show a more northerly track, 
thus brining precip into the area. So while timing is starting to 
come together the track is still up in the air. Will continue to go 
with superblend guidance which gives us slight chance pops north and 
chance pops south for Wednesday, until better model agreement. 
Again, if the ECMWF is correct we could still see some light snow on 
the back end of the system across the high terrain of our eastern 
mountains. System moves east of us by Wednesday night but we remain 
in northwest flow. Some clouds around Thursday as a weak impulse 
moves down through the long wave trough, seasonal temps expected. 
Friday we start to see ridging build back into the area ending our 
NW flow pattern, which puts us back into the mid to upper 50s. 
Ridging even stronger Saturday and we are in the low to mid 60s. 
Thursday through Saturday look dry for now.

snow in the higher elevation of Northeast Tennessee/Southwest 
Virginia behind the fronts associated with these systems, but will 
wait till better agreement between the models before bringing in any 
widespread snowfall into the actual forecast.

struggling with this system so very low confidence at this point.

high pressure starts to build back in.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
235 AM EST Fri Feb 10 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and tonight)...
A dry NW flow in the mid to upper levels will continue today, while 
high pressure at the surface will be drifting east across the 
Carolinas. Scattered high clouds should have little impact today, 
and full sun should bring high temps into the 50s for the entire TN 
Valley, with CHA approaching 60. Tonight, with the surface to 850 mb 
high near FL and a strengthening low pressure system moving into the 
Great Lakes, a strong LLJ will develop over the TN Valley region. 
While the W-SW direction of the jet will not favor a mountain wave 
setup, model depictions of 50-60 kt winds at 850 mb could result in 
advisory level winds in the higher elevations. The Wind Advisory for 
the Smokies will be continued. Resulting warm advection with the jet 
will also bring an increase in clouds late tonight. 

.LONG TERM (Saturday through Thursday)... 
Temperatures will keep increasing on Saturday as the low level jet 
continues to crank in warm air from our southwest while ridging 
builds pressure over the area. This trend will continue on Sunday as 
a front approaches the area, to the point where some places might 
flirt with 70 degrees for a high temperature on Sunday. These 
temperatures will be running about 20 degrees above normal, and the 
Tri-Cities record high for January 12th is 68 set back in 1938, 
which will be in danger of falling as the forecast high is right 
around that mark. Knoxville and Chattanooga both have record highs 
of 76 degrees for that day, so their records will be more difficult 
to break. On thing that could dampen record high chances is some 
precipitation that will be possible over the weekend.

We could see a round of rain ahead of the front as some moisture 
might be drawn off of the main jet to our north and combine with 
lift ahead of the front. If any rain does occur it would be pretty 
light as the moisture in the atmosphere will be pretty minor, but 
there should be enough to keep us somewhat cloudy through the 
weekend. As the front pushes through late Sunday/early Monday we 
could drop temps down quick enough to see a brief switchover to 
light snow flurries in the higher elevations for a brief period of 
time overnight. 

Drier and colder air quickly replaces the warm air, and we get back 
slightly below normal temperatures by the middle of the work week. 
Long term models then show a low/trough diving down out of Canada 
across the Great Lakes and into New England and a second low/trough 
moving across the southern United States as we get closer to the 
weekend. There is disagreement with the strength and speed of the 
southern system which, depending on it's track could bring another 
round of precipitation to our area. Will keep in low end 
precipitation chances for the end of the forecast and wait for model 
trends and better agreement as it gets closer.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
321 PM EST Thu Feb 9 2017

.SHORT TERM /Tonight and Friday/...
Low stratus and isolated snow showers are finally diminishing
across NE TN and SW VA this afternoon, with no additional
accumulation expected (save for the highest mountain peaks). 
After sunset, the sky will quickly become mostly clear, allowing 
for good radiational cooling in place. The cold, dry air mass will
drop temperatures into the upper teens to mid 20s across much of 
the Valley by the early morning on Friday. A high pressure ridge 
will build in for Friday and winds will veer and increase from the
SW by the afternoon. This will allow for a nice warm-up as highs 
will soar into low to upper 50s across the Valley. Some clouds may
sneak into SW VA during the day, so will keep them a little 
cooler than would otherwise. Overall, A sunny and dry day across 
the Tennessee Valley. 

.LONG TERM /Friday Night through Thursday/...
Models continue to be in modest agreement for the weekend system 
coming through Sunday/Monday. Disagreement still exist on the cut-
off low for next week. 

Friday night we see a very nice rebound in overnight lows with high 
pressure over the South Eastern Coast. Overnight lows will be 15 to 
20 degrees warmer than tonight, which will be around 10 degrees 
above normal. 850 jet really gets going across our area Friday night 
into Saturday morning. Both the GFS and NAM show between 50 and 
60kts. This has prompted the issuance of a wind advisory for the 
high terrain of Blount, Sevier, and Cocke counties. Elevations above 
2500 feet will see sustained winds from 20 to 30 mph with gusts up 
to 40 mph. Elevations above 3500/4000 feet will see sustained winds 
from 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph. The strong LLJ will also 
create a very strong temperature inversion. Overnight lows Friday 
will be warmer in the high terrain of mountains by as much as 5 to 
10 degrees compared to valley locations.

850 surge of warm air continues on Saturday and further cranks up 
our temperatures into the upper 50s and low 60s. Although warm, 
there will be some cloud cover around out ahead of an approaching 
system on Sunday. There will also be a slight chance of showers 
through the day on Saturday but amounts will be very light. Very 
mild Saturday night with lows warmer than our normal daytime highs! 
Lows will be in the lower to mid 50s, spring-like. Temperatures even 
warmer Sunday with highs in the mid to upper 60s. ECMWF continues to 
be quite a bit faster with precip out ahead of the cold front than 
GFS. ECMWF brings main band of precip in around 00z Monday whereas 
the GFS is closer to 06z Monday. The actual front pushes through 
late Sunday night and brings about a 10 degree cool down for Monday, 
with highs in the lower to mid 50s, but still above normal.

After the front passes we stay in northwest flow through the rest of 
the long term as a long wave trough resides over the entire Eastern 
U.S. Around Tuesday, a large cut-off low is in place over the 
Dessert Southwest and Northern Mexico. The ECMWF and GFS still 
handling progression and development of this system quite different. 
The ECMWF is much quicker to absorb this low into the long wave 
trough and race it through the area Wednesday into Thursday while 
the GFS is much slower and doesn't move it through until 
Thursday/Friday. The GFS also keeps this system suppressed to our 
south with no precip affecting our area. The ECMWF solution would 
bring us some precip. For now, will continue to follow superblend 
guidance on pops until better model agreement.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
341 AM EST Thu Feb 9 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Behind the cold front that crossed the region late last night, a 
brisk northwest wind will help advect cooler, more seasonable air
into the forecast area. Highs this afternoon will be in the upper
20s/lower 30s across the north and higher elevations and struggle
to reach 40 across most of the Tennessee Valley. It will be 
breezy today with wind gusts up to 35 mph. Additionally, upslope 
flow combined with a bit of lingering moisture will help produce 
some light snow showers across the higher terrain this morning. 
Some light accumulations are possible, generally above 3500 feet. 
No impact is expected at lower elevations. A Special Weather 
Statement has been issued to highlight this potential.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...
Models are in modest agreement through Monday on the evolution 
and timing of next frontal system expected to push through the 
area late Sunday and Sunday Night. However, differences arise by 
Tuesday for the following frontal system expected mid-week.

Friday starts with high pressure over the SE US shifting offshore by 
evening as return flow and low level warm air advection starts in 
earnest. Highs Saturday will climb about 10 degrees above normal 
while Sunday may even see daytime highs reach nearly 20 degrees 
above normal. Although Saturday afternoon will see some rain chances 
ahead of the front, the primary opportunity for pcpn will likely be 
Sunday afternoon and evening, ahead of the approaching front. 
Based on timing of front and best instability/shear, areas in the 
Plateau could see a rumble of thunder in the afternoon, but 
elsewhere showers are to be expected. 

Biggest difference between models remains with the handling of the 
Pacific upper level low that is fcst to drop southward along the 
west coast Saturday then across Northern Mexico through Monday 
morning. From this point on, ECMWF is much more progressive with 
this low by pulling it NE into the Plains by Tuesday while GFS 
cuts off this low over Northern Mexico and then slowly drifts it 
eastward toward the NW Gulf coast through Wednesday. 
Interestingly, the majority of GFS ensemble members also tend 
toward a slowly moving cut off low over Mexico/Texas while the 
Canadian model sides with ECMWF. As models remain consistent with 
themselves and still unable to trend toward any consensus, have 
retained chance POPs Tuesday and Wednesday for the time being.

FXUS64 KMRX 081956
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
256 PM EST Wed Feb 8 2017

.SHORT TERM /Tonight and Thursday/...
An upper-level trough continue to race east toward the Tennessee
Valley and Southern Appalachian region this afternoon. Ahead of
this system, lingering low stratus trapped in the inversion and
debris mid/high clouds ahead of this system still prevail across a
good chunk of the area. However, the latest satellite trends
indicate some breaks have begun to develop, especially across
northern Alabama and Middle Tennessee. This is expected to 
continue over the next 2-3 hours across the Central and Southern 
Valley areas of East Tennessee and the Cumberland Plateau. As a
result, some modest instabilty is expected to develop by early
evening.

As the cold front pushes east into the Plateau by 22-00z, a broken
line/areas of convection is expected to develop across middle TN
and move into the Plateau. Depending on how much the atmosphere
can destabilize, this activity will be strong to severe. With the
steep lapse rates and low wet bulb zero heights, severe hail will
be the biggest risk with the strongest activity -- along with
damaging straight-line winds. The shear profile shown on the model
soundings (and supported by the straight hodographs) suggest
supercelluar structures and multicell clusters as storm mode.
Additionally, a weak boundary in place will create a very
localized weak tornado threat. The peak of this event will be
between 23-05z this evening when upper-level divergence peaks and
the LLJ pushes NE into the Valley. 

In it's wake, strong cold air advection will occur as NW flow
ramps up behind the frontal passage. There will be an opportunity
for some light snowfall accumulations (generally above 3500-4000
feet) in the TN/VA/NC mountains due to the orographic upslope
component and the lingering moisture between 09-15z early Thursday
morning. Accumulations could be an inch or two along the peaks,
but lowers elevations are not expected to be impacted. As such,
will handle this with a Special Weather Statement for now.
Otherwise, a cold breezy day is expected for Thursday with highs
in the 30s to lower 40s across the Valley. 

.LONG TERM /Thursday Night through Wednesday/...
Some ridging and dry advection should allow for a dry period to 
start the long term from Thursday night through Friday night. By 
Saturday, an amplifying Western U.S. upper trough and associated 
surface low pressure system will be moving east toward the 
continental divide. While winds turn southwesterly ahead of this 
feature, warm and moist air advancing northeast across the 
Southern Appalachians could generate some showers Saturday into 
Saturday night. However, the main period of higher probability for
showers and even some thunderstorms would be Sunday into Sunday 
night as the system cold front presses southeast across the 
forecast area. Drier and cooler air fills in behind the front for 
Monday through Monday night bringing an end to the rain. The 
Superblend procedure trends toward the wetter ECMWF solution 
toward the end of the long term bringing a stronger southern 
stream short wave through the Lower Mississippi Valley Tuesday 
night into Wednesday with more rain, and perhaps some higher 
elevation snowfall. The nice thing through the forecast is the 
most pleasant warming trend where temperatures warm well into the 
60s over the weekend ahead of the early work week cold front.

FXUS64 KMRX 080839

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
339 AM EST Wed Feb 8 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...We'll start the morning with
areas of patchy fog and low clouds, with residual boundary layer
moisture from yesterday's rain. Ceilings will lift by the
afternoon hours as a cold front slowly approaches the area.
Temperatures this afternoon will be unseasonably warm with warmer,
moist air advecting into the area. Showers and thunderstorms are 
expected ahead of the front this evening. While earlier model runs
indicated storms moving in by late afternoon, latest high- res 
models slow down convective initiation over middle TN/southeast 
KY, and it looks like this will be more of an evening event for 
our forecast area. Currently the SPC has our area outlooked for a 
marginal risk of severe weather. NAM forecast soundings show a 
skinny CAPE profile with SBCAPE values up to 1000 J/kg (MLCAPE 
values up to about 750 J/kg), about 70kt of SFC- 6km shear, and 
mid level lapse rates around 7 degrees C/km across our forecast 
area. Combined with incoming colder air aloft and the front acting
as a forcing mechanism, this would be enough to produce some hail
across mainly the northern half of the CWA. Additionally, 
accelerating line segments along the front may cause some gusty 
winds. It should be noted however, that there are some large 
differences in how models handle this situation and the resulting 
severe potential with the GFS showing much less instability than 
the NAM. As the cold front crosses the area Wednesday night, winds
will shift and increase a bit. With colder air rushing in behind 
the front, some snowflakes will mix in with the rain showers, 
especially at higher elevations in SW Virginia and the Smoky 
Mountains early Thursday morning.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)... As the front finally 
pushes through, cold air will surge into the area on Thursday. 
Lingering moisture and lowering temperatures through the day will 
allow for some snow showers and lingering flurry activity mainly 
in SW Virginia and the higher elevations of the Smoky Mountains. 
However, lack of substantial moisture with the arrival of the cold
air will result in only a light accumulations across those areas,
with up to an inch or two possible in the highest elevations by 
Thursday evening.

Temperatures should drop or remain steady through the day on 
Thursday with overnight lows Thursday night dropping about 10 
degrees below normal before rebounding to near seasonal norms on 
Friday. Return flow by Saturday will boost weekend temperatures to 
about 10 degrees above normal Saturday, increasing to 15 degrees 
above normal on Sunday.

Models are then in good agreement through the weekend as a cold 
front approaches the area by Sunday evening. ECMWF is a bit quicker 
with the front while GFS is a bit slower. Similarly, GFS ensemble 
members even suggest a slower progression of the front through 
Sunday evening. However, current consensus expectation is for best 
pcpn chances to occur Sunday night. 

Beyond Sunday night, we see the greatest disparity in models late 
Monday and Tuesday when weekend frontal boundary has pushed south 
extending along the gulf coast back to a developing low pressure 
system along the SE Texas coast. It seems that a middle level low 
over northwest Mexico on Monday is at the root of the disagreement 
in soln for Tuesday. ECMWF is more aggressive in handling of middle 
level low over northern Mexico and is already lifting this low NE 
across Texas by Tuesday while GFS and GFS Ensemble keep the low over 
northern Mexico through most of Tuesday. This results in more 
progressive surface low in the ECMWF which brings pcpn back into the 
area by Tuesday afternoon while GFS lags about a day behind. With 
uncertainty of soln and using super blend as basis, went with 30 POP 
across much of the southern half of the area for Tuesday.

FXUS64 KMRX 070850
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
350 AM EST Tue Feb 7 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...
Latest water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicating
trough digging southeast across Kansas and Oklahoma this morning.
Ahead of this feature over West Tennessee, convection is 
beginning to develop this morning and is expected to track 
eastward across the state through the day reaching into our 
Plateau counties by early this afternoon. Hires HRRR and RAP 
models both indicate that the activity will reach into the Plateau
counties by 18-19Z before pushing into the Tennessee Valley by 
20-21Z this afternoon.

Models have been consistent over the past day in keeping highest
CAPE values southwest and west of the area with favorable shear 
profiles that extend further east into our CWA. Given that SFC-6km
shear values in excess of 40 kts and SFC-1km storm relative 
helicity values in excess of 200 meters squared per second squared
will be found across much of the Plateau and southeastern 
Tennessee counties by afternoon, any thunderstorms that do develop
could become organized enough to produce damaging winds, hail, 
and a possible isolated tornado with main threat being damaging 
straight line winds.

Any instability and vertical shear will decrease as we move toward
midnight with much of the activity expected to push east of the 
area by late evening. Leftover showers will linger past midnight
before tapering off before morning as middle level trough axis
shifts east of the area and dry air aloft begins to move into the
area.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday)...
A cold front will move through the area Wednesday 
afternoon/evening, bringing another chance for some scattered 
showers and thunderstorms. A few of these storms may become 
severe, with damaging winds being the main threat. Although this 
is not that far away, there is still a good bit of model 
disagreement with regards to the amount of instability and shear 
present (with the NAM much more bullish on the severe weather 
potential than the GFS). Additionally, PWATS look to max out at 
about 0.90" in the Tennessee Valley -- which is around the 90th 
percentile for this time of year. The latest SPC Outlook has our 
entire forecast area in a marginal risk, so will continue the 
mention for isolated severe in the HWO for now. 

Temperatures Wednesday night will dip to near freezing or slightly 
below at the higher elevations in SW VA, the Cumberland Plateau, and 
along the Smoky Mountains. With lingering moisture, this will result 
in some light snow overnight, with very little actual accumulation 
expected. As the front continues to push out of the area on 
Thursday, a few light showers remain possible in NE TN and SW VA. 

Northwest flow behind the frontal passage will usher in cooler air 
for Thursday and Thursday night. Highs on Thursday will be around 5 
degrees below normal.  Lows Thursday night will be 5-10 degrees 
below normal. The cold snap will be short-lived with high pressure 
building over the Gulf of Mexico as we head into the weekend.  This 
will result in SW flow over the area, advecting warmer, more moist 
air into the region. This will also result in another chance for 
showers on Saturday, although models disagree with how much moisture 
will actually be present. A frontal boundary will then push through 
the area Sunday night/Monday morning, bringing a better chance for 
more organized showers and thunderstorms.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
316 PM EST Mon Feb 6 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today through Tuesday night)...
Currently seeing a round of rain move up through the Tennessee
Valley this afternoon. Pretty light accumulations of less than a
tenth of an inch are expected as it rolls through the valley. Once
this round moves through we should get a brief break from rain
overnight and into tomorrow morning as the frontal boundary
approaches our area. High resolution models are generally pointing
towards a mid afternoon arrival of showers and thunderstorms from
our west. Forecast sounding show that there will be little in the
way of CAPE to work with, but much more shear for storms to tap
into. CAPE values are more impressive to our south and west, but
if storms are able to form in these higher CAPE environments and
tap into the shear caused by a strong low level jet, they could
remain strong to severe as they move into the western counties of
our forecast area. Currently the main threat with the strongest
storms will be straight-line winds, but with good shear to work
with, we can't rule out some hail or an isolated tornado (however
unlikely). As the front pushes through precipitation will slowly 
fizzle out overnight.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday)...
A weak disturbance will move through the area Wednesday...bringing
another chance for scattered showers and thunderstorms. Models 
differ on timing of the convection moving through. With the low 
level flow out of the SW and instabilities increasing to over 1000
j/kg...kept timing late afternoon through the evening. 
Directional shear will be weak at the surface...with 30 to 40 kt 
in the mid levels. Can expect the strongest storms in areas south 
of I40...with a few storms becoming severe. Damaging wind will be 
the main threat at this time...with localized flooding also a 
possibility. The PW values are above the 90th percentile for this
time of year. 

Temperatures overnight Wednesday and into the early morning Thursday 
are expected to drop at or below freezing...with light snow 
possible...mainly in NE TN and SW VA. For now...not expecting any 
accumulations more than a dusting. This convection will continue to 
move east through the day Thursday...with only light scattered 
showers remaining in NE TN and SW VA Thursday afternoon. NW flow 
sets up behind the showers moving out of the area...with 
temperatures dropping below normal for Thursday night and Friday. 
High pressure will then set up in the Gulf for Thursday night 
through Saturday morning...transitioning the winds from NW to the 
SW...bringing warmer air and more moisture to the area. 

A slight chance for scattered showers is possible Saturday through 
Sunday...though models disagree on amount of moisture that will 
actually be present. A frontal boundary will then push through the 
area Monday morning...with the next chance for scattered 
thunderstorms possible through the morning.
