FXUS64 KMRX 182010
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
310 PM EST Wed Jan 18 2017

.SHORT TERM (Tonight through Tomorrow Night)...
Latest surface analysis indicates a low pressure center having
formed along the tail end of a sfc front which extends across
central North Carolina southwest to coastal Texas. This low over SE
Texas today, will deepen some as it moves NE through Thursday Night
moving into the Ohio Valley by Friday morning. Middle level low
located over Western Oklahoma this afternoon will begin to lift NE
tomorrow becoming located over Iowa by Friday morning.

Under a building middle level ridge tonight, subtropical moisture 
continues to pump northeastward from the tropical East Pacific
into the SE US. Model soundings indicate enough moisture advection
that PW values approach or exceed the seasonal maxima by Thursday
night at points across the southern third of the area, while
locations further north still reach above the 90th percentile for
this time of the year. As the middle level low finally lifts NE, a
series of shortwaves eject eastward from the base of the low
providing dynamic support to produce a fairly efficient rain maker.
QPF totals in excess of 1 inch are possible over the SW portion of
the area through Thursday night while the NE corner of TN and all
of SW VA will likely remain around 0.25 inches or less as the front
is yet to push through that area by the end of the short term. With
some instability creeping into our SW counties by tomorrow evening,
a few rumbles of thunder are possible with this round of
precipitation, particularly over the southern half of the area.

Under the continued southerly flow, temperatures will remain well
above normal. Overnight lows tonight should be about 10 degrees
above normal increasing to near 20 degrees above normal for
tomorrow night...but still about 5 degrees below record high
minimum temperatures. Meanwhile the daytime high on Thursday will
approach 15 degrees above normal under rainy and cloudy skies. 


.LONG TERM (Friday through Wednesday)...

Our first system will continue to slowly exit the region to the
northeast and we will see a brief period of quiet weather to end the
work week as we head into the weekend. A good jet will help to bring
in moist on Saturday, this moist air will be pretty unstable for
this time of year and we have a good chance to see showers and
thunderstorms Saturday through Sunday. As the precipitation moves in
there will be a boundary draped across the region and it could act
to focus thunderstorm chances in our area. CAPE values in our area,
specifically the southern Tennessee Valley could be in the 1000 J/Kg
range, this in combination with good shear along the boundary could
be the ingredients needed to see strong to severe thunderstorms. 

The low moving across the Southeastern United Sates will eventually
kick out any remnant thunderstorms on Sunday into Monday and we will
continue with widespread rain chances into early next week. The low
finally exits to our east by the middle of the week and we get a
chance to dry out as drier northerly/westerly winds take over.
Another frontal boundary will make a run at the area at the end of
next week and we could see a brief bout of rain with this frontal
passage as well. 

During this entire forecast we will continue to see unseasonably
warm temperatures with highs topping out 10-15 degrees above normal.
These unseasonably warm temperatures will keep any precipitation we
see in the form of liquid throughout the entire forecast.

FXUS64 KMRX 180909

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
409 AM EST Wed Jan 18 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and tonight)...

Upper trough moving east across Ohio Valley this morning is pushing
a cold front across eastern sections of the forecast area this
morning. Light rain showers across eastern third of the region will
move out by mid morning. Some drier air will move in behind the
front with skies clearing by afternoon. The break in the clouds
will be brief this afternoon and evening as surface low in Texas
along the front moves into the lower Mississippi valley tonight.
The front to the south will begin to move back north as a warm
front with moisture overrunning it late tonight. A few showers will
develop late across southeast Tennessee. Highs today will be
several degrees cooler than Tuesday behind the front but still in
the mild mid 50s to lower 60s. Tonight with partly cloudy to
possibly clear skies early lows will drop to near freezing
northeast and mid 30s to near 40 elsewhere except southern plateau
and valley where clouds move in first lows will stay in the mid to
upper 40s.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...

An active pattern is expected throughout the extended forecast with
higher than normal PW values and temperatures expected throughout
much of the forecast period.

For the beginning of the extended period on Thursday morning an
upper level trough will be moving eastward across the Central and
Southern Plains. At the surface, a warm front will be located just
to the south of the area with a cold front across the Lower
Mississippi River Valley. Southeasterly downsloping flow around an
exiting high pressure to the northeast will counteract some of the
isentropic ascent ahead of the approaching warm front and pushed
PoPs back a bit with highest chances Thursday afternoon and into the
overnight hours. These downsloping winds will lead to the highest
temperatures along the foothills with highs in the low to mid 60s.
The upper level trough will take on a negative tilt later in the day
as it moves into the Tennessee River Valley. At this point, there
will be some weak instability and have mentioned a slight chance for
thunderstorms in the forecast late Thursday afternoon into early
Friday morning. Upper level drying moves into the region Friday as
the trough axis passes to the east and a shortwave ridge moves into
the area. Highs on Friday will still be well above normal with
values generally in 60s. 

The next system will move in on Saturday as strong low level warm
air and moisture advection continue into the weekend. A tropical jet
will bring in a series of shortwave trough across the Southeastern
U.S. over the weekend. Rain chances will increase through the day
Saturday with strong warm air and moisture advection. Models depict
a warm front lifting northward during the afternoon with a good
directional shear along the boundary with SBCAPE values nearing 1000
J/Kg across the Southern Valley and Southern Plateau late in the
afternoon. An upper level trough will close off across the Lower
Mississippi River Valley early Sunday. The continued warm advection
and moisture advection will push SBCAPE values up into the 500-1200
J/Kg range across the forecast area, however, there is a bit of a
capping inversion on the GFS forecast soundings. Low level shear
still remains decent around 150-250 m2/s2. The system is still
several days away but will go ahead and add the mention for strong
to severe storms to the HWO for Saturday and Sunday with the threat
on Saturday limited to the Southern Valley and Plateau. 

Cooler temperatures are expected to start the work week as the upper
level low moves overhead. This will keep chances for showers
continuing late in the forecast period. Despite the cooler air
aloft, all of the precipitation from the upper level low should be in
the form of rain. The upper level low will eventually drift to the
northeast Monday night into Tuesday with drier air moving in for the
middle of the work week.

213 
FXUS64 KMRX 171954
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
254 PM EST Tue Jan 17 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tomorrow)...
Cold front will be crossing the forecast area this evening and
pushing east of the area tonight. With very little instability to
begin with, the setting sun should limit convection chances even
further, and we should not see any thunder after nightfall. Some
lingering showers are possible across the east Wednesday morning,
then drier air moves in for the remainder of the day. Skies will
clear a bit during the afternoon and we should see at least a few
peeks of sunshine. Winds will shift from the west behind the front
and gusts will diminish. Despite a cold front moving through, the
air behind it isn't too much cooler and highs tomorrow will still
be in the 50s.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...
An active weather pattern continues through this period as a trio
of closed cyclonic circulations move across the lower 48.

The first system will remain to our west, with a negatively-tilted
trough extending from its center into the TN Valley region Thursday
night. A 40+ kt LLJ will efficiently transport Gulf moisture into
our area starting late Thursday afternoon, with strong lift provided
by favorable positioning of the left exit region of a jet streak.
Some weak instability during the time of strongest lift should
provide at least a slight chance of thunderstorms for the southern
and western half of the area. Drying aloft will bring an end to rain
chances Friday morning, and with some afternoon clearing and a
continuing SW low-to-mid level flow, temps will reach the mid to
upper 60s on Friday. 

A second closed low tracks NE across the Plains on Saturday, but
stays west of the MS River. However it will keep the Gulf open to
the TN Valley, with additional moisture spreading back into the area
and bringing a chance of showers Saturday. Temperatures will
continue to be well above normal, with highs in the 60s.

A third and more significant closed low tracks across the Red River
Valley to West TN on Sunday. The GFS points toward a warm conveyor
belt with tropical connections across the Southeast, along with a
coupled jet structure over the TN Valley. If this holds, we could
see some significant heavy rainfall and possibly thunderstorms. One
caveat might be if strong convection develops along the Gulf coast
and cuts off the northerly flow of warm/moist air, which is what the
ECMWF hints at happening. Falling temps aloft as the low moves
overhead will keep showers going into Monday. Given model
consistency and agreement with the general pattern, likely PoPs are
warranted for Saturday night through Monday. At this time,
temperatures stay warm enough for all liquid precip under the closed

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...

Seeing a couple of upper level features that will be important in

northeast into the Great Lakes region with the second shortwave
trough moving to the southeast across the Northern Plains. At the
surface, a low pressure center is directly underneath the first
shortwave trough near Chicago with an associated cold front
stretching southward towards Memphis and further southwestward
towards Houston. Current radar imagery depicts widespread showers
across Middle and Western TN and northwards into Kentucky. The area
of showers has made little progress to the east but should begin to
see that closer to daybreak as the first trough pushes more to the
east. Timing of the precipitation will be the main forecast
challenge today. The atmosphere will be highly saturated with PW
values near maximum levels observed for mid-January ranging from 1.1-
1.4 inches. Looks like the first batch of precipitation should
move through mid-morning as the first trough pushes off to the
east. It looks as though there will be a brief break in the
precipitation late this morning into early this afternoon between
the two systems. Precipitation should move in again ahead of the
front later this afternoon and evening as the second trough passes
just to the north. Models indicate some weak instability with
MUCAPE values generally <250 J/Kg. Therefore, expect there could be
a few rumbles of thunder through midnight or so. The cold front
will be approaching the mountains late in the Short-Term forecast
with cooler air moving into the Plateau and Southwest VA. The cold
air advection behind the system is not overly impressive and lows
behind the front will only drop down into the low to mid 40s across
the Plateau and Southwest VA.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday)...

High pressure tries to build south behind a cold front later
Wednesday and Wednesday evening. Drier air behind the front will
lower temperatures briefly but not clear skies significantly before
increased moisture with surface low moving up from the lower
Mississippi Valley spreads more clouds and rain from the southwest
late Wednesday night and Thursday. Increased instability...strong
low level jet...upper level divergence in warm moist air mass later
Thursday and continuing Friday ahead of this slow moving system
will allow a few thunderstorms to develop. High temperatures both
days will be in the mild upper 50s to lower 60s Thursday and lower
to mid 60s Friday. The frontal system will move east of the region
later Friday. Rain will end Friday night and be mostly dry into the
first half of Saturday. Then yet another system will move into the
Mississippi Valleys Saturday and deepening Sunday spreading another
wave of showers north from the Gulf. Temperatures still mild with a
chance of thunderstorms again Sunday possibly lingering into Monday
as this system moves slowly east. Colder air finally poised to move
in behind this system Monday night cooling temperatures into the 30s
to lower 40s

possible again late tonight into early Tuesday, but winds
increasing ahead of the cold front should help hinder widespread
fog development tonight.

By late morning, showers are possible across the northwestern
portion of the forecast area as the cold front nears. Model
solutions still vary a bit -- with some models indicating more
moisture and showers ahead of the front than others. For now, have
likely PoPs NW and chance PoPs SE for most of the daytime hours.
Then, likely PoPs everywhere Tuesday evening into the overnight
hours to coincide with the actual frontal passage. There does
appear to be enough weak instability by midday Tuesday to support a
few rumbles of thunder, mainly across western locations and have
carried/added in a slight chance of thunder to account for this
along and just before the frontal passage. PoPs will taper off from
NW to SE late Tuesday night as the front exits the area. A 40-50kt
850mb jet will accompany the frontal passage. This will result in
some gusty winds Tuesday afternoon, especially over higher terrain,
but winds look like they should remain below advisory criteria.


.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Monday)...
A cold front will be exiting the area Wednesday morning, and high
pressure from the surface through the midlevels will be building in
from the west through the day. Forecast soundings on Wed show a
strong inversion trapping low level moisture in the Valley, so will
lean high temperatures on the cool side of MOS guidance. Deep
moisture builds back in rapidly on Thursday as the surface
high/ridging aloft shift to the east of the mountains. PoPs
increase through the day as a trough axis over TX becomes
negatively tilted and the southerly 850 mb jet increases to 40+
kts. Favorable upper jet positioning for divergence and 850 mb
theta-E values above 320K suggest a mention of t-storms is
warranted Thursday night, at least for southern sections. Model
agreement on timing of lift gives confidence to increase PoPs to
categorical on Thursday night, lowering to chance PoPs Friday.

An active and abnormally mild pattern continues through the weekend
as the models show a deep closed low developing in the lee of the
Rockies. The GFS and ECMWF are in surprisingly good agreement with
the timing and positioning of this closed low, taking it to the Mid-
MS Valley by 00Z Monday. Thus confidence is high enough to bring
likely PoPs into the area for Sunday and Sunday night. The closed
low slowly tracks NE across the Ohio Valley on Monday, so we will
remain under its influence with scattered showers beneath the low
through the day. The question for Monday will be whether
temperatures will be cold enough for snow or rain showers. Given the
recent warmth and the lack of a strong punch of cold air behind the
closed and slow-moving upper low, will keep precip all rain to start
Day 7.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
325 AM EST Sun Jan 15 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...

The overall pattern remains somewhat stagnant with a stalled surface
boundary bisecting the area. PW values across the region are around
an inch, which is over the 90th percentile for mid-January. The lack
of any significant forcing has kept showers isolated to scattered at
best. The main difference since yesterday morning is the lack of
widespread dense fog. There are a couple of locations below 1 mile
but it does not appear that widespread dense fog will be as much of
an issue this morning. Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air
analysis indicate that the shortwave trough that brought in more
widespread showers to the Southern Appalchians is now over the Mid-
Atlantic. An upper level ridge currently exists across the Gulf oF
Mexico with a closed low located acrosS Baja California. Closer to
home, upper level and mid-level flow is mostly zonal with a
shortwave ridge just to the west.

For today, expect to start off with patchy fog and clouds with mild
temperatures. A few light isolated showers/drizzle will be possible
with the anomalously high PW values. The lack of any forcing will keep
any precipitation amounts light. The surface boundary will linger
across the forecast area with warmer than average temperatures
continuing with highs in the upper 50s to upper 60s. Went on the
higher sides of guidance with temperatures being much warmer than
forecast over the last couple of days. The shortwave ridge will
move into the area late today into tonight with the mid-level and
upper level flow taking on more of southwesterly direction. This
will push the front further to the north and should lead to lower
rain chances across the area late this afternoon and into tonight.
Mild overnight lows will continue with readings in the upper 40s to
low 50s.

.LONG TERM (Monday through Saturday)...

The boundary that has been stalled along the northern TN border
will lift north on Monday as weak ridging develops over the area.
With a moist...warm air mass in place...could see a few isolated
showers develop Monday afternoon and evening. The main concern for
the extended period continues to be a cold front expected to move
through around the Tuesday/Wednesday time frame. Models continue to
have difficulty in timing of this feature...but the trend is for a
frontal passage Tuesday night. Could see scattered showers develop
Tuesday ahead of the main band of showers. Then...the best chance
of showers will be Tuesday night for likely pops and then scattered
showers lingering into Wednesday. Models continue to diverge
Thursday through Saturday. The GFS takes the front out of the
region quickly and puts us between systems for Thursday...then
lifts an area of low pressure through around Friday and
Saturday...providing our next chance of showers. The ECMWF keeps
the front in the area on Thursday with a short wave riding through
for additional shower activity...then brings the area of low
pressure in slightly slower for the end of the extended. With the
low confidence in the detail will keep low to chance pops for an
unsettle weather pattern in place through the end of the period. As
for temperatures...expect above normal temperatures which will
allow precip to generally fall as rain.

difference and gone with slight chance to chance PoPs.

Friday, but timing and strength vary. For now, have stuck with
chance PoPs for this system.

overnight lows in the 40s and 50s.

shortwave trough passage and upper divergence will increase rain
chances area-wide after 00Z tonight. The front stalls just north of
our area, and a second shortwave trough will bring additional
showers on Wednesday morning. Thunderstorms cannot be completely
ruled out with this second shortwave passage, but instability
looks too weak to add a mention of it at this time. As a second low
pressure system tracks across the Great Lakes, a SW flow of 40-50
kts at 850 mb will continue to provide warm conditions, but we
should stay dry on Thursday as all lift and deep moisture will be
to our north. Highs will be well above normal, in the mid to upper
60s. Precip chances rise again late Thursday night for northern
sections as a cold front moves into KY.

.LONG TERM (Friday through Monday)...
 The long term period continues to look rather decent with no
airmass cold enough to allow for the mention of snow. It should be
a little unsettled with the Eastern U.S. upper trough strengthening
early in the period across the Northeastern states. This would push
a cool frontal boundary into the northern part of the forecast area
increasing the chance for showers a bit on Friday with slowly
decreasing probability into the daytime period Saturday. However,
upper ridging over the Southeastern states and the advance of a
healthy upper trough through the mountain west into the plains
should push the cool front back north of the Southern Appalachians
with just a small chance for a shower Saturday night into Monday.
The western trough and associated cold front will be pressing
toward the forecast area later Monday night into Tuesday with an
increasing chance for rain showers. Temperatures should be very
pleasant late this week into early next week running a good fifteen
degrees above normal for highs with lows around fifteen to twenty
degrees above normal.

year. Once the warmer temperatures hit they will stick around
through at least the weekend. In addition to the warmer temperatures
there will be several impulses that move across the boundary which
could cause an increase in wind speeds, particularly in the higher
elevations.

elevations of the Southern Appalachian Mountains could briefly hit
wind advisory criteria on Tuesday. Boundary will try and push
through the area and we could see some precipitation along the
boundary. Models have come in a bit slower with the arrival of the
boundary which should hopefully help keep snow away and any precip
in the form of pure rain except maybe in the highest elevations.
Rain chances continue into the middle of the week before the
boundary moves out of our area.

Late in the work week my confidence starts to decrease as models are
still in disagreement with what to do with our next system. Both the
GFS and ECMWF show a frontal boundary getting stalled somewhere in
the vicinity, but the ECMWF stalls it out over our area with
precipitation smeared out. While the GFS keeps a tighter
precipitation gradient and stalls the boundary out over Western
Tennessee/Kentucky. Wherever this boundary stalls will see good
precipitation. ECMWF then kicks the associated low pressure out
through the Great Lakes region and moves precipitation out by early
next week. On the other hand the GFS shows a more broad trough that
slowly moves through the Central part of the U.S. and keeps
precipitation chances going for longer. Once again I will keep
precipitation chances going through much of the end of the
week/weekend to account for the discrepancies in the long term
models.

mid to upper 20s for most areas.

region on Monday with temperatures finally reach above freezing for
all but the highest elevations.  The next system moves in around
Tuesday/Tuesday night.  If any precip reaches into the area Tuesday
morning...expect a mix of rain and snow.  However...the main band of
showers should push in late Tuesday afternoon and Tuesday night...
and temperatures at this point should be warm enough for all rain.
Additionally...a strong 850MB jet will accompany the system and
winds...especially over higher terrain...will become breezy and
gusty. The main frontal boundary moves in on Wednesday for
continued shower activity. Models diverge through the rest of the
extended and confidence low. However...overall should remain in a
rather unsettle weather pattern as a frontal boundary remains
across the region through around Thursday...followed by a cold
front moving in around Friday night into Saturday.

FXUS64 KMRX 070800
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
300 AM EST Sat Jan 7 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and tonight)...
Snow is winding down across the area, and only our northeastern
counties will see additional accumulation in the next few hours.
However, TDOT reports that roads across much of the TN Valley remain
slick and snow-covered, and with temperatures in the teens and 20s
through the day, conditions may not improve much until the clouds
break late in the late morning/early afternoon once the mid/upper
trough axis moves through. 

The WSW will be updated to scale back the warning to an advisory in
areas that will not get more accumulation but still have hazardous
travel conditions - this includes SW VA, most of the TN Valley, the
Smokies, and SW NC. The advisory for the Plateau counties will be
canceled. The Warning will be maintained for the NE TN mountains
where an additional half to one inch accumulation will be possible
through 15Z. 

The main issue through tonight will be the bitterly cold
temperatures and wind chills. Much of the area will have single-
digit low temps tonight. In addition, winds in the mountains will be
near 10 mph, bringing wind chills down to the -8 to -12 range. Will
extend the current Wind Chill Advisory for the mountains through
Sunday morning. The remainder of the Advisory will remain the same.

.LONG TERM (Sunday through Friday)...
Over the weekend we will see very cold temperatures continue
behind our main winter system. Drier air from the north will keep
temps down and clearing skies in the overnight hours will allow for
good radiational cooling bringing overnight lows into the single
digits in some places on Sunday night/Monday morning. Winds will
finally swing around to the southwest on Monday and we will begin a
warming trend through the rest of the week. Many places will
finally get above freezing on Monday for the first time since
before the snow fell.

A frontal boundary will move through on Tuesday and if it gets here
a bit ahead of schedule we could see some brief light snow before we
switch over to all liquid. But the current models and the forecast
depict the precipitation starting late enough that it will be all
rain. After that forecast confidence decreases since the long term
models diverge in how to handle our next round of precipitation.
Models hint at a stalled boundary somewhere north/west of us, but
can't agree on what would happen south of that boundary, or if/when
it gets a nice shove and pushes on through our area. Will go ahead
and paint broad strokes of precipitation chances across several days
towards the end of the week and into the weekend, but these will
definitely be tightened up as the event draws closer. In addition
current temperature forecast shows that any precipitation that does
occur at the end of the week would remain all liquid.

741 
FXUS64 KMRX 062039
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
339 PM EST Fri Jan 6 2017

.SHORT TERM /THIS EVENING THROUGH SATURDAY/...
A very complex forecast this afternoon as a significant winter
storm continues to approach the region from the southwest. There is
still a great deal of uncertainty with the exact track of this
system, which will have a big impact on total snowfall. What is
certain is that most areas will likely see an inch or two of snow
at minimum, with areas along and west of the I-75 corridor
potentially seeing a few to perhaps several inches more. The
development of the wintry precipitation tonight is tied to a fast
moving longwave trough over the Southern Plains that will quickly
shift into the MS/TN Valleys overnight. This will bring a broad
area of snow, with some bands producing locally heavier snow
squalls along the mountains.

The area most likely to experience these conditions will be the
East Tennessee and Southwest North Carolina Mountains and their
surrounding foothills, where between 3 to 8 inches of snow will be
common by Saturday morning. In the Valley the forecast is much
tricker. Models are still showing a plume of moisture moving in
late this evening through the overnight hours. Highest confidence
is counties along and east of the I-75 and I-81 corridors where a
Winter Storm Warning is in place. There, amounts in the 3 to 5 or 3
to 6 inch range are possible overnight. However, there will be a
very sharp gradient as you head west as drier air moves on the back
side. Locations along the Plateau may only see an inch, but it may
quickly increase as you head east of I-75. A Winter Weather
Advisory is in effect for all other locations. 

Regardless of how much snow accumulates, the subfreezing
temperatures in place will allow any snow that falls to stick,
creating very hazardous travel conditions on untreated and
secondary roads. Travel is discouraged if it can be avoided
overnight.

Drier air will quickly move in from the west by sunrise as winds
increase. This will dip wind chills along the mountains of East TN,
SW VA and the Plateau to dangerously cold levels (in the -5 to -10
degree range). Thus, a Wind Chill Advisory has been issued for
those areas from 09-18z on Saturday. Bitter cold highs are expected
under northerly flow with subfreezing air in place, only peaking in
the teens and 20s. Needlessly to say, secondary roads will remain
hazardous through most of the day tomorrow. 

.LONG TERM /SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY/...
At the beginning of this period the Winter Storm will be away to the
east as the upper trough, and very cold air will be pumping into the
region.  By this time the snowfall will be done, but the cold temps
will remain through the rest of the weekend, with widespread single-
digit low temps Sunday and Monday mornings.  Finally on Monday, the
entire area should rise above freezing, and temperatures should turn
warmer for the remainder of the week.  

The forecast is slightly touch-and-go with respect to precip type on
Tuesday.  Temperatures Tuesday morning are forecast to go below
freezing, and precip will be moving in during the day, but it looks
like the precip will probably start after temperatures warm above
freezing. So, right now not expecting any hazards in the forecast
next week. Even the return flow next week is not expected to induce
enough instability for thunderstorms ahead of a weak front around
Wednesday.

425 
FXUS64 KMRX 060838
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
338 AM EST Fri Jan 6 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today through Saturday morning)...
Through this morning and early afternoon, only very light snow or
flurries are expected as the column will have adequate moisture but
weak to no lift. With only a slight chance of any measurable liquid
precip and high temperatures near or slightly above freezing, no
snow accumulations over a tenth are expected through mid afternoon.

Lift will start to increase late in the afternoon as the amplifying
midlevel trough moves into the MS Valley region and the entrance
region of the jet become positioned over the Southern Appalachians.
Frontogenetic forcing ramps up in the 03-06Z time frame, although
the NAM and GFS have some differences in positioning, with the GFS
being a bit more S and E with its QPF. So although their amounts in
our eastern sections fairly close, there are some large
differences in snow amounts for the Plateau, SW VA, and western
Valley. This is the area of lowest confidence. The SREF mean has the
highest amounts and is a bit concerning, showing a couple inches
more than the 00Z NAM and several more than the 00Z GFS. The 06Z
run of the NAM has come in with slightly lower amounts than the 00Z
run, lending confidence to undercutting the SREF amounts. Precip
should begin to taper off from 09Z to 15Z with the passage of the
midlevel trough axis, with only additional light accumulations east
Saturday morning.

Storm total snow amounts are expected to be in the 4-7 inch range
for SW NC, the TN mountains, and foothills - this is an expansion
westward from the previous warning. The timing of the current
warning will be moved later to start at 00Z. The rest of the area -
along and west of I-81 and along and west of a line from Morristown
to Cleveland - will be in an advisory for 1-3 inches.

.LONG TERM (Saturday afternoon through Thursday)...
With the snow moved out of our area by Saturday afternoon the
biggest weather story will be the very cold temperatures through
the rest of the weekend. Drier winds out of the north will help to
funnel in unseasonably cold air and clear out the skies through the
second half of the weekend. These will combine to give us
temperatures overnight in the single digits/low teens across most
of the area (about 20 degrees below normal for this time of year).
Daytime won't bring much relief temperature-wise with most
locations staying below freezing throughout the entire weekend.
Luckily winds should be pretty light at the surface so the wind
chill values won't be dramatically lower than the observed
temperatures this weekend.

Many places will finally get above freezing for the first time on
Monday, and it wouldn't suprise me if some places experience over
100 hours of continuous sub-freezing temperatures leading into
Monday. Luckily the warming trend will continue through the rest of
the week with many places forecasted to be in the upper 50's by the
end of the work week. With the gradual warming we will also get our
next chance for precipitation. A front will sweep through the area
in the middle of the week and bring a good chance for precipitation.
Temperatures will have warmed up enough to where any precip that
does occur should be all liquid. Can't rule out some brief switch
over to snow in the highest elevations in the overnight hours, but
the vast majority will just see rain. Also of note with this front
will be the winds ahead of the front as a strong low level jet moves
over us. We could see some breezy winds in the higher elevations and
some of it will translate down into the valley, making the overnight
wind chill temperatures Wednesday morning unpleasant.

Another slow moving system could move through at the end of the work
week, but models are in disagreement with timing/location of this
one. At this point it looks warm enough that any precip that does
occur will still be in the form a just rain.

192 
FXUS64 KMRX 052049
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
349 PM EST Thu Jan 5 2017

.SHORT TERM /Tonight through Friday Night/...
A very complex storm system will impact the region over the next 36
hours, bringing widespread winter weather impacts to the Tennessee
Valley and Southern Appalachian region. The initial clipper system
tonight will not have much in the way of appreciable moisture with
it, through there will be some added lift along the mountains of SW
Virginia. Some locally higher amounts of 1 to 3 inches of snow are
possible there overnight, but generally 1/2 to 1 inch is expected
across much of the rest of the Valley (generally I-40 north). This
system will quickly exit the region leaving subfreezing, arctic
air in it's wake.

Another winter storm system will quickly approach the region from
the south and west, bringing light snow into the eastern Tennessee
valley as early as 18z Friday. This precipitation is progged to
overspread the area over the course of the afternoon and evening
and confidence is increasing that a widespread heavy snow event
will occur. There will be a sharp cut-off point, which will highly
be dependent of the track of this system and where the jet sets up.
However, feel confident that the east TN/west NC mountains will see
warning conditions and have upgraded to a warning there.

How much the valley gets is less certain. However, there is a
decent possibilty of 2 to 5 inches occurring across a broad area
(borderline warning criteria), beginning late Friday afternoon
through Saturday morning). Regardless of how much snow occurs the
subfreezing temperatures will create treacherous road conditions
on any untreated surfaces (even with 1-2 inches of snow). Given the
model fluctuations, have gone with a Watch for the Valley and a
Warning for the Mountains for now and will let the evening/midnight
shifts take another look at it. Am more confident about the Plateau
seeing less snowfall and have gone with an Advisory there. For more
information on the impacts of this storm system, please see the
Winter Storm Watch/Warning/Advisory (WSW) product and the Hazardous
Weather Outlook (HWO).

One last note, the closest Analog for this event is the January 28,
2014, winter storm that dropped 2-4 inches of snow across the
region, and created treacherous road conditions on untreated
surfaces to the subfreezing temperatures.

.LONG TERM /Saturday through Thursday/...
At the beginning of this period the Winter Storm will be exiting the
area, the upper trough will be on top of us, and cold surface high
pressure will be building into the area.  Saturday morning there
will likely be some lingering snow showers in our eastern counties,
with light accumulations--mainly less than 1/2 inch--once again main
confined to the counties along the TN/NC state line.

The surface ridge will be nosing into the area by Sunday
morning...making for lighter and lighter winds to enhance
radiational cooling.  Will go about a category colder than the blend
min temps for Sunday morning, closer to the GFS MOS mins. The ridge
should move the rest of the way over the area during the day on
Sunday.  As the ridge slides east, early next week, a southerly
return flow sets in that should show a fairly quick warm-up.  

The next cold front looks to push through the area around mid-week.
Looks like a deep low pressure with this system that on the surface
looks like it might have some wind with it, but for us, it tracks so
far north, that the faster winds will be to the north as well. Might
have some gusty southwest winds for one 12 hour period, just ahead
of the front.  Looks like precip will be mainly in a band along the
front.  Models not showing much instability surging north ahead of
the front, but as deep as the low is, it is worth keeping up with
low level moisture trends for chances of thunder--will just keep as
showers for now.  Also, even on the cold side of this precip, right
now it looks like all liquid as the cooling happens after the
moisture has eroded away to our east.

FXUS64 KMRX 050855
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
355 AM EST Thu Jan 5 2017

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Clouds will increase across the forecast area this morning, ahead
of a clipper system that will push through the area this evening
through Friday morning. High temperatures today will reach the
upper 30s across the Cumberland Plateau and southwest Virginia, the
lower 40s across the Tennessee Valley, and the mid 40s near the
TN/GA line before colder air rushes in behind the arctic front.

Rain showers will change over to snow this evening across the
northern Plateau and Cumberland Mountains, then snow showers will
spread further south overnight. With overnight lows in the 20s,
snow will accumulate and cause some travel difficulties --
especially on untreated roadways. Total snowfall through Friday
morning will range from 1-3 inches (with locally higher amounts)
across northeast TN and southwest VA to 0.5-1 inches across the
northern Tennessee Valley to a few tenths south of I-40.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...
As the first snow maker leaves the area tonight, a second system
starts to wind up in the northern Gulf of Mexico. Models have been
consistently showing this system for the last several days, but
location is everything, and that is where the models have been a bit
more inconsistent with it. ECMWF has been fairly steady over the
last several days with sfc low moving along the northern Gulf coast
Friday and moving off the SE coast Friday night. GFS and NAM have
also been depicting low in the northern Gulf, but the track has been
a bit further south. Models coming a bit more in line this morning
on the track which brings wintery precipitation right to our eastern
and southern doorsteps. Presently there is consensus among the SREF,
GFS, ECMWF, and NAM that snow will be primarily confined to the
extreme eastern portion of the area and southwest North Carolina.
Similarly, snowfall totals look to be on the order of 1-2 inches in
northeast Tennessee increasing to 2-3 inches over the southern third
of this area. Going back to the fact that location is everything,
a slight change in the surface low track could have significant
implications on snowfall in our area. A bit further south and the
area in northeast Tennessee would see nearly nothing, a bit further
north and portions of the East Tennessee Valley could see some
accumulations overnight Friday into Saturday morning. Certainly
need to keep a close watch on the model handling of this system
over the next run or two.

System quickly shifts east by Saturday afternoon with skies clearing
behind it by Saturday evening. Then the arctic cold takes hold with
temperatures struggling to get above freezing across much of the
area through Sunday. A gradual warming trend starts Monday where
most of the area will reach into the upper 30s under full sun. Next
system approaches the area Tuesday night with decent agreement btwn
GFS and ECMWF on track and timing for now. With this system,
temperatures will continue to warm through Wednesday with prospects
of more rain as this system passes through on Wednesday

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
320 PM EST Wed Jan 4 2017

.SHORT TERM /Tonight and Thursday/...
Drier air quickly moving into the region this afternoon, creating a
mostly clear sky overnight. This will allow temperatures to drop
into the low to mid 20s over much of the region due to the good
radiational cooling. Some mid to high clouds will move in late
tonight into Thursday morning ahead of an arctic front that is
progged to move east into the region late Thursday afternoon and
evening. Some peaks of sunshine will allow highs to warm into the
40s ahead of this boundary, but colder air will quickly filter in
behind it. Latest forecast has the boundary pushing into the
northern Plateau and Cumberland mountains between 18-21z, quickly
changing any light rain with it to snow for the evening commute.
This trend will continue into the evening hours and after sunset as
these broad areas of snow will overspread the area. A Winter
Weather Advisory has been issued for the Northern Plateau and
Cumberland Mtns from 21z Thursday to 12z Friday and across much of
the rest of the area from 00-12z (addressed below).

.LONG TERM /Thursday Night through Wednesday/...
A clipper system will dive southeast from the Northern Plains
tonight and will be cross the Southern Appalachian region Thursday
night into Friday morning. This is a fast moving upper trough but
should have enough sub-freezing air and enough moisture to produce
some accumulating snow across much of the MRX forecast area.
Typically greater snowfall accumulation is expected on the higher
terrain features including the Cumberland Plateau, Southwest
Virginia, and the mountains along the Tennessee and North Carolina
border. In these areas, snowfall totals should be at least one to
two inches, although some of the higher terrain across Southwest
Virginia could pick up two to four inches. Would expect amounts
around one inch in the Tri-Cities area by daybreak Friday with
totals around one half to one inch across the Great Valley from
around Knoxville northeast into the Tri-Cities region. Of course,
this would cause some travel difficulties with overnight snowfall
and temperatures dropping into the 20s. Although the deeper
moisture and lift would be exiting early in the day Friday, enough
lower level moist air and cold air advection should be in place to
keep some light snow or flurries going through mid day. The next
system that will have a minor impact on our forecast area will be a
short wave driving east through the Lower Mississippi Valley Friday
night and across the Southeast Atlantic Coastal states by Saturday
morning. The forecast ideology utilized a compromise between the
weaker and farther east GFS and the stronger ECMWF which features a
deepening surface low much closer to the Southeast Atlantic coast.
In this scenario, most of the deep moisture and short wave lift
will be south and east of the MRX forecast area. Thus, used a thin
stripe of pops aligned along the far East Tennessee mountains with
the highest probabilities at 50 percent for light snow on the
mountain terrain. This system moves out quickly with skies clearing
by Saturday afternoon. A dry regime persists for a rather lengthy
period behind the departing storm system. The forecast area should
enjoy more sun than clouds from Saturday afternoon through Tuesday
afternoon. However, it will be very cold with a northerly flow
pulling arctic air into the region well into Monday. Highs will not
make it above freezing for most of the area through the weekend,
but will recover to at least the mid to upper 30s on Monday.
Another upper trough and surface frontal system will be pressing
into the Eastern U.S. Tuesday night into Wednesday which should
help boost high temperatures back into the 40s on Tuesday and lower
to middle 50s on Wednesday. Of course, more rain will be in the
forecast during this final part of the extended as it is lifted
ahead of the system cold front.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Cold front continues to push east through the forecast area
early this morning. Rain showers will quickly taper off this
morning and cloud cover will become scattered as cooler, drier air
moves in behind the front. With the cooler air moving in, afternoon
temperatures will be steady or slowly falling. Cloud cover will
increase from the west again tonight, ahead of our next weather
system. With the colder airmass firmly in place, lows will dip
into the 20s across the area.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...
Forecast confidence is growing as models continue to come into
alignment over the upcoming snow event late Thursday through Friday.
Although there are still some discrepancies between accumulation
amounts, timing and areal extent of the frozen pcpn looks to be
increasing in consensus among the models. 

Most of Thursday should be dry area wide as cold air pushes in.
Temperatures will struggle to climb into the middle 30s during the
day over SW Virginia and northern portions of the Cumberland
Plateau. By afternoon, the leading edge of the arctic airmass pushes
into northern areas as shortwave trough passes along the TN-KY-VA
border. As that passes larger scale trough axis begins to push into
the area early Friday. Result is increasing clouds with pcpn to
develop by late afternoon. With a very dry airmass at the surface,
expect much of the pcpn to start and stay as snow, even though
initial sfc temps may be above freezing. Biggest disparity in
guidance is on amounts, particularly over SW VA. However, all
solutions seems to agree that there will be more moisture available
from Thursday night through Friday to see snow totals of 2-3 in SW
VA. Expect highest elevations of SW VA to see up to 3 inches of snow
while the rest of that area gets around 2 inches over the course of
the 30 hour event. E(Thursday through Wednesday)...
Forecast confidence is growing as models continue to come into
alignment over the upcoming snow event late Thursday through Friday.
Although there are still some discrepancies between accumulation
amounts, timing and areal extent of the frozen pcpn looks to be
increasing in consensus among the models. 

Most of Thursday should be dry area wide as cold air pushes in.
Temperatures will struggle to climb into the middle 30s during the
day over SW Virginia and northern portions of the Cumberland
Plateau. By afternoon, the leading edge of the arctic airmass pushes
into northern areas as shortwave trough passes along the TN-KY-VA
border. As that passes larger scale trough axis begins to push into
the area early Friday. Result is increasing clouds with pcpn to
develop by late afternoon. With a very dry airmass at the surface,
expect much of the pcpn to start and stay as snow, even though
initial sfc temps may be above freezing. Biggest disparity in
guidance is on amounts, particularly over SW VA. However, all
solutions seems to agree that there will be more moisture available
from Thursday night through Friday to see snow totals of 2-3 in SW
VA. Expect highest elevations of SW VA to see up to 3 inches of snow
while the rest of that area gets around 2 inches over the course of
the 30 hour event. Elsewhere in the area, primarily N of I-40, we
could expect to see 1-2 inches with the 2 inches generally found
over higher terrain, of course all of this accumulating over the
course of 30 hours.

For Saturday, models are in general agreement on the track of
developing Gulf low expected to move east across the northern Gulf
coast then NE thereafter. ECMWF has the more northern low track and
therefore the greater pcpn amounts in our SW NC counties. GFS soln
is much further south tracking across central Florida before turning
up the coast, and that solution is much drier for our area. Tended
to lean a little more toward the ECMWF solution for now as there are
enough GFS Ensemble members keeping the system further north hinting
at a possible solution which lies closer to the ECMWF at this time.
Therefore keeping chance POPS over the eastern half of the area
early Saturday before shifting chance POPS to just mountains of east
TN and SW NC by Saturday afternoon. 

Beyond Saturday, good model agreement on cold and dry weather
through Tuesday with gradual warming ahead of the next sensible
weather maker approaching the area on Wednesday.lsewhere in the

Majority of pcpn with this system has pushed N and E of the area

With some enhancement to the pressure gradient over East TN as
this system moves NE, winds have remained on the order of 5 mph
across much of the area. This mixing should reduce prospects of
area wide fog for morning so removed mention of it and replaced
with patchy fog in sheltered and low-lying areas instead.

As low moves NE, sfc trough swings across the area finally shifting
winds from S to SW. With plenty of moisture left in the lowest 300
mb, chance POPs remain area wide through the day. By tonight, trough
has exited and cold front moves across the area finally shifting
winds out of the NW as the atmosphere starts to dry out and pcpn
begin to decrease across the southern half of the area.

As the shortwave lifts NE, zonal flow returns by this evening with
a weak impulse moving rapidly eastward along the TN/KY border on
Wednesday. This impulse will help to keep clouds and slight chance
POPS over the northern third of the area and particularly SW VA
into Wednesday afternoon.

Cold air finally starts to push into the area on Wednesday with
daytime highs expected to return to near normal. Although the cold
air arrives to late in this event to produce any threat of frozen
pcpn, some of the higher elevations in SW VA and NE TN may see a
few, a very few, flakes of snow late Wednesday before the dry air
rushes in.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday Night through Monday)...
Models continue to have large differences for the extended
forecast period, resulting in a relatively low-confidence forecast.
Both the GFS and the ECMWF indicate a weak shortwave dragging a bit
of moisture across the region late Thursday into early Friday.
However, the GFS keeps most of the precipitation north of our
forecast area, while the ECMWF shows moisture sinking further
south. Bottom line is light snow showers are possible Thursday
night into Friday morning, especially across the north. Have
limited POPs to 30 or less due to uncertainty on how far south the
moisture will make it.

The 00Z ECMWF shows a more significant winter event for Friday night
into Saturday morning. In contrast, the 00Z GFS also indicates the
potential for snow, but brings the snow in closer to daybreak
Saturday, and keeps the best moisture south of our forecast area.
Additionally, both model solutions continue to vary greatly from run
to run. Ensembles are not providing much additional clarity, so for
now will go with a low confidence forecast with slight chance POPs
from Friday afternoon through Saturday evening. Sunday and Monday
look dry as the upper level trough swings east and surface high
pressure builds overhead, but northwest flow will help colder air
remain in place with highs in the 30s and lows in the teens.

across the area are reaching 1.3 inches, putting them near maximum
observed values for early January. As the warm front pushes NE into

instability and support for severe storms lies generally to our SW
and over portions of Middle TN, our Southern TN Valley and Plateau

moisture also lies west of the area over Middle TN, but still

Cooler and drier air mass continues Wednesday night but model blends
bring a weak system into the region Thursday and Thursday night.
Still expect a chance of rain or snow although may not be
significant. This system to move east Friday with drier and colder

560 
FXUS64 KMRX 011943
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
243 PM EST Sun Jan 1 2017

.SHORT TERM (This Afternoon through Monday)...

A mild cloudy drizzly day to start the New Year with a warm front
located to the south of the area stretching from W-E from Central
Alabama eastward to the Carolina Coast. Current water vapor and RAP
upper air analysis indicate a weak upper level trough moving across
the Central Plains stretching southward into the Southern
Mississippi River Valley. Light showers/drizzle will continue
throughout the afternoon and evening as low level isentropic ascent
will persist to the north of the advancing warm front.

Mid-level and low-level flow will become southwesterly ahead of the
approaching trough. Moisture and warm air advection will increase PW
values into the 1.1-1.3 inch range, which are near the maximum
values observed for early January. The best lift and moisture will
be across the mountains where the highest PoPs are featured. The
warm front will continue to progress northward during the overnight
hours but should remain to the south of the forecast area. Due to
this, went ahead and removed the mention of thunder to the overnight
forecast. 

A surface low will track from South Texas to the Mississippi Delta
on Monday as another shortwave trough races across the Southern
Plains. Expect there could be a brief break in the precipitation
Monday morning as the system exits late tonight before the next
system arrives late Monday. Models indicate a 35-45 kt low level jet
by the end of the day with the front pushing into the Southern
Valley. With this, there will be some limited instability (SBCAPE
values < 250 J/Kg). Due to this, included a small area of
thunderstorm Monday afternoon across portions of the Southern
Valley. Overall, rainfall amounts for the short-term period will
range from around 0.25-0.75 inches with amounts over an inch
possible across the mountains. 

.LONG TERM (Monday night through Saturday)...

Trough will be moving right over us by Monday night, and we will
continue to see thunderstorms in area. We will continue to see
moderate CAPE in the southwest counties and some minor shear to
where we could see thunderstorms with a few potentially strong ones
continue into the evening. After the low moves through winds will
swing around to the northwest by Wednesday afternoon. Most of the
precipitation will dry up after the front passes through on
Wednesday when temperatures begin to cool down quickly. However...
there might be enough moisture lingering around for some light
snowfall in the higher elevations Wednesday night into Thursday
morning. Any accumulations would likely be relegated to the highest
elevations and generally only a few tenths of an inch or less. 

Much colder weather will then persist over the area the rest of the
week and through the weekend. Quiet and cool weather will continue
till the end of the week where models begin to diverge a bit. GFS is
still sticking with it's dry solution through the work week while
the ECMWF is showing a weak system moving through and bringing a
round of cold rain/snow. However the ECMWF is continuously changing
it's tune while the GFS has been a bit more consistent in it's
solution. With that being said, have hedged closer towards the drier
GFS for the end of the work week, but will continue with slight
chances of precipitation on the chance the ECMWF is the correct
solution. Long term models then agree that the weekend will likely
be dry, but remain cold with high temperatures topping out in the
20's or 30's.

FXUS64 KMRX 010922
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
422 AM EST Sun Jan 1 2017

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...
Surface cold front extending SW across the Ohio Valley into NW
Arkansas this morning will become nearly stationary as it sags SE
toward Middle TN tonight. Southeast of this front, well defined
stationary boundary with juicy dewpoints to 60 degrees south of it,
extends east to west from south Alabama into east Texas. Meanwhile
water vapor imagery indicates shortwave trough over northern
Mexico this morning that will gradually lift NE in an amplifying
eastern US ridge, toward the Southern Appalachians by Monday
morning.

As the Texas shortwave lifts NE toward the area, flow aloft will
continue to become increasingly SW through the deep layer. This
will lead to continued cloudy skies and periods of rain and
rainshowers through tonight. As flow aloft shifts more SW tonight,
deep moisture will move in from the western Gulf Of Mexico. As it
does, models indicate PW values reaching to near 1.4 inches over
the southern third of the area by Monday morning, putting them near
the climatological maximums for early January. Then as the Texas
shortwave moves through tonight, a rather sharp gradient of QPF
will set up along and south of the southern border counties of TN
and SW NC in the area of best combined dynamics and moisture.
Although much of the area will see pcpn amounts on the order of 0.1
to 0.3 inches as this system moves NE tonight, the most favored
area will remain south of the TN and NC borders through Monday
morning where WPC pcpn estimates reach 0.5 to 1.0 inches over
northern GA. By late tonight, under continued warming, instability
begins to increase over the southern third of the area. Although
CAPE values are just starting to climb toward 100 J/Kg, did put
mention of isolated thunder in that area as elevated instability is
beginning to develop.

Persistent southwest flow under cloud cover is going to keep
temperatures near constant in the upper 40s to middle 50s across
most of the area through tonight which is near the climatological
maximums for January... but about 20 degrees above the
climatological minimums for early January.

.LONG TERM (Monday through Saturday)...
A Stationary Front is expected to be just to the south with a
surface trough over the Ohio and western Tennessee Valleys early
Monday. A significant shortwave is expected to eject out of the
Southwest states and move rapidly northeast toward the Great Lakes.
A secondary surface low is expected to move northeast out of Texas
into the Tennessee Valley by Monday evening. The stationary
boundary to the south will bring deeper moisture north. The
atmosphere will destabilize and thunderstorms will be possible
Monday and Monday evening. Temperatures will warm into the lower to
mid 60s. There is a slight risk of severe storms just to the
southwest in northern Alabama afternoon and evening and a few
strong storms southern Tennessee Valley and Cumberland Plateau
counties. The main threat would be damaging winds. As the surface
low moves northeast Monday night into Tuesday widespread showers
will continue as well as mild southwest flow. High rain chances
continue Monday night and then decrease Tuesday. Temperatures will
not drop much Monday night and likely be a few degrees warmer
Tuesday but the threat for storms will shift east. There still
could be a storm or two across forecast area but more significant
threat will shift northeast with surface low.

At midweek rain moves out by Wednesday as Higher pressure tries to
move in from Northwest and much colder air mass. Thursday and
Thursday night GFS model shows a weak system bring a little snow and
rain to the region moving through a cold northerly flow aloft with
the ECMWF wetter and more moist and lasting through Friday. Will
keep rain and snow chances in for both days. Warmed temperatures
slightly above model blend but with north to northwest flow
temperatures will struggle to reach freezing mountains and be mostly
30s elsewhere. Saturday will keep most areas dry with just slight
chance of rain or snow eastern border. Temperatures will be slightly
warmer south but still cold north.
